sp.speaker: Eliz.
sp.p: Becauſe you are Captain Flaſh, and that is reaſon enough.

sp.speaker: C. Flaſh.
sp.p: And what has Captain Flaſh done, that a lady cannot even paſs an ordinary compliment with him?

sp.speaker: Eliz.
sp.p: Nothing with me nor ever ſhall: Perſons of undoubted veracity have told me that this ſame Captain Flaſh leaves his duty in the a • my, and makes • t his whole buſineſ to ſteal the hearts of unguarded ladies, and then ſacrifice them to infamy, or conſign them to comfortleſs ſolitude. I wiſh for no acquaintance with ſuch a man.

sp.speaker: C. Flaſh.
sp.p: Does not a lady of your good ſenſe know that the world commonly aſperſes men of merit.

sp.speaker: Eliz.
sp.p: I know alſo that men of real merit can clear themſelves of the aſperſion—will you upon my charge confront Mr. Tukely.

sp.speaker: C. Flaſh.
sp.p: Yes, or any man.

sp.speaker: Eliz.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe you may challenge him when abſent, but not when he is preſent. He knows you too well.

sp.speaker: C. Flaſh.
sp.p: He knows me not nor I him.

sp.speaker: Eliz.
sp.p: Would you utter a deliberate falſhood? It will not recommend you to me—do you not court at once Maria, Tukely • s ſiſter, and her aunt Lovecaſe the fat widow— and how can you ſay that you do not know him?

sp.speaker: C. Flaſh.
sp.p:
It is all 〈◊〉 from the beginning to the end— I court Maria that fond diſguſting ſl ••
▪ I would as ſoon court a meſs of plumb porridge—as for the widow—did you know •• —ſhe is an intolerable ſnuff • aker, and it ſticks in the down on her upper lip; that ſhe looks like a Turk in his whiſkers. Upon my truth ſhe looks like the grand Mogul • dreſſed up in petticoats.

sp.speaker: Eliz.
sp.p: To ſcandalize other ladies, captain, is not the way to find acceſs to •• —It is alſo ſaid you have deſigns on Liſetta the little Prude.

sp.speaker: C. Flaſh.
sp.p: That is as great a lie as all the reſt. Why, ſhe uſes volatiles to ſuch a decree that ſhe ſcents of them a mile's diſtance—give it all up, Eliza, it is mere invention, give me that ſweet little hand, and take a little walk with me.

sp.speaker: Eliz.
sp.p: I ſhall not do it.

sp.speaker: C. Flaſh.
sp.p: Then excuſe the preſumption of a lover driven to deſpiration by her who is the object of all his deſires.

sp.speaker: Eliz.
sp.p: Let me go, Captain.

sp.speaker: C. Flaſh.
sp.p: I cannot quit this ineſtimable prize.

sp.speaker: Eliz.
sp.p: Unhand me, inſolent wretch, this inſtant, or I will call my footmen, and they ſhall give you proper dicipline. (He unhands her and ſhe ſays going out) There, go now, and herd with your own ſort. [Exit Eliza.]

div.head: SCENE IV.—TUKELY and Capt FLASH.

sp.speaker: Tuk.
sp.p: WHAT is the matter with you, captain, you look confounded?

sp.speaker: C. Flaſh.
sp.p: Only a little girl here behaved with rather too much prudence and propriety—She is a ſenſible gir1, I wiſh to marry ſometime or other, what if I follow her, and by means of her relations make honorable propoſals in good earneſt. (Follows her out.)

div.stage: [Two ladies enter on one ſide—Tukely ſteps aſide and liſtens.]

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.p: MISS Philenia, I am aſtoniſhed at your confidence—To contend for your intereſt in a man. You might be aſhamed.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: You do exactly the ſame—I ſay the truth, if he invited you to Whites at the Ball, he invited me to Miſs Mohairs

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.p: I have a dozen letters of his in the moſt paſſionate ſtile, the language of the heart.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I have fifteen in ſuch a ſtile as to ſhow him the ſincereſt of lovers.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.p: I hope you will not lie, you miſtake the man. The true Capt Flaſh lodges at M • s. Simpſon's in Threadneedle Street.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Mine are from Capt. Flaſh of the third regiment, their ſtation, Gibralter. He is recruiting in this city and lodges at Mrs. Simpſons in Threadneedle Street.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.p: The Captain is a man of the ſtricteſt truth. He has ſworn his love to me a hundred times on the ſalvation of his ſoul.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: He would not deceive me I know, he has ſworn his love to me a thouſand times, ſo what ſays your madamſhip to that.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.p: Some perſon has impoſed on you. Let me ſee one of your letters, the handwriting and the ſeal.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I ſhall not betray the letters of my friends—ſhow one of yours, it will do as well.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.p: I know that thoſe he wrote to me are genuine.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: There is no impoſition certainly in thoſe which he wrote to me.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.p: I am ſure to confound you now—I have his picture in miniature ſet with diamonds.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: And I have a picture ſet with diamonds of the true identical Capt. Flaſh.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.p: I adviſe you to deſiſt—you will become the ridicule of the town.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: You are the ridicule of the town already, you have taken a phantom for a lover; I am content with the reality.

sp.speaker: Tuk.
sp.p: (ſtepping forward) Ladies if you will take your ſtation where I will place you; the whole affair will be explained to your mutual ſatisfaction. (Leads them out.)

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: It is a matter very intereſting to me. I deſire you will inform me whether Capt. Flaſh makes love to every lady of his acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.p: I believe he does not make love to every lady of his acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Then he does to many.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.p: He oftens boaſts of his exploits to me.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Pleaſe to inform me then of his whole character and conduct.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.p: Let us know how far you have gone with him; it may not be ſafe to inform you.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: His addreſſes have been honorable. I own I have admitted his viſits freely at home, and have been with him in public places, and he has appeared to me a man of merit.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.p: So he has made propoſals of marriage, to which you have conſented▪ then he has abſented himſelf.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: He does not viſit me ſo frequently as he did.

sp.speaker: Blunt
sp.p: You ſhould have known his character before you admitted his viſits freely.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p:
If he be true I ought to have the happineſs to know it •
• f • e be falſe I ſhould be undeceived—Either way you are inhuman and cruel if you do not inform me.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.p: You would not believe any thing from me; u •• leſs it were agreeable to your wiſhes—But here is a gentleman (He preſents her to Tukely.) who will put you into a ſituation to inform yourſe •• es.

sp.speaker: Tuk.
sp.p: (Leading her out.) Here madam take a ſtation which I ſhall point out to you and your affairs will be cleared up in a few moments. [Tukely and Amoret go out.]

sp.speaker: C. Flaſh.
sp.p: THAT little jewel Eliza has eſcaped me. She has too much good ſenſe to be caught with chaff—I ſhall marry her if any of them. But ſee, are there any more of the quarry? (Peeps in his glaſs at the ladies behind the curtain.) Yes my ſweet little prude Liſetta, ſhe loves extreme delicacy and keen ſcandal. I'll doſe her well with both—my friend Liſetta. This is a happy day becauſe I meet you. (Addreſſing himſelf to Liſetta as ſhe enters.)

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: C. Flaſh.
sp.p: My heart loves virtue and good ſenſe, I am enraptured with the beauties of Liſetta's mind.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: I cannot endure flattery, Captain—It is odious as wormwood to the bee, who rambles among the ſweeteſt flowers of the field.

sp.speaker: C. Flaſh.
sp.p: Think not I have any tho't of making love to Liſetta—I know her averſe to love, that mad paſſion which deprives human beings of reaſon and virtue—Friendſhip and eſteem, are all the affections I could expect to excite in the moſt virtuous Liſetta.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: The love of virtue for virtue's ſake. I deſpiſe any thing that has connection with intereſt, or the ſenſes.

sp.speaker: C. Flaſh.
sp.p:
I abominate the barbarous cuſtom of marrying.
I ſhould be a •••• ed of a fa •• ly if I had one—Let me reſpect you without the leaſt profit, and ſerve you without the leaſt hope of reward.

sp.speaker: Liſet.
sp.p: How pleaſing it is to talk with a man of ſenſe; But you are devoted to the intereſt of Philenia.

sp.speaker: C. Flaſh.
sp.p: That is impoſſible—It is a fact that ſhe drinks ſtrong waters—Did you never obſerve the tip of her noſe how red it is? Split me to atoms, if ever I could bear the ſmell of brandy.

sp.speaker: Liſet.
sp.p: But then ſhe ſings ſo ſweetly.

sp.speaker: C. Flaſh.
sp.p: Blaſt my conſtitution if I think ſhe ſings ſweetly—There is a ſcreech in her voice which reſembles the whetting of a ſaw. It always ſets my teeth on edge to hear her.

sp.speaker: Liſet.
sp.p: The little Amoret perhaps may pleaſe you.

sp.speaker: C. Flaſh.
sp.p: That ſimple little ideot—She is the ſhalloweſt of all womankind—She could not ſmell a rat if it lay dead before her noſe—What are theſe to the pure, the delicate, the divine Liſetta?

sp.speaker: Liſet.
sp.p: I ſhould admire the man who could love like an angel, and be content with mere adoration of his miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: C. Flaſh.
sp.p: Then here is the man for you (Laying his hand on his heart.) admit me tomorrow evening to converſe with you at home, at 10 o'clock. You ſhall ſee how we will paſs the time in the moſt diſtant and enraptured admiration of each others perfections.

sp.speaker: Liſet.
sp.p: You may come, but be ſure that your mind be pure as moonlight before you preſume to enter my houſe— At preſent I muſt withdraw. [withdraws.]

div.head: SCENE II.—Capt. FLASH alone.
div.p:
WELL how many ladies have I on hand. (Takes out a liſt, and comments upon it.) There is Maria—I muſt ſpare her, or her brother that fireſkull will kill me—I'll tell her ſtory however, over a bottle of wine—The widow, the prude and Amoret, I mean to ſacrifice to the Goddeſs pleaſure, the only Deity, Vanity excepted, that I adore. Narciſſa and Philenia, they muſt thank themſelves for their folly—If I once gain liberty of a private interview they will hardly eſcape me finally—They will do to make ſtories of, to divert my brother officers on a dull campaign. Eliza is the only one I can think of marrying—She underſtands
the Trap and avoids it, one might take her and not fear.

div.head: SCENE III.— [BLUNT, TUKELY, and all the LADIES enter at once—and the Captain appears extremely confounded— remains ſilent ſome moments—at laſt ſpeaks.]

sp.speaker: C. Flaſh.
sp.p: WHAT all in a company!

sp.speaker: Tuk.
sp.p: The Captain uſed to reconnoitre—the ladies have been reconnoitring the Captain.

sp.speaker: C. Flaſh.
sp.p: But what brought you here all together?
We begin to ſmell a rat even before he is dead.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: You ſeem to be dull, captain. How ſhould you like a ſong that would ſet your teeth on edge, or ſhall we raiſe your ſpirits with brandy?

sp.speaker: Liſet.
sp.p: Volatile ſpirit might keep him from fainting.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sometimes when perſons are failing it has ſerved as a good reſtorative to give them a meſs of plum porridge.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: The ladies inſult you Captian but never mind it, pleaſe to take a little Spaniſh ſnuff out of the grand Mogul's box, it is the beſt thing in the world for low-ſpirits.

sp.speaker: C. Flaſh.
sp.p: Blunt, you raſcal—you have betrayed me.

sp.speaker: Blunt
sp.p: I have not.

sp.speaker: Tuk.
sp.p: He is harmleſs—But I being apprehenſive for my Siſter, placed the ladies in the poſt of obſervation—Now you may reſent it if you dare. (Pauſes, but C. Flaſh makes no anſwer.) Ladies how ſhall we puniſh him? ſhall we throw the raſcal into Roſamond's pond?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: No, let me give him his doom—We will bring his character on the ſtage, and expoſe him to public ridicule— for the inſtruction of women, and the terror of all his kind.

sp.speaker: C. Flaſh.
sp.p: Well Ladies I have as good an opinion of you now, as I ever had—ſo good bye. [He goes out—and all the performers withdraw ſoon after him.]

div.head: The Growth of Rumors. A DRAMATIC DIALOGUE, IN ONE ACT.
ABSURDITY OF MAGNIFYING REPORTS.
div.p: Next to the folly and wickedneſs of framing deliberate falſehoods and propagating them concerning honeſt people, is the pernicious diſpoſition, which inclines ſome perſons, if they hear any diſagreeable report, to magnify and ſpread it. An ill impreſſion is ſometimes made in an hour, which it will require years to efface; and perhaps it can never be effaced—a good man "taketh not up an ill report againſt his neighbor."

list.head: MEN.
list.item: LONGHEAD—a man who makes the worſt of every thing.
MADAM PIPER—an aged woman who hears their Dialogue, and ſpeaks as ſhe is affected by it.—Madam Piper ſits and works at a diſtance thro the whole Dialogue.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: DID you hear of the melancholy affair which happened in this Town, this morning?

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: I have heard nothing new of late.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Neighbor Greetwell's family is in the utmoſt confuſion—Never was a more tragical ſcene.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: This is the firſt liſp I have had of it.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: I wiſh I had never heard it, it really makes me melancholy to think of it—Did you know his daughter Eliza?

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: Yes, a beautiful and amiable girl.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: She is ruined, and I fear the happineſs of the whole houſe is gone forever.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: You don't ſay ſo — I am frighted: I loved that family about as well as I loved myſelf.

sp.speaker: M. Piper.
sp.p: That is a tolerable lie to begin with, neighbor Catchword.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: She was courted by Mr. Brightman you know— and it was tho't to be a fine match.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: Have they broken off? Well if they have done it by conſent—

sp.speaker: M. Piper.
sp.p: You will hardly ever get a woman to do that —It's a loſing game.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: But they did not do it by conſent; and it is a melancholy affair indeed.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: People ſaid their love was ardent and ſincere— Why! they were to be married this evening.

sp.speaker: M. Piper.
sp.p: Then I don't believe a word about their breaking off, not I—Would they be fools?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Aye but they have, and the bride is all in tears— and the bridegroom in the utmoſt diſtreſs and deſpair.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: Pray tell me on what account.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: You know ſhe was to have been married this evening—what grand preparations there were for the wedding—and it was found out this morning, and not till this morning, that ſhe was deſparately in love with another man.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: That was a pity indeed—But is it fact? Is it fact?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: O yes, it muſt be, Eliza Greetwell was ſeen to careſs with tender endearments, and with tokens of paſſionate fondneſs, another man, who was not her lover, at leaſt not her intended bridegroom—So both families of the bride and bridegroom, are in the utmoſt diſtreſs and confuſion.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: 'Tis a pity—'Tis a pity certainly.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Aye but it is too true. We all thought her a girl of the firmeſt principles—But there is no truſting women now a days.

sp.speaker: M. Piper.
sp.p: Any more than men, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: I could tell you more, but I'm in haſte, and bid you adieu. [Exit Longhead. Breedbate enters.]

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: WELL brother Catchword what news?

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: Very ſurpriſing—You have heard how Eliza Greetwell and her ſpark have parted. The matter is a • up about their being married this evening.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: That is curious, they ſeemed as if they were made on purpoſe for each other, and only wanted to be one in intereſt, as they were one in heart and ſoul.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: Alas, how ſhall men and women put confidence in one another any more? And it is the women's fault you ſee—There is no truſting them.

sp.speaker: M. Piper.
sp.p: If I were near you, you wretch, I would box your • ars well.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: The young bridegroom was much offended at his bride, for giving ſuch evident preference to another man, the very day ſhe was to be married—he forgave her, and would not forſake her: for he's a generous fellow.

sp.speaker: M. Piper.
sp.p: Now I would have you laugh at women for telling ſtories about ghoſts and apparitions—Yours are not half ſo probable.

sp.speaker: Catch▪
sp.p:
〈◊〉 always was a fine lad truly a fine man. I
am ſorry, it will mortify him, as long as he lives. I am very ſorry for him. It did not uſe to be ſo when I was young. No man would make a woman half a dozen viſits unleſs he meant to marry her. And the ladies never admitted more than three viſits, to any gentleman, unleſs they had a liking to him.

sp.speaker: M. Piper.
sp.p: Then I ſhould have turned you out of doors long before I did; and got more credit by it.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: Aye, but the times are ſadly altered now—I expect one of theſe days, huſbands and wives will diſmiſs one another, and ſay nothing about it.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: I hope not, I am not quite ready to part with mine.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.p: I ſhall be melancholy this whole day. But inſtead of grieving for other people I muſt attend to my own affairs. [Exit Catchword.]

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: WHAT do you think neighbor of Miſs Greetwell. Did you ever hear the like?

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: I cannot ſay a word—I am as dry as the deſert of Arabia—I cannot ſay a word till you let me have ſomething to drink. [Breedbate goes out.]

sp.speaker: M. Piper.
sp.p: You will make fine work of it I dare ſay when you have raiſed your ſpirits a little. (Breedbate enters gives him a cup of liquor, he drinks, holds it, and talks, and drinks, alternately.)

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Well, what do you think of that?

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: O this is due— (drinks again) It goes to the very right ſpot of my inmoſt ſoul—This is the cordial that keeps men alive—It does not trip up one's heels you ſee, but only makes him che •• y, merry—Now as to Eliza Greetwell, what of her. (Taking the poſture of attention.)

sp.speaker: M. Piper.
sp.p: You'll be juſt in nice trim to talk about her, when you drink a little more.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: I ſhall talk the better then.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Such a thing when I was young would have rung thro all New-England—But people make light of theſe things now-a-days.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: I diſlike theſe matters very much, but I am apt to think, this affair will not turn out ſo bad as expected.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Why ſo?

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: Becauſe Brightman treats the matter very lightly.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: He is a fellow of a fine temper, but he muſt needs feel very diſagreeably—He is of a noble temper, can bear any thing. They ſay he keeps all his diſagreeable feeling • to himſelf. (Redface drinks again.)

sp.speaker: M. Piper.
sp.p: Now the poor women are to have another baſting I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: That is generous in him, if that be fact—Yet what reaſon can we find that one perſon ſhould be made unhappy for the ſake of another, who does not deſerve it?

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: No, I think it f • ll enough, to do it then, when it can no longer be avoided. For we take them in marriage for better or for worſe.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: But when people in their courtſhip quarrel and ſeparate, how can we judge who is to blame? they will hardly ever tell the facts which relate to the matter, and who can judge without the facts?

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: But it ſeems Mr. Brightman was not in fault.— Every body ſays that he was attentive and conſtant, and ardent, and perſevering.

sp.speaker: M. Piper.
sp.p: Miſs Greetwell would be the beſt judge of that herſelf.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: Alackaday the world grows worſe as it grows older—It did not uſe to be ſo when I was young—The men were as true as the ſun—and they would not injure a woman if they knew they might—The girls actually when I was young, depended more on their ſweethearts honeſty, than on their own diſcretion; but you ſee, it is not as it was, when I was young.

sp.speaker: M. Piper.
sp.p: Yes, I remember when you was young; it uſed to rain gingerbread every night. We planted our potatoes and they produced fat turkies ready roaſted.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: If the men were ſo honeſt how were the girls pray?

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: How were the girls! They were as kind as turtledoves. If you offered to marry one, ſhe would take you up as quick! and hold you to your promiſe. There was no getting rid of her—for, as I told you before, the young men were extremely honeſt.

sp.speaker: M. Piper.
sp.p: You do murder truth abominably. The men never were ſo honeſt as you tell of, nor were the women ever ſuch fools.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: Well neighbor Curious, what news?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Only about Mr. Brightman and Miſs Greetwell.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: That is indeed a curious matter—I have thought much of it, and cannot account for it. Yes, it i • talked of by blackſmiths and barbers, by tradeſmen and merchants— The phyſicians are up in arms about it—The lawyers are buying up blanks and quills—The clergy it is expected will not be ſilent—We ſhall have a number of ſmart ſermons on the ſubject—and ſome of the ſenators and repreſentatives think it beſt to bring in a new bill for the prevention of ſuch evils in time to come.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: • ut the public in one reſpect is miſinformed—It was not a proper diſappointment on either part.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: How could that be?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Becauſe they parted in mutual good humor; and agreed to ſeparate.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: Who then can ſay they have done wrong? If parties have aſſociated ever ſo long, and agree to ſeparate, who can ſay they are to blame? It may be ſaid indeed that ſo much time has been ſpent in vain, becauſe it can never be remembered with pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Ah! I hardly know what to think about the ſin of it—But it makes one's heart ache dreadfully to part with a beloved object. But when one gets a little weaned by the diſcovery of new faults, new deformities, &c. the parting is not ſo hard—I tried it (ſighing) once myſelf.— Every man is his own friend, and loves to indulge his own humor; but we ſhall not ſettle the matter if we talk •• fortnight about it.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: That is true; and as I have a cuſtomer waiting for me in my ſhop this moment, I muſt go. [Drinks off his liquor, ſets down the empty glaſs and goes out.]

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Well, that was a very curious affair about Miſs Greetwell and Mr. Brightman.

sp.speaker: Tell.
sp.p: Yes, they had a ſharp quarrel; but they were ſoon reconciled, and were married with great rejoicings.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Hah! was that the caſe? I thought they had agreed to part.

sp.speaker: Tell.
sp.p: No—there was ſome little ſquabble, I believe, but it was ſoon over, and they were married very honorably, and I am very glad of it, for the ſeparating of lovers who have long been acquainted, is often attended with very diſagreeable conſequences.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Yes, and I wonder why men in all their wiſdom have never found a remedy for that evil.

sp.speaker: Tell.
sp.p: Becauſe they want experience—For that ſince I have been honored with a ſeat in the legiſlature, I have thought of bringing in a bill for the prevention of theſe evils.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: What pray ſir.

sp.speaker: Tell.
sp.p: The firſt proviſion in the act is—that no lady, unleſs ſhe thinks her ſuitor an agreeable man, ſhall give him more than five audiences and an half, thirty whiſpers, and fifteen ſmiles.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Under what penalty?

sp.speaker: Tell.
sp.p: That ſhe ſhould receive no attention from any gentleman for a whole month.

sp.speaker: M. Piper.
sp.p: O, ſir, alter that part, by all means, that is intolerably ſevere. They'll never bear it.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: What is to be done with the gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Tel.
sp.p: It will be enacted, that every gentleman ſhall at leaſt by the thirty ninth audience kiſs a lady's hand in token of reſpect & tell her ſhe is agreeable—by the fortieth, that ſhe is particularly agreeable—by the forty-firſt that he ſhall declare his love in a ſet ſpeech—by the forty-ſecond, he ſhall profeſs eternal amity to her—and by the forty-third, be ſhall come directly to the point and canvaſs the ſubject of marriage.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: And what if ſhe does not proceed thus?

sp.speaker: Tell.
sp.p: He ſhall be liable to all the pains and penalties of a refuſal, becauſe his ſuit will be out lawed.

sp.speaker: M. Piper.
sp.p: I am afraid if liberty were given for every one to delay ſo long, the women would be in a worſe ſituation than they are now.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I don't think I ſhould like, with all ſorts of women, to be confined to theſe rules.

sp.speaker: M. Pip.
sp.p: Your ſcheme will never hold ſir.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I am of the ſame opinion.

sp.speaker: Tel.
sp.p:
well then, we muſt have all things in courtſhip and marriage, which relate to forming the alliance to the parties themſelves, as before, if they are to blame they
muſt bear it themſelves—People are always ungrateful to their rulers. (Looks ſorry.)

sp.speaker: M. Piper.
sp.p: I conſent to that.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: And I too.

sp.speaker: Tel.
sp.p: Madam Piper you do not feel intereſted in this matter at this time of life.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Did you ever know a woman give up the idea of gallantry while her breath was in her?

sp.speaker: M. Piper.
sp.p: Or a man to part with his vanity till he parted with his laſt ſpark of life.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: WELL neighbor Tellfair what is the news of the day.

sp.speaker: Tel.
sp.p: Only that I am healthy, except what is ſaid of Mr. Brightman and his lady.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: There was never any difficulty between them.

sp.speaker: Tel.
sp.p: Aye but indeed there was.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: No there was not.

sp.speaker: Tel.
sp.p: There was to be ſure. (warmly.)

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Certainly there was not, and I can tell you how the whole ſtory took its riſe.

sp.speaker: Tel.
sp.p: Then you can tell a wonder, for it is told and believed for a truth thro the whole town—The town has even been in an uproar about it.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: And about nothing—Mrs. Greetwell, wife to the bride's brother, ſeeing the ſon of her former huſband, who was brought from nurſe to the wedding, was overcome by the tenderneſs of a mother, caught him fondly in her arms and kiſſed him.

sp.speaker: Tel.
sp.p: And how came the ſtory to get abroad.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Only a child told it at a neighbor's houſe and made the common miſtake of putting miſs for miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Tel.
sp.p: Well I ſhall never believe ſuch reports again, when told of honeſt people.

sp.speaker: M. Piper.
sp.p: I told you it was not at all probable that they wou'd quarrel when they were juſt going to be married. I would not anſwer for them, months or years after.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: And you may take it for granted that in nine inſtances out of ten, the common ſcandalous ſtories told about people who in the general courſe of life are virtuous and worthy, are totally without foundation.

sp.speaker: M. Piper.
sp.p: Well I deſire the men will never ſay any more about women's tattling; for they have talked this whole day, and ſet the whole town in an uproar becauſe a fond mother happened to kiſs her own baby.

div.head: The Gameſter. A DRAMATIC DIALOGUE, IN THREE ACTS.
MILDNESS OF TEMPER.
div.p: Every human being has ſome vices. Huſbands muſt expect to find them in their wives, and wives in their huſbands—parents will find vices in their children; and children when they grow up will find them in their parents. How ſhall we cure, or alleviate thoſe vices in our near relations—by mildneſs or ſeverity?—is not mildneſs moſt likely to gain the heart, and conſequently to give us the greateſt influence?

div.head: PERSONS.

list.head: MEN.
list.item: MR. VAN KEPPEL—a merchant of Amſterdam and a gameſter.
MR. LEERKINS—brother to Mrs. Van Keppel.

list.head: WOMEN.
list.item: MRS. VAN KEPPEL—wife to Mr. Van Keppel.
MADAM LEERKINS—mother to Mrs. V. Keppel.
MRS. PAULUS—aunt to Mr. V. Keppel.
MISS LEERKINS—ſiſter to Mrs. V. Keppel.

div.p: The ſcene of action is ſuppoſed to be a merchant's houſe near the bank at Amſterdam.

div.head: SCENE. I.—Madam LEERKINS and Mrs. V. KEPPEL.

sp.speaker: M. Leer.
sp.p: YOU ſee what has been the conſequence of your obſtinacy. You would not liſten to my advice—You ſhall be an example to all daughters who marry without their parents' conſent.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kep.
sp.p: It might have been better for me to have followed your counſel—Yet I am not abſolutely ſure of it— It might have hurt me as much to have loſt the object of my deareſt affections, as to have had a diſſipated and inattentive huſband.

sp.speaker: M. Leer.
sp.p: I cannot ſay that I am very ſorry—You feel the curſe of diſobedience and ſhall be a warning to others.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kep.
sp.p: I may feel the effect of folly. But how dear Madam can you call it diſobedience? When I was eighteen you told me, I was free.

sp.speaker: M. Leer.
sp.p: But you would have Keppel againſt my advice and conſent; and now you feel the curſe of that ſin.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kep.
sp.p: The curſe of my folly rather. I was free at eighteen and did not marry till twenty five; If I was free I was not bound, ſo I cannot ſee how you can make either ſin or diſobedience of it.

sp.speaker: M. Leer.
sp.p: You will be unhappy as long as you live.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kep.
sp.p: I greatly fear it, and my ſufferings perſuade me, that girls would do well to liſten to the advice of their elder relations more than they do—but either freedom is nothing or we may make uſe of it in the moſt intereſting concern—the choice of a partner for life.

sp.speaker: M. Leer.
sp.p: You, I ſee, can be wicked and juſtify it too. The curſe is likely to reſt upon you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kep.
sp.p:
I am very unhappy, and I wiſh that you would
reflect that you are my mother, and not increaſe your daughter's miſery—yet miſerable as I am, I am not beyond hope—I hope yet to reconcile you to me, and engage my huſband to virtue.

sp.speaker: M. Leer.
sp.p: You will have a very hard taſk to do either one or the other. [Exit M. Leerkins]

div.head: SCENE II.—Mr. and Mrs. KEPPEL.
div.stage: (Mrs. Keppel ſpeaks to Mr. Keppel as he is entering.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kep.
sp.p: O I am glad you are come home. Sit a little with me my dear; and I will get you a delightful little ſupper in a few moments. I have ſent to the market and have got the beſt things for you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Kep.
sp.p: I thank you my dear, but I cannot ſtay. I muſt go gack to the ſign of the Leopard—I have loſt about ſeventy pounds, I came back to get more money that I may play again and recover what I have loſt.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kep.
sp.p: I am rather afraid that you will loſe the whole. If I dared I would adviſe you to leave off gaming; for I am verily afraid it will ruin you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Kep.
sp.p: O bravo, fine times indeed, a woman adviſe her huſband, why, think my girl, you live in Holland. Did you think you lived in the United States of America? I remember, that, while I was in Maſſachuſetts; if I aſked ſome of the moſt reſpectable men in the ſtate, if they would do this or that, they would ſay I will hear what my wife ſays, or, I will aſk my wife. But you live in Holland my dew.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kep.
sp.p: I wiſh from what you ſay, that I lived in Maſſachuſetts. I reſpect that people exceedingly. I would then adviſe you to leave off gaming, for I verily fear it will ruin you. [Enter Mrs. Paulus.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kep.
sp.p: A fiddle's end of that. There is not a man in the univerſe, who can play againſt me. [Exit Keppel.]

div.head: SCENE III.—Mad. LEERKINS, Mrs. V. KEPPEL and Mrs. PAULUS.

sp.speaker: M. Leer.
sp.p: So your huſband is gone off to the tavern again, you are likely to be miſerable enough.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kep.
sp.p:
I greatly fear the worſt—But I wiſh, Madam,
that you would not ſeek to increaſe my miſery. It is already as great as I can bear.

sp.speaker: M. Leer.
sp.p: You ſee, Mrs. Paulus, what my daughter has bro't upon herſelf—and I cannot pity her ſo much as I ſhould—if ſhe had not bro't her mother's curſe upon her by marrying without my conſent.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pau.
sp.p: But you ſurprize me, you did not curſe one of your own children!

sp.speaker: M. Leer.
sp.p: Yes ſhe diſobeyed me, and I curſed her, and the curſe has been fulfilled an • I never will revoke it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pau.
sp.p: O madam, I am afraid you are more to blame than ſhe—I ſhall now begin to take her part.

sp.speaker: M. Leer.
sp.p: Why, had I not a right to curſe her?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pau.
sp.p: Perhaps not—You had a right to think ſhe was a ſilly girl. For it is a great folly in young people to reject that counſel of elder perſons which is the effect of experience, and count it as nothing. But your daughter was free, and what avails liberty if we cannot uſe it in that concern which is deareſt to the human heart? So you may ſay ſhe was ſilly; and had a right to think ſo, and place the leſs confidence in her on that account. But how ſhe could be ſo guilty as to deſerve an irrevocable curſe I cannot comprehend.

sp.speaker: M. Leer.
sp.p: But ſhe ought to have heard to me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pau.
sp.p: That is very true, and ſhe was a ſilly girl that ſhe did not. But perhaps not guilty of any real crime. There are in the human conſtitution remarkable and unconquerable attachments and averſions—The convictions of the mind will not always bear ſway, much leſs take advice from others—What would you do if any perſon ſhould put a cat under your table or under your pillow—What would you ſay?

sp.speaker: M. Leer.
sp.p: O horrible! I can't bear a cat, I ſhould faint away, or go into fits.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pau.
sp.p: And you love dogs as much as you hate cats. —I have ſeen you, when a girl, carry one in your arms, from your father's houſe to the ſchool, which is, at leaſt, a mile. And I believe you always have one with you when you ride out.

sp.speaker: M. Leer.
sp.p: Yes, to keep my feet warm. Trip always lies at my feet and keeps them warm.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pau.
sp.p:
What if your parents had killed your little
dog, and had put a cat in his place, or that inſtead of warming your feet, you ſhould warm your heart with a cat.

sp.speaker: M. Leer.
sp.p: I could not have borne it, I muſt have died.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pau.
sp.p: Well, I have ſeen men whoſe company I abhorred as much as ever you did that of a cat; who yet were eſteemed by my friends and by the public—And I have ſeen one, elſe I never would have been married, for whom I had as great an attachment, as ever you had to Trip—This was my caſe I fully own, and might be that of your daughter. Was ſhe then to be blamed?

sp.speaker: M. Leer.
sp.p: You are a ſtrange woman, and truly I do not know what to ſay to you—But Keppel is coming in, I will go out for I cannot bear to ſee him. [Exit Mad. Leerkins.]

div.head: SCENE I.—KEPPEL enters with a diſtracted air.

sp.speaker: Mr. Kep.
sp.p: WHAT a wretched man am I? I wiſh I had hearkened to my wife. I have not only loſt my money but every thing elſe. I deſpiſed the counſel of the moſt amiable of women. What a fool!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kep.
sp.p: My dear friend, who has offended you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Kep.
sp.p: No one, but myſelf. I am the greateſt fool on earth. I wiſh I had followed your advice.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kep.
sp.p: Have you then loſt the reſt of the money?

sp.speaker: Mr. Kep.
sp.p: Yes▪ every farthing, I never had ſuch ill luck.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kep.
sp.p: Chance governs the game. It was to be expected. I am not diſappointed in the leaſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Kep.
sp.p: I am utterly undone.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kep.
sp.p: No my dear, utterly undone, no; my affection to you is the ſame as ever.

sp.speaker: Mr. Kep.
sp.p: That is no comfort to me ſo long as I have made you wretched.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kep.
sp.p: Made me wretched! I value not the loſs of our money. It was no great ſum. You may raiſe twice as much on the mortgage of the houſe, and regain what you have loſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Kep.
sp.p: The houſe, my dear friend, is already mortgaged and loſt.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kep.
sp.p: There is the ſhop, my dear, & all the goods in it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Kep.
sp.p: They are mortgaged alſo and all the money raiſed on them is loſt.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kep.
sp.p: The moveables, the furniture of the houſe— you might raiſe ſomething on them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Kep.
sp.p: I may as well let you know the worſt as not. I have mortgaged all my houſehold furniture, carriages, horſes, &c. indeed every thing; and the money raiſed on them is loſt.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kep.
sp.p: Well, and what of that? I can work for my living. I care not for it. But you muſt be miſerable. What, cannot I think of ſome way? are you ſure it was only ill luck.

sp.speaker: Mr. Kep.
sp.p: We may reſign ourſelves to our fate and die. But I know I can play a game well.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kep.
sp.p: Then ſee, I have a little box of jewels given me by my Aunt Van Riſſell; it is worth a large ſum—This you could not mortgage, for it was not your property.

sp.speaker: Mr. Kep.
sp.p: But I ſhall not touch that. It is enough that I am a fool. I will not alſo be a villain, and ſpend the laſt part of my wife's property.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kep.
sp.p: But you need have no ſcruple when I give it to you. (She goes out to bring the box.)

div.head: SCENE II.—Miſs LEERKINS and Mr. KEPPEL.

sp.speaker: Miſs Leer.
sp.p: IT is no matter of my particular concern but I cannot bear your conduct to my ſiſter

sp.speaker: Mr. Kep.
sp.p: If ſhe be contented what is it to you?

sp.speaker: Miſs. Leer.
sp.p: You treat my ſiſter ill beyond all ſufferance. You leave her alone theſe long winter evenings, that you may ſpend your time in taverns, and gaming houſes. The whole care of the family reſts on my ſiſter; and you are even a ſtranger in your own houſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Kep.
sp.p: If my wife be ſatisfied, what buſineſs of yours is it; that you ſhould lecture me on the occaſion?

sp.speaker: Miſs Leer.
sp.p: My ſiſter is indeed a fool. She has not the ſpirit of a woman of ſenſe in her, or ſhe would manage otherwiſe than ſhe does.

sp.speaker: Mr. Kep.
sp.p: What would you do were you in her caſe.?

sp.speaker: Miſs Leer.
sp.p:
Inſtead of cooking you 〈◊〉 with all manner of good things, when you come home from your midnight cabals
—I would lay your whole conduct before you. I would ſing you ſuch a ſong of your crimes; that you ſhould go to ſleep, if you ſlept at all, with a ſting in your heart.

sp.speaker: Mr. Kep.
sp.p: I adviſe you if you ever do marry to marry ſome perſon who never wiſhes to ſleep, for I am perſuaded your tongue muſt be a mortal enemy to repoſe.

sp.speaker: Miſs Leer.
sp.p: I would not bear with you, as my ſiſter does— I would not diſcover the leaſt degree of good nature towards you—And I would let you know that I never would, till ſuch time as you would reform.

sp.speaker: Mr. Kep.
sp.p: Suppoſing you wanted cuſtomers in your ſhop, would you ſet a dog on the firſt perſon who entered the ſhop door?

sp.speaker: Miſs Leer.
sp.p: No, for that would drive them all away.

sp.speaker: Mr. Kep
sp.p: You would gain as little by ſcolding at a huſband for ſtaying our late.

sp.speaker: Miſs Leer.
sp.p: Then you might go and ſhift for yourſelf if you pleaſed. I would not concern myſelf for you in the leaſt, and account myſelf happy that I was rid of you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Kep.
sp.p: If you were fond of me you could not do that.

sp.speaker: Miſs Leer.
sp.p: Do you think that I ſhould care for ſuch a wretch as you—why could I not do that?

sp.speaker: Mr. Kep.
sp.p: It would make your heart ache, my dear, and you would not bear it.

sp.speaker: Miſs Leer.
sp.p: Make my heart ache, a fiddleſtick. My heart would never ache for ſuch a wretch as you—I almoſt wiſh you were my huſband that you might ſee how I would manage you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Kep.
sp.p: I have no thought of wiſhing you to be my wife at any rate—And mind this, that ſingle women always know how to rule their huſbands well—but they fail a little in two points; either they never get huſbands or loſ • the faculty of ruling them the moment they are married.

div.head: SCENE III.—Mrs. KEPPEL and Mr. KEPPEL.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kep.
sp.p: HERE my dear take theſe, and may you be more fortunate than before.

sp.speaker: Mr. Kep.
sp.p: No my dear wife—no, 'tis yours, do not let me ruin you—no.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kep.
sp.p: I value it not, take it, and do your beſt—I give it you, tis now yours.

sp.speaker: Mr. Kep.
sp.p: The kindeſt creature that ever lives I believe.

div.head: SCENE IV.—Miſs LEERKINS and Mrs. KEPPEL.

sp.speaker: Miſs Leer.
sp.p: SISTER I am aſhamed of you. You behave out of all ſenſe and reaſon.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kep.
sp.p: Why ſo?

sp.speaker: Miſs Leer.
sp.p: You know that your huſband has ſpent all his own eſtate and yours, and he treats you with the moſt ſhameful neglect. And yet you place confidence in him, and have given him the laſt remains of your fortune. Are you not very fooliſh?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kep.
sp.p: Perhaps not, but if I be; how can I help it?

sp.speaker: Miſs Leer.
sp.p: How can you help it. You are a diſgrace to your ſex—There is no ſpirit in you; and let him treat you as he will, you are all patience, and dare not reſent it. I'd give him a good lecture upon the ſubject, ſuch as he never would wiſh to hear again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kep.
sp.p: Then you would never ſee him again.

sp.speaker: Miſs Leer.
sp.p: What then, I ſhould eſteem it a happy riddance. So much the better. I would have the whole houſe to myſelf and do what I pleaſed in it—That would not fright me at all.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kep.
sp.p: You know nothing about it.

sp.speaker: Miſs Leer.
sp.p: I know nothing about it—I know that a bad huſband is worſe than none. I will have a good one or none —What makes you think that I know nothing about it?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kep.
sp.p: I won't tell you.

sp.speaker: Miſs Leer.
sp.p: What? that is kind to be ſure—Not tell your ſiſter. But you ſhall tell me what is the reaſon I don't know.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kep.
sp.p: Poſitively I will not tell you; wait till you have a huſband of whom you are fond—who yet has ſome vices, as I ſuppoſe they all have, and then you will know.

sp.speaker: Miſs Leer.
sp.p: You treat me ſo ill—I will not talk with you. (Exit Miſs Leerkins, Mrs. Keppel ſoon follows her.)

div.head: ACT III.
div.stage: Mr. KEPPEL and Mrs. KEPPEL. (Keppel enters firſt, walks about diſturbed—ſhe enters ſoon after.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Kep.
sp.p: O My ſtars—what a wretch,—I am— ruined,—there is no help for me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kep.
sp.p: My friend, what's the matter.

sp.speaker: Mr. Kep.
sp.p: Let me alone—I'm ruined.

div.stage: (Mrs. Keppel looks grieved and ſpeaks tenderly.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kep.
sp.p: Not unleſs you are unkind to your wife

div.stage: (Keppel looks hard at her, is ſilent, then ſpeaks.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Kep.
sp.p: O my dear, my wife—I will not be unkind; but I am diſtracted; I am certainly undone, I have loſt all the money I had raiſed from your box of jewels—O that I could die with innocence; then I ſhould be glad to die.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kep.
sp.p: What, die, becauſe you have loſt your money: fie my huſband, fie upon it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Kep.
sp.p: I have now loſt every thing, and have completely ruined you, as well as myſelf; we are as poor as the pooreſt beggars—My dear, were it not that I would live as a mere ſervant to you, I could wiſh to die.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kep.
sp.p: Do you not recollect that when my mother oppoſed our marriage you told me, in one of your ardent raptures, nay you ſolemnly declared, that you could be happy even in the meaneſt cottage, and to live by the hardeſt labor, if you could only live with me—I laid that up in my heart.

sp.speaker: Mr. Kep.
sp.p: That was not the effect of rapture. It was my ſerious ſentiment, and I think ſo now.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kep.
sp.p: Then we have loſt nothing; only leave gaming, and we ſhall be happy.

sp.speaker: Mr. Kep.
sp.p: Leave gaming, I deteſt it. I perfectly abhor it—I will bind myſelf by the moſt ſolemn engagement never to touch a card again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kep.
sp.p: Can you keep your reſolution?

sp.speaker: Mr. Kep.
sp.p: I am ſure that I can.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kep.
sp.p:
Then only quit bad houſes and live reputably
with me—I will maintain you and myſelf—I underſtand many little handy matters—If my work ſells cheap I will work the more, and I am ſure I can maintain us both.

sp.speaker: Mr. Kep.
sp.p: Excellent woman—Your excellence exceeds all the power of language to expreſs it; I am confounded— But the idea of your virtues gives me the keeneſt pain, while I think I have made you wretched.

div.stage: (Mr. Leerkins enters with a box, to him Mrs. Keppel ſpeaks.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kep.
sp.p: Brother, you promiſed me for the forty pounds I lent you yeſterday to let me have all your winnings at cards for three days. This ſir (introducing her brother to Mr. Keppel) is my brother, yeſterday from the Eaſt Indies.

sp.speaker: Mr. Leer.
sp.p: Here madam is what I have won this day, and I find I won it of your huſband—But it is now yours. I ſcorn to violate my promiſe—Here is the whole in mortgages and bank notes. Take it. (She takes it.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kep
sp.p: Mr. Keppel this is now mine.

sp.speaker: Mr. Kep.
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kep.
sp.p: Accept the whole then as a preſent from me, I will not be denied.

sp.speaker: Mr. Kep.
sp.p: I am ſo ſurprized I can ſcarcely breathe—O my excellent wife!—Have I then eſcaped the gulf of ruin. I do ſolemnly proteſt I will never touch a card again. For I do verily believe that gaming, drunkeneſs, and bad company, have deſtroyed more men, than the ſword, peſtilence, and famine. (He takes the box and they all withdraw.)

div.head: The Triumph of Temper. A DRAMATIC DIALOGUE, IN THREE ACTS.
KEEP YOUR TEMPER, AND KEEP YOUR HOUSE.
div.p: Which ought have the ſupremacy of a houſe within doors—might be a delicate queſtion to decide between a man, and his wife; but a certain matter of fact helps us out. Whichſoever of the parties has the beſt command of temper and acts moſt rationally, will, other matters being equal, have the greateſt influence in the affairs of the family.

list.head: friends on equal condition, all new married men.

div.head: SCENE by way of prologue—JOHN SLY & Dr. BIRCH.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: SUR your ſervants—what, don't you know old John Sly?

sp.speaker: Birch.
sp.p: I have not the leaſt acquaintance with you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Why that's diſmal ſtrange now—that folks don't know their old friends after they have been to college— did not you kn • w Tom Sly the chimney ſweeper—Will Sly the Tinker, and Thoph Sly the Scowerer—up in the other end—there was a whole lane full of Slys.

sp.speaker: Birch.
sp.p: It was of as much conſequence to me as if it were full of crows—

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Well ſir you know that I pad up and down to ſell little books and pamphlets—I loſt one that I liked grandly— it uſed to make me laff. I think—I think, ſir, 'twas called Turning the Screw, or ſome ſuch name

sp.speaker: Birch.
sp.p: You mean Taming the Shrew—we have found ſuch a one—we have altered its name, we call it the Triumph of Temper—my ſcholars have learned it, and they are to act it this day.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Will you pay me for it?

sp.speaker: Birch.
sp.p: I have (feeling his pockets) had lately right ſchool maſters luck not a penny in my purſe; but a ſcholar when his purſe fails muſt draw upon his genius—here Mr. Sly, did you ever ſee a play acted?

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Never, pleaſe your honor.

sp.speaker: Birch.
sp.p: How ſhould you like to ſee one.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Grandly—ſir I ſhould like it grandly.

sp.speaker: Birch.
sp.p: The houſe is rather full but here ſet your box down and ſee how they go on with it.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Thank you maſter, a thouſand times—the gentlefolks there—won't take it •• l—

sp.speaker: Birch.
sp.p: No ſir, keep your ſtation, and you will not offend any body.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: WELCOME my friend Horatio—what are you alive?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Alive? why not?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: I heard that you had been married.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: What then? Does that kill folks? ſo have you been married too—

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: But I mean on account of the woman you married.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: I think I married a very agreeable one.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: I heard you married Ketura Roughgrain, daughter of old Robert Roughgrain the Peltmonger.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: True, I married her—'twas my choice.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Did you not know what a perfect tygreſs ſhe was— when at ſchool?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: I do not recollect every particular.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Many a time ſhe has boxed my ears till they were nearly bliſtered—at other times ſhe has attempted to claw my eyes out.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: And ſerved you right too—however I ſhall let your own conſcience anſwer for that.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Seriouſly I wonder you had the courage to marry her; for, to ſpeak my real ſentiments, ſhe was a perfect fury.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: You do not act right, my friend Bernardo—you ſee I am married—If your ſentiments made any impreſſion it could only make me diſcontented with my wife. But I think ſhe is a fine woman.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: You may think as well of her as you pleaſe—the happier you, the more you eſteem her.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p:
Will you, with Marcello, and your wives, ſup
with me this evening—you ſhall ſee that we are on happy terms with each other. Come early in the afternoon.

div.head: SCENE II.—HORATIO and KETURA.
div.stage: [She enters with a riding dreſs and a whip in her hand—Horatio looks ſurprized.]

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: What my dear, are you going out?

sp.speaker: Ket.
sp.p: Yes, I am. (In a croſs accent)

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: I had rather you would not go out, we are to receive company this evening.

sp.speaker: Ket.
sp.p: I know it, you mean to invite what company you pleaſe—and I muſt wait on them even to ſink with faintneſs and fatigue; you will have it ſo.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: We muſt receive company ſometimes if we mean to keep a houſe.

sp.speaker: Ket.
sp.p: Yes, I know what a ſcrape I have bro't myſelf into by being married; to keep a houſe, wait upon company and fatigue myſelf to death and get no thanks for it—I have tried it long enough, and I mean to get away.
Stay my dear, we ſhall be happy.

sp.speaker: Ket.
sp.p: So you told me before I was married, and you deſerve to be puniſhed for telling me ſuch lies—But that's the way of the men.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: We have not been married long enough yet, to form a judgment of it—We have been married (Looking at his watch) only five days, fifteen hours, fourteen minutes, and five ſeconds.

sp.speaker: Ket.
sp.p: You mean to turn it all into mirth; but you will find it a ſerious matter, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Let it be a ſerious matter then. We have been married five days, fifteen hours, fourteen minutes, and five ſeconds—and till theſe laſt ſeven minutes, we have been happy. It is about a thouſandth part of the time, that we have been on ill terms—Never mind it, my dear—We ſhall do very well.

sp.speaker: Ket.
sp.p: I have tried it long enough.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: No we can have no idea of the marriage ſtate yet— Had we lived ſixty years together, acquired and expended a large eſtate, brought up and ſettled in li • e, about a dozen children, then we might be ſaid to know ſomething about it.

sp.speaker: Ket.
sp.p:
If that is all to be done I will hear no more of it—
I'll get away as faſt as I can— (She appears to be going▪ he catches her by the arm, ſaying) Stay my dear one moment. (She ſtrikes him on the fingers)

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: O you jade! my ſweet bride I mean—You'll come back again in the evening.

sp.speaker: Ket.
sp.p: No I ſhall never darken theſe doors again—I am going to my father's houſe; from whence I came, and from whence I ought not to have come.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: You will let me come in the evening and wait on you home.

sp.speaker: Ket.
sp.p: No I forbid your ever coming after me again.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Then if you will not live with me I wiſh you may be happy without me.

sp.speaker: Ket.
sp.p: I ſhall never be happy if you can prevent it.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Keen ſponk! I vags for that.

She is gone, but I ſhall manage her well enough yet— It was happy for me that I was able to keep my temper— Had I loſt the command of myſelf I might have ruined all my plan— But I ſhall have a good wife of her yet.

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p: This has been no bad day's work (Caſting figures on his hat.) —1600 wt. of ſkins at an advance of 2 pence on the pound, is thirteen pounds ſix ſhillings and eight pence— Not a bad day's work—How do ye do my ſon? (Looks about him) Where is Ketura?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: I thank you ſir, we are all well except my wife, who is gone to your houſe.

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p: I tho't you were to have company to day.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Yes. but ſhe is gone home.

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p: Has ſhe any of her old tricks.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Old or new ones, they are ſuch as you ſee. When ſhe is to receive company ſhe runs home.

sp.speaker: Rough
sp.p: She means to come back again ſoon.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: She ſays ſhe never will.

sp.speaker: Rough
sp.p:
Never will. I'll ſee to that— You've bought a wild rabbit and you ſhall keep her—She ſhan't come home
to make ſuch a carnal noiſe and racket as ſhe uſed to do at our houſe.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Whatever you do, treat her kindly for my ſake—I will go to your houſe in the evening and ſee if ſhe will not come home.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: I'd ſee her burnt firſt.

div.head: SCENE I.—HORATIO, BERNARDO, MARCELLO, PORTIA, JULIA, all enter in ſucceſſion.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: YOU are welcome my friends you are heartily welcome—my wife is gone out—But ſuch attendance as we can make with our ſervants we ſhall give you with pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: We heard ſir, on our way, of the elopement of your wife, we began to congratulate you upon it.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: What, are they at ſeperate maintenance already. They ought, in decency, to have waited till the honey moon was over.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Our friend Horatio invited us here, I believe, to ſee a curioſity—and his wife, I am confident is the greateſt in America, of the kind—but we are likely to be deprived of the pleaſure of ſeeing her.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Well, he was not ignorant of what he had when he took her.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: I ſhall have a fine wife of her yet.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Then you will mould dry ſand into pye cruſt, for I ſhould think the order of nature muſt be changed before you will ſee a good wife of her.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: You are extremely ſevere on my wife—but ſhe is a woman of excellent qualities—and I will have a tender, kind, loving wife of her yet—I'm a connoiſſeur in women.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: You have ſhown it by your choice, as all the world knows.

div.head: SCENE II.—ROBERT, HORATIO, BERNARDO—the reſt ſtanding ſilent, Robert comes in all out of breath.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: WELL ſir your wife is coming home again.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: I expected it: but how do you know it is true.?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I followed your directions and ſtayed about the houſe to watch her motions; but kept out of her ſight, at laſt the old gentleman came home.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: What ſaid he to her?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: He was in a perfect rage, when he found ſhe talked of ſtaying, he ſwore ſhe ſhould return that minute—he took your horſe with your wife's new hunting ſaddle, put them into the ſtable, and locked them up.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: How could ſhe come home then?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: He took an old horſe out of the plough, whoſe back was ſharp as a pike; and you might have counted his ribs at twenty rods diſtance—then mounted your wife on an old pannel that ſhed feathers—with a girt of red tape and the bridle of twenty pieces of ſheep's leather—the crupper, of the ſtraps of an old knapſack thus he ſet her out on her journey. And the old horſe could not be got out of a ſtep all the way.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: How did ſhe proceed?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: The dogs barked, the boys halloed, and the feathers flew all the way, and when the old horſe got againſt the great tavern in the middle of the village, the horſe ſtopped, and the mob gathered round, and huzza'd, and it was ſometime before we got him ſtarted again.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: What became of her after that.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: When we came down the hill by the brook, the old brute ſtumbled, and threw your wife off—and it was a long time before we could pick her up, and tie up her ſtrings again.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: What became of her then?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: She burſt into tears, for every thing plagued her heart out—and deſired me to go forward and aſk you to come, and bring her home.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Bernardo, your chaiſe is ready, let me take it, and wait on her immediately.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: You may take my chaiſe, but ſhe ſhould di • in the ſtreet before I would go after her.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: I am not of your mind, I ſhall bring her home, in the gentleſt manner poſſible.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: That looks darn'd fooliſh; but he knows a ſheep's-head from a carrot, I'll lay a mug on't.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: SO he is gone after her; I'm vexed with him that he humours her ſo.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: She deſerves to lie in the ſtreet all night—To abuſe ſo good a huſband!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: He may know how to manage her. He had about 150 quarrels with her before ſhe conſented to be married. But he made her conſent.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: We will withdraw into the oppoſite room, for if he fondles and careſſes her, when ſhe comes in, I ſhall loſe all patience.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Beſt withdraw, and leave them to themſelves a little, when they firſt come in.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: SEAT yourſelf, my deareſt friend, you muſt be extremely fatigued.

sp.speaker: Ket.
sp.p: Oh! I am juſt ready to faint.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Shall I bring you a glaſs of wine. This is ſoft, and pleaſant, a little of it will revive you.— (Gives her a glaſs.)

sp.speaker: Ket.
sp.p: You are exceeding good to wait on me home, and treat me ſo kindly.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: I am extremely rejoiced to ſee you come home again.

sp.speaker: Ket.
sp.p: O what a raſh girl I was to leave you in ſo much ill humor!

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Never think of it a moment. If you are come to live with me again, all is as it ſhould be.

sp.speaker: Ket.
sp.p: O ſir, you are generous beyond all bounds.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Very generous to be ſure to gain the heart of ſo fine a woman—But go my dear and wait on the company.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: That's right—flatter her up—It works like wool— She'll melt like wax by and by.

div.head: SCENE V.—BERNARDO, HORATIO, WILLIAM and KETURA.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: WELL you have brought her home then?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Yes I knew I had as good a wife as any of you.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: So you have broke my chaiſe you villain.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Only I was going to the ale houſe ſir.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: And got drunk before you went, and drove my chaiſe into a ditch, and broke it.

sp.speaker: Ket.
sp.p: Bernardo, there muſt be no noiſy paſſions in my houſe. Chide your ſervant elſe where. This houſe is ſacred to peace.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: If one were to ſee you in this trim only, he would think you were an angel.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: ROBERT I underſtand you have been ſpeaking diſreſpectful • y 〈◊〉 my wi • e—Tell me your wages, let me pay you, and 〈◊〉 .

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: So I beg you would not ſend me away, to a diſtance from my wife a •• children.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: No man ſh • ll live with me who abuſes my wife —You have ſinned bey • nd pardon ſo you muſt go.

sp.speaker: Ket.
sp.p: Spare him for my ſake—He is a good man, do not ſend him away from his wife, and children.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: See what a good waman you have offended.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I aſk a thouſand pardons, and will ſerve you to the laſt moment of my life.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Go then to your work, and know that he who inſults my wife, more than inſults me.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: I HAVE bro't the riding coat I was making for your wife.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: (Taking up the coat and looking at it.) It is too broad acroſ the ſhoulders. It is big enough for a Porter.

sp.speaker: Hot
sp.p: A woman ſhould have broad ſhoulders who ſuperſ • des her huſband. Pardon a joke ſir.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: What pardon a joke, I'll break your back Do you mean to inſult my wife. If I hear ſuch a thing from you again, I'll be meaſure your back, you cabbage eater, till you never ſhall think of joking again while you live. (Catches his yard ſtick from him.)

sp.speaker: Ket.
sp.p: (Interpoſing) Spare, ſir, the good man for my ſake. (She then takes up the coat and gives direction for altering it.) Here take it in about ſo much, and it will do very well.

sp.speaker: Ket.
sp.p: SIT ſtill my dear. I wiſh to talk with you, we muſt find ſome way to reſtrain theſe angry paſſions.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: He inſulted you, had he inſulted me, it would not have moved me in the leaſt.

sp.speaker: Ket.
sp.p: But I wiſh we might agree and make is a habit to live in perfect amity with each other.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: There is nothing I more ardently deſire.

sp.speaker: Ket.
sp.p: I wiſh for it more as I have been erroneous: I need you for my example and guide.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: You can guide yourſelf—I am not afraid to truſt your own diſcretion for fifty years to come. Do juſt as you pleaſe in every reſpect.

sp.speaker: Ket.
sp.p: I do not chuſe it. You ſhall be my friend, protector and guide—how happy your goodneſs makes me.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: What think you now, my bride, cannot perſons be happy in the marriage ſtate?

sp.speaker: Ket.
sp.p: O yes, indeed I have enjoyed more happineſs, more heartfelt felicity in one half hour, ſince I returned to you, than in all the reſt of my life, you ſhall this moment accept me as a pupil, and teach me how to live.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: I will be your friend unchangeably. But we muſt ſee our company.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Now madam your'e gone for't, after this you may ſet up your Ebenezer if you can.

div.head: SCENE I.—MARCELLO, BERNARDO and HORATIO.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: THE ladies wiſh to be by themſelves, what ſay you my friend to taking a hand of cards.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Horatio will not play, his wife will come and whip him if he does,

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Yes, I will—but a different game from any you imagine. I will bet—tho I'm an enemy in principle to games of hazard. I will—bet—twelve dozen bottles of the beſt Madeira wine that upon any trial you pleaſe, my wife will be more obedient to me than either of yours to you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I'll ſtand with twenty four dozen againſt twelve.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: So will I, for my ſweet girl, and you are taken in, old gentleman, you may depend on it.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: What ſhall be the proof?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: The ladies are very buſy by themſelves, and will be loth to come away —let each ſend for his wife to come to him immediately.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: That's a good proof—yes—yes—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: (To his ſervant) Duncan, go and tell my wife to come to me immediately.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: (To his ſervant) William, tell my wife to come to me immediately.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: (To his ſervant) Robert, tell my wife to come to me immediately.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What ſays my wife?

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: She ſays ſhe'll come preſently, as ſoon as ſhe has played out her hand of cards.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: And what does my wife ſay?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: She ſays ſhe is very buſy, and ſhe wonders why you cannot have the complaiſance to come to her. [While this is doing Ketura comes behind her huſband, unſeen.]

sp.speaker: Ket.
sp.p: What would you have of me?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: (Springing up) My dear, you are indeed come yourſelf. Sit, my ſweet girl. Well, what do you ſay now, gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: You've won, you have won.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I wonder my wife would ſerve me ſo?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: I'll know the reaſon, why my wife did not come.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p:
Patience gentleman—No man ſhall ſay any ill-natured thing to a wife in my houſe—I ſhould deem it a profanation—The great ſecret of managing a wife is always to treat her kindly; and keep your temper; then if ſhe be not a perfect fury ſhe will do very much as you pleaſe to have her—But a man of harſh temper may kill a woman,
but he cannot govern her—You might as well ſet a blackſmith to making watches.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Well ladies! Ketura has won the prize on the trial of kindneſs to her huſband. She came firſt of the three—we have loſt only twenty four dozen of Mad • ria each. (The ladies look mortified.)

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Never mind the wine. I'll give twenty four dozen, and we will form ourſelves into a ſociety for promoting matrimonial happineſs—the wine ſhall ſerve us when we meet.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: We all ſay amen to that. (They aſſent.)

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Well then, our ſupper is ready, we will paſs the evening in the true ſtile of feſtivity and joy.

div.stage: [Actors go off—each gentleman leading out his wife.]

sp.speaker: Birch.
sp.p: A PERSON has put a ſhilling or two into my hands, I will pay you now for your pamphlet.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: No matter no, your play has put me into pure good humor—Nothing at all maſter.

sp.speaker: Birch.
sp.p: Yes take it, and this too. There's your pay. (Gives him one piece) There's intereſt for the delay of your money. (Gives him another.)

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Thank you ſir a thouſand times—But maſter, your play makes me think—maſter it makes me think.—

sp.speaker: Birch.
sp.p: Think of what Mr. Sly?

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: My Jane and I had a ſnapſhort this morning and we have not ſaid a good natured thing to each other all day long—But I have a great mind, not to go to a tavern, and ſwill away alone like a beaſt—but to buy ſomething good to eat with this, (Shows one piece of money) and ſomething good to drink with this, (Shows the other piece) and go home, and take a ſweet little ſupper with Jane, and ſet every thing to rights before we ſleep a wink. (Slings his box and goes off ſinging.)

lg.l: MY Jenny was a pretty maid;
And we did love when we were young—
We wiſh'd to wed; the Parſon ſaid
The word, and ty'd us firm and ſtrong.
My Jenny proved a charming wiſe;
And ſtill is ſweet at fifty-five—
She loves me ſtill, which makes me feel
As glad as any man alive.
For love is juſt like bottled beer,
'Tis pleaſanter for being old—
And it is like a buttered toaſt;
'Tis much the worſe for being cold.
The more we love the more we may,
As turns the wheel of life about;—
This ſpark of fire, in our cold clay,
Is the laſt ſpark that e'er goes out.

div.head: The Mother of a Family. A DRAMA, IN THREE ACTS.
PATIENCE.
div.p: One of the moſt uſeful of human virtues is patience. To bear afflictions and every event which tends to diſturb the mind, with calmneſs, denotes a highly improved underſtanding. There is no condition of human life which cheriſhes this virtue ſo much as marriage. It is eaſy, and promotes the higheſt degree of ſelf approbation, to bear diſtreſs for the ſake of thoſe whom we love.

list.head: WOMEN.
list.item: MRS. GOODHEART—a farmer's wife with a large family.
MISS KEENSIGHT—her younger ſiſter, a manhater.
NELLY — a romp, the third daughter, aged 14.
SOFTLY—woman aſſiſtant to Mrs. Goodheart, in the care of the family.

div.head: SCENE I —Col. RIVERS and Miſs KEENSIGHT.

sp.speaker: Col. Riv.
sp.p: YOU muſt know, Miſs Keenſight, that I have long paid my diligent reſpects to you.

sp.speaker: Keen.
sp.p: If you have been agreeably employed they may ſtill continue.

sp.speaker: C. Riv.
sp.p: But I am tired of uncertainties, I wiſh we could underſtand one another.

sp.speaker: Keen.
sp.p: Well ſir what would you pleaſe to have?

sp.speaker: C. Riv.
sp.p: Sometime within the limits of duration, I hope you will be mine.

sp.speaker: Keen.
sp.p: How yours?

sp.speaker: C. Riv.
sp.p: I mean by marriage, I wiſh not for equivocation.

sp.speaker: Keen.
sp.p: We may wait a little longer.

sp.speaker: C. Riv.
sp.p: I am tired of waiting and wiſh to have my fate decided.

sp.speaker: Keen.
sp.p: There is no need of that.

sp.speaker: C. Riv.
sp.p: I think there is, I will be reſolved, and not pay my reſpects in vain.

sp.speaker: Keen.
sp.p: Then withdraw them, if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: C. Riv.
sp.p: Why then have you detained me ſo long?

sp.speaker: Keen.
sp.p: It is well enough to have a gentleman to conduct one to balls, aſſemblies &c. But as for marriage, I deteſt it—It is of all things the moſt odious to me.

sp.speaker: C. Riv.
sp.p: This is the moſt generous ſpeech you ever made to me. Now I know what to depend on. I thank you moſt heartily and wiſh you a good evening.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Where is Col. Rivers, does he not ſtay to tea?

sp.speaker: Keen.
sp.p: No, and I hope he never will paſs much of his time in this houſe.

sp.speaker: Good
sp.p: And have you taken offence all at once?

sp.speaker: Keen.
sp.p: No, I never felt myſe • f intereſted enough, with reſpect to him, to do that.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Have you taken a ſudden diſlike?

sp.speaker: Keen.
sp.p: No, for I never liked him or any other man.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: But tell me plainly why does he not ſtay to tea? I hoped for the pleaſure of his company.

sp.speaker: Keen.
sp.p: The plain truth muſt be known, I have given him his final diſmiſſion.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: You aſtoniſh me. What reaſon had you to diſcard him? Is he not an accompliſhed gentleman? Has he not an excellent moral character? Does be not make offers of fortune far beyond any juſt claim of yours?

sp.speaker: Keen.
sp.p: More than that, I own that be is one of the moſt agreeable of men; which you may think a ſimple confeſſion.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: I ſhould not think that a good reaſon for diſmiſſing him.

sp.speaker: Keen.
sp.p: That was my reaſon, I found that if I did not diſmiſs him ſoon, I never ſhould.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: You are too prudent; and may hereafter repent your diſcretion.

sp.speaker: Keen.
sp.p: My name is Keenſight you know.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: So was mine once but I changed it for Goodheart; & have ever ſince been glad of the exchange—I found that was the way to be happy.

sp.speaker: Keen.
sp.p: You happy! Bleſs my ſtars▪ you happy! I would not live the life you do for the wealth of the United States, and that is the reaſon why I will not marry. I would not marry the fineſt gentleman who treads this earth.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: So you ſay now, when you may marry if you pleaſe; when you cannot marry you will think otherwiſe. I have ſeen maidens of fif • y ſetting their caps at young gentlemen of twenty five and rendering themſelves perfectly ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Keen.
sp.p: That you will never ſee in me, ſo you may ſet your heart at reſt.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p:
Why not in you as well as in others, and why
ſhould my ſituation afright you—Why do I not appear to be happy?

sp.speaker: Keen.
sp.p: Why ſhould I not think you happy? I wonder you do not die outright with vexation—You work extremely hard, and have to pay the ſevereſt attention from night to day, and from day to night—Your children are the moſt diſorderly crew that ever were hatched, when they are out of humor they are always a bawling—There will be half a dozen of them tuning up at once—They are ever fighting and clawing one another—When they are in good humor they play with execeſſive noiſe and violence as if the houſe were going out at the windows—Then they are upſetting every thing thro the whole houſe—They are ever breaking their own ſhins or one anothers noſes—They are ever loſing their hats and their ſhoes—One falls down ſtairs and is taken up half dead—One is burnt and another is ſcalded— Another cuts his leg, or his hand, and is bleeding to death. Then you are all in tears—and—

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: And can you think of nothing farther? You have not told me half of the truth yet. I have ſeen and ſuffered ten times as much as you have any idea of; and yet I am not unhappy—I have a very kind huſband.

sp.speaker: Keen.
sp.p: O, yes, I ſuppoſe that kind huſband makes up for all—He pretends to be fond of you, and flatters you—He is cunning enough for himſelf. You place entire confidence in him. Were he to tell you that a bedlam was a palace, you would believe him. After your children had worried you all day, on ſeeing your huſband come home at night I have ſeen you ſhed tears of joy—and you had to wait on him two hours. I really felt aſhamed for you.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: What a ſimplicity you are ſiſter, with all your boaſted ſenſe.

sp.speaker: Keen
sp.p: Simplicity I will be then—your huſband by being ſo obſtinate has brought a lawſuit upon himſelf, which many people ſay will ruin him. I expect in a few days to ſee you turned out of houſe and home. I ſee plainly that all this is in conſequence of your marriage, and if any man ever ſees me catched in that trap he ſhall bleſs his eyes for the ſight. (Exit Keenſight.)

sp.speaker: Goodheart alone.
sp.p:
O DEAR, I am extremely fatigued
But I muſt attend to the buſineſs of the family. I ſhould like to take ſome reſt for a few moments, but my children, poor little rog • es, they muſt be taken care of.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: I am glad to find you at home, Mrs. Goodheart, I have a little 〈…〉 with you.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: And I am no leſs gla • to ſee you. I had thought of ſending for you.

sp.speaker: Softly.
sp.p: I wiſhed to know whether I could live with you— you need ſome perſon, you are ſo taken up with the children—I will do the work of the family; but I will be treated as a houſekeeper, not as a maid.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: You ſhall be treated as a friend. I will give you more than maid's wages, becauſe being a relation. I hope you will be kind to the children.

sp.speaker: Softly
sp.p: Then I will begin as ſoon as may be—I am out of buſineſs, and am perfectly tired of idleneſs.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: It is nearly time for tea; go and ſet the tea table, and get tea ſoon.

sp.speaker: Softly.
sp.p: I will go then in a moment, for I am happy to have ſomething to do (Softly goes out)

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: alone. I am glad of this girl's coming; ſhe is good natured, and will have patience with the children. Very few of the maids we hire have any diſcretion to manage the little ones. [Letitia enters.]

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: LETITIA, I am happy to ſee you; take a ſeat, my dear.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: I have long wiſhed for an opportunity to viſit you, and am extremely gratified that at laſt I have found one. Where's Nelly?

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: She is traipſing about ſome where. Poor girl— I wiſh ſhe had a little more ſteadineſs.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Does ſhe not go to ſchool?

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: She is utterly averſe to it. She ſays that ſhe is ſo big, and ſo awkward, that ſhe is aſhamed to go.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: But it is a great pity; as ſhe is naturally agreeable; her genius is good, and her natural diſpoſition excellent.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p:
Poor girl, ſhe has no advantages. When ſhe is at home ſhe is always buſy in ſome family care; and there
is always ſo much muſic at our houſe, that one might as well ſtudy in a tavern. [Keenſight enters]

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: I doubt not that ſhe might be perſuaded to • o to ſchool, and were ſhe once placed there ſhe would make good progreſs in her learning.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: I wiſh you would try, for ſhe is ſo awkward now that I am quite aſhamed of her and ſhe is aſhamed of herſelf. Her manners are rough—her words are courſe and her knowledge of grammar is nothing — her pronunciation is extremely vulgar—ſhe writes very ill—and as to arithmetic and muſic ſhe knows nothing of either.

sp.speaker: Keen.
sp.p: You ought to ſay ſhe is a monſtrous romp and that ſhe ſpends half her time in company with Jack Lounger. She has no idea of a proper choice of company.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: You need not make my girl worſe than ſhe is. She is bad enough in her preſent ſtate. But it is not ſo much her fault, as of her ſituation in life.

sp.speaker: Keen
sp.p: O yes, ſhe is a precious child to be ſure, and one of the ſolid comforts of matrimony, if it were only the mere poſſibility of having one ſuch child it would forever deter me from marriage. [Exit Keenſight.]

div.head: SCENE V.—LAURA, SOPHIA, LETITIA and GOODHEART.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: I DESIRE Ma'am that you would let me look of ſome of your work—I wiſh to imitate it.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: I have none here my child—I will go out and look for ſome—But if I do not find any, Letitia will furniſh you.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: I wiſh you would let me ſee yours, I have a great deſire to go to your houſe, on purpoſe to ſee how you work.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: I can ſhow you here. (Shows her work.)

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: O how beautiful this is. It is elegant. I never ſaw any thing of the ſort ſo pretty. I will try to do ſomething like it. We ſeldom have opportunity to do any thing elegant—We have to tend the dairy and make coarſe clothes for the younger children.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: And I will ſee what I can do.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: DON'T ſay any thing to my aunt Keenſight about the young gentlemen's coming here this evening.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Why not to her?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: She ſays ſhe will drive away the whole tribe of fops from the houſe while ſhe ſtays. She won't have her nieces turn fools, and be married as their mother was.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Now which had you rather be, ſuch a woman as your mother; or your aunt Keenſight?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p:
That is eaſily an • wered—I know my mother ſuffers extreme fatigue and • a •
▪ Yet ſhe is forever pleaſant, and good humored My aunt does very little, but conſult her own eaſe. Yet ſhe f • ets a hundred times to where my ma'am does on 〈◊〉 . They are ſiſters.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: What can make the difference?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: When ma'am means to divert us, ſhe ſays it is being married that makes the difference, and adviſes us all to be married, that we may be kept in good humor.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: It is likely enough to be a ſerious truth. People who love only themſelves will always be fretful; but they who feel kind to other perſons will certainly be otherwiſe.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: I cannot find any work of mine; but Letitia can anſwer all your demands. Where is Laura?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: She went out ſometime ago, and is not returned.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: I wonder what makes her ſtay.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: We will go out and ſee. [All withdraw.]

sp.speaker: Plain.
sp.p: IS not Mr. Goodheart returned?

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: He has not certainly.

sp.speaker: Plain.
