sp.p: I hoped to have ſeen him before his ſuit ſhould be determined.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Why before that time?

sp.speaker: Plain.
sp.p: Becauſe he ſtands indebted to me for a ſmall ſum, and I wiſh for good ſecurity.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Why for ſecurity now, when I have often heard you ſay his word was ſufficient?

sp.speaker: Plain.
sp.p: He will do as well as he can, but he may not be very able when he has done with his ſuit.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Why, do you think he will loſe?

sp.speaker: Plain.
sp.p: I am really afraid he will, I adviſed him not to go on with it—but he never would hear to me—Let me know when he comes home.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Plain.
sp.p: Be ſure you do it. What a pity it was he did not hear to me. [Exit Plainfield.]

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: I am ſure I did not deſire it, unleſs you had more ſenſe. [George enters.]

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: WHAT my ſon have you come home to tarry. Is it vacation?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: No—but I am like to get into a b • d ſcrape at College—I was in company with a ſet of fellows, who did miſchief in the night—and am called to account.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: I am afraid that your father and I are never to have any comfort of you George—you are ſo irregular— and—

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Why Ma'am tho I was in their company, when I ſaw them about to do miſchief, I was gone ſo quick that I could now bring a man to ſwear I was in another place; and I want to know your advice whether I ſhall bring the man to ſwear or not.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Not certainly, unleſs to ſwear to the truth. Tho I cannot wiſh you to be puniſhed—Yet I do not wiſh you to eſcape by any thing which has even the appearance of falſhood.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: But I am certainly innocent.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Let truth have its courſe then and it will appear— and you may yet be a comfort to your mother—Go and ſtand trial and tell no lies. (Exit George.)

sp.speaker: Softly.
sp.p:
Madam, I am very much concerned for Laura—
She has a pain under her left arm near her heart, very ſharp and ſevere.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: And does that alarm you?

sp.speaker: Softly.
sp.p: Mr. Woodru •• had juſt ſuch a pain about three hours defore he died of the appolexy. (She riſes to go out▪ and is met by Sally in haſte)

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: O dear ma'am, I'm af • aid Billy has broke his arm. He has fallen down ſtairs—and hurt him dreadfully—He can ſcarcely move his arm one inch. (Goodheart goes out and Softly follows her.)

sp.speaker: Keen.
sp.p: (To Letitia and Sophia) Now girls let me give you one piece of advice. Above all do you avoid being married. It is the worſt of all evils. You ſee what a deplorable ſituation your mother is in. Her eldeſt ſon is going to be expelled from the college—There is one child dying of the apoplexy. Another has broke his arm, one girl ſo awkward and ſo vicious that ſhe plagues her heart out. Her huſband abſent, and muſt loſe his eſtate before he comes back. Now young ladies fix the matter in your own minds that you never will be married. Then let the men coax and teaze, and plead, and flatter, and careſs you ever ſo much, be ſteady, let them know you won't, and that's enough.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: I am rather too old for counſel. I have made up my mind upon that matter ſometime ago.

sp.speaker: Keen.
sp.p: And what do you ſay Sophia?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: I am fully determined what to do if I have the opportunity of choice.

sp.speaker: Keen.
sp.p: And which way are you determined ladies?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: That muſt remain a ſecret. If I ſay I will refuſe, that will offend my mother. If I ſay I will accept, that will offend you. If I ſay I will—not▪ at any event, that is inſulting the young gentlemen— 〈◊〉 I ſay I will, it is like ſetting up myſelf for ſale like a cheap • r • ic •• in the market. So I believe madam it is beſt for young ladies never to anſwer that queſtion till it be ſuitably propoſed.

sp.speaker: Keen
sp.p:
You are very prudent young ladies, but I underſtand the matter. It is all done to vex me, done on purpoſe
I know. [Goodheart returns and ſeats herſelf with a number of papers in her lap.]

div.head: SCENE V.—GOODHEART, SOFTLY, SOPHIA▪ LETITIA, and KEENSIGHT.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: [giving Softly a paper] Here Miſs Softly take this and bruiſe it very fine—moiſten it with ſpirits and warm it over the fire, and lay it on a ſoft bandage, to put on Billy's arm.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: I will do it immediately.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Stay, take this and diſſolve it in warm water—then put to it half a glaſs of wine, a tea ſpoonful of paregoric— let it remain in a tea cup till I come out.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: How does uncle Goodheart now? One of our neighbors writ home the other day to his wife, that he was likely to loſe his cauſe; and if he did it would ruin him entirely.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: I hope not, I am ſure: what will become of me and my poor children?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: And did you know ma'am of brother George. It is ſaid he has got into a very bad ſcrape at college—and is in great danger of public puniſhment.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Oh dear! I tho't I had trouble enough before.

div.stage: [She riſes to go out, a great noiſe is heard, and Softly ruſhes in.]

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Oh ma'am, ſee, only ſee what a piece of work here is. The tea table is turned over, and every thing is broken to pieces.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: There is half the ware we had in the houſe broken to pieces—There's that beautiful china bowl, which we made punch in, the evening I was married—and that curious mug, which we uſed to call the enchanted mug—with all the tea furniture. How came every thing on the tea-table?

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: I got ſome drink for Laura in the enchanted mug—and was going to get ſome in the china bowl for the ladies.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: How came the table overſet?

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: The children were not to blame. Nabby climbed the back of a chair; and was going to fall, Tommy flew to ſave her, touched the tea table, and overſet it. He is dreadful ſorry ma'am.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p:
I could be ſorry at another time, but I have ſo
much greater troubles now.—Siſter come and help me about the children; and Sophia—you come—I will ſend Nelly to wait on Letitia.

sp.speaker: Keen.
sp.p: Little miſchievous brats, I am glad I have none of my own to wait on, I know.

div.head: SCENE VI.—LETITIA and NELLY.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: WHAT was the reaſon, Miſs Nelly, that you did not go with us to ſchool▪

sp.speaker: Nel.
sp.p: Really now what do you think of theſe times? Every body is going to ſchool, do you think they gets any good by it?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Your every body is a ſmall number—There are but thirty perſons in the town, who have any education more than in the common ſchools, and there are a thouſand inhabitants—Divide 1000 by 30 and it will give you the proportion.

sp.speaker: Nel.
sp.p: I could not do that any more than I could fly.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: [Takes a ſtate and makes figures.] See 1000 by 30 quotes 33—that is even more than the number that pay any uncommon attention to learning.

sp.speaker: Nel.
sp.p: Why the jingo! I tho't it was more. I wondered what we ſhould do for girls to make butter—Uncle Triſtram ſays he hates to have girls go to ſchool, it makes them ſo darn'd uppiſh and ſo deuced proud that they won't work—Mawther want's I ſhould go.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: I believe your mother is right and your uncle is wrong—Good ſcholars are no more idle at ſchool, than at home.

sp.speaker: Nel.
sp.p: But why do you need ſo much larning; you ſtudy religion, d'ye mean to preach? No I ſee the trick, you mean to marry parſons, and make us poor farmers girls call you madams.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Would it grieve you to marry a perſon, whoſe principle, practice, and profeſſion, all lead him to treat you well.

sp.speaker: Nel.
sp.p: No fags! that it woud'n't—When I hear a clean looking young preacher hold forth upon love—I cannot help thinking that he would make a jim huſband. It is fir'd pretty to be talked to nicely—But one ſhould not think ſo a ſabbadays.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: You correct your improper thoughts I dare ſay— But eloquence is very pleaſing.

sp.speaker: Nel.
sp.p: And you ſtudy ratterick at ſchool; the art of talking —now to women it ſeems to me quite natural—You ſtudies Phloſophy natural and mortal.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: You mean moral I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Nel.
sp.p: It it all one to me—Brother George ſays Phloſophers uſed to wear long beards—He makes fun of you, and calls you the ſmooth chin'd Phloſophers.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: George ſhall treat one with more decency than he commonly does, or he ſhall one day dread to hear the name of the ſmooth chin'd Philoſophers.

sp.speaker: Nel.
sp.p: Sometimes he is rather too jolly with the ladies— Fawther ſays 'tis not worth while to ſend him to college to larn miſchief—But dont you think there are clever men at college?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Yes, many of genuine learning, and refined merit, and ſome otherwiſe.

sp.speaker: Nel.
sp.p: But there is one of your ſtudies which I ſee no uſe for 'mongſt plain working folks—muſt a farmer learn politeneſs to talk genteelly to his oxen?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: He muſt ſometimes talk to his children, his friends, his wife. He ſays to his oxen—Haw and Jee—and "twig up Whiteface." Would you have him ſay ſo to you?

sp.speaker: Nel.
sp.p: No—I'd make him know with a vengeance that he ſhould talk handſomer to me.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: You would wiſh to have your huſband, if he were a farmer, poſſeſs a tolerable ſhare of politeneſs—do you not remember our going up into the further part of the town— called mud-puddle corner, to what they called a frolic?

sp.speaker: Nel.
sp.p: A frolic! 'Twas a right down jamm. The fellors were as drunk as wheelbarrows. The girls were all daſhed into nothing and were as dumb and diſmal as all nature. Had I known afore how I ſhould have felt I would not have gone any more than I'd have flewed.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: And do you not remember our going to Fairſide— did you not like the entertainment?

sp.speaker: Nel.
sp.p:
Yes that was nice at any thing. 'Twas as 'cute as a jewel. They did not ſay: came along Nell—and here it goes Nell—but ſhall I have the pleaſure to dance with you Miſs Nelly. Shall I help you to a ſlice of orange, Miſs Nelly—They would not laugh at, and mortify one, that did
not talk ſo coupee. They treated me ſo well that it really made me feel purely.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: The men in Fairſide are in the ſame employments as thoſe in mud-puddle corner. Then education makes an agreeable difference. Did any of the gentlemen viſit you ſince?

sp.speaker: Nel.
sp.p: Yes ſeveral times Mr.—N— (whiſpers to Letitia) and he bro't me a fine pair of verſes all writ out in proſe.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: In proſe! you mean in verſe. Poems are always written in verſe.

sp.speaker: Nel.
sp.p: That's the way I always come off, when I try to talk genteel, ſometimes I think I never will try again.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: But were you properly inſtructed, you might try; and meet with ſucceſs.

sp.speaker: Nel.
sp.p: But don't you think the folks in the right down genteel, nipping way, are more deceitful than others?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Not always; but ſome think it genteel to treat people handſomely when preſent, and when abſent to render them ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Nel.
sp.p: Law! mercy on us—I'll never be genteel then▪

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: But could you gain eſteem by a ſuitable behavior?

sp.speaker: Nel.
sp.p: That I ſhould like deſperately.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: And that is real gentility.

sp.speaker: Nel.
sp.p: But how will the young fellows take it if we ſhine away and don't like their humdrum ways—Won't they be as mad as vengeance—and aſhociate with the girls who don't go to ſchool?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Let the ill bred women and the ill bred men go together—if they leave the well bred men to us we will thank them—Do you not think I am right my dear?

sp.speaker: Nel.
sp.p: I obſarves ſince you went to ſchool that you often calls me my dear, and my friend. Do you really think ſo, or do you only mean to palaver—ſome folks ſays it is all a •• am, and that you mean nothing by it.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: I mean what I ſay, and always ſhall be really happy to have you for my friend.

sp.speaker: Nel.
sp.p: Well now if I really tho't I could get a nice huſband I don't know but I ſhould try to larn—what likelihoods do you think there is that I ſhall be married.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: In the country—it is calculated that of 78 women who live to 18 years, 72 are married under thirty—then (figures on a ſtate) as 72: 6: • 12—1—twelve for being married to one againſt it—well bred women have a fairer proſpect ſtill.

sp.speaker: Nel.
sp.p: They told me Arithmetic was a dry ſtudy. I am ſure it is quite entertaining—Ma'am will be glad of it— I'll go to ſchool with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: I adviſe you to maintain that reſolution.

sp.speaker: Nel.
sp.p: Well now this beats all, that you ſhould tell by arithmetic the likelihoods of being married—I'll learn arithmetic, I vum I will. Good-Nighty.

div.stage: (Drops a low curteſy and goes out.)

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Let one, if you be going out, walk with you.

div.head: SCENE I.—GOODHEART, NELLY, SALLY and KEENSIGHT.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: IT is ſaid that if troubles come faſt they will ſoon be over—Mine come faſt indeed—I am determined not to loſe patience, for then I ſhall be truly miſerable.

sp.speaker: Nel.
sp.p: (Ruſhing in) O ma'am I'm willing, I'm willing to go to ſchool.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: I am very glad to hear it; I have been very much mortified that you were ſo averſe to learning—I hope you will make up loſt time—you ſhall go to ſchool next week.

div.stage: [Sally enters with a baſket of fruit.]

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: See ma'am what beautiful fruit; I pick out the beſt for you, becauſe you are ſo good to me. Are all mothers ſo good to their children?

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: I believe they are generally well diſpoſed.

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: Then I gueſs they are quite happy, for it makes me feel nicely when I do things that are good.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Then you feel nicely now I believe.

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: O yes ma'am—I am always very glad when I have done any thing to pleaſe you.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: You are a very good child my dear.

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: I hope I ſhall make papa ſay the ſame when he comes home. I will gather a fine baſket of fruit for him —William has given me a fine melon—It is yellow as gold, I will ſave that for pà. The men are very good to work for us, and raiſe fruit and almoſt every thing we have.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Yes, and ladies may reſpect them in a proper manner—at leaſt they may reſpect their own fathers.

sp.speaker: Keen.
sp.p: And if your girls don't worſhip the men I ſhall think they have not the leaſt ſpark of their mother's genius.

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: But if pa loved us as much as we do him, would he go away and ſtay from us ſo long?

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: I do not knew when he will return, nor in what ſituation of his affairs. (She covers her face and wipes her eyes.)

div.head: SCENE II.—SOFTLY, GOODHEART and LAURA.
div.stage: (Softly enters at the beginning of the ſcene.)

sp.speaker: Softly.
sp.p: Madam, Billy's arm gets better very faſt, he can move it now very eaſily—It is only bruiſed and will get well ſoon, I am glad for the poor child's ſake.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: You may take off the bandage then and bathe it in ſpirits and it will do. (Laura enters.) Why Laura, my good child, are you come? I was afraid I never ſhould ſee you well again.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Yes ma'am I am quite eaſy now—I hurt myſelf by drinking cold water—I dared not to tell while I was ill for fear of increaſing your concern—But I am very ſure that I have ſuffered enough to make me careful for the future.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: I hope you will be, for many perſons have died by ſuch imprudence.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: I have juſt received a letter from George. He is acquitted, and ſays he is reſolved to live a ſober, ſteady life.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: That is great joy to me if he reſolves he will do ſo—for never was a perſon more fixed in his purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: There is a perſon knocking; ſhall I go and wait?

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Yes. [Exit. Laura.]

div.stage: [Sophia and Letitia enter ſhowing Sophia's work.]

div.head: SCENE III.—SOPHIA, GOODHEART, LETITIA, and LAURA.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.p: What do you think of this ma'am?

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: You did not do this?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Yes, ſhe did ma'am.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: It is certainly very elegant.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p:
It was almoſt the firſt work of the kind that I ever
did; but I paid great attention. Here Laura enters with a bundle and letters.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: If I know by what means I could reward you for ſuch a piece of work; I would certainly do it, for it is indeed very fine.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: I will do as good a piece as ſhe has done when I get entirely well, and then you may reward us both, for here is a letter of my father, which ſays that he has got his cauſe with damages and coſts, and uncle Trueman, whoſe will was not to be opened till ſix months after his death, has left us two thouſand pounds. And here is a bundle too.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: (Opening,) So here's a letter too, and what a beautiful ſilk, well I believe he has met with good ſucceſs, a fine ſilk and a great deal of it too.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: There is enough to make you a gown.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: There is enough for a number of gowns, But— (reading a letter.) —But haſte, get tea, your father writes that he ſhall be at home on Thurſday at ſix o'clock, that will be in half an hour. (Looks in her glaſs.) Bring me a clean cap, Sophia.

sp.speaker: Keen.
sp.p: That is curious, I have not ſeen you look in your glaſs till now for three weeks.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: True my huſband was gone, and I felt very little ambition to ſhine, now he is coming home after ſo long abſence—I own—I ſhould be happy to be agreeable to him.

div.stage: (Sophia comes, and ſhe puts on her cap)

sp.speaker: Keen.
sp.p: O yes, and we muſt all worſh • p him to pleaſe you and we ſhall have ſweets and dears and fond queſtions till we be perfectly ſick.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Now ſiſter that is quite wrong. We ought to rejoice in mutual good-will, for the ſudden happy change in our proſpects—I ſhall give my ſincereſt thanks to heaven— for our proſpects, from the moſt dark, are al • ered to the moſt joyful, in one half hour—And thus it often is in the affairs of a family—and generally, there is an endleſs variety of events—and if we truſt divine providence all turns out happily. (Sally runs in and cries out.)

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: Pà is coming; Pà is coming.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: (Riſing ſuddenly.) I will wait on him myſelf; no one ſhall deprive me of that happineſs.

div.stage: [She flies out in extacy of joy.]

sp.speaker: Keen.
sp.p: Before I'd be ſo fond of a man, I'd live an old maid till I pin'd all away to breath and bones.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: That will no doubt be your fate▪ Aunt, and to bones without breath you muſt pine, madam. But girls I commend your mamma's attention; ſoft arts and kind allurements are the only ways for wom • n to carry their points—They never get any thing by angry co •• eſts.

lg.l: She who her huſband by peverſeneſs pains,
Finds dull neglect and coldneſs all her gains;
But ſhe who acts the patient, modeſt part;
Seems to obey; but reigns within his heart;
From all obſervers merits honeſt fame;
For every age •• veres the matron • name.

div.head: The Captive. A DRAMATIC PIECE, IN FIVE ACTS.
COMPASSION TO THE MISERABLE.
div.p: This may juſtly be ranked amongſt the brighteſt of human virtues. Nor is it any part of ſuperſtition to believe, that he who is kind to perſons really in diſtreſs will be paid in the kindneſs of Heaven. The liberal ſoul ſhall be made fat, and he that watereth ſhall be watered alſo himſelf. —And when our Savior deſcribes the kindneſs of the good Samaritan, he ſays to each of his auditors— go thou, and do likewiſe.

div.head: PERSONS.

list.head: WOMEN.
list.item: DAMARTIS—the woman who buys the captive.
TRYPHENA—the woman who ſells the captive.
LASYRA—the other captive living with Tryphena.

div.p: SCENE.—A citizen's houſe in Elis, a city of Peloponeſus, ſubject to the Spartans.

sp.speaker: Clim.
sp.p: MELANCHOLY, my dear friend, ſeems to have taken entire poſſeſſion of you.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: And why not—I loſt my huſband in the bloom of life, three of my ſons fell in battle—and in the laſt ſiege of this town I loſt my only daughter.

sp.speaker: Clim.
sp.p: Why, of all valuable things, did you not ſecure your daughter! An only daughter too?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: The town was taken in the night. The inhabitants fled every way—I miſſed my daughter in the crowd, and ſaw her no more.

sp.speaker: Clim.
sp.p: Do you think ſhe was killed?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I cannot think ſo—The learned and polite Athenians our conquerers, invited all to return to our homes the next morning. No carcaſes, no ſtain of blood, was ſeen in the ſtreets, no houſe was damaged, mine was juſt as I left it. But my little daughter I ſaw no more.

sp.speaker: Clim.
sp.p: I am very ſorry for your diſtreſs, and ſhould feel it more if I had experience.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Bitter indeed to a mother is the loſs of her children—I often run like a diſtracted creature, and ſearch for my little darling thro the whole houſe—rummage her caſkets and boxes. And finding no relief from my pain, throw myſelf down on the bed, where • he little jewel uſed to lie; and reſign myſelf to all the agonies of grief.

sp.speaker: Clim.
sp.p: Perhaps your daughter may yet be alive.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I fear that more than her death, that ſhe is alive, and a ſlave—Good heaven!

sp.speaker: Clim.
sp.p: You muſt miſs her in your houſehold affairs.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: That I do. One's own children are worth twice as much as ſtrangers. They feel for the intereſt of the family. And we are, naturally, inclined to be pleaſed with them.

sp.speaker: Clim.
sp.p: How can you perform your houſehold work?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: What happens to be done is done, the reſt is left undone—Hired ſervants have vexed me to death—I have none of them▪

sp.speaker: Clim.
sp.p: But you cannot hold out to do all your neceſſary work.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: My health by ſorrow and extreme labor is on the decline—I have tho't of purchaſing a captive for myſelf.

sp.speaker: Clim.
sp.p: Would you deal in that inhuman traffic.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Not to make any one miſerable but to make one happy—I would treat her as mine own child. Then I would pray to the Gods for mine own poor child in captivity.

sp.speaker: Clim.
sp.p: I know a lady who has two very likely captives— She needs but one, I will ſpeak to her on your behalf.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: MY deared Niece, If fortune ſent you to me, I am obliged to her.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: It was not fortune but pleaſure—The pleaſure of ſeeing and talking with you.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I thank you. Do you know any thing of a captive, which Tryphena has to ſell?

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: Yes. But you would not like the reaſon ſhe has for ſelling her.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: What is that?

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: Tryphena's ſon is in love with her.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I will not buy her, I will have none of their baſe amours at my houſe.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: He would be angry if you tho't him baſe. He courts her in form like any fine lady.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Then I think I would buy her, tho I ſhould aſk an abatement in the price.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: Would you run ſuch a riſk?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: She might prove to be good for nothing, and ſhe might be an excellent girl.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: I have heard many houſe keepers ſay that girls are good for nothing after they are courted.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: It is according as their natural temper may be— It alters them certainly—It makes good girls better, and bad girls worſe. But my car is ready, I will go and ſee the woman who has the captive to ſell.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I'M afraid, ſir, you mean to deceive me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: No my girl, no, not for my life, ſee here. Do not I always treat you with as much reſpect as any lady whatever?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: You do, and I wonder how you can.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: It is becauſe I know you to be a fine girl, you was certainly born of very good parents and your early education was virtuous and genteel—Can you remember nothing of your parents?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Yes, they lived very well—But they have changed my name ſo often, and ſold me backward and forward —that I hardly recollect where they lived.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: No matter, I will leave no means untried to diſcover them—Till then, I will do every thing for you and aſk no reward—only—Remember that lad that loves you. (Exit Philander.)

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: What a fine young gentleman—How kind he is to me, and treats me with as much reſpect as if I were a goddeſs. Now if I were not a captive how happy I could be.

sp.speaker: Philo.
sp.p: MELISSA what makes you cry?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Your mother means to ſell me, what have I done?

sp.speaker: Philo.
sp.p: It is not becauſe ſhe diſlikes you.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Does ſhe know of your brother's kindneſs to me?

sp.speaker: Philo.
sp.p: I believe ſhe underſtands that matter.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Then I am undone indeed. I do not wonder ſhe reſolves to ſell me.

sp.speaker: Philo.
sp.p: You are not to blame, you never ſought his addreſſes.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I never did, but I was born to be wretched. I was taken from my mother in the night, ſold for a ſlave, have had my name changed a number of times, have been ſold this way and that way. Here your brother, by his kindneſs, ſoftened the rigor of my captivity Now I am to be ſold, all my hope is loſt, my life ends in wretchedneſs.

sp.speaker: Philo.
sp.p: I do not believe my brother will ever forſake you.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Then I ſhall ruin him—I ſhall deſtroy the youth whoſe happineſs ſhould rather be bought with my life.

sp.speaker: Philo.
sp.p: Shall not I then tell him whither you are gone.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I ought to ſay no. I ought to ſay, Philander you muſt ſee me no more—But O Philomede you know nothing what pain this heart has felt. Yes Philomede tell him where I am to live—His wiſdom may ſave him, tho my folly would deſtroy him.—But I am called, and muſt go to your mother.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: (entering) YOU may ſtay where you are, Meliſſa; we may as well do it here as any where—this is the girl whom I propoſe to ſell, ſhe is a healthy ſtrong girl, I believe.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I am principally concerned to know whether ſhe be a good girl. For I mean to treat her as if ſhe were mine own daughter.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I thank you madam.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: What do you aſk for her?

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: She is worth at leaſt twenty five Attic talents.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I ſhall not give that for her, for a reaſon that has been told to me, (Meliſſa hides her face) and for which you want to get rid of her—I will give you twenty, and no more.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Were it not for the circumſtance you mention—you ſhould not have her for thirty, and ten more.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: But you muſt keep your ſon at home.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: I ſhall find means to do that.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p:
You may ſend her this very afternoon, with her
little property that muſt come with her, and the money ſhall be ready.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: (The ſcene changes to the houſe of Damartis, the captive enters in her working dreſs, and lays down a bundle of cloaths.)

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: (alone) WHAT a miſerable life is allotted to me— born to an eaſy life, but hurled by war from my peaceful habitation—I could almoſt wiſh eternal perdition' on tyrants and ambitious men. How many ſweet maidens, the hope of proſperous families, are ſold into ſlavery—how many widows mourn the loſs of their huſbands, cut off, in the very bloom of life. The blood of the fineſt youth fattens the fields of Arcadia. As for me, wretched I am, and wretched I muſt be. Since I became ſenſible of the loſs of liberty—every thing looks dark about me. Earth is a dungeon, and the ſky frowns on me from above—bo't and ſold like a beaſt— O wretched, bitter ſlavery—Is there no remedy but death—the generous Philander only makes me wiſh to live. But now I loſe him—O welcome, moſt welcome would be the ſleep of death, to a poor captive who has loſt her liberty—loſt her fortune, loſt her poor broken heart and is weary of the world▪— (Meliſſa ſits down and covers her face and weeps, and remains ſilent for ſome minutes then ſtarts up ſuddenly.) —Captivity itſelf has ſome good in it, it teaches invention—my new miſtreſs' niece comes to appoint me my employment. What if I tempt her to let Philander have acceſs to me with the offer of favoring her on like occaſions. (Lemone enters.)

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: (courtſying) MY ſweet lady I was waiting for your orders.

sp.speaker: Lem
sp.p: Well I can tell you what will pleaſe you, my aunt if you pleaſe her, means to treat you as her own daughter.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I have been told ſo a great many times, and had to work extremely hard after it.—

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: You will not be deceived here.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: There was a young gentleman who treated me as a brother at Tryphene's houſe—will he be permitted to ſee me here?

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: I have heard that he was more than a brother to you.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Perhaps you know what it is—if you can give him liberty to ſee me, perhaps I can requite the favor in kind.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: No, Meliſſa, I can do nothing in that matter.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: But if I ſhould let him come, would you expoſe me to the family?

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: Perhaps not—people of our age do not commonly think ſo bad of thoſe matters as older people do—but come with me, I muſt ſhow you your work in the family.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: MY good madam will grant me one very ſmall favor?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Not till I know what it is.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: That my friend Philander may come to this houſe.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: He ſhall not come, I know what he wants, to indulge himſelf with Meliſſa.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: No madam upon his honor he only wants to ſpeak with you—he will ſay nothing to any other perſon unleſs you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: He ſhall never have acceſs to Meliſſa, I can promiſe him.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: That ſhall be as you pleaſe. [Exit Artamon.]

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: MADAM, your moſt obedient ſervant.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Sir, I know what makes you ſo complaiſant, you wiſh to have acceſs to Meliſſa. (Coldly)

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: You mean to treat her as your own daughter. She is worthy your care.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Yes, ſir, that is my determination.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: And as you would have your daughter treated in captivity—Your ſentiment is excellent. It is uncommon and generous.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I think it is not bad.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: And I think it a mean thing for a young fellow to creep into a houſe unknown to the owners—I aſk liberty to viſit your daughter Meliſſa—I think of her as you do, I wiſh to treat her in the ſame ſtile.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: You are a ſly rogue—It is your maxim I believe to court the mother inſtead of the daughter—I won't break my word, you may come.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Madam I thank you. (Bowing reſpectfully he withdraws.)

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: That wretch! I was predetermined to refuſe him, but he was ſo bold, and ſo ſly, and ſo polite—and I being a woman, how could it be done—that I ſhould refuſe him.

sp.speaker: Clim.
sp.p: YOUR project appears to me quite a wild one.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: So does every thing that is generous to a perſon of a cold heart.

sp.speaker: Clim.
sp.p: Let us then hear the whole of your ſweet project.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Her clothes ſhall be made juſt as if ſhe were my own daughter, and ſhe ſhall have the ſame education.

sp.speaker: Clim.
sp.p: I fancy the little thing has moved the feelings of your compaſſion.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: She has, and I am not aſhamed of it.

sp.speaker: Clim.
sp.p: Our philoſophers would laugh at you for ſuch a ſentiment.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p:
I care for our Philoſophers in general as I do for a ſet of old broomſticks—They ſtudy four or ſix years in ſome academy or univerſity, and come forth with all their
paradoxes about ſenſation and ideal exiſtence—Liberty and neceſſity—But friendſhip, domeſtic care, and tenderneſs of heart, are to them inexplicable myſteries.

sp.speaker: Clim.
sp.p: They would think you mad, in your project concerning this girl.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Thoſe who expect good things of the Gods muſt do good things themſelves—By theſe very means the hearts of thoſe who have my daughter may be turned to pity her, and I may diſcover her yet before I die.

div.head: SCENE IV.—TRYPH • NA, CLIMENE, DAMAKTIS, and MELISSA.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: IF my ſon comes to your houſe you muſt ſend him back again immediately.

sp.speaker: Clim.
sp.p: Will you not let him ſee this lady's daughter?— She adopts her captive as her child. I am ſure every body will laugh at her.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: My ſon ſhall not aſſociate with her. He have her for his wife? I'll find other employment for him, I promiſe him.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I ſhall do what I think reaſonable and proper.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: (From behind one edge of the curtain.) That's right▪ my new miſtreſs is better than my old one.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: HAVE you dreſſed her up as my daughter?

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: I have, and ſhe looks ſweetly. She is a pretty girl, and as genteel as one of the firſt rank.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Introduce her then. (While Lemone is gone out Damartis talks to herſelf.) How the conſcience feaſts itſelf on good actions—Never did I take pleaſure in doing a kindneſs, as I do in relieving the miſeries of this girl—There is ſomething very intereſting in her appearance—How dreadful it is to think of Women, born of reſpectable parents, ſold f •• ſlaves.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p:
Here madam is your pennyworth.
(Introducing
Meliſſa.)
I think you have good judgment in buying girls —If I tho't you had as good a taſte for boys, I would get you to buy a ſweetheart for me.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: O you ſweet little nymph, I want to kiſs you this minute—But I won't be quite a fool—Come miſs, and ſit down by me. You ſeem to look quite ſmiling.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: It feels good to be well dreſſed. I have not had on a good ſuit of clothes theſe ſix years.

sp.speaker: Dam
sp.p: (To the girls.) There is company, girls, go and wait on them in.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Since I concluded to treat this girl as my daughter, fancy is buſy to find a reſemblance of her—She feels to me like my own fleſh and blood—What lively eyes, ſo much like my huſband! Her forehead and eyebrows too are like his! But alas! it is all a deluſion—Had my daughter been in all G • eece, by the pain, I have taken, I muſt have found her.

div.head: SCENE II.—LASYRA, DAMARTIS, LEMONE, and MELISSA.

sp.speaker: Laſyra.
sp.p: So miſs you have got to be a fine lady—you won't ſpeak to a body I ſuppoſe: I wiſh this lady would buy me too.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: My aunt does not wiſh for two girls.

sp.speaker: Laſyra.
sp.p: When you come from our houſe you left your key, and a little caſket. Madam do you not think this to be a very curious key? (ſhowing it to Damartis)

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: This key? (looking at it) is mine: where did you find it?

sp.speaker: Laſyra.
sp.p: It belongs to the little caſket ſhe always had— I bro't the little caſket too, which ſhe left at our houſe.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: The key is mine certainly, and I ſuſpect you to be my own child, O heav'ns!

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Well madam if I be your own child; will you not let Philander come and ſee me here.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: O yes, if you be my daughter you ſhall have a ſweetheart and every thing elſe, that is good—But we will be ſure of that firſt; run, and fetch the caſket. (Laſyra goes and brings the caſket in.)

sp.speaker: Laſyra.
sp.p: This is that ſhe always had with her.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p:
This caſket is mine certainly—But my daughter
had the ſcar of a burn on her left wriſt. Let me ſee. O how my heart beats with anxiety. (Looks at her wriſt). O my ſoul ſhe is my own child. (Here the curtains ſhould cloſe.)

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: (Claſping Meliſſa in her arms.) O my ſweet child, let me fold you in my arms, and be the happieſt mother in the whole nation of Sparta.

div.head: Ronſcevalles. A DRAMATIC DIALOGUE, IN THREE ACTS.
SELF GOVERNMENT.
div.p: To govern one's temper, inclination, and paſſions, comprehends almoſt the whole ſubſtance of virtue. It gives any perſon great ſecurity againſt the intrigues of the vicious, and the ſtratagems of the artful. This ſelf government chiefly depends on a comparative ſlighting of temporal concerns, when ſet in oppoſition to the ſolid recompence of virtue, and the rewards of another life.

div.head: PERSONS.

list.head: MEN.
list.item: SILVANO—an officer expreſs from the camp.

list.head: WOMEN.
list.item: DONNA CLARA—aunt and governeſs to the young Princeſs.
ISABELLA—rival of Maria, with regard to Alonzo.
FIVE LITTLE GIRLS—who enter in one ſcene only —The action the drama celebrates is ſuppoſed to have taken place on the day of the famous battle of Ronſcevalles.

div.p: SCENE—A pavilion, on a hill near the plain of Ronſcevalles.

sp.speaker: Xim.
sp.p: DONNA Clara, I eſteem it my duty, to warn you of a danger, which threatens the princeſs.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: What do you mean in particular? There are a thouſand dangers which threaten young ladies.

sp.speaker: Xim.
sp.p: I mean the attention of Alonzo to her. The preſumptuous boy is heir to the Caſtilian government, only in the third degree.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: I have obſerved their motions. There is ſcarcely any thing in this court which can eſcape me.

sp.speaker: Xim.
sp.p: I do not deny your vigilance; but would, as a faithful ſervant of the public, diſcharge my duty.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: I ſhall be always guarded, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: MY good princeſs, there is a certain point of diſcretion.

sp.speaker: Maria
sp.p: Bleſs me! My dear governeſs, have I failed in any point of diſcretion?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: No, you never have failed, my fear is only that you may fail.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Have I not always, my dear governeſs, liſtened to your advice▪?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: It is only—this. You, if any perſon, muſt one day be the firſt lady in Spain. Remember that. A word has been dropped about the General's ſon.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: And can that bear any reference to me?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: I hope not, and it is my duty to tell you, it muſt not—Becauſe you are one day to be the firſt lady in Spain. You muſt not conſult your own happineſs; but love and hate only as the court directs you—Alonzo is related to the government, only in the third degree—you underſtand me, I hope.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Then I muſt have no affection for him?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: That is it exactly. What a fine princeſs! How quick and ready you are. You will remember it.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: (Alone.) REMEMBER it! well indeed I may, from the pain it gives me—They call me princeſs, but— in my kindeſt affections, I muſt not conſult my own happineſs, but merely the intereſt of the ſtate. Is it ſo indeed? Then I had rather be a ſhepherdeſs. (Louiſa enters.)

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: My excellent princeſs, why ſo ſad to day? That mind is too delicate to bear the pangs of grief.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: I hope I am not more ſad than uſual.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Poſitively, my dear princeſs, you are. Would I be ſad to make another happy: what a fortunate boy is my Lord Alonzo.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Shame on you, Louiſa, to talk ſuch nonſenſe, what is my Lord Alonzo to me?

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Nothing as yet, only I ſuppoſe you wiſh he may be.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Louiſa, who has given you power to take ſuch liberties with me? I ſhall not be ſo harſh as to order you out from my preſence, but if you proceed, I ſhall abſent myſelf, and leave you to your own medications.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Nay but my dear princeſs be not angry. I aſk pardon, I only enquire why you cannot always be light, and eaſy like me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: How can I be light and cheerful? This day a battle is determined. In yonder plain it will be tried, in three hours, or leſs, whether the Chriſtians or Moors are to be maſters of Spain.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: And what of that? The men love to fight. Let them have enough of it. Whoever be the conquerers, it concerns not you and me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: Whoever be the conquerers they will pay attention to the ladies, I ſuppoſe—Pleaſure is my maxim; I live to be happy.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Can you not feel the loſs of your friends? Can you part with your religion, and become a ſlave to the ſlaves of Mahomet?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: Much the ſame—Whoever governs, the fate of woman is ſubordination—Yet ſtill, had I a lover in the battle, and he led the van, ah! Alonzo.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Leave me, Louiſa, leave me. You are ſo impertinent that I muſt deſire it.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: As I cannot love, myſelf, I delight to plague thoſe who do, I know. [Exit Louiſa]

sp.speaker: Maria
sp.p: alone. Why all theſe hints at Alonzo? Have I a tenderneſs for him? Let me examine my own heart. It never yet deceived me. I admire his virtues. So does every one beſide. Is the whole nation in love? I think his addreſs is elegant. So do all others. I rejoice in his ſucceſſes. They are uſeful to the public. His attentions pleaſe me. So they pleaſe my aunt, old, and grave as ſhe is. His abſence makes me uneaſy—Is this owing to tenderneſs? No—He is valuable to the nation: and it is a pity that ſo fine a youth ſhould be loſt. So, Maria, this heart is ſound yet, and I am glad of that. [Enter Iſabella.]

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: I AM come to you with a matter, which is very ſerious. It is ſpread thro the whole court.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What affair?

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: I am afraid your reputation is ruined forever. I could not have tho't ſuch a ſtory would have ſpread ſo much.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What ſtory?

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: I am aſhamed to mention it; but perhaps it is the only way to prevent its ſpreading.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Pray, what is it?

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: I am aſhamed to tell. But they ſay that you, regardleſs of the nation's honor, and intereſt, as well as your own; have married Alonzo privately; contrary to the admonitions of your friends, and every principle of right.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: A likely ſtory, I wonder who made it. Have they not ſomething to ſay about Alonzo too?

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: It is ſaid▪ and every body believes it, that he is a moſt debauched fellow and aſſociates with the vileſt women in the Court and Town.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And nothing more? That is not half ſcandalous enough Were I at the coſt of a lie, I would tell a big one.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: They ſay he is the meaneſt of all cowards: that in the laſt battle, he ran away from the head of his diviſion, and hid himſelf under a baggage cart.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: That is ſcandalous enough I find the matter to be very ſerious —Who do you think invented theſe lies?

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: That muſt be a ſecret▪ at preſent: But I am ſure it concerns you very much, to put a ſtop to them.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What, in the warmth of your friendſhip, do you adviſe me to do?

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Forbid Alonzo your preſence entirely. That is the only way to ſtop every one's mouth.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Then he will be wholly at leiſure to give his attentions to you. I thank you madam for your good advice.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: You will do as you pleaſe. If you will not take my advice you muſt abide the conſequence. [Exit Iſabella]

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: YOU did right to affront Iſabella. She is the moſt impertinent girl that ever exiſted.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: She has no cauſe to be offended.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: She means to injure you.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: And I had almoſt ſaid, who does not?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: You may depend on my ſecrecy.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: I have no myſteries to truſt to you, or any one elſe.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Only with regard to my lord Alonzo. That is all, my dear princeſs.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Not with regard to him. The public is pleaſed with him, ſo are you, and Iſabella, and twenty others, and I among the reſt.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: So you are afraid to truſt me—If ſo I ſhall attend to other matters.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p:
(alone) So here are the pleaſures of being a princeſs. I muſt love and hate only for the public good, and give up all idea of my own happineſs—I am envied
by one, rivalled by another—maligned, and teazed by them all—yet never did harm intentionally in my life—how dearly do they, who govern nations, pay for their pre-eminence. [Exit Maria.]

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: I HAVE done all you deſired me?

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: And with what ſucceſs?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: She owned every thing ſo frankly, that I could diſcover nothing.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Do you ſuppoſe there is any concern of importance between her, and young Alonzo.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: I know not: ſhe profeſſed the ſame regard for him that others had, and behaved with the utmoſt compoſure.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: She is a ſtrange girl.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: And you might ſay, ſhe is a good girl, ſhe is a perſon of as delicate a mind, and as perfect ſelf command, at I ever ſaw.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: I ſhould like her virtues better if they did not oppoſe my happineſs. And if I can diſcover any intrigue of hers; I will improve it to my own advantage.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: In what manner?

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: I will inform the court—Alonzo is only heir in the third degree to the government. Should I only know that ſhe was attached to him, I could have her ſhut up in a convent.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Then perhaps Alonzo would be baniſhed, and what would you gain by your intrigue?

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: I may have the ſatiſfaction to find that he is not attached to another, and that he cannot be.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: I ſhould eſteem that a very cold comfort.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Cold as it is, it is the beſt that I now have—but I will try this matter further. [Enter Lorenzo.]

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: AH! Lorenzo—what news have you?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: The battle is determined, and the troops in great ſpirits—young Alonzo has a great honor conferred on him this day.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: What is that?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: He is to lead the van, as he requeſted.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: That is a poſt of honor: but is it not a poſt of great danger?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: It certainly is, and few envy him his ſtation.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Be ſure to tell Martinez of that; ſhe will tell Maria.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Martinez, you have heard of young Alonzo.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: What of him?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: He will make Maria's heart ache to day, for he commands the firſt attack, and in all probability he muſt be killed.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: The princeſs ſhall know of that, and then we will ſee how madam will keep her compoſure.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: What is the reaſon that all you ladies ſeem to be envious of the princeſs Maria? Is there no man about the court worthy their notice but Alonzo? (Exit Lorenzo.)

div.head: SCENE IV.—MARTINEZ and MARIA.
div.stage: (Maria walks penſive acroſs the ſtage—turns, and Martinez purſues her.)

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: MOST reſpectable princeſs.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why, Martinez, do you purſue me every where? Can you not ſuffer your reſpectable princeſs to enjoy herſelf one moment.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: If my preſence be in the leaſt troubleſome I withdraw. [Withdraws ſuddenly.]

sp.speaker: Maria
sp.p:
alone. What is this. Chilly horrors run thro my nerves, and veins; and I am cold as if dipt in the Stygian lake. What is the cauſe? Only that I have heared that Alonzo commands the van in this day's battle. His life
will be the forfeit of his bravery—I have watched my heart that it might not oppoſe duty—The leaſt ſpot of indiſcretion has never tainted my imagination—Why then ſhould I dread the fate of Alonzo—Alas Maria, thou haſt thy affections too—But they are pure, and pure they ſhall be.

div.head: SCENE V.—ISABELLA and MARIA.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: (Aſſuming coolneſs and compoſure.) MY princeſs, the battle is determined and Alonzo begins the attack.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: That I believe, for you look as pale as a ghoſt.— Are you afraid he will be killed?

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: He is very brave.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: He is! O, I tho't the laſt time I ſaw you that he was a great coward—But he is truly brave, and he conquers, or falls this day.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Do you think he will be killed?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I expect nothing elſe, I depend on it.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: (Falters and walks trembling away—then ſpeaks faintly.) Martinez, bring me a cordial, and ſome water.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: (Obſerving her.) So in attempting to catch me you have caught yourſelf. But why does the girl delay to relieve her—I will go myſelf. [Exit Maria.]

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: (Faintly behind the curtain.) Martinez bring me ſome water.

div.stage: (Louiſa coming to her aſſiſtance, brings her back to the ſtage and ſeats her, and offer her a cordial and ſome water.)

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: Take this, and it will revive your ſpirits.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Has any one come from the field of battle?—Have you heard any thing of Alonzo?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: Not a word. But ſuppoſe he is killed—There are a thouſand other coxcombs in the world.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: You never loſt a friend I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: I never had one to loſe—All that I care for is to live eaſy. I never loved any perſon in m • life.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: That is the reaſon why no one ever l • ved you

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p:
Probably enough; bu • why ſhould I entangle ••
with the cares of half the world. Come cheer up. One party no doubt will win the day—And they will take notice of the ladies.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: There needs ſomething more than nonſenſe to comfort an afflicted heart.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Come Louiſa, lead her to my apartment, and let her take ſome reſt.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Reſt I fear is no more for me.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: I heard this moment, but I did not tell Iſabella, that the Spaniards have gained the victory, and that Alonzo is killed.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: It is juſt what I expected.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Then you never had any partiality for him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: How do you know that?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Becauſe the hearing of his death does not diſturb you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You ſharp folks know nothing—You may tell whom you pleaſe that I had. And now he is dead I will ſhow all the reſpect to his memory I can. You can ſearch bad hearts; but you know nothing of good ones. Go and call my little girls. (Five little girls enter and pay their honors to Maria▪) My little girls, your Lord Alonzo is dead.

sp.speaker: A Girl.
sp.p: What not my Lord Alonzo!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Yes, he was killed in battle this day, while he defended us all, and beat the Moors. (The little girls put their handkerchiefs to their faces.) Don't cry my children; it will do no good. Go, and get your little baſkets, and gather red baum, meadow-pinks, marjoram and other ſweet flowers— So when they bring up the corpſe and lay it out in ſtate you ſhall go with me, and we will dreſs the bed with flowers. (The little girls go out curtſying to Maria)

sp.speaker: A Girl.
sp.p: We will do it for we always loved my Lord Alonzo. (Speaking as they go out)

lg.l: Now could I weep. This day proud Spain has loſt,
But why ſhould ſorrow fill theſe melting eyes,
For one whoſe merit lives beyond the ſkies.
The hard commands of power, the ſource of woe,
Barred all our hopes and proſpects here below.
By generous death, Alonzo now is free,
And the ſame fate the heavens deſign for me.
No joys for me, can wretched Earth ſupply;
And my heart dies in me, I feel it die.—
I'll meet Alonzo in the realms above;
Where angel-minds are not aſhamed to love.—
There ſhall the generous paſſion be ſupplied,
And heaven ſhall give what envious earth denyed.
Meantime with him it ſoon ſhall be my doom,
To fill the cold receſſes of the tomb.
Nigh his cold corpſe ſhall my cold aſhes lie;
Till the laſt trump ſhall call us to the ſky.—
Nor yet ſhall envy blaſt my ſpotleſs fame,
Since in the grave, there's neither ſin, nor ſhame.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: NOW Alonzo is gone, Maria and you will contend no more about him.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: But how does ſhe bear it?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: She ſays ſhe is not uneaſy that he is dead — ſhe never could have enjoyed his ſociety in this world, ſhe means to enjoy it in heaven.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: A ſaucy toaſt; I could tear her eyes out—I have a great mind to die firſt.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: You will not have the courage.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: True, I never could bear to think of any thing but the pleaſures of this world.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Theſe ſublime characters have the advantage of us—they expect to be happy in whatever manner they exiſt. I have tho't ſo much of it that: I am almoſt determined to quit diſſipation, and be a ſober conſiderate girl.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: So have I, but ſome amuſement has always put it out of my head.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: LADIES you know the loſs of Spain this day.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Would you command us in any thing?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: You muſt aſſiſt the miſtreſs of the wardrobe in procuring the neceſſary dreſſes, for the court muſt all go into mourning. (Iſabella and Martinez go out.)

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: WHAT have you been doing with the little girls, Maria?

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: I ſent them into the park to gather flowers to dreſs the bed of the deceaſed young general.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: It is ſuitable to his merit; no one will blame you now he is dead.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Blame me or not, I ſhall do it. Perſons in public ſtation cannot honor their friends while living— Muſt they be reſtrained from it when they are dead?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: They will not be. But you have a new duty— To forget Alonzo in leſs than a month.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: In leſs than a month!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: It would be a diſgrace to a princeſs to mourn longer.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: I knew we were reſtrained in our joy, but I thought we might mourn as long as we pleaſed.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: No you muſt neither love nor hate, laugh not cry, ſleep nor wake, eat nor drink, but for the public good, and by leave of the nation.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What reward have we for this?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: The trouble it coſts them who govern except now and then to be ſhot at or pelted—as they ride the ſtreets—aſſaulted by a mob — libelled in public bills, or burnt, or hung in effigy.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Are theſe the bleſſed effects of ſupremacy?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: The preciſe fate of all the great characters I have heard or read of: tho ſome have obtained reputation after death.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Then I reſign the ſucceſſion.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Aſking your pardon—that will throw the nation into a quarrel—it muſt not be done.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I will die then.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: You muſt not die unleſs the State pleaſes.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: I wonder you can be witty upon ſo dreadful a ſubject.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: I am as ſerious as the ſubject itſelf. Twenty phyſicians may be employed to keep you alive to a certain period—then you may die by the public executioner.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: I ſhall deceive their hopes, I am now threatened with a decline.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: But the Duke of Lemos means to demand you in marriage in a few days.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: The man whom of all beings I moſt deteſt—I truſt I ſhall do as I pleaſe in that matter.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Nay you muſt marry him if the court pleaſes; and love him too, or all the nation will hate you.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Now I ſhall die certainly—The loſs of Alonzo, and the marriage of the Duke of Lemos will ſoon bring me to an end.

div.head: SCENE III.—LOUISA, who enters here; CLARA and MARIA.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: There is the ſtrangeſt ſtory told here that ever was heard—Alonzo is not dead. He was wounded, but has recovered his ſenſes and they are bringing him back in triumph.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: They are indeed! I will know the truth of this affair—Maria what will you ſay now?

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: I am petrified with aſtoniſhment.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: It is true, an officer reports it who comes expreſs to the court.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Alonzo had rather have died, than ſee me married to the Duke of Lemos.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: Now you ſee that you had better have done as I; lived in diſſipation, and loved no one but yourſelf,

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: No, I had rather ſuffer every moment of my life, than be of ſuch a temper. But let us go and enquire.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: TELL Silvano, how is this affair of the young General's coming to life again?

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p:
The fact is—He engaged Abdallah king of the Moors, and was by him ſtruck down by a blow on the head, and was left on the field—But after the battle, when
the friends came to view the ſlain, it was tho't he diſcovered ſigns of life. A ſurgeon opened a vein; he bled freely, and in a few moments recovered his ſenſes. And they are bringing him back in triumph.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: How came the Spaniards to gain the victory, after the young General was dead?

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: His father, knowing his ſon was ſtruck down, and ſuppoſing him dead, enraged to the utmoſt degree, encountered Abdallah, king of the Moors, killed him; and took Alonzo, his ſecond in command, priſoner This is all I can tell you, madam, I muſt inform the reſt of the court.

div.head: SCENE V.—CLARA, ISABELLA, LOUISA, MARIA, and MARTINEZ.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: WHAT Louiſa ſaid is the truth. They are bringing him back in triumph.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Then I muſt be hurried back to miſery again.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: No; the heads of the nation aſſembled, immediately after the victory, and the recovery of Alonzo; firſt agreed to a thanksgiving. Then finding that the prince of Aſturias and Duke of Lemos had been both killed in the battle; and that Alonzo is heir to the government, it is propoſed that he be married to the princeſs Maria the evening after the feaſt.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Well madam I hope you will be contented with life now. I ſee you are gratified in every thing.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: I ſhould wiſh that I had ſome affection beſides the love of myſelf, if I could be ſo fortunate.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: To receive my honors by the loſs of the great heroes of Spain is no great conſolation to me.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: But it is as much your duty to be happy for the nation's ſake, as to be miſerable—Come, my dear girl, it is now your duty to be happy.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I ſhall yield to the call of duty. Yet truly I am diſappointed to be a queen on earth: I had much rather be a ſaint in Heaven.

lg.l: The blaze of grandeur laſts but for an hour
And danger treads upon the heels of power.
The higheſt fall the deepeſt in deſpair.
Yet ſince 'tis duty's call I bear the ſway,
Content to live in ſorrow for a day.
The greateſt good ſhall be my greateſt aim.
I'll build on juſtice all my hopes of fame.
Then if grim death my wordly bliſs annoy,
I'll gain that heaven I muſt not yet enjoy.

div.head: Panthea. A DRAMATIC DIALOGUE, IN A SUIT OF SCENES.
THE EXCELLENCE OF MODESTY AND OF VIRTUOUS LOVE.
div.p: The antients wrote that there were two loves. One the ſon of Jupiter, by the Goddeſs of Beauty. This was the cauſe of modeſt amours, of love which terminated happily. He was perfectly harmleſs; his darts were headed with gold, and dipt in balm and honey. The other, the ſon of Erebus, by the Queen of Night. His darts were headed with lead, and dipt in gall and poiſon. The moral of theſe allegories is very uſeful to young perſons of both ſexes.

div.head: PERSONS.
div.p: SCENE—The camp of Cyrus on the borders of Babylonia—immediately after the firſt battle with the Babylonians.

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: I WILL immediately give orders to the Prieſts to inſtute to Eternal O • omaſd • s, the ſource of light, of being and happineſs, a ſolemn Thankſgiving for the victory of this day. (To Mithras who is entering.) Long live my brave counſellor.

sp.speaker: Mith.
sp.p: Moſt excellent Cyrus, live forever. This victory will give ſplendor to the Perſian Commonwealth, and immortalize your name.

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: I regret this deſtructive war. But the Babylonians will be content with nothing but making mankind the ſlave of their luxury and avarice.

sp.speaker: Mith.
sp.p: The ſword of Cyrus will bring them to reaſon.

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: Do not flatter me, Mithras—Rather freely tell me of my faults, and point out thoſe vices of which I am in danger.

sp.speaker: Mith.
sp.p: It would be a hard taſk to find out your faults.

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: I do not wiſh to think myſelf ſure of ſucceſs. Many cauſes may ruin a young man of twenty three at the head of a great army. I tremble when my friends call me great. What is your opinion, Mithras, of a great man?

sp.speaker: Mith.
sp.p: It is not ſurely he, who eats and drinks and ſleeps more than others—or who lives in idleneſs on other men's labors.

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: No, ſuch men are rather objects of contempt.

sp.speaker: Mith.
sp.p: Nor he, who is learned without uſefulneſs, rich without profit, liberal without judg • ment, courageous without caution, or witty without prudence.

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: No, reaſon muſt govern. The manner and uſe of every thing muſt be conſidered.

sp.speaker: Mith.
sp.p: On theſe principles might not one deſcribe a great man.

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: He muſt be a great man who is ever doing the beſt things in the beſt manner.

sp.speaker: Mith.
sp.p: There is one point more to be conſidered.

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: I cannot conceive of it.

sp.speaker: Mith.
sp.p: Not conceive of it!

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: No, you muſt tell me.

sp.speaker: Mith.
sp.p: Muſt he not do all from a ſenſe of duty, from a free choice, and diſpoſition to do good?

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: My good old friend, you are perfectly right. The will to do good makes a man reſemble the great God— There is an advantage in age, it brings experience.

sp.speaker: Mith.
sp.p: You will grow old too ſoon.

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: My worthy friend you ſhall not go yet.

sp.speaker: Mith.
sp.p: Some private affairs call me.

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: Private affairs muſt ſubmit to the public—You ſhall not go, till you have told me, how I may eſcape the odium which commonly falls on princes and rulers of ſtates—You may tell me briefly, but tell me.

sp.speaker: Mith.
sp.p: The firſt point it to avoid indolence and luxury —Chuſe to labor for others rather than that they ſhould labor for you. And excell all others in thoſe things in which they moſt excell.

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: I never could bear to be outdone in any thing. I can live without ſleep. I watched three whole days and nights with my grandfather, when he was ſick in Media. I can endure the want of food—I have hunted often from break of day till evening and ate nothing but a piece of dry bread, and a bunch of creſſes pulled out of a brook.

sp.speaker: Mith.
sp.p: Theſe are true ſigns of future greatneſs. But chaſtity in love affairs is very neceſſary—If you would be happy you muſt • ave but one wife.

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: Why ſo? Moſt of our eaſtern princes have from a hundred to a thouſand.

sp.speaker: Mith.
sp.p: Yes and that is their ruin—nature makes for one man only one woman. The ſexes are almoſt preciſely equal in numbers.

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: But might not one man engroſs more to his own advantage?

sp.speaker: Mith.
sp.p: A poor man can maintain but one; and it is ſtill more neceſſary that a rich man ſhould have but one.

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: Why ſo?

sp.speaker: Mith.
sp.p: If he have more it will be the intereſt of each to plunder her huſband the moſt.

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: Princes regard themſelves more than their families.

sp.speaker: Mith.
sp.p: It is not good for themſelves. Love is moſt happy, when directed to a ſingle object—as a river flowing compact is noble, and diſpenſes a thouſand bleſſings; divided, it ſinks in mean rivulets, and dirty puddles—divided love has ruined moſt of the princes of the eaſt.

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: I thank you, kind Mithras, attend now your private affairs—but I ſhall often ſend for you, and you muſt not be ſparing of your advice. [Exit Mithras.]

sp.speaker: Araſp.
sp.p: NOBLE Cyrus, live forever—I can tell you ſomething which will pleaſe you.

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: Speak then Araſpas if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Araſp.
sp.p: I have taken a moſt beautiful woman. I found her among the ſlain, on the field of battle, ſitting on the ground, in obſtinate ſilence, and her eyes ſtreaming with tears. I with another officer raiſed her by the arms, and bore her to my tent.

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: Alas! how war tears aſunder the deareſt bands, and breaks thoſe ties which are twiſted with the fibres of the heart. It is ſome woman, probably, who loſt her huſband in the battle. The ſtory does not pleaſe me, but gives me pain.

sp.speaker: Araſp.
sp.p: It was her beauty which I expected would pleaſe you. Her complexion is fine; her features ſoft and regular—Her eyes are lively blue—Her brown hair waves over her neck, which is white as ſnow. She has a delicate ſhape and eaſy manners; and the fineſt expreſſion in her countenance—Her motions are like thoſe of a goddeſs, and the graces attend all her ſteps.

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: Do you think ſhe is handſomer than my wife?

sp.speaker: Araſ.
sp.p: She is very handſome, and I expected would be an agreeable preſent to you.

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: I thank you, I wiſh but for one woman. But are you not afraid to have her near you, if ſhe be ſo beautiful?

sp.speaker: Araſ.
sp.p: Not I—You ſee I am growing old.

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: Keep her then; you are the moſt proper perſon— I do not wiſh to ſee her.

sp.speaker: Araſ.
sp.p: Your temperance, illuſtrious prince, is aſtoniſhing—May your ſucceſs be equal to your virtues.

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: Have you, Sacas, ſeen the lady taken by Araſpas, in this days's battle?

sp.speaker: Sacas.
sp.p: I have; every body went to ſee her.

sp.speaker: Cyrus.
sp.p: Is ſhe handſome?

sp.speaker: Sacas.
sp.p: Yes indeed—That ſhe is.

sp.speaker: Cyrus.
sp.p: Is ſhe as handſome as your miſtreſs? I mean Mandanè my wife.

sp.speaker: Sacas.
sp.p: Why—ay—as to that—if ſhe is not, ſhe is the next handſomeſt woman in the world.

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: Did you talk with her?

sp.speaker: Sacas.
sp.p: Yes, ſhe ſpeaks very good Perſian—She is the wife of Abradatas, Prince of Shuſhan, a brave officer: her name is Panthea. She wiſhes to ſend to their army to enquire for her huſband. She ſays ſhe is afraid, living only with the men—enemies too—and that Araſpas does not always behave becoming.

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: I will call Araſpas to an account, and protect her; but do not bring her here; I do not wiſh to ſee her.

sp.speaker: Sacas.
sp.p: What ſhall I do then?

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: Pitch a tent for her behind the armoury. Let two of our beſt maids wait on her. Then enquire for her huſband—if he be killed, is a priſoner, or with the Babylonians.

sp.speaker: Sacas.
sp.p: I ſhall gladly do it, for I want to ſee her again.

div.head: SCENE IV.—MITHRAS, CYRUS, SACAS, and KADMIEL.

sp.speaker: Mith.
sp.p: Illuſtrious general—I have brought you a curious old man, a captive, who complains of your ſoldiers—His name, he tells me, is Kadmiel.

sp.speaker: Cyr
sp.p: Kadmiel, I wiſh you health and happineſs. (Kadmiel keeps his diſtance.) Kadmiel, fear not to approach me— The • n •• med ſoldier is my brother. (Gives Kadmiel his hand.) You were taken in this day • s battle.

sp.speaker: Kad.
sp.p: I was.

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: Have my ſoldiers uſed you ill?

sp.speaker: Kad.
sp.p: They have neither killed nor wounded me.

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: Did they offer you any indecency?

sp.speaker: Kad
sp.p: They refuſed me water to waſh; they ſaid it was ſcarce in the camp. They offered me vinegar—But that's not the law.

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: Did they injure you otherwiſe?

sp.speaker: Kad.
sp.p: I told them I was hungry—They bro't me the legs of fowls diſhed with parſly ſauce—My blood ran cold at the ſight!

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: And were you hungry too—ſtrange!

sp.speaker: Kad.
sp.p: That was not the worſt—They offered me half of a roaſt pig, diſhed with gravy and ſweet herbs. What an abomination!

sp.speaker: Sacas.
sp.p: Excuſe me Cyrus, this is certainly a mad man.

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: Peace, Sacas, peace. I'll aſk your advice when I want it—Mithras, what ſhall I do with this man?

sp.speaker: Mith.
sp.p: Let me examine him a little. Kadmiel, what injury was there in offering you the legs of a fowl diſhed in butter; or a piece of a roaſted pig?

sp.speaker: Kad.
sp.p: I have kept the law from my youth. I have never eaten of the ſinew that ſhrank, of ſwine's fleſh or creeping things, the abomination, or the mouſe, or drank the breath of abomination.

sp.speaker: Sacas.
sp.p: (Laughing) If this be not a crazy fellow there never was one.

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: Peace, Sacas, peace, or you ſhall feel my diſpleaſure. (Directing his ſpeech to Kadmiel.) Of what nation are you Kadmiel?

sp.speaker: Kad.
sp.p: I am a Hebrew.

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: The ſame whom we call Jews?

sp.speaker: Kad.
sp.p: Yes, the Lord's people.

sp.speaker: Mith.
sp.p: As they ſay. Have they not a moſt ſingular law, which forbids the eating of ſwine's fleſh, commands you to waſh often, and ſo on.

sp.speaker: Kad.
sp.p: That is all true.

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: Addreſſing himſelf to Kadmiel. Be comforted my old friend. Your religion makes you ſingular. I love a man who is firm to his principles of religion—You are no longer a captive—You are my friend.

sp.speaker: Kad.
sp.p: May I be ſure of your protection?

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p:
You ſhall have water to waſh—You ſhall go to the
ordinary and prepare your food in your own way.

div.stage: (Mithras, Kadmiel and Sacas go out—Mandane enters.)

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: WHAT my dear wife brought you here ſo ſuddenly?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Have you ſeen the beautiful captive?

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: I have not, nor do I mean to ſee her.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: But you can do as you pleaſe in that matter.

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: I truſt I ſhall always do as I ought with regard to my wife—My vows are ſacred.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: It was reported that you had received her with great attention.

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: Be aſſured I will receive no woman but yourſelf— The wife of my choice is the ſole object of my love.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Thanks to my excellent huſband—The great are apt to neglect ſuch obligations. But why I know not, unleſs there is more dignity in vice, than in virtue.

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: Permit the moſt unfortunate of men to lay himſelf at your feet.

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: Relate your misfortunes.

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: I fled to the army to ſave my wife, the moſt beautiful of women, from the impious views of Belſhazzar the Babyloniſh King—In the late battle ſhe followed me, thro affection, to the field. Since which time I cannot find her.

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: What would you do here?

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: I will unite my forces with yours. My eſtate ſhall be my pledge. At the end of war if I be faithful, they ſhall be mine. If I be unfaithful they ſhall be yours.

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: Well then if I receive you as an ally, I muſt provide for your comfort—There is a widow who lives behind the Armory, who loſt her huſband in the battle. Your mutual ſorrows may conſole each other. For, regard my words, they are true, there you will find the beautiful Panthea.

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: (In rapturous ſurprize.) Panthea! O heavens, Panthea! I fly to my ſweeteſt life, O Panthea! (flies out.)

sp.speaker: Sacas.
sp.p: That fellow left your noble preſence with very little ceremony

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: I can forgive him, I have a young and handſome wife as well as he.

sp.speaker: Sacas.
sp.p: THERE is a centinel at the door, with a priſoner. Shall I bring him in?

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: Immediately.

sp.speaker: Gad.
sp.p: The fame of your clemency, illuſtrious Cyrus, has reached our ears.

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: May fame never ſay any thing of me but what is true.

sp.speaker: Gad.
sp.p: I come not illuſtrious Cyrus to aggravate the picture of my injuries—I am governor of the fertile province of Gaditana—The impious Belſhazzar has ſtolen from me, my moſt delightful wife, within a year of our marriage— He took her by force of arms, and armed men. I followed the raviſhers to Babylon, and petitioned the king to reſtore her. But he ordered his ſervants to take, and abuſe me, in the moſt infamous manner, and then diſmiſs me—I live, Cyrus, for revenge, for juſtice. And my ſword is impatient to employ itſelf againſt the king of Babylon.

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: What kind of man muſt this Belſhazzar be?

sp.speaker: Gad.
sp.p: The moſt voluptuous of men. Wine and women employ him forever, the women have him as the gates of hell—He is drunk every evening, and his guards are drunk quite to the city gates.

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: Stay, you ſhall ſerve me—This Belſhazzar is raiſing recruits for me laſt out of his own dominions.

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: ILLUSTRIOUS Cyrus—The enemy are in motion —It is now a good time to bring off the Su • i • n Charioteers.

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: You ſhall take the command of the chariots yourſelf—I retire to give other orders. [Cyrus goes out.]

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: My noble huſband—What, i • armor already?

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: I am impatient to perform ſome noble ſ ••• ice for our deliverer.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: But you may fall in battle.

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: True, yet that is no argument againſt my duty.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Certainly you are right. Go, and be virtuous— regard not the tears of Panthea.

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: If anything could make me value life above glory; it muſt be the poſſeſſion of ſo amiable a woman.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I ſhall not detain you from the field of fame—Go, and if you die, I will die with you.

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: I go without reluctance—Let the incenſe of your prayers aſcend to the Gods and I am ſure of victory.

sp.speaker: Sacas.
sp.p: WHAT did Cyrus intend by ſending for Araſpas?

sp.speaker: Arz.
sp.p: To puniſh him I ſuppoſe, for being rude to my miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Sacas.
sp.p: How queer that is, that my maſter ſhould think of puniſhing him for that?

sp.speaker: Arz.
sp.p: Why not puniſh him for that?

sp.speaker: Sacas.
sp.p: Becauſe if a woman defends herſelf, no harm is done—if ſhe does otherwiſe, two cheats make an even bargain.

sp.speaker: Arz.
sp.p: Do you mean to abide by that principle?

sp.speaker: Sacas.
sp.p: Yes, that I do.

sp.speaker: Arz.
sp.p: Very well, abide by it—But I hear that Araſpas has ſent for your pretty ſiſter, as you call her, to come and live with him.

sp.speaker: Sacas.
sp.p: A dog—I'll horſewhip him, he's a vicious old rogue as ever lived.

sp.speaker: Arz.
sp.p: What makes you angry?

sp.speaker: Sac.
sp.p: A ſiſter is one's own fleſh and blood. If ſhe gets diſgraced, the infamy comes to me.

sp.speaker: Arz.
sp.p: Suppoſe he ſhould attempt any thing againſt her intereſts?

sp.speaker: Sacas.
sp.p: I'll ſtab him.

sp.speaker: Arz
sp.p: Suppoſe he ſhould utterly ruin the happineſs of her life?

sp.speaker: Sacas.
sp.p: I'd kill him—I could not bear it.

sp.speaker: Arz
sp.p: O, I thought that two cheats made an even bargain. Upon your own ſentiments you ought to be horſewhipt, ſtabbed and killed. Well, I ſuppoſe it is no more than you deſerve. [Exit Arzina.]

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: Go, Sacas—Araſpas is in waiting—tell him to come to me now.

sp.speaker: Sac.
sp.p: I obey your orders, ſire. (Araſpas is brought in.)

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: Well, Araſpas, how does your philoſophy bear it; you was not afraid to be with Panthea, tho ſhe was ſo beautiful?

sp.speaker: Araſ.
sp.p: O Cyrus, illuſtrious general, I have been faulty— but did you know my caſe you would pity me. I plainly perceive that I have two ſouls—one good, one bad. When the good ſoul prevails, then I treat this woman well; when the bad ſoul prevails • hen I uſe her very ill. Did you know my caſe you would pity me.

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: Other men, I believe have as many ſouls as you. But you muſt follow t • dictates of the better ſoul. All honeſt people do; and becauſe the bad ſoul is apt to be moſt miſchievous when people have leaſt to do, I order you to go on duty every day for ſix months together.

sp.speaker: Araſ.
sp.p: I ſhould ſuppoſe that ſix months hard employ, would make any k • nd of ſoul peaceable. (ſorrowfully.)

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: Go then and make the experience. [He goes out.]

sp.speaker: Mith.
sp.p: I find my old friend Kadmiel a curious man. He pretends he has a book which • old of you, one hundred and ſeventy years before you was born.

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: Where did you find that, Kadmiel?

sp.speaker: Kad.
sp.p: In the writings of Iſaiah.

sp.speaker: Mith
sp.p: Iſaiah, who is Iſaiah?

sp.speaker: Kad.
sp.p: The greateſt of our prophets next to Moſes, a man of fortune and family—But the beſt of him was that he was a good man, and a prophet.

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: How could he know any thing of me?

sp.speaker: Kad.
sp.p: Aye that's the point—But he writes thus. (Shows an old manuſcript.) "Thus ſaith the Lord to Cyrus, to his anointed, to Cyrus—Whoſe right hand I have holden to ſubdue nations before him, and I will give him the hidden treaſures."

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: M • ght not this be ſaid of another Cyrus?

sp.speaker: Kad.
sp.p:
What other has there been. Beſides, do not you
worſhip towards the ſun, conſider light as the divin • preſence and darkneſs as the influence of the devil?

sp.speaker: Mith.
sp.p: Yes, theſe are parts of the Perſian religion.

sp.speaker: Kad
sp.p: To theſe our prophet a ••• des—That they may reſpect me more than the riſing of the ſun; becauſe there is none beſide me—"I form the light and create darkneſs— I make peace and create evil. I the Lord do all theſe things."

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: What ſays your prophet of me in particular?

sp.speaker: Kad.
