sp.p: In the name of the Lord he ſays. Cyrus is my ſhepherd, he ſhall perform all my pleaſure; ſaying to Jeruſalem—Thou ſhalt be built, and to the temple, Thy foundation ſhall be laid. Jeruſalem was our Capital, deſtroyed by the Babylonians, the temple, our chief place of worſhip.

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: Well, Kadmiel, this is a fair trial of propheſy, to ſee if it will come to paſs. If I take Babylon, and get the hidden treaſures, then I will build your temple again, and reſtore your city and nation.

sp.speaker: Kad.
sp.p: The Lord of the Hebrews bleſs and proſper you.

div.head: SCENE XII.—GADATAS (enters with looks of deep ſorrow) and CYRUS.

sp.speaker: Gad.
sp.p: NEVER did my eyes before ſee ſo wretched a ſight —The fair Panthea followed her huſband, at a ſmall diſtance to the field of battle.

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: Surprizing how love will overcome fear.

sp.speaker: Gad.
sp.p: Her huſband by a preconcerted ſign brought off the S • ſian charioteers. The Babylonians irritated at this, poured all their archers upon him—an arrow pierced his breaſt—Panthea, ſeeing him wounded, flew thro the ranks and ſupported him in her arms—till in another ſhower of arrows, one pierced her ſide—Both then fell together, and the ſtreams of their blood were mingled in their f • ll—The Babylonians by our ſwordmen were ſoon diſperſed, and when we came to look for our friends among the ſlain, we found Abradatas and Panthea, the huſband dead, and the wife juſt expiring, faſt locked in each others arms, and their boſoms filled with their mingled blood.

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p:
Theſe then are my orders. Let Abradatas and Panthea be buried on the very ſpot where they died—Let a monument of the moſt durable marble be erected on the ſpot, bearing this inſcription, THE MARRIED LOVERS.
There 〈…〉 to the lateſt poſterity, 〈…〉 the reſpect which Cyrus, and the Perſian Commonwealth, have for virtuous 〈◊〉 , and the ſacred compact of marriage —and of their deteſtation of thoſe unmanly vices which have not only ruined families, but nations. And for which the vengeance of heaven, now remains, ſcarcely ſuſpended, over the devoted city of Babylon.

div.head: The Foundling. A DRAMA, IN THREE ACTS.
THE CONTEMPT AND MISERY WHICH FOLLOWS A LIFE OF PLEASURE.
div.p: From the ſcenes of groſs voluptuousneſs nothing is to be expected but miſery, infamy, and baſeneſs—And the man of pleaſure, often leſs ſcrupulous than any honeſt man ſhould be, ſows the ſeeds of the bittereſt remorſe, when he imagines himſelf gathering the faireſt flowers of delight.

list.head: MEN.
list.item: FIELDFARE—a rich man, a man of pleaſure.

The Character of Puffpaſte cannot be too much burleſqued every point, except of honeſt good-nature, which is the only pleaſing quality the character is intended to represent. PUFFPASTE—a ſingular man a baker.
SAM. MOORE—reputed ſon of Dr. Moore.

div.head: SCENE I.—MELVIL and FIELDFARE.
div.stage: The ſtage preſents the two gentlemen ſitting, and a row of boys before them.

sp.speaker: Melvil.
sp.p: I DO not know how you reliſh our domeſtic ſcene—I love to live with my children.

sp.speaker: Field.
sp.p: It is a pleaſing ſight to ſee a number of ſpruce young fellows ſitting together, and the •• is one of theſe boys whom I fancy very much.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: People have often ſmiled when they have ſeen you give him apples, and gingerbread.

sp.speaker: Field.
sp.p: Is he no • your ſon?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: No, nor my wife's ſon.

sp.speaker: Field.
sp.p: You have a very pretty company, and I have tho't more of late than I uſed to do of the amuſement of an agreeable family.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I have often wondered that a man of your genius ſhould not wiſh to marry. You Bachelors form wild ideas of domeſtic life.

sp.speaker: Field.
sp.p: I always tho't it a ſtate of confinement.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: It gives juſt as much ſenſe of confinement as the ſoul has in being confined to the body—or as a man has in having an eſtate of his own, or living in a houſe, or on a farm, of his own.

sp.speaker: Field.
sp.p: What is the drift of all that?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p:
Should you eſteem yourſelf free, becauſe you had nothing to eat at home, but muſt buy a meal at an extravagant
price, at a tavern? If you had no houſe, but muſt hire a wretched lodging in a garret—If you had no money but what you borrowed or ſtole, kept no table, but dined where you could, or went without a dinner.

sp.speaker: Field.
sp.p: No, but a wretched dependent.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Yes, ſuch is exactly the freedom which a man enjoys who refuſes marriage, except that it is neither ſo innocent, nor ſo reputable.

sp.speaker: Field.
sp.p: Then you think the acquiſition of valuable property makes no man the leſs free.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Much leſs does the acquiſition of valuable friends. All that liberty is worth is that we may gain ſuch poſſeſſions, and ſerve them; but the evil of want of principle, is great. It hurts many perſons who ought to be happy.

sp.speaker: Field.
sp.p: If women would take care of themſelves, no perſon would hurt them.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Simplicity will not juſtify roguery—Suppoſe a merchant ſhould take of a child dollars inſtead of ſhillings.

sp.speaker: Field.
sp.p: You'll beat me perhaps in the argument, I never was much of a reaſoner.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I never knew a man of pleaſure that was.

sp.speaker: Field.
sp.p: Let that be as it may—I ſeem to like that boy. But that he is not your ſon puzzles me.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: He is not my ſon, nor my wife's ſon. He was brought up by Dr. Moore, and is an apprentice to Mr. Puffpaſte the baker—I can enquire concerning him.

sp.speaker: Field.
sp.p: DOCTOR, your ſervant, I hope you are well.

sp.speaker: Dr. Moore.
sp.p: I thank you and am ſurprized to ſee you alive.

sp.speaker: Field.
sp.p: Why not alive?

sp.speaker: Dr. Moore.
sp.p: Becauſe I know nothing more likely to ſhorten a man's days, than ſuch a life as you lead.

sp.speaker: Field.
sp.p: Doctors can give advice and phyſic but take neither of them, themſelves—But can you tell me who that boy is who is apprentice to Mr. Puffpaſte the baker?

sp.speaker: Dr. Moore.
sp.p: I do not know, his birth is a ſecret to every body but Mrs. Moore.

sp.speaker: Field
sp.p: Do you not conjecture whoſe child he is?

sp.speaker: Dr. Moore.
sp.p:
All that I know of him is that Mrs. Moore,
after an evening viſit brought home a beautiful child in a baſket; we bro't him up and bound him out apprentice to a baker.

sp.speaker: Field.
sp.p: Whoſe child does he paſs for in your family?

sp.speaker: Dr. Moore.
sp.p: For mine, and were I conſcious that he were my ſon, I have not a child who would give me more pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Field.
sp.p: Then he is a likely lad.

sp.speaker: Dr. Moore.
sp.p: Very likely?

sp.speaker: Field.
sp.p: Does he not, thinking himſelf your ſon, complain that you bound him apprentice to a baker?

sp.speaker: Dr. Moore.
sp.p: He ſaid he tho't it was odd—But he quieted his mind in thinking that he was our own child.

sp.speaker: Field.
sp.p: He muſt be a good tempered boy.

sp.speaker: Dr. Moore.
sp.p: He is! The more is the pity, that he cannot have a ſuitable education—and certainly, I think his father, whoever he be, muſt feel as much remorſe on that account, as for any injury done to another perſon.

sp.speaker: Field.
sp.p: Ah, there is no doubt of that!—But do you aſk Mrs. Moore, perhaps ſhe may tell—I will enquire of Mr. Puffpaſte; and find out the truth if poſſible. [All go out.]

sp.speaker: Y. Mel.
sp.p: DICK where's Sam Moore?

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: He is gone to get his new ſkates.

sp.speaker: Y. Mel.
sp.p: He will be ſo proud now, there will be no touching him with a boat hook.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Sam is quite ambitious. But he is a good-natured fellow.

sp.speaker: Y. Mel.
sp.p: Somehow I feel ſaucy to day, I ſuſpect I ſhall affront him.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: What makes you ſaucy. Have you been drinking hard?

sp.speaker: Y. Mel.
sp.p: I don't love rum. But the girls like Sam Moore better than they do me.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: How do you know that they like him better than you?

sp.speaker: Y. Mel.
sp.p: Becauſe I walked home with Miſs Mincer, becauſe it was dark and ſlippery, and you would have been affronted had you been in my place.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Why affronted?

sp.speaker: Y Mel.
sp.p: Becauſe when I was walking, ſhe would ſay—ſhame don't be rough—Sam Moore would not behave ſo. Nothing is right, but what is done like Sam Moore.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: You muſt not blame girls for being quite nice— You know if they are not pretty exact we are very apt to laugh at them when we are alone.

sp.speaker: Y. Mel.
sp.p: I do not know that Sam Moore is better than every body elſe neither.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Nor are you quite right, you appear to be a little envious.

sp.speaker: Y. Mel.
sp.p: He will be here in a minute, and you will ſee enough of his ſelf importance. [Enter Sam Moore.]

div.head: SCENE II.—YOUNG MELVILL, DICK and SAM MOORE.

sp.speaker: Y. Mel.
sp.p: WILL you go a ſkating with us to day?

sp.speaker: S. Moore
sp.p: Yes, I long to try my new ſkates—if they perform as well as they look I ſhall go like the wind.

sp.speaker: Y. Mel.
sp.p: You always can beat every body—we ſhall be nothing to you. I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: S. Moore.
sp.p: I never ſaid I could beat every body, but if my ſkates were well fixed, I believe I ſhould try to beat you.

sp.speaker: Y. Mel.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe you think you could do as well with me, as with Miſs Mincer.

sp.speaker: S. Moore.
sp.p: I do not know what you mean by doing well with Miſs Mincer. I always meant to treat her decently.

sp.speaker: Y. Mel.
sp.p: Is that the way to make the girls like one. I tho't the way was to be very bold and ſmart.

sp.speaker: S. Moore.
sp.p: It is according as how bold, and how ſmart you are—girls of no delicacy are as mean as the dirt in the ſtreets.

sp.speaker: Y. Mel.
sp.p: It is a hard taſk I believe to pleaſe them.

sp.speaker: S. Moore.
sp.p: If you think ſo, you will not pleaſe them—moſt certainly.

sp.speaker: Y. Mel.
sp.p: Tell me then how it is done.

sp.speaker: S. Moore.
sp.p:
Why if there be any thing kind or good to be done for them, do it quick and make no excuſes—never do
or ſay what they diſlike, or ſpeak bad of them—and they will ſoon find out one that likes them.

sp.speaker: Y. Mel.
sp.p: Then you think I don't treat them well I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: S. Moore.
sp.p: I ſaid no ſuch thing, your jealouſy muſt have told you ſo.

sp.speaker: Y. Mel.
sp.p: My jealouſy! that's well for you, a poor baſket bird.

sp.speaker: S. Moore.
sp.p: Who's a baſket bird?

sp.speaker: Y. Mel
sp.p: You ſir, if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: S. Moore.
sp.p: [Seizing him by the ſhoulders] You villain! I'll tear your heart out.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: You ſhan't puniſh him for ſaying truth.

sp.speaker: S. Moore.
sp.p: What do you mean, gentlemen? I was as well born as any of you—and whoever maintains the contrary I'll fight him.

sp.speaker: Y. Mel.
sp.p: Who was your father, ſir?

sp.speaker: S. Moore.
sp.p: Dr. Moore, and I am prouder of his blood, than I ſhould be of the blood of the twelve Caeſars.

sp.speaker: Y. Mel.
sp.p: There you are miſtaken, ſir.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: And who do you think your mother was?

sp.speaker: S. Moore.
sp.p: Mrs. Moore—whom, becauſe ſhe appears ſo grand, all the people call Madam Moore. I am prouder to be born of her than to be born of an empreſs.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: There you are miſtaken again.

sp.speaker: S. Moore.
sp.p: Who were my parents then?

sp.speaker: Y. Mel.
sp.p: No body knows—you was made a preſent of to Madam Moore in a baſket; that's fact and diſprove it if you can.

sp.speaker: S. Moore.
sp.p: Let me alone and I'll whip him well—I'll teach you to talk of baſkets in preſence of gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: He has told no more than the truth, you ſhall not puniſh him.

sp.speaker: S. Moore.
sp.p: You inſult me beyond all patience, I will throw off ſome of my clothes and then I will whip you both well. [In ſtripping to fight, Dr. Moore enters.]

div.head: SCENE III.—Dr. MOORE and S. MOORE.

sp.speaker: Dr. Moore.
sp.p: SILENCE!—Boys what is this rout here? what ſtripping to fight, for ſhame Sam! I could not have • ho't this of you.

sp.speaker: S. Moore.
sp.p: Why ſir, any man would fight to be inſulted ſo. He ſays I am not my own father's ſon; and that my mother never bore me—He lies, I know he does.

sp.speaker: Dr. Moore.
sp.p: I ſhould have been more diſpoſed to have laughed at him than to have beat him for that.

sp.speaker: S. Moore.
sp.p: He ſaid it in malice, ſir, and it is more than fleſh and blood can bear.

sp.speaker: Dr. Moore.
sp.p: He ſaid it in malice! I will enquire into that▪ Do you ſtay, the other young gentlemen will withdraw.

div.head: SCENE IV.—DR. MOORE and SAM. MOORE.

sp.speaker: Dr. Moore.
sp.p: NOW tell me Samuel, tell me, what has been the cauſe of this quarrel.

sp.speaker: S. Moore.
sp.p: They began to talk about ſkating and about Miſs Mincer—They took offence at what I ſaid—called me baſket bird—and ſaid that you was not my father, and that Mrs. Moore was not my mother.

sp.speaker: Dr. Moore.
sp.p: Well you muſt not beat them for that.

sp.speaker: S. Moore.
sp.p: It is not true I hope.

sp.speaker: Dr. Moore▪
sp.p: Not far from truth. But you muſt not be kept ignorant—You are not my ſon, nor is my wife your mother—And I know not whoſe child you are.

sp.speaker: S. Moore.
sp.p: O my grief—you not my father, Mrs Moore not my mother—O my heart will burſt! (Laying both his hands on his boſom.) I ſhall die, I ſhall die.

div.head: SCENE V.—FIELDFARE, DR. MOORE and MELVILL.

sp.speaker: Field.
sp.p: (Looking concerned.) That boy went out in extreme anguiſh—I always fancy he reſembles me. I always love to ſee and obſerve him—I feel very much for him now.

sp.speaker: Dr. Moore.
sp.p: He may be very near to you. But I know nothing of the matter

sp.speaker: Field.
sp.p: Go after him Doctor, and take care of him; I will pay you well.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p:
You heart, my friend Fieldfare, is not half hard enough 〈◊〉 a • ake—You ought to be inſenſible to the groans 〈◊〉 fathers, the ſighs of tender mothers, the tears and ago
••• s of diſtreſſe •
〈…〉 ſufferings and cries of deſerted
infancy, the undeſerved infamy of deſerted children— nay his heart, that he may not feel remorſe, ſhould be harder than the Baltic ſteel.

sp.speaker: Field.
sp.p: Good heavens! what a deſcription! Such a man muſt be unfit to live.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: A proper rake is I ſuppoſe always unfit to live.

sp.speaker: Dr. Moore.
sp.p: This lad is dangerouſly ill—His ſymptoms are very bad—The fits are violent, and the ſpaſms cen • re about the pericardium—I wiſh you would look out for a good nurſe for him

sp.speaker: Field.
sp.p: I ſuſpect this lad is my ſon—would to heaven I could find out his mother; ſhe muſt be the propereſt nurſe for him.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I cannot tell you. I would not for ten thouſand pounds undertake to track you in all your ways.

sp.speaker: Field.
sp.p: That is true, but I have extreme anxiety for this boy—Should he die, I find I muſt ſuffer extremely—would to heaven I knew who his mother was.

div.stage: (He goes out and the others follow him.)

div.head: SCENE I.—Mr. and Mrs. PUFFPASTE, (entering together.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Puff.
sp.p: CAN you tell, my woman, any thing about this boy. I find there is likely to be a noiſe about him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Puff
sp.p: Ye • , I could if I tho't it ſafe and proper.

sp.speaker: Mr. Puff.
sp.p: You would not conceal any thing now from old ſpark ▪ that's as true as a die—I won't tell tales; burn my whiſkers if I do.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Puff.
sp.p: I will tell you if you will undertake to plague Fieldfare a little—I'd make him feel with a witneſs—He has uſed the mother of this boy very ill—And men who uſe women ſo ill ought to ſuffer.

sp.speaker: Mr. Puff.
sp.p: That's right, I like to ſee a woman good ſponk to ſtand up for her ſex, burn my whiſkers if I think there is a man in a thouſand who blames them for that.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Puff.
sp.p:
Well I know who ſhe is well enough, you
remember that woman in a Bengal gown who was here yeſterday to buy biſcuit—you obſerved how melancholy ſhe looked. That was the very woman.

sp.speaker: Mr. Puff.
sp.p: Shave me up, if I ever tho't of that; I've got my clue now. I'll plague him well. (Exit Mrs. Puffpaſte.)

sp.speaker: Mad. Moore.
sp.p: MR. PUFFPASTE, has Mr. Fieldfare been enquiring of you about Sam's mother?

sp.speaker: Puff
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: M. Moore.
sp.p: Well, tell him not a word—we will contrive the matter ſo as to do her juſtice yet.

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: Madam I do not mean to tell any tales out of council—but I mean to give him a hearty ſweat—Truſt old Spunky for that.

sp.speaker: M. Moore.
sp.p: Swea • him well with all my heart. If it were in my power I would ſweat ſuch fellows one half of an eternity at leaſt.

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: Leave that to me—I'll plague him well; people ſay I'm a queer fellow; but I like the women right well. There's my wife now, fat, eaſy, and contented—As plump a Joan as there is in town.

sp.speaker: M. Moore.
sp.p: She does credit to your good nature Mr. Puffpaſte.

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: Aye that ſhe does, and I'll keep her yet as fat as buttered bunns, truſt me for that.

sp.speaker: Field.
sp.p: WHAT exceſſive pain it gave me to ſee this boy ſick—I wonder if I ſhould feel the ſame degree of joy on his recovery? It is poſſible—this boy then, if it be in the li • e of poſſibilities, ſhall be raiſed up again—till I ſuſpected this boy to be my ſon, I did not know what feelings my heart was capable of—Mr. Puffpaſte—I am on the rack of anxiety till I can diſcover the truth concerning this boy.

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: Why there it is now—I'll wager you fifteen to a quarter—that a married man can learn more in one year, than a rake can in ten.

sp.speaker: Field.
sp.p: Why? you take me up drily—and what can he learn?

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p:
Why that it is better to do right than to do wrong, by a large ſlice—and to be married to a good wife is better
than to be ſingle—that a wiſe man is b • tter than a fool —and to be a father is better than to be nothing.

sp.speaker: Field.
sp.p: Don't any man know ſuch things, who has common ſenſe?

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: Then you have not common ſenſe, you are ignorant of every notch in the paſte; you don't know a mince pie from a ſea biſcuit.

sp.speaker: Field.
sp.p: Do not I know tis eaſier to do right than to do wrong?

Naw—that ye dânt—you've been this whole day looking after your boy, and you don't know you've found him now, ſ • ttin. Naw you come to me to aſk for your wife—I'll be buttered if I ever come after you to aſk for my wife. Let a man only uſe his wife well, and he can find her the darkeſt •• ght that ever was.

sp.speaker: Field.
sp.p: Finiſh, ſince you've begun. Any man knows that it is better to do right than to do wrong.

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: Na ye don't know it neither. You dined once at a naſty tavern, you ſaid, and was drea-a-dful ſick after it. Keep a table of your own, and then you may dine nice—and you'll find it better by a large ſlice.

sp.speaker: Field.
sp.p: A fiddles end of your obſervations. I want to find out Sam's mother, and ſet her to nurſe him.

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: There 'tis again—What a carnal fool you are; aſk me what you ſhould know yourſelf. I know Sam's mother, I believe I do; but I will not tell you unleſs I pleaſe. Think'd I come to you to aſk for my wife? If your wife was where ſhe ſhould be, you could find her.

sp.speaker: Field.
sp.p: I have no wife.

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: Burn me if I don't think you lie now, honored ſir. Suppoſe you and I take a biſcuit—You hold one ſide and I t'other, and we break it right in the middle—Don't we hold equal halves? Burn my whiſkers if I don't think your ſon's mother is your proper wife.

sp.speaker: Field.
sp.p: A truce with your nonſenſe then, and tell me where to find her.

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: I ſhould have a great mind to tell you if I thought proper—No I wont—It will get abroad that I told tal •• — It will be for her benefit—Now I'm a good mind to tell you—But I may make miſtakes—Now I wont tell you.

sp.speaker: Field.
sp.p: Come old friend, tell me without any roundabouts, where ſhe is—I'm all impatience to know.

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p:
All impatience. Then I won't tell you—I long to
puniſh you—cruel to your wife—I ſaw her the other day— ſo thin!—ſo pale!—eyes ſo red!—cries ſo much!—Now my wife you ſee—folks ſay I hav'nt half the wit that you have—fags, I would't ſwap heads with you for a piſtareen to boot. See my wife, how fat ſhe is in the face, and as freſh as a four penny cake. A wiſe man knows more than a fool. A wife man keeps his wife, and a fool forſakes her, d'ye ſee!

sp.speaker: Field.
sp.p: You are the moſt impertinent raſcal that breathes —There! (ſhakes his cane over his head) tell me, or I'll cudg •• you well, you old ſhepherd. [Puffpaſte ſprings acroſs the ſtage, and ſtands at the entrance]

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: There ſir, I can outrun you; or if you do knock my brains out, I'll never tell you where your wife is, ſmoke me if I do—I won't be forced to do as I pleaſe, ſo good night, ſir.

sp.speaker: Field.
sp.p: Now I'm as far from my purpoſe as ever. I have abuſed the women, and loſt reſpect among the men—Old ſquaretoes, to treat me ſo—How low I muſt be ſunk! How the wretch tormented me! What I feel for this boy! I love him—I ſhould have loved his mother. Could I have loſt my liberty by living with thoſe whom I loved—Could I find her ſhe muſt be more ugly than ſin, or I would have her—My ſon live with old Puffpaſte! Sam is made for better things. I'll find her out yet and do her juſtice.

sp.speaker: Dr. Moore.
sp.p: Your ſon, ſir, is in a fair way of recovery.

sp.speaker: Field.
sp.p: He is? I thank you ſir—Never did the ſpeech of man give me ſuch ſincere raptures. I thank you for this happy news.

sp.speaker: Dr. Moore.
sp.p: His ſickneſs has brought out the whole ſecret. The mother, hearing he was on the point of death, came half diſtracted to my houſe—

sp.speaker: Field.
sp.p: Let me ſee her, let me ſee her; for heaven's ſake, let me ſee her!

sp.speaker: Dr. Moore.
sp.p: She will not be ſeen, unleſs you firſt engage to marry her.

sp.speaker: Field.
sp.p: What, marry and never ſee her? She may be the moſt diſagreeable hag in the world.

sp.speaker: Dr. Moore.
sp.p: I am ſorry if you have had ſuch connections. But • he lady poſitively will not be ſeen, unleſs you will firſt engage to marry her, and take her into immediate maintenance.

sp.speaker: Field
sp.p: Why ſo ſecret about it?

sp.speaker: Dr. Moore.
sp.p: She ſays ſhe has tried your word and ſhe cannot truſt you upon that; then if every body knows what is hitherto a ſecret, her character is utterly ruined.

sp.speaker: Field.
sp.p: How does ſhe mean to hold me?

sp.speaker: Dr. Moore.
sp.p: You muſt ſign a bond to forfeit ten thouſand dollars, if after you have ſeen her you do not have her. She will alſo ſecrete her ſon that you ſhall never have him.

sp.speaker: Field.
sp.p: I cannot blame her. Yet to what a wretched dilemma I am reduced. She may be ſome low dirty ſlut.

sp.speaker: Dr. Moore.
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Field.
sp.p: Or an abominable ſcold; and one might as well marry a thunder cloud.

sp.speaker: Dr. Moore.
sp.p: Very true.

sp.speaker: Field.
sp.p: A notorious liar.

sp.speaker: Dr. Moore.
sp.p: Likely enough.

sp.speaker: Field.
sp.p: A thief.

sp.speaker: Dr. Moore.
sp.p: So much the better, ſhe will ſteal enough to maintain you both.

sp.speaker: Field.
sp.p: She may be bad as—the furies!

sp.speaker: Dr. Moore.
sp.p: I know that.

sp.speaker: Field.
sp.p: I am very—very miſerable, and can blame no one but myſelf.

sp.speaker: Dr. Moore.
sp.p: I aſk you but this once whether you will ſign—if not I put up my papers, and you neither ſee the woman nor the boy forever.

sp.speaker: Field.
sp.p: Alas! what ſhall I do? I may ruin myſelf at one ſtroke— But better outward miſery than inward remorſe. Thus we, in our riper years, atone in deep remorſe and anxiety for the follies of youth. Thus I ſign perhaps my own death warrant. (Signs the paper—riſes in agony, and daſhes his pen on the floor in a rage) There, tell me now, have I cut my own throat or not. If I have, let me lie down and die on the ſpot. [Throws himſelf backward into a chair.]

sp.speaker: Dr. Moore.
sp.p:
Riſe ſir, and know your deſtiny—no ſir you are pledged to a very worthy woman—the moment a
〈1 page missing〉

div.head: The Female Gameſters. A DRAMA IN THREE ACTS.
DANGER AND CURE OF VICIOUS HABITS.
div.p: EVERY vicious habit ſubjects the mind to a real ſlavery. The moſt ſacred relations of life, with the duties annexed to them, are contravened by a vicious propenſion which has once maſtered the reaſoning faculty—This in no inſtance is more evident than in that of women, otherwiſe delicate and well bred —addicting themſelves to GAMING—Few vicious habits are cured but by ſome very powerful cauſe, ſuch as extreme ſickneſs, or fear of preſent death— we ſhould not therefore complain of life on account of frequent dangers and fears. They are medicines of providence to cure us of our vices.

div.head: PERSONS.

list.head: MEN.
list.item: MR. OMBRE—a merchant, and a very indulgent huſband.
ALLWORTHY—a very methodical, but very genteel man.

list.head: WOMEN.
list.item: MRS. OMBRE—a female gameſter, conductreſs of a party.
MEACHUM—a wife in ſlaviſh fear of her huſband.
SMART—a high ſpirited wife, counterpart to her huſband.
ARTFULL—a wife who values herſelf on her canning.

div.p: SCENE.—A merchant's houſe in the city of Briſtol in England.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Smart.
sp.p: WELL, I hope you have no objection to my going to Miſs Bridget's this evening.

sp.speaker: Mr. Smart.
sp.p: Certainly I have; and muſt tell you that you poſitively muſt not go.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Smart.
sp.p: Very pretty indeed! ſo as ſoon as we be married we muſt be laid under poſitive commands.

sp.speaker: Mr. Smart.
sp.p: Poſi • ive, or not, I mean to be maſter in my own houſe, and you go at your peril.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Smart.
sp.p: Lordly indeed, Mr. tyrant—But why may not one ſee a little company?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smart.
sp.p: Company is not your only object, it is well known that Miſs Bridget keeps a gaming table for ladies. You might as well be unfaithful to my love as addicted to gaming.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Smart.
sp.p: I gueſs you will find that I ſhall go where I pleaſe nevertheleſs.

sp.speaker: Mr. Smart.
sp.p: You ſhall go where I pleaſe, ſo prepare yourſelf to go in a chaiſe with me to Glouceſter.

div.head: SCENE II.—Mrs. SMART and Mrs. ARTFUL.

sp.speaker: Smart.
sp.p: I proteſt I won't bear this—To be led by the noſe by a huſband—I ſcorn it.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Can you not flatter him into good humor?

sp.speaker: Smart.
sp.p: There never was ſuch an obſtinate deſpot as my huſband. There is no bearing with him.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Poh! The leaſt ſaid is ſooneſt mended: you cannot diſgrace your huſband without diſcracing yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Smart.
sp.p: I wanted to go and ſee couſin Bridget, but my ſaucebox ſays that he has engaged me, and I muſt go with him to Glouceſter.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: And why not? The journey is pleaſant, with an agreeable friend too—I always delight to ride abroad with my huſband.

sp.speaker: Smart.
sp.p: But they are to have a card party at Miſs Bridget's this evening—And my tyrant refuſes, and I am determined I won't bear it. (Exit Smart.)

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: (alone) THIS woman is out in her politics, an obſtinate huſband is never reclaimed by raving.

sp.speaker: Meach.
sp.p: 'Happy to meet you, my good friend, I wiſh to know of you, how you manage your huſband.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Why do you need ſuch counſel—I tho't you and your ſweetheart lived in the promiſed land of matrimony flowing with honey, and all ſweets imaginable.

sp.speaker: Meach.
sp.p: We never quarrel, but it is all owing to me. If he frowns upon me I tremble—I am afraid of him as of a lion—He is very ſovereign I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: I believe you are a piece of a fool for that.

sp.speaker: Meach.
sp.p: How would you prevent it?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Prevent it! a woman may have her due influence with her huſband if ſhe acts right.

sp.speaker: Meach.
sp.p: That is juſt what I wiſh to know.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: For a general rule, never ſeek any thing but to make your huſband happy.

sp.speaker: Meach.
sp.p: What ſhall I gain by that?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: When you wiſh to carry a particular point, you will have great influence.

sp.speaker: Meach.
sp.p: And is that alone ſufficient?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: When he is in good humor never put him out of it.

sp.speaker: Meach.
sp.p: But I croſſed him a good deal when I was firſt married to let him know I would not obey.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: There you was not cunning. You put him on his defence, and he was obliged to carry his point, or be your ſlave.

sp.speaker: Meach
sp.p: Now I wiſh to go to Bridget's, but he ſays poſitively he will not live with a gameſter.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Does that affright you?

sp.speaker: Meach.
sp.p: I am but a child to take care of myſelf: were he to leave me, I ſhould be the wretchedeſt woman in the world.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: So he has found out that—But what arts have you ever uſed with him?

sp.speaker: Meach.
sp.p: I was determined once to ſcold him well; but he always left me to enjoy my own muſic.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: What did you do then?

sp.speaker: Meach.
sp.p: They told me that a huſband of feeling could not reſiſt my tears—I cried for every thing I wanted, and it anſwered very well for a while.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: But did not laſt I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Meach.
sp.p: I ſometimes feigned it, and ſo when I cried for trifles he would not regard me.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Then you did wrong; you ſhould never cry but in matters of conſequence, as for example, for a new gown, or to go out againſt your huſband's will. There is great art in crying properly.

sp.speaker: Meach.
sp.p: You do nothing but blame me—But they ſay your huſband indulges his wife more than any other.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: What if he do?

sp.speaker: Meach.
sp.p: I wiſh to go to Bridget's but my huſband will not conſent; and without that I might as well die as go.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Tell him he is the beſt huſband in the world, and that you will be the goodeſt, and the kindeſt, and the ſweeteſt, wife to him that ever was, if he will let you go.

sp.speaker: Meach.
sp.p: Will ſuch ſilly coaxing have any effect?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Try it and ſee: and remember never to ſcold at your huſband at all; and never cry, but when there is reaſon for it—and not often when there is. [Exit Artful, and Smart re-enters, but Meachum does not ſee her, becauſe her face is turned the other way.]

sp.speaker: Meachum
sp.p: (with herſelf.) WELL if coaxing will do I'll coax him to perfection—I have ſome talents for that—

sp.speaker: Smart
sp.p: (interrupting her.) Coax him. I would choke him firſt; I ſuppoſe you mean your huſband. What brutes theſe creatures are!

sp.speaker: Meach.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Smart.
sp.p: And do you coax him? I'd let him know I would do as I pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Meach.
sp.p: And how can you do that?

sp.speaker: Smart.
sp.p: I never enquire how I can do it; but do it without enquiring of my ſauce box—To day he was as high as my lord becauſe I talked of going to the card-party.

sp.speaker: Meach.
sp.p: And how did you get away?

sp.speaker: Smart.
sp.p: I told him I would go to the card-party and would not ſtir to Glouceſter—And I went out of the room, topping high—went up ſtairs—He looked very angry and roſe to follow me—I went up ſtairs very faſt—he went up a few ſteps and ſtopt, then went up again, then ſtopt; I watched him; at laſt he came up ſlowly, I ſlipt down another pair of ſtairs, ſtept into the carriage and drove away.

sp.speaker: Meach.
sp.p: And what will be the conſequence?

sp.speaker: Smart.
sp.p: I care not, he may go to Glouceſter on foot or hire a carriage if he pleaſes. [Enters Allworthy.]

sp.speaker: Allw.
sp.p: Ladies, you ſeem all to be engaged on ſome adventure, pray, what is it?

sp.speaker: Smart.
sp.p: Yes, Mrs. Allworthy you will go with us to the card-party.

sp.speaker: Allw.
sp.p: No▪ indeed I ſhall not.

sp.speaker: Meach.
sp.p: Why not, madam?

sp.speaker: Allw.
sp.p: I will not diſſemble my ſentiments, I do not think it proper.

sp.speaker: Meach.
sp.p: Not think it proper?

sp.speaker: Allw.
sp.p: No, I do not for a woman to leave the company of her huſband, and the care of her children; to go to ſome public houſe, and paſs the evening at cards—where, if ſucceſsful ſhe ſtays late—if unfortunate ſhe comes home peeviſh—and the worſt company imaginable to her family.

sp.speaker: Smart.
sp.p: You are an old faſhioned creature.

sp.speaker: Allw.
sp.p: Good faſhions ought to laſt forever, and I think it a very good faſhion in a lady to refuſe gaming.

sp.speaker: Smart.
sp.p: Well that is clever now. You are juſt like your old grandmother. I remember how ſhe uſed to put her ſpectacles on, and ſing it out, Cards and dice, are the Devil's device. If you'd enjoy your day, abſtain from play. So you think too.

sp.speaker: Allw.
sp.p: You have given a ridiculous turn to the ſentiment. But let me expreſs it and ſee if it can be deſpiſed. It is dangerous for a woman to be a gameſter. She will loſe her character, her huſband's affections, and the reſpect of her children, and then ſhe cannot be happy.

sp.speaker: Smart.
sp.p: You are the moſt old faſhioned creature that ever was, ſo, I ſay no more to you.

sp.speaker: Allworthy alone.
sp.p: If theſe woman be not ruſhing on their own perdition I have no reaſon—It is full bad enough for men to game at public houſes, and keep late hours—If women do the ſame they appear diveſted of the proper delicacy of the ſex. [Exit Allworthy.]

sp.speaker: Mr. All.
sp.p: I WAS ſorry this moment to meet my friend Smart very angry at his wife.

sp.speaker: Mrs. All.
sp.p: His wife may have given him juſt provocation. But I obſerve that in caſes of this kind, you always favor the women.

sp.speaker: Mr. All.
sp.p: The cauſe may be that I have ever been acquainted with women who are virtuous and reaſonable.

sp.speaker: Mrs. All.
sp.p: Your extreme complaiſance almoſt makes me ſuſpect you of flattery.

sp.speaker: Mr. All.
sp.p: Think, my lovely friend, that when • man truſts his honor, his intereſt, the keeping of his heart and happineſs to a woman, this is ſomething more than flattery.

sp.speaker: Mrs. All.
sp.p: It certainly is, and the ſureſt mark of confidence. I eſteem it a great honor to be entruſted with ſuch a precious charge. But ſuppoſing I ſhould wiſh to go to the card party?

sp.speaker: Mr. All.
sp.p: You may if you think proper—I leave you to your own reaſon and diſcretion. [Exit with a low bow.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. All.
sp.p: One thing I am certain of. No woman can be happier than I, with reſpect to her huſband.

div.head: SCENE II.—Miſ EIGHTEEN and Mrs. ALLWORTHY.

sp.speaker: Eight.
sp.p: You ſay your life has been more agreeable ſince you married than before—Yet I am determined never to be married.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: You may alter your reſolution.
No, never, you may depend upon it.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Bravely reſolved. But ſuch reſolutions have often failed.

sp.speaker: Eight.
sp.p: Mine ſhall not—ſhall not—unleſs I could have ſuch a huſband as yours, I admire him.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Why that is frank indeed, to confeſs a particular regard for my huſband.

sp.speaker: Eight.
sp.p: I did not ſay that neither, but it might be the caſe if it were not a crime.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Worſe and worſe—But what qualities have you diſcovered in my huſband, to attract your notice?

sp.speaker: Eight.
sp.p: Becauſe he is always ſo generouſly complaiſant. My mamma ſays, that you behave together not like old married folks, but like a couple juſt going to be married.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: True, I know no difference but on the beſt ſide.— Mr. Allworthy has ever been more kind and more attentive to me ſince we were married than before. The truth is, he always was a proper gentleman.

sp.speaker: Eight.
sp.p: It is ſaid that he always lets you do juſt as you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: He does—I never knew him, in any caſe, to give me a direct refuſal.

sp.speaker: Eight.
sp.p: Would he let you go to the card party?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: He never forbad it.

sp.speaker: Eight.
sp.p: Now I wiſh to know how a woman can make a complete gentleman ſo attached to her.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: That is needleſs, as you never intend to be married.

sp.speaker: Eight.
sp.p: Why, perhaps I might, could I be as happy as you, and have ſuch a huſband as one chuſes.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Certainly I would chuſe only ſuch as I have.

sp.speaker: Eight.
sp.p: But how could you make him like you ſo? that is the thing I want to know.

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: It was not my beauty, certainly.

sp.speaker: Eight.
sp.p: No, it is not extreme, but well enough.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Nor my gaiety, or frequenting public places.

sp.speaker: Eight.
sp.p: No, for people ſay you go about much more ſince you married than before.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Yes; you ſee then it was none of theſe matters.

sp.speaker: Eight.
sp.p: Well, you torment me, I want to know what it was.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: To be ſerious then, all I know of it is this, that I firſt conſidered whether Mr. Allworthy were a reaſonable man. I found that he was—Then I made it my conſtant aim, to perform whatever was agreeable to him, and avoid whatever was diſagreeable to him, both before ma • age and ſince.

sp.speaker: Eight.
sp.p: But they ſay a roſe is no roſe without its thorns— and that all ſweet, and no ſour ſpoils the appetite.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Human life has thorns enough without making any artificial ones—And is it not a fact, that both men and women are moſt attached where they feel moſt happy? They are moſt eaſy in their minds where they are beſt treated, and enjoy the pleaſure of ſelf eſteem. I conſider vice and folly as out of the queſtion.

sp.speaker: Eight.
sp.p: But it is not delicate to take ſuch pains to pleaſe a man.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: It is as delicate as to torment him. A dove is at leaſt as delicate a creature as a ſnake—Beſides, who needs to know your views, you ſimple ſenſe?—You may find out what a man likes or diſlikes, by himſelf or his neighbors— ſay nothing of your deſigns, but avoid the offence, and perform what is agreeable. In that conſiſts the whole ſecret —and tho you do it by deſign, a man who loves you, will always think you do it from the native goodneſs of your heart.

sp.speaker: Eight.
sp.p: If that be the way I ſhall let him paſs, I am determined they ſhall love me for my beauty and my fine accompliſhments: and if ever I be married I will do as I pleaſe, that is poſitive.

sp.speaker: Allw.
sp.p: That is no more than I do, who never was poſitive about it.

sp.speaker: Eight.
sp.p: But I won't have it in that way; and to be ſure I will not be reſtrained in gaming—I intend to begin before I am married, ſo that my huſband ſhall have no face to find fault with me.

sp.speaker: Allw.
sp.p: Huſband! Huſband! I thought you never meant to be married.

sp.speaker: Eight.
sp.p:
O I forgot myſelf; I do not intend to be married
—but I can have a huſband if I pleaſe, I would have you to know; ſo I will dreſs myſelf for the card-party this minute. [Exit Eighteen.—Mrs. Smart enters again.]

sp.speaker: Smart.
sp.p: SO I am going you ſee, and my huſband, poor to • d, may go to Glouceſter on foot like a ſaucy wretch; think to reſtrain me!

sp.speaker: Allw.
sp.p: What if he ſhould take a coach and go with ſome other woman.

sp.speaker: Smart.
sp.p: He is too honeſt for that.

sp.speaker: Allw.
sp.p: That is a very curious reaſon for uſing him ill. But honeſty may ſometimes meet with his match. Nothing is more likely than ill treatment, to make him ſeek the graces of another.

sp.speaker: Smart.
sp.p: You are a wretch for ſtarting ſuch a thought. Heav'ns how it pains me here! (Laying her fan on her boſom.) I will haſte to the card-table and forget it as faſt as I can.

sp.speaker: Allw.
sp.p: You will have enough to do to forget it even there.

sp.speaker: Mr. Om.
sp.p: HERE my good girl, ſee how I leave matters. There is money with the houſekeeper to buy proviſſions for the family, and to purchaſe you a ſuit for your wedding day; I give this to you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Om.
sp.p: I know it, and there is money left here by Mr. Oldfield for you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Om.
sp.p: I do not need it, I have enough to anſwer the demands of the day.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Om.
sp.p: I hope you will not forbid me to go to the card-party.

sp.speaker: Mr. Om.
sp.p: Forbid you, no, tho I do not love cards—and ſhould be very well contented if you did not. It is a very inſipid game to me—but you will be robbed if it be known that you go—you have money.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Om.
sp.p: That is only to terrify me from going to the party.

sp.speaker: Mr. Om.
sp.p: But I will eſcort you for fear of harm.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Om.
sp.p: You may ſave yourſelf the trouble: the men are very fond of ſhowing how neceſſary they are to the women—I ſhall be as well without you.

div.head: SCENE II.—Mrs. OMBRE and Miſs PINCH'E • .

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: WHERE is the money which my huſband left to buy proviſions?

sp.speaker: Pinch.
sp.p: It is here; but why does not Mr. Ombre buy proviſions himſelf.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: becauſe he trades remote from the market in the further part of the city—ſo he leaves the money with me.

sp.speaker: Pinch.
sp.p: I would help myſelf out of the money very freely —I ſhould love a careleſs huſband.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: O I ſhall not forget that, you may depend on it. But how much may we venture to take?

sp.speaker: Pinch.
sp.p: Well if I help you to this money you muſt keep me ſafe from harm, for there is no way but to pinch it out of the family.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: It grieves me for the poor children, but then it muſt be done. It is genteel you know.

sp.speaker: Pinch.
sp.p: Well here are thirty guineas which we may ſave —your huſband left ſixty to buy flour, but brown bread will do for the children, and it will not coſt more than half ſo much.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: Well, and to make it paſs, we will eat the ſame—ſo if Mr. Ombre ſhould enquire, we can tell him that the children eat as good as we.

sp.speaker: Pinch.
sp.p: No madam I am not going to eat brown bread neither—while I do the work, I will live upon the beſt.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: Then ſet brown bread on always for the children, and for me, when my huſband is abſent. But there is no other way that a ſaving can be made?

sp.speaker: Pinch.
sp.p: We might mix the ſtrong beer with water half and half, and by that means raiſe a conſiderable • um.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p:
There is the money which my huſband left me to purchaſe a ſuit of clothes to celebrate my wedding day— I will borrow a ſuit of your clothes and wear it that day, my huſband will never mind it—ſo do you give me what
you have ſaved at preſent, it may pay this day's debt—but there is another thing which I have thought of.

sp.speaker: Pinch.
sp.p: What is that?

sp.speaker: Om
sp.p: There is the ſum which Mr. Oldfield left for my huſband. I will take that to ſave the chance of being out of caſh by a bad run. I ſhall win in my turn enough to make it up. Go, for the preſent, to the buſineſs of the family, and ſee what further ſavings may be made.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: alone. Now many perſons would have made theſe ſavings to increaſe their own private eſtate. But I to pay my debts of honor, mine is the nobleſt motive. Indeed it went againſt my conſcience a little to ſhorten the allowance of my poor children. But what is to be done—one had better be out of the world than be ſingular in good company. [Enters Eighteen, and after her Mrs. Allworthy.]

sp.speaker: Eigh.
sp.p: WELL I am determined to go—I won't have my huſband ſay after marriage that I cheated him. I'll bring him up to cards.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: The huſband you are reſolved never to have.

sp.speaker: Eigh.
sp.p: I will not be inſulted any more with that Mrs. Allworthy—I can have a huſband if I pleaſe, but I won't (makes a long pauſe) unleſs I pleaſe.

sp.speaker: All. to Om.
sp.p: Your huſband is very kind, he loves not cards; but he never troubles you about it.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: He is very kind and he loves not cards, but who that has learnt the faſhion, ever pretends to care for that— I ſhall go, (Exit Ombre.)

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: NOW my dear girl you are not yet hardened in vice. I adviſe you not to go to the card party this evening. It is a dangerous practice.

sp.speaker: Eigh.
sp.p: I determine to go, and there is nothing that you can ſay which will hinder me. But I am waiting for Miſs Idle, as ſoon as ſhe comes I ſhall go. But you may ſay any thing in the mean time.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p:
You are uncommonly generous for a woman who loves cards, and for that reaſon I tell you, that if you purſue
this practice of gaming you may give up every proſpect of a happy ſettlement in life.

sp.speaker: Eigh.
sp.p: I care not for that: I wonder what makes Miſs Idle ſtay. I will not wait for her any longer.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: alone. What a ſtrange infatuary vice! The moſt affectionate pairs are ſeparated, and alienated from each other. Girls give up the proſpects, which are deareſt to the youthful heart—mothers can deprive their families of their food, and be hard hearted againſt their own children —nay can even give up their beloved dreſs, all for that wretched inſipid game of cards.

div.head: SCENE V.—PINCH'EM running in to ALLWORTHY who remains.

sp.speaker: Pinch.
sp.p: O mercy!—what ſhall I do? miſtreſs is murdered I believe.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: What makes you think ſo?

sp.speaker: Pinch.
sp.p: As I came from the Grocer's ſhop which is at the head of Bembow ſtreet, I ſaw three very ugly fellows in cloſe converſation at the corner of a coal houſe. I got as near to them unſeen as poſſible, and overheard them ſay that they knew of a card party at Miſs Bridget's, and that, the ladies would have money; and they meant to way-lay, rob and murder them. Poor miſtreſs, I am frighted out of my wits, ſhe is gone for it, I believe.

div.head: SCENE VI.—All the ladies ruſh in with noiſe and confuſion▪ except Mrs. OMBRE.

sp.speaker: Smart.
sp.p: THERE was the dreadfuleſt noiſe of quarrelling in Bembow ſtreet; and they cried out murder, murder! Somebody is killed, I believe.

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: I am aſtoniſhed, as every one muſt know they had money, that they ſhould go thro Bembow ſtreet, as they muſt know it is famous for robbers.

sp.speaker: Smart
sp.p: It was the ſhorteſt way to Miſs Bridgets, and we were in a hurry to get there.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: The love of gaming is even dearer than life.

div.stage: (Mrs Ombre enters—They lay hold on her.)

sp.speaker: Pinch.
sp.p: Are you alive?

sp.speaker: Ombre.
sp.p:
Yes, I am alive, but had it not been for my kind and generous huſband, I certainly had been murdered— He knew that I muſt go thro that ſtreet, and tho I perverſely
refuſed his protection—he▪ expecting the robbers would aſſault me, placed himſelf in a proper ſituation to defend me.

sp.speaker: Smart.
sp.p: 'Twas a great chance that you was attacked near where he was placed.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: It was: firſt two ugly fellows laid hold on me with great knives in their hands; and a third was coming up with a cutlaſs. My huſband felled one with his cane and run another thro with a ſword, he grappled with a third, and left him helpleſs, he received five wounds himſelf but none dangerous.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: So Mrs. Meachum, you was there.

sp.speaker: Meach.
sp.p: By Mrs. Artful's direction, I got leave.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: 'Twas I put her in the way of it.

sp.speaker: Meach.
sp.p: But I wiſh I had not gone.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: But if no harm is done we may take another courſe and go yet.

sp.speaker: Meach.
sp.p: No, miſchief enough has been done already. I ſaw your huſband, Mrs. Smart, in a hackney coach, with a noted woman going to Glouceſter.

sp.speaker: Smart.
sp.p: O heav'ns, my huſband—I ſhall die— (She flies off the ſtage in a paſſion.)

sp.speaker: Pinch.
sp.p: And the miſchief does not end here—The gentleman who was courting Miſs Eighteen, coming to her houſe, and learning that ſhe was gone to the card-party▪ went and took up her rival, and is gone with her to Bath.

sp.speaker: Eight.
sp.p: Confuſion ſeize them—Oh I'm diſtracted, oh!—

div.stage: (Appearing to go off the ſtage in agony.)

sp.speaker: Omb.
sp.p: Let us never take a ſtep that way again. I muſt have perriſhed had it not been for my generous huſband— and ſhall I employ my time to the utter ruin of his affairs? I had almoſt ruined his family before—his generous kindneſs ſaved me. I will abuſe it no more.

lg.l: Thus dangers are the cure of human crimes,
And preſent death awakens fear, betimes.
Then blame not Providence for human woe,
It is the medicine of our lives below. [All go out.]

div.head: Scanderbeg,The Epirots called this remarkable perſon, Alexander. Among the Turks he was called Scander-Beg—that is, "Alexander the Prince"—But his true name was George Caſtriot, and the title he gave himſelf in his letters, was, "The Soldier of Jeſus Chriſt"—For about 30 years he was the champion of the Chriſtian States againſt the Turks. Temperate, dextrous, indefatigable and active, he ever met with ſucceſs. He was mild in his temper, almoſt to a fault—and three times pardoned his couſin Ameſa, a voluptuous youth, the crime of high treaſon. He died with glory—and the Turks wore pieces of his bones, ſet in jewels and rings, as amulets againſt danger. His height of glory was about 1440. OR THE PRINCE OF EPIRUS. A DRAMATIC DIALOGUE—IN VERSE. IN THREE ACTS.
div.p: VOLUPTUOUSNESS DANGEROUS TO YOUTH.

list.item: ACHMET— Viſier of the Turkiſh army.

list.head: WOMEN.
list.item: ZEPHORA—Eliza's nurſe, both having been captives to the Turks.
PAULINA—a grave lady, captive, and ſervant to the Viſier.

sp.speaker: Scan.
sp.l: HAIL ſacred Paſtor, may this happy day
Refreſh thy ſoul, and baniſh grief away.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Ah no! illuſtrious prince, high Heaven decreed,
That half my flock, my precious ſheep, ſhould bleed.
Heaven was the object of their warm deſire,
I bade their zeal to heavenly joys aſpire.
Yet half this much loved people now are ſlain.
Their bones are whitening ſtill on yonder plain.

sp.speaker: Scan.
sp.l: Yet Heaven with victory our arms has crowned;
Myriads of Turks have marked their length of ground.
There proudeſt Baſhaws, Beys, and Viſiers lie;
Whoſe haughty ſouls dared Chriſtian arms defy.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Whole armies ſlain, vaſt armies ſtill ariſe.
The Turkiſh empire endleſs ſwarms ſupplies.
Their boundleſs wealth can ceaſeleſs wars defray;
Their endleſs troops renew the fatal day.

sp.speaker: Scan.
sp.l: The great Eternal Power, who rules the ſkies,
By his own ſtrength the wrath of man defies;
He gives the victory and vengeance due;
And ſaves alike by many or by few.
Then I, to ſave the ſtate, ſtill lift the ſword.
No Chriſtian ſoul ſhall own a Turkiſh Lord.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Heaven bleſs your hopes, and give your arms ſucceſs;
May Heaven's high juſtice give our wrongs redreſs;
May you adorn the bright triumphal car;
Yet ſtill I weep, and dread deſtructive war.

sp.speaker: Scan.
sp.l: Thine, worthy paſtor, are the arts of peace:
The virtues by thy labors ſhall increaſe▪
My heart impels me to the martial field;
There the proud Turks ſhall to my Chriſtians yield.
Thine be the milder work, to preach and pray;
But mine the glory of the well fought day.
Go, and for us, thy pious vows be given;
No work ſucceeds but by the will of heaven.

sp.speaker: Scan.
sp.l: Com'ſt thou thus idle, midſt dire war's alarms?
Where, couſin, is thy brilliant ſuit of arms?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Had I but hope, I ſtill might ſeek the fight,
And thouſands ſee my deeds, and do me right.
Can our whole hoſt, a handful at the beſt,
O'er-power theſe mighty conquerers of the Eaſt?

sp.speaker: Scan.
sp.l: Yet have I ſeen, when others blood ran cold,
Thee, keen for fight, and as a lion bold,
Seen thee performing deeds, in foremoſt line,
On which the ſun might even be proud to ſhine.
But love reſiſtleſs lays thy glories low,
The beſt or vileſt paſſions, mortals know;
The fair Circaſſian ſlave in yonder fields,
Melts thy fond heart, and all thy courage yields.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: True; I have ſeen the faireſt female form,
That ever did a hero's boſom warm.
To none of all her ſex her beauty yields;
And true, the fair reſides in yonder fields.

sp.speaker: Scan.
sp.l: Yes ſhe is there, and there you wiſh to go,
Make peace with Turks, and lay our glories low.
Wouldſt ſell thy nation, and wouldſt wed thy ſhame,
And bury every ſpark of honeſt fame.
Wouldſt bed in bagnios with a Turkiſh ſlave,
A better bed for thee, would be thy grave.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: But have not all the braveſt poets ſung,
Of love? to tender lays their harps have ſtrung.

sp.speaker: Scan.
sp.l: Yes—ſung of Samſon's locks, and Helen's ſhame,
And every ſon that ever bore a name.
The fruit of lawleſs love, the boundleſs crimes,
Of earlier periods, or of later times.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Tell this to our rich dames, who point the dart,
Full proud to fix it in a hero's heart.
〈…〉 object loves,
To virtue like a burning ſe • aph moves.
All is alive to bleſs the lovely prize,
And catch the virtues kindling from her eyes.
And ſuch the fair Circaſſian ſlave may be:
None bleſs the ſun but who have eyes to ſee.

sp.speaker: Scan.
sp.l: No—no—a baſe born ſlave for ſordid gold,
Bought for ſome brutal Turk, decayed, and old,
The lothing partner of his ſordid bed;
To ignorance and to impoſture bred.
I'll hear no more, prepare to tread the plain;
On heaps of daſtard Turks, deſpoiled and ſlain.
Spring to thine arms, fly ſwifter than the wind,
This ſword is for the knave who ſtays behind.

div.head: SCENE I.—HALY, a Turkiſh ſpy, enters. HALY and AMESA.

sp.speaker: Haly.
sp.l: WHERE is this wretch who longs to ſell his ſoul:
Already liſted in the infernal roll
Of traitors? Here's the poiſon, precious bane!
That muſt deſtroy what virtues yet remain
Lingring in his galled heart. But huſh, 'tis he,
He's coming—Now let proſper villainy.
sp.stage: (Steps aſide till Ameſa enters, then addreſſes himſelf to Ameſa.)
sp.l: —Illuſtrious Hero of the far fam'd line!
Whoſe deeds in ſong, and ſculptured marble ſhine;
Deſcended from the famed A chillean Boy,
• yrrhus, who laid in duſt the towers of Troy.
Why ſhouldſt thou ſerve a petty tyrant Lord?
Can his bald realm a recompence afford?
My maſter has the prize that's worth thy toil,
Long treaſured riches of imperial ſpoil.
Beſide, the loved Circaſſian ſlave is thine,
Whoſe beauties far the light of heaven outſhine.
All theſe, if you deſert the Chriſtian bands;
Shall be delivered ſafe into your hands.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: The gold is nothing—What is duſt to me?
Jewels and veſts, mere ſordid trumpery.
The fair Circaſſian maid alone I prize,
Joy of my ſoul, and comfort of my eyes.
When late in our proud court a captive ſhe
Appeared, a princeſs fair ſhe ſeemed to be.
Not one of all our great imperial line
Could young Ameſa's captive girl outſhine.
The prince, O cruel Lord, forbad my love.
To conquer fate, alas! in vain I ſtrove.
Then, by exchange, my captive maid returned,
To her rough Lord—My heart her abſence mourned.

sp.speaker: Haly.
sp.l: Now then young prince the captive maid is thine,
To morrow thou in Turkiſh gold ſhall ſhine.
If thou a choſen band this hour wilt lead;
To bring impaled, the Chriſtian hero's head.
Thou well the hour of ſafe attack may'ſt know,
Wronged in thy love, thou well may'ſt be his foe.

div.stage: [Takes the bribe—Haly goes out, and Ameſa makes his reflections with himſelf.]

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: O fatal! fatal power of lawleſs love!
Nought could his gold, nought could his preſents move.
The fair Circaſſian maid alone I prize;
Joy of my heart, and comfort of my eyes.
For her alas! I to his offers yield.
And now, a blaſted villain, take the field.
Sunk, and diſgraced, my nation I betray;
Blaſt all my glories on this fatal day.
Sell all that's dear—O yet can I return!
And in my ſoul this torment ceaſe to burn—
Ah no, the flame accurſt torments me ſtill.
And ſcarce the villain quivering on the wheel
Of varied torture, feels ſuch pangs as mine—
Sure fruit of crimes, the meed of ill deſign—
O had I ne'er been born, or thoſe fair eyes
On this dull earth were never ſeen to riſe.
Heaven, earth, I loſe, and vanquiſh glory's charms;
To ſink entranced in fair Fatema's arms.
Yet ſuch my pain, if all the world could ſee
The vileſt wretch on earth—they'd pity me.

div.stage: [Haly enters again—Viſier Achmet enters—with Muſtapha as Ameſa is retiring.]

sp.speaker: Viſ.
sp.l: THIS then the place muſt be, from whence we ſcan
The Chriſtian camp, and learn their mutual plan.

sp.speaker: Haly.
sp.l: Ameſa told the whole, and you may ſee,
Well with his words the facts eſpied agree.
Below yon cliff (points as if obſerving a camp, looks thro a proſpect glaſs) which threats the arching ſky,
Proud of their ſtate, the bold Venetians lie.
Their numbers few, with ſilver mounted arms,
Each man a hero, fired with glory's charms—
The fierce Hungarians on the left are placed;
Large leathern belts encircling every waiſt,
Whence hang theſe heavy ſwords with which they ſtrike,
And deal out death, to horſe, or man, alike,
Next theſe on either part Epirots lie,
Men who in fight our fierceſt troops defy.
All cloathed in iron, In the midſt they place
Militia of Epirus' hardy race.
Behind the whole the troops reſerved recline,
Two aged generals rule that valiant line.

sp.speaker: Viſ.
sp.l: Speak out, then, warriors, ſhall we, as they lie,
Attack them, and the force of battle try?

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.l: Illuſtrious chief, from battle I diſſent,
Shame waits the man who is on battle bent:
Never ſaw I, an army ranged ſo well,
Both to attack a force, or to repel.

sp.speaker: Viſ.
sp.l: Baſe woman hearted Baſhaw, canſt thou fear
A boy ſcarce reached his twenty ſecond year,
A youth, not half a man, whoſe face can ſhow
Scarce beard enough to fit him for a beau.
Shall I then tremble at his name, and fly?
Rather would I, with my whole army, die.

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.l: A coward, viſier! ſay not that again,
Or thou no more ſhall fill the liſt of men,
A coward I, who from my youth hate bled,
In battles more than thou haſt ſeen, or read.

sp.speaker: Viſ.
sp.l: Why then deny the chriſtian force to fight,
Or think'ſt a boy can put us all to flight?
What will the Ottomans at Pera ſay▪
That Viſier Achmet ſhunned the glorious day.

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.l: Say what they will. 〈◊〉 fight w •• h thouſands coſt;
What will they ſay when our whole army's loſt?
Conſider chief, the man whom we oppoſe,
Not written in the liſt of common foes.
Deſcended from a grand heroic race,
Whoſe deathleſs deeds ſong, hiſtory, marble, grace.
In all the pureſt chriſtian morals bred,
No fumes of wine becloud his princely head.
No lawleſs loves his manly nerves unbrace,
No wanton feats his youthful day diſgrace.
Aſpaſia, miſtreſs of unrivaled charms,
Fires him to virtue, and the deeds of arms.
Heireſs of all Epirus, if he gain
The victory, on this tremendous plain.
The chiefs decree to that heroic boy,
T •• ſtate its lovely heir and every joy.

sp.speaker: Viſ.
sp.l: Why ſpeak of that? Let them decree again,
I'll not recede an inch from yonder plain.
Muſtapha go, and rouſe the troops to arms,
Bid martial glory ſpread her awful charms.
Say not a word of fear, but ſay aloud,
That all may hear as thunder from a cloud.
"This is the day the chriſtian croſs ſhall fall,
"The Turkiſh creſcent riſe and conquer all."

sp.speaker: Viſ.
sp.l: What ſays my ſecretary? not in fear,
I hope, as Heaven ſhall hold my ſafety dear.
Shall I retreat from that ſoft chriſtian boy,
And not both him and all his ſlaves deſtroy?

sp.speaker: Eff.
sp.l: Ah if thou canſt I wiſh he were deſtroyed,
But the young prince hath all his ſkill employed,
To range his army in the • tteſt plight,
Either to wait th' attack, or meet the fight.
If you attack, they in defence remain,
And force of fire, or thunder might ſuſtain.
Huge cloud capt rocks on either wing ariſe,
Who hide their ſummits in the darkened ſkies.
A deep moraſs extends along their rear,
And half their flank, and ſhuts out every fear▪
If we attack, they're ſafe from every blow,
And hurl unpuniſhed death on troops below.
Or if they ſhould the fierce attack approve
The moment when your troops begin to move
In bogs and fens both horſe and foot muſt fall,
Slow they muſt march, if they can march at all,
Then to this ſpot if Scanderbeg ſhould come,
Entire defeat and ſlaughter is your doom.
Your troops incumbered in that marſhy ground,
May yield him victory without a wound.
There whatſoe'er our court of us ſhall ſay,
'Tis by not fighting that we win the day.

sp.speaker: Viſ.
sp.l: O worſ • than women, let us leave the field,
Allow that Turks to Chriſtian arms muſt yield.
He camps with ſkill—he will that ſkill retain,
And he as ſkilfully can camp again.
Is there no woman here, whom we might try?
She would not fear with Chriſtian arms to vie.
sp.stage: (Calls Paulina to mortify his officers: Paulina enters.)
sp.l: Say dame, what would you do to check the courſe
Of Chriſtian bands, and give our arms ſwift courſe?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: When all their men are gathered in a band,
Send out your fleeteſt horſe thro all the land.
Collect the women, whom each huſband leaves,
With all their babes, and ſell them all for ſlaves.
They once diſperſed thro all the Turkiſh lands,
With them Epirus, and her glory ends.

sp.speaker: Viſ.
sp.l: A glorious ſcheme! Effendi is your man,
Or Muſtapha, to execute the plan;
To lead the party, who with dire alarms,
Attacks the babes and wars with woman's charms.
Like waſps diſturbed they'll fight with tenfold rage,
And every clown will in the war engage.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: No other way can ever be ſubdued
A nation, which is every year renewed.

sp.speaker: Viſ.
sp.l: What other way can they their race renew;
Than Turks and other nations all purſue?
Like leaves on trees are all the race of men;
Their generations riſe and fall again.
Our Father ſlept in duſt and we ſurvive;
When we ſhall ſleep another group •• all live.
When we ſhall gain the victory, we truſt,
Whoe'er is ſlain will kindly ſleep in duſt.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: 'Tis not mere life, but morals form the ſoul.
The mind will all inferior powers control.
Your women in the haram's walls confined;
Know neither faith nor ſanctity of mind—
You keep them ſlaves, they view you as their foes.
They neither ſ •• k your bliſs, nor your repoſe.
〈◊〉 if they break their bonds, rage unconfined;
Nor dream of ſweet conſtraint within the mind.

sp.speaker: Viſ.
sp.l: And do not other women do the ſame?
What that vague ſex, but bolts and bars, can tame.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: Nay, from their infancy, each cheerful day,
The Chriſtian boys and girls together play.
Nay even in age mature, the girls are ſeen
In gayeſt paſtime dancing with the men.
They live and love at large, nor ever find,
Reſtraint, but which ariſes in their mind.

sp.speaker: Viſ.
sp.l: Impoſſible—confuſion muſt enſue,
They ſoon muſt be a baſe and filthy crew.
Some ſordid end bids you theſe tales conceive:
And deem'ſt thou that ſuch tales I can believe?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: Could I miſtake, who half my life have been
With Chriſtians, have their manners tried, and ſeen?
To you, who but as ſlaves your women deem,
Freedom with purity appears a dream.
Yet with the Chriſtians every pleaſing day;
The youth with maidens innocently play.
Some chuſe their mates and delicately love,
Like the bright Houris—the Virgins of paradiſe—whoſe delightful converſation, the virtuous, according to the Koran, enjoy after death. Houris in the world above.
Such love as by your Koran is expreſſed;
Among the ſaints ſuperlatively bleſſed.
And when they would unite in marriage bands,
The ſimple vow the parties heart command,
Their ſprightly brides retain their freedom ſtill,
See company, when, how and where they will—
The wife and huſband mutual cares employ,
Their children are their parents deareſt joy;
Theſe bred to virtue flee all vicious ſenſe,
And form the nation's ſureſt, beſt defence.
And ſhould their army fall a ſacrifice,
Another army inſtantly would riſe,
Unleſs their women be removed away,
In vain their chiefs we fight, their ſoldiers ſlay.

sp.speaker: Viſ.
sp.l: Mere fables theſe and fond chimera all!
This day decides, the Chriſtians ſtates ſhall fall.
My chiefs are cowards, but my ſoldiers feel
A courage, keener than the tempered ſteel.
Fly hence, Eſſendi, inſtant fly amain,
And hear my orders to the diſtant plain.
Let then the trumpet ſound—To arms, To arms!
Let martial glory ſpread her dreadful charms.
"This day decrees the Chriſtian ſtates to fall;
"The Turkiſh Creſcent riſe, and conquer all."

div.head: SCENE I.—MORATH and HAEMON.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: SAD is the difference of youth and age.
When I was buſy on life's buſy ſtage,
My place was ever foremoſt in the van;
Nor deigned to tremble a • the face of man.

sp.speaker: Hae.
sp.l: Our prince indeed is wiſe; he orders right
Old men in council young men in the fight—
'Twas well for the attack to give command,
Men have more courage moving than to ſtand.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Yet ſtill I 〈◊〉 . The younger prince is fled,
His ſtratagems and active force I dread.

sp.speaker: Hae.
sp.l: The prince indeed is fled, but fled alone.
Not even a centinel his cauſe would own.
Caught in the toils of vice, he vainly ſtrove
With pains extreme, to conquer traitorous love.
Loſt to himſelf, his nation, and his friends,
In this vile act his race of glory ends.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Experience ever proves the dreadful truth,
That lawleſs leve's the certain bane of youth—
While ſtill the heart is pure from wanton ſtains
The love of virtue and of good remains▪
But who to brutal pleaſures ſinks his ſoul,
Corrupts its active powers, deſtroys it whole.

But who comes here—
(Looking out, ſees Am • ſa coming guarded.)
—Sure, ſure he's taken, ſee,
O what diſtreſsful ſpectacle to me!
Ameſa guarded, and unarmed he ſtands,
And tears his golden hair with both his hands.

div.stage: [Ameſa enters unarmed—his hair looſe, his eyes dejected, &c.]

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: O worthy ſeniors, let me, let me die!
What elſe but death can bury infamy?
A traitor to my nation I have been—
I've reached, tho young, the utmoſt bounds of ſin.
Pronounce my ſentence, ſeniors, let me die—
What elſe but death can bury infamy?
I've not a prayer to make, a tear to ſhed;
O let me but be numbered with the dead.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Unhappy youth! thy ſad example proves
The dreadful dangers of unlawful loves.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: I've trod thoſe paths where mercy finds no place.
I've ſinned beyond the reach of human grace.
The ſun ne'er ſhone upon a guiltier head—
Than this which longs to ſleep among the dead.
Yet loſt to virtue and to ſenſe of ſhame—
I cannot wrong an honeſt woman's name.
The fair Circaſſian ſtill her fame retains;
And pure from me, and all my crimes, remains,
Deteſts my treaſon, and abhors my love—
And her contempt, the laſt of griefs, I prove.
Then let me die—Perhaps that grace divine,
May pardon ſins for ſorrows ſuch as mine.
Pronounce my ſentence, fix the fatal ſpot,
Let me as martial rule directs—be ſhot.
May your keen ſoldiers take a careful aim—
And end at once my ſorrows, and my ſhame.

sp.speaker: Hae.
sp.l: At once, ſad youth, we could the law declare,
The law by right muſt finiſh your deſpair.
But we the fate of battle now expect,
And what the prince our general ſhall direct.
No witneſſes we need, confeſſion ends
The proof, and anſwers all the law intends.
The prince himſelf pronounces angry fa • e,
May he be proſperous as he's good and great.

div.head: SCENE III.— (A ſingle centinel enters with a woman priſoner) —ZEPHORA and MORATH.

sp.speaker: Zeph.
sp.l: O where the valiant prince? Heaven be his guide,
The will of Heaven muſt o'er his ways preſide.
Eternal counſels aim his deeds to bleſs;
Whatever he attempts will meet ſucceſs.
What pleaſures muſt his godlike boſom feel,
When I the wondrous ſecrets ſhall reveal.
She's wrongly deemed the fair Cicaſſian maid,
Twas I who watched her in her infant bed.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Then tell year wonder—your aſſertion prove,
The noble general will reward your love.

sp.speaker: Zeph.
sp.l: If yet the glorious chief I cannot find,
I'll keep the ſecret locked within my mind.
Unleſs the good Helenor know my face,
And place good faith, in my full ripened days.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Are prieſts the only men that women truſt?
Can you not think a valiant ſoldier juſt!

sp.speaker: Zeph.
sp.l: Aye—yes, but then the prieſt moſt ſuits my mind,
Or elſe the chief moſt brave and not leſs kind.
To him a myſtery I ſhall diſcloſe,
Which ſhall our joys complete, and end our woes.
But till the prince or ſacred prieſt I find,
I keep the ſecret locked within my mind.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Go, c • ntinel, conduct her to the prieſt,
And be the ſecret from her ſoul releaſed.
If from its public fame ſuch bleſſings flow,
To fill our joys, and baniſh all our woe.

div.head:
SCENE IV.—SCANDERB ••
(entering with martal muſic.) MORATH and HAEMON.

sp.speaker: Scan.
sp.l: The battle's done, the glorious day is ours,
Thank, reverend ſeniors, to th' eternal powers.
O •• wrongs are all redreſſed by heaven's decree,
This day the chriſtian lands again are free.
Yet what a field of blood, what waſte of men,
May I ne'er look on ſuch a ſcene again.
Baſhaws in heaps there end their martial toil,
And ſlaughtered Viſiers ſwell the dreadful pile.
Juſt is the war, which truth and right defends

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: I • luſtrious chief, to heaven our nation owes,
Victory and ſafety from our mortal foes,
This glorious day, ſhall every heart rejoice,
All ranks and ages ſhall unite their voice,
To praiſe in raptured ſtrains th • eternal name,
And waft thy glory on the wings of fame.

sp.speaker: Hae.
sp.l: Now may theſe eyes contented cloſe in death,
In peace with all the world I yield my breath,
Since heaven from war, ſhall give our ſtate repoſe,
And put this glorious end to all our woes.

div.head: SCENE III.—AM • SA reentering guarded, SCANDER • EG an • HELENOR.

sp.speaker: Sc.
sp.l: [Turning to Ameſa.] BUT who is this?

sp.speaker: Am
sp.l: [Anſwers without looking up] A villain!
That is true?
O couſin thou art loſt.

sp.speaker: Am
sp.l: Death is my due,
O let me as a traitor yield my breath,
The only prize of ſuch a crime is death.
Let death atone at once for all my crimes,
Sad warning to the youth of later times.

sp.speaker: Scan.
sp.l: Thou haſt deſerved thy fate, and it muſt be,
Yet what a blaſt on my ſucceſs and me.
Victorious on▪ the field of fame I ſtood,
Yet here muſt bathe me in my kinſman's blood,
Ameſa dear to me as vital breath,
Muſt I pronounce thy ſentence, give thee death?
Is this the period of this glorious day?
That very period takes its joys away.
sp.stage: [Helenor enters, and Scander • eg addreſſes him.]
sp.l: Illuſtrious paſtor, ſee thy friend returns,
Rejoicing, and in midſt of joy he mourns.
On yonder plain, where the proud Othmans ſtood▪
There has the Turkiſh Creſcent ſet in blood.
Peace o'er the land, ſhall her ſweet branch extend,
And Chriſtian virtues ſwift from heaven deſcend,
But this unhappy youth is loſt to • ame,
And ſinks, a traytor, to eternal ſhame

sp.speaker: Hel
sp.l: No. Crowns of joy muſt ſhine on every head,
Let not a drop of Chriſtian blood be ſhed.
Thus the good ſpirit teaches me within,
Th' extreme of juſtice is a part of ſin.
Th' Almighty will the chief of ſins forgive,
The chief of traytors by his goodneſs live.
Forgive the youth, with cheerful grace, nor lay
One ſtain of grief on this important day.

sp.speaker: Scan
sp.l: Would I forgive for heaven's ſake, and thee?
Yes, blameleſs prieſt, thy thoughts with mine agree.
Take then, dear nephew, take my hand and heart,
Again from virtue never may'ſt thou part,
This crime hath coſt thy couſin tears of blood.
The grace of Heaven can change and make thee good.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: My crime is infamous, I wiſh to die.
The cheerful light is painful to my eye.
Fain would I hide in duſt from human view,
And take for all my crimes the vengeance due;
Yet ſince my death ſo dear a friend might grieve,
With ſad reluctance I conſent to live.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Live youth, and let thy better ſenſe be ſhown,
Let future virtues for thy crimes atone.
And thou, illuſtrious chief, prepare to hear,
What ſcenes of glory in our land appear.
This day, by truth▪ I ſaw the opening ſkies,
And heaven's bright viſions ruſhed upon my eyes,
Saw thee, young chief, benignant, good, and great,
With mildeſt order bleſs our happy ſtate.
Peace ſmiled o'er all the realms, and plenty flowed▪
And every ſoul was ſmit with LOVE OF GOD.
A courſe of triumphs o'er the Turkiſh bands,
Defends thine own, and all the Chriſtian lands,
For ſafe by thee, the Chriſtian ſtates remain,
Nor ſhall the world itſelf thy fame contain.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: Ceaſe holy paſtor, nor thy rank diſgrace,
By groſſeſt flattery to thy prince's face.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: 'Tis true as heaven ſhall help me, Prince 'tis true,
Then roſe thy fair domeſtic ſcenes to view,
I ſaw thee bleſt in love. Thy princeſs fair,
To make her virtue and thy joys her care,
I ſaw thy couſin, temperate, good and great,
Bend all his mind to bleſs his native ſtate,
I ſaw him meet the fair Circaſſian bride;
By ſtrongeſt ties of blood to thee allied,
She, deemed Circaſſian, on her infant day,
Was from thy native frontier borne away.
Nurſed with the Turks, is now a captive here,
Know, prince, ſhe is thy German ſiſter dear,
Whom as a ſtranger late thou didſt deſpiſe,
In thy own palace meets her brother's eyes.
This ſilver cup has ſhown this very day,
Which was with her when captive horne away,
From this ſame cup, in ſign of heavenly grace,
I poured baptiſmal waters on her face,
And ſee this mark ſhall juſtify my fame,
ELIZA CASTRIOT, ſee! her Chriſtian Name.
Great ſource of bliſs! what bleſſings doſt 〈◊〉 ſhower,
What boundleſs grace upon this happy hour.
This day to virtue, I have gained my friend,
His glories now commence, his crimes ſhall end.
This day full victory o'er the Turkiſh bands,
Gives ſmiling peace to all the Chriſtian lands.
This day from heaven, refreſhing viſion clears,
The brilliant proſpect of our future years.
This day my long loſt ſiſter I regain,
What lively joy ſucceeds to anxious pain.
Let now, my friends, loud gratulations riſe,
To fill the world, and rend the vaulted ſkies.
Tumultuous joys I change for ſofter charms,
And ſpring exulting to my ſiſter's arms.

div.head: The Maid of the Groyes. A DRAMA, IN FIVE ACTS.
A RESPECTABLE CHARACTER IS MORE VALUABLE THAN RICHES.
div.p: RICHES only make a perſon contemptible without virtue and good breeding—the man of virtue is infinitely better calculated to make his friends happy than the man of wealth—and if a perſon ſhall only be firm in the ways of virtue, there is ſcarcely an inſtance in a hundred, in which the event will not be proſperous—the arm of providence ſuſtains the heart that is honeſt—virtue can acquire friends, and wealth; but mere wealth can neither procure virtue, nor friends.

list.head: MEN.
list.item: CAPT. BLOOMSGROVE—an officer of the army of the United States.
MR. MANLY—a ſubaltern, of the army, engaged in farming.
O' CONNOR—ſervant in pay of Manly.

list.head: WOMEN.
list.item: MRS. IRONSIDE—wife to Mr. Ironſide, aunt to Julie • .
MAYFLOWER—a coquette—rival of Juliet in pretenſions to beauty.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: WHY Miſs Bloomſgrove are you ſo uncommonly pe • ſive?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I ſh • uld appear very awkward, were I to tell you my dreams.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Your dreams muſt be elegant as well as your waking ideas—tell me one 〈◊〉 diſlike it, never tell me another.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: My imagination laſt night repreſented in the moſt lively manner my father returning and approving of my whole conduct in his abſence.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: That viſion is my property —it decides a very important queſtion—if you are to be mine—This heart c •• never know tranquility till completely bleſſed in your love, or frozen by the blaſt of deſpair.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I can decide on no one's ſuit till my father returns: you muſt have patience or quit your pretenſions.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Do you remember your father's looks?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Very faintly—when he went into the army I was but four years old—they ſay I look very much like my mother—I cannot remember her.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: You are extremely like her, and a fine woman ſhe was.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I was ſo pleaſed with the imaginary ſight of my father—that when the pleaſing viſion was fled, I could not refrain from tears—How happy muſt child • en be, who daily ſee their parents and enjoy their protection.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: How did your father appear in your ſleep?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p:
A man of middle ſize, a plump round face, black eyes,
his eyebrows rather thick—his look ſedate and ſteady— and I imagined he ſhowed me a ſcar on his right arm.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: That was the very look of your father; and he was wounded in the right arm in the battle of Princeton.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: But it were fooliſh to place any dependance on dreams.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Dreams are liars—yet they may tell the truth and tell me, Juliet, who always tell the truth—whether I be diſagreeable to you—If I be I will not trouble you any more with my preſence.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: O ſir I eſteem you virtuous, well bred, and a valuable acquaintance—and on this account, eſpecially becauſe you always let me be miſtreſs of myſelf.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: He muſt be deteſtable who could think of injuring ſo amiable a perſon.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Then you muſt withdraw—for if my aunt ſhould ſee us together, I ſhould have no peace for one fortnight.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Nothing is ſo delightful to me as to converſe with you, my dear Bloomſgrove, but if my preſence be in the leaſt troubleſome, I abſent myſelf in a moment.

div.head: SCENE II.—Mrs. IRONSIDE and JULIET.
div.stage: (Mrs. Ironſide takes up Juliet's work, and looks at it)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Iron.
sp.p: LET me look of your work, Jule, ſee here, you have ſewed this on wrong. Pray what have you been thinking about? about Manly I ſuppoſe; han't you been crying and whimpering about him—hold up here—an't your eyes red?—why no, tolerably bright, brighter than common I think—he can't have been here ſurely.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Why ſhould you think of his being here? you never heard me ſpeak a word in his favor in my life.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Iron.
sp.p: And think the more—you are not ſpiteful to him, I know, for he is always tagging after you.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Why ma'am I never feel ſpiteful to any body.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Iron
sp.p: Why can't you find ſome one to your liking? I only forbid you Manly.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I cannot determine ſoon.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Iron,
sp.p: I knew it; you have a notion for a man of fine taſte and tip • top breeding—why can't they ſuit you.

sp.speaker: Jul.
