sp.p: Some are ſo rough with me that they break my fingers, and pull my dreſs all to pieces.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Iron.
sp.p: They are not all ſo rough I hope.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Some are ſo officious that they will not let me take care of myſelf—I am always • n picket guard with them— they are the moſt unſufferable coxcombs in the world.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Iron.
sp.p: Some girls like fellows that can talk and rattle away like any thing.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Yes the monied blades to be ſure—I like the ſilent ones beſt — I love to have them ſit ſtill and ſay nothing; then I'm quite happy.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Iron.
sp.p: You are peculiar in your notion.

sp.speaker: Jul
sp.p: I love propriety, if we cannot act rationally we had better not act at all.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Iron.
sp.p: What do you think of Mr. Butterford?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: He is very large, and fat, and rich.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Iron.
sp.p: Then you will not like him any better than the reſt.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I never ſaid a word againſt him. I have admitted his viſits, and certainly would • o • betray him—He ſhall ſtill be admitted if you deſire it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Iron.
sp.p: That's my good girl now, you will like him I dare ſay when you are uſed to him. He's grandly rich, and rides the fineſt horſe of any man in town—He's got a coat branfire new on purpoſe to court you in, he's coming to day: do you prim up and look ſmart: he'll cut a grand flaſh I'll warrant you, come, go to your glaſs and rig up immediately. (Juliet goes out and Ironſide after her.)

div.head: SCENE I.—Mrs. and Mr. IRONSIDE
div.stage: Front curtain draws and ſhows Mr. Ironſide at a table with a part of a loaf of bread and a cheeſe—Mr. Ironſide is eating —Mrs. Ironſide comes up to the table.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Iron.
sp.p: I REALLY think, huſband, you have eat enough.

sp.speaker: Mr. Iron.
sp.p: Why wife I hope you do not grudge your huſband his victuals.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Iron.
sp.p: You have been eating this great while and grain, huſband, is very dear.

sp.speaker: Mr. Iron.
sp.p: If you could pin ••• enough • u • of me to prevent a general ſamine it might be worth your pains.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Iron.
sp.p: I know you have eat enough. (She ſnatches away the bread and cheeſe, he catches off one end of the cheeſe then follows her to the middle of the avenue, and ſnatches off a piece of bread and returns eating, to the middle of the ſtage.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Iron.
sp.p: Rather ſaucy, fact, but a prudent wife. Rather ſaucy—but a very prudent ſaving wife (gets away)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Iron.
sp.p: Well huſband I have been talking to Jule and ſhe ſeems quite willing to let Butterford come and ſee her.

sp.speaker: Mr. Iron.
sp.p: I would not let him come, he'll eat up ſome of your bread and cheeſe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Iron.
sp.p: Jule has ſo much company that they are likely to eat us out of houſe and home. I long to have her married.

sp.speaker: Mr. Iron.
sp.p: Let her marry then: I ſuppoſe ſhe is willing enough—I muſt beat the anvil and puff the bellows, manage within doors as you will, I cares not.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Iron.
sp.p: But Juliet has a great opinion of parſon Treadwell, I have a great mind to get him to adviſe her to marry Butterford.

sp.speaker: Mr. Iron.
sp.p: Much you'll get by that: you'll have to give him a dinner and break one of our beſt jugs of beer, and then he won't give his advice unleſs he has a mind to. He is the plaguieſt fellow for a parſon that ever was—you can't make him do any thing but what is right. Hee—e —e—m—h.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Iron.
sp.p: from within. RUN, Jule, Mr. Butterford is coming. Put up and look as ſmart as you can—put on your new moroker ſhoes, and a clean ſhawl, quick, quick.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: There is no cauſe for hurrying. He is ſo fat and ſhort-breathed, that it will take him a great while to get to the houſe—yet. [She goes out very deliberately.]

div.head: SCENE III.—BUTTERFORD, Mrs. IRONSIDE and JULIET.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: [Making a very awkward bow] GOOD evening, Madam, How do ye do?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Iron.
sp.p: Well I'm glad to ſee you—Why I hardly know how I do do—but I'm fain to do whatever I have to do.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Where's Jule, is ſhe to home?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Iron.
sp.p: Yes ſhe is ſtept out, and will be in, in a minute—I don't know what makes her ſtay. Juley!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Coming ſoon ma'am.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Well how does Jule do now—I'm going to make her my offers. Do you think ſhe'll bite ſharp. No man can give a better aſtayte than I. —

sp.speaker: Mrs. Iron.
sp.p: You are well in that, Juley!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Coming ma'am very ſoon.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Iron.
sp.p: She's not quite dreſſed I ſuppoſe. Theſe girls have a deſpot notion of rigging up—when they are to meet a ſpark: that's quite natural d'ye ſee — I told Juley you'd got a new ſuit—It ſeemed to make her quite merry. —Juley!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Coming ſoon ma'am.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Then ſhe was merry to think I had got theſe clothes —I hope that is a good ſign. If I could make Jule have me I ſhould be poſſed glad—Then I'd ſit in my great chair and tell her to bring this and carry that—Then I'd laugh in my ſleeve to ſee how obedient ſhe'd be—and when ſhe waited on me like a little ſpaniel — and I'd ſpeak ſharp and make her tremble and fly—and a man would come in and ſay what a ſweet pretty wiſe you have, Mr. Butterford— Then I give him a tuck in the ribs—Hah! old fellow, why you fool, way could'nt you get ſuch a wiſe hoh! hoh! hoh!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Iron.
sp.p: Jule!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p:
(Faintly.) Coming ma'am—
(Mrs. Ironſide go • to the entrance of the ſtage—ſees Juliet weeping—and doubling her fiſt threatens Juliet.)

sp.speaker: Mrs Iron.
sp.p: What! crying again. Wipe up your eyes in one minute, and come here, or I'll know the reaſon why.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: An't ſhe willing to come, or is ſhe only a little daſh'd about being courted?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Iron,
sp.p: She'll come by and by. (Juliet comes to the entrance of the ſtage, attempts to preſent herſelf—burſts forth in tears—ſteps back—wipes her eyes, and then enters with a very genteel courtely.)

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: (Nodding his head, ſtill ſitting in his chair.) Sarvant Miſs Jule. How do you do? Jule.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Iron.
sp.p: (With a ſilly affection of cunning.) Well I may as well go away. Young folks at ſuch times don't want old folks about. [Mrs. Ironſide goes out.]

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I am ſure ma'am I am very willing you ſhould ſtay.

div.head: SCENE IV.—BUTTERFORD and JULIET.
div.stage: (Butterford ſitting, hitches his chair towards Juliet, partly backwards.)

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: WELL Jule. I think now we have a fair chance to make a bargain.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Mrs. Ironſide does all the trading in our family— ſhe has bought in her ſtock of butter and cheeſe—and

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Poh, I did not mean ſo—you're joking Miſs, let us have ſome fun? (Slaps her on the ſhoulder.)

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I do not love fun, it is the mirth of low bred people.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Whew, why won't you let me talk with you?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Yes ſir, if you will not ſay any thing that is improper.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Well then, I tell you what miſs, I expect you'll be a little ſhy at firſt juſt for the notion on't, tho you won't mean ſo—But I tell the right down truth—I come on purpoſe to ſee if we could not trade and be married; that's plain downright ſtuff now.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Do you expect to conclude ſo great an affair at once.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Why not as well as in a thouſand year— I'm willing to have you, why ſhouldn't you be willing to have me?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I muſt firſt know if we be ſuitable perſons to be united—I muſt conſult my heart to know if I have a proper regard for you. I muſt act ſeriouſly: for marriage is one of the moſt important changes of human life.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p:
O you can have no objection— I have the moſt
money, the moſt cattle, the fineſt horſe, and dreſs moſt coſtly of any man in this town, what would you have more?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: A man may have all theſe and yet be a very bad huſband.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: But how the duce can that be? money makes the man, girls love rich men, who can let them have as muſt money as they can ſpend.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: If I marry you for your money, I muſt know whether I may ſpend it or not—If that be the only motive I muſt ſpend the whole.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: You are all upon the joke now— (Slaps her on the arm and chucks her under the chin.) hoh! hoh! hoh!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Poſitively, if you will not be decent I will withdraw from the room.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: How ſhall I be decent, hoh! hoh! hoh!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Sit peaceably in your own chair, that will pleaſe me moſt—then anſwer to ſuch queſtions as I aſk you—or aſk me ſuch queſtions as I can anſwer with propriety.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: (ſits confuſed a few moments, then burſts into a great laugh.) Hoh! hoh! hoh!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: What makes you ſo merry ſir?

sp.speaker: But
sp.p: 'Tis da • n'd clever, hoh! hoh! hoh!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: What is that which is ſo clever; will you not let one partake of your mirth?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Fayther's got all the advantage of uncle Sye.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: What advantage has your father got of your uncle?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Uncle Sye's land lies on the hill, and fayther's land lies all below. Uncle Sye carries out all manner of naſty truck on his land for manyure, and fayther's land gets all the waſh of it. So fayther has clean the advantage of uncle Sye.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: (with expreſſions of contempt.) Is that of any conſequence to you and me?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: O yes! Fayther's on his laſt legs—He has had another tight ſnap of the gout—I don't know's he will die this whet—But he can't ſtand it long at this rate—Then if I have you, and he dies the eſtayte all comes into my hands.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Suppoſe I ſhould marry you, and you could get money by it, would you not wiſh me to die too?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Why that muſt be a m •• er of after conſideration.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I think the whole had better he a matter of after conſideration.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: You will let me come again, won't you?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I have not the command of the houſe. My aunt will admit you for ſhe is fond of you. But you muſt excuſe me for the preſent I muſt be left to myſelf.

sp.speaker: Juliet
sp.p: alone. Good heav'ns! what a huſband my aunt is preparing for me!—But he is rich—That is all merit with her—In all his converſation not a word of me, nor even of himſelf—but of his wealth. And could even pleaſe himſelf with the proſpect of his father's death—How much virtue or humanity can he have!—I'm poſitive I will not have him, I will die firſt. [Juliet goes out]

div.head: SCENE I. — Mrs. IRONSIDE and BUTTERFORD.
div.stage: (Entering on the oppoſite ſide of the ſtage.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Iron.
sp.p: WELL, how do matters go on? pretty well? or will ſhe • lab you off by and by?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Not very bright, tho ſhe wan't very croſs. I wanted to have touzled and ſlapt her about a little, but ſhe made me ſit plucky ſtill, and was darned tort upon me now and then.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Iron.
sp.p: My niece is very nice in her manners.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: O ſhe's cute, I know ſhe's cute—but if I could once get her under my thumb, I'd make her do more as I would have her, I promiſe her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Iron.
But.
sp.p: Pardon a joke—If all were like you, I ſhould think ſhe was—Hoh! Hoh! Hoh!

div.head: SCENE I.—Mr. TREADWELL enters and ſpeaks alone.

sp.speaker: Tread.
sp.p:
I HAVE read of the trial of fire ordial—A
lady whoſe character was ſuſpected, walked barefoot among red hot ploughſhares, with ſcarcely room to ſet her feet to the ground; and if ſhe burned her feet in the leaſt, it was concluded that ſhe was guilty. Such is the life of a Miniſter of a pariſh. Manly is a perſon whom I truly like, tho his eſtate is but moderate. Butterford is a proper clown, and a vicious fellow. The families both treat me well. The blackſmith and his wife are ſingular, but they are kind to me—They wiſh me to adviſe Juliet, my amiable pupil, to marry Butterford. Can I in juſtice do it? Certainly not. This is an ugly affair—Let me think— won't this do? Mother Ironſide loves to talk morals and have all the talk to herſelf—Suppoſe I let her go her own length, till ſhe his confuted herſelf—Will any call that prieſtcraft? Let then if they will—Nothing is more honeſt than to let thoſe, who are in the wrong, confute themſelves.

div.head: SCENE II.—TREADWELL and JULIET.
div.stage: [Juliet enters with a bundle of Books.]

sp.speaker: Mr. Tread.
sp.p: Juliet! my good girl, how ready you always are to meet me.

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: I have read the books you ſent me—They are extremely pleaſing, I am confident I ſhall be the wiſer for them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tread.
sp.p: If they be uſeful I ſhall be happy. My pupils always keep their rank in my affections next to my own children. But there is a particular reaſon for my attentions to you.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I never knew any reaſon but that you wiſh to ſee every perſon happy.

sp.speaker: Tread.
sp.p: There is a very particular reaſon. Your excellent mother, that bright example of all the virtues, in the laſt moments of her life, affectionately graſped my hand— • am, ſaid ſhe, on the confines of the world of ſpirits—My huſband muſt ſerve the ſtates in this neceſſary war—Juliet is left and extremely expoſed—look after her; direct her; keep her, if poſſible, from error and vice. This is my dying requeſt. Could I fail to regard it? This is the cauſe of all the attentions which I have given to your affairs.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p:
My uncle and aunt are very anxious that I ſhould
he married. I have had ſeveral offers. I wiſh to live ſingle till my father comes home, that I may be diſpoſed according to his pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Tread.
sp.p: I think it beſt for you to be married at a proper time. That kind of life has its thorns and its cares—but it is better than lonely, diſmal celibacy—And if you do marry a ſenſible man, a man of good ſound judgment, all other virtues will follow. You do right not to marry, as you are under age, till your father returns. It will be a particular pleaſure to him to have the diſpoſal of you himſelf.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Your approbation gives me the ſincereſt pleaſure, as it exactly agrees with my own ideas.

sp.speaker: Tread.
sp.p: Proceed my worthy girl in your virtuous courſe, I will ſupport you to my utmoſt ability.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Will you ſpeak to my uncle and aunt? I am anxious to know how they will reliſh your ſentiments.

div.stage: (Juliet goes out and he with her.)

div.head: SCENE I.—IRONSIDE, TREADWELL and Mrs. IRONSIDE.

sp.speaker: Mr. Iron.
sp.p: SARVANT ſir, I am glad to ſee you.

sp.speaker: Tread.
sp.p: How do you do my friend Ironſide. Are you well madam? you are all well I hope.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Iron.
sp.p: Pretty well ſir, and we ought to be thankful, we are apt to think very little of what we enjoy, as you told us that was a fine ſarmon, you ſaid that if we had no more than we deſarve, we ſhould have but little.

sp.speaker: Mr. Iron.
sp.p: You talk too much, wife—Mr. Treadwell has been here but a moment and you are rattling away and one can't put a word in edgeways.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Iron.
sp.p:
Do I talk? I will talk—I can talk better than you any day—If we had no more than we deſarved we ſhould have but little, yet we are always craving, tho riches are but vanity, young folks think it is grand to make a ſhow, but it is all vexation—Handſome is that handſome does. Let virtue ſhine and you'll be fine. The beſt thing in the world is peace of conſcience, and to be rich
in good work • —An't I right Mr. Treadwell? When we die we carry nothing away and our works will follow. I want you ſhould give me your opinion about our Juliet. I think it is high time ſhe was married—It is quite a charge to keep her and all her company. Mr. Butterford is rich, and can maintain her well, and would be glad to have her.

sp.speaker: Tread.
sp.p: Yes madam, but riches are but vanity.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Iron.
sp.p: But he can maintain her well, and they can make a decent ſhow.

sp.speaker: Tread.
sp.p: Very true, but it is all vexation. Let virtue ſhine and you'll be fine—Your plain maxims contain excellent truth.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Iron.
sp.p: Now ſhe has a notion for Manly, who is not half ſo rich; tho we know he is virtuous and induſtrious and all that.

sp.speaker: Tread.
sp.p: And is ſhe not right? The beſt thing in the world is peace of conſcience, and to be rich in good works —What ſignifies it to be always craving—When we die we can carry nothing away, but our good works will follow.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Iron.
sp.p: I would not give a farthing for a miniſter if he could not give better advice, and ſuch advice as one wants to have. (She goes out pouting.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Iron.
sp.p: Mr. Treadwell has given you no advice but your own, that's fact wife, ſay what you will—I wiſh you would hear him further, and then you would not pinch us all ſo about our victuals.

sp.speaker: Tread.
sp.p: There is Manly's ſervant coming in this moment.

sp.speaker: Mr. Iron.
sp.p: Excuſe me ſir, neighbor Speedwell is at the ſhop and wants his mare ſhod this minute.

sp.speaker: Tread.
sp.p: CONNOR, is it you, how does your maſter?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Very well zur, only ſick to death of love. Love zur has got the grap of him—Bad thing, that love, it has made many a clever fellow's heart ache before yet, maſter.

sp.speaker: Tread.
sp.p: And who is he in love with?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p:
Oh dear zur, that Julie, all our young fellows have loſt their fine ſenſes at her, they are as thick about her as
flies round a flop of molawſes—they will be ſipping and taſting you ſee, if they die for't

sp.speaker: Tread.
sp.p: And would he conſult me on that m •• ter? Is it any thing about Juliet? I hope not—Theſe caſes of love are even worſe than caſes of conſcience.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: You hit the right nail • maiſter—ſee what a thing it is to be a miniſter, we ſweak at them when the liquors gets here, (touching his forehead) but we can't be ſick, nor well, be in love, nor be married, be chriſtened, nor die, without a miniſter—By my ſhowl were I to grow young again, I'd go to College whether I could get there or no, and when I was out, the firſt thing▪ I'd do would be to live and die a miniſter, you ſee.

sp.speaker: Tread.
sp.p: Well, and what does Manly deſire of me?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: He would have you come till his houſe—he wants a—a—maſter's poorly, tis love, I gueſs, he's as thin as a ſhad in reeping time, ſir.

sp.speaker: Tread.
sp.p: Let him come to my houſe? I have ſomething, of importance to communicate to him.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I hope ſir, I pray you come, Maſter's a clever ſoul, he's quite poorly, and if he ſhould die with love, it would be a diſgrace to him, as long as he lives. (Connor goes out.)

div.head: SCENE III.—TREADWELL and JULIET.

sp.p: MISS Juliet will you come to my houſe in half an hour, to ſee the letters which I have received from your father?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Were there none for me?

sp.speaker: Tread
sp.p: There were not?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: That is very ſtrange. But I ſhould be glad to ſee the letters which • y 〈◊〉 wrote to you.

div.stage:
[
〈◊〉 well goes out, and as Juliet is following, Mayflower enters.]

div.head: SCENE IV—MAYFLOWER and JULIET.
div.stage: (Mayflower advances ſlowly and coldly keeps a large diſtance from Juliet.)

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: SERVANT M •• Jul •

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Miſs May • , my friend, I am happy to ſee you.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: I might be happy too if you could clear yourſelf of the charge of treachery againſt me.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p:
Charge of treachery. When did I ever 〈◊〉
with any of your affairs more than you deſired me to do?

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe you mean to make me believe that you know nothing of it.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: It is abſolutely true that I know not what you mean.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: I meant to have aſked advice how to proceed with you. But ſince you are here I will confront you myſelf—and you may anſwer if you can—Who wrote this letter to ſlander my character?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Not • certainly.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: How can you deny it—it is your own ſigning.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: It is not my hand, I ſhould be aſhamed of ſuch a ſcrawl.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: I have ſuffered ſeverely, but Mr. Daffodil, whoſe attentions I own were pleaſing, has left me with diſguſt; an • is gone to the town with Fidelia. If you have not done it, it i • beyond my comprehenſion.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: It was not I however—but let me think, yes it is the hand writing of that villain, who writes letters for Butterford—who is ſuch an ideo • that he cannot write himſelf.

div.head: SCENE I—MANLY and JULIET.
div.stage: Scene is changed to the miniſter's houſe, the ſtage repreſents his ſtudy with chairs, tables, books, manuſcripts, &c. &c.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: MY amiable friend, how happy to meet you in perſon, when the mere idea of you ever give me delight.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Your ſentiments Mr. Manly are even 〈◊〉 obliging —but to urge a declaration can only give me pain—I ſhall give no one a decided preference till my father's return, or while the hope of it remains.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Are you not at leaſt my friend?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Certain I know how to eſteem you as a man of merit—But my determination is ſacred.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: You are perfectly reaſonable, nor can I deny it, theſe hours of ſuſpenſe are almoſt inſupportable.

div.head: SCENE II.—TREADWELL and JULIET.— (All the party except Ironſide and his wife.)

sp.speaker: Tread.
sp.p: MY amiable pupil almoſt as dear to me as a daughter —I have received a letter, from your father that he ſhall not ſoon return. He has received a letter which ſtates that you died the 12th of July laſt—On which he orders me to ſell his eſtate, and he is about to embark for the Eaſt-Indies.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: O my worthy good friend—I was made to be wretched—I never ſaw my mother that I remember—nor my father ſince I was a child, except in my dreams. My relations here would throw me into the arms of a contemptible wr • tch—O ſir, can you not interpoſe to ſave me?

sp.speaker: Tread.
sp.p: Amiable girl, I regret your diſtreſs. But can I be concerned • n making, or breaking of matches—or incroach on the rights of families, my character would be loſt —very ſoon.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Now my beautiful, my charming friend conſent to be mine—I will protect you tho you may ſee your father no more—Let me be father, friend, brother, and every thing elſe to you.

sp.speaker: Tread.
sp.p: I have ſent letters ſeveral ways informing that you are ſtill alive—I may bring him back for I have written to Canton in China—But after all, his return is uncertain.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: My heart forbodes that I ſhall never ſee him again, my anguiſh is almoſt inſupportable, I reſpect you Mr. Manly. But can I think of any thing that is pleaſant when I muſt no more ſee my father—I live a wretched life with Mrs. Ironſide, confined, and almoſt ſtarved at times. This laſt ſtroke is Butterford's work. I am confident, he hires a baſe fellow to write for him. He forged a letter yeſterday to Mr. Daffodil, to ſlander Miſs Mayflower and ſigned it with my name to involve me in a quarrel with Miſs Mayflower and her family. He means to get me into his power, I had rather ſuffer death. He is a dreadful inſtance of the power of an unprincipled rich man over the poor—pity me, moſt reſpected ſir, aſſiſt a poor girl in extremity.

sp.speaker: Tread.
sp.p: Alas! what would the world ſay of me, ſhould I take yo • from your relations and guardian into my own cuſtody. It would give riſe to ſcandal. Many would reſent ſuch an intruſion on the rights of families.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Once more, my dear girl, liſten to a faithful friend. I will take you under my own protection, and defend you with my life

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: But can I 〈◊〉 in ſuch diſtreſs, on my father's account—or can I live with a bachelor. Should my father return, could I ever look him in the face?

sp.speaker: Tread.
sp.p:
We are all right and yet are all in extreme diſtreſs—Yet my dear young friends, let us do nothing wrong —Here is a trial of our truſt in Divine Providence. Be obſtinate. Virtue muſt triumph, tho we know not how.— I will think for you, and do you (approaching Juliet) retire, my good girl, whoſe heart is ſorely burdened, and pour out your tears to him who numbers the tears of the afflicted.
She is con • ucted by Treadwell to the avenue, and i •
• oarce behind the curtain when ſhe exclaims—

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: O my father! my father!

sp.speaker: C. Bloom.
sp.p: O my daughter—how like my wife—a little girl when I left you—now a grown woman—and how beautiful—my ſweet Juliet, alive and well—and O how much like her mother. (Manly goes to the curtain, peeps behind the curtain; ſees Capt. Bloomſgrove, and leaps about the ſtage in a frenzy of joy.)

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Her father is come—Capt. Bloomſgrove is come▪ as you live 'tis he, I know him. The whole company we ruſhing to the opening of the curtain, out Mr. Treadwell ſtays them.

sp.speaker: Tread.
sp.p: 'Tis he; I know him by his voice; but reſtrain your curioſity—give a parent and child a few tender moments at their meeting—Their tranſports are too ſacred for common obſervation. (Capt. Bloomſgrove appears at the entrance with his face turned partly back, talking to Juliet.)

sp.speaker: C. Bloomſ.
sp.p: Come my dear, wipe your eyes, and let us ſee the reſt of the company—Sweet girl; I left you at four years old, and you are now a grown woman—you look juſt like your mother when I was married.

div.stage: [Bloomſgrove enters, nobly dreſſed, and bowing genteelly]

sp.speaker: Tread.
sp.p: O Captain, my worthy friend, how happy to ſee you again.

sp.speaker: C. Bloomſ.
sp.p: Next to my little daughter here you are the deareſt perſon to me on earth—and who is this?

sp.speaker: Tread.
sp.p: It is miſs Mayflower.

sp.speaker: C. Bloomſ
sp.p: She was about three years old—when I went away, a little proud Sylph—I remember how ſhe would •• per when ſhe was dreſſed up.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: [Catching Mr. Treadwell's ſleeve.] This good man has done a thouſand good things for me, will you not reward him?

sp.speaker: C. Bloomſ.
sp.p: I will find a time for that my dear child. And what friend is this, Manly? Yes it is Manly; my brave Lieutenant, who ſelled the Heſſian to the ground— who wounded me in the battle of Princeton—He preſerved my life. If there be any thing in this world whereby I can reward him, it muſt be his.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: He has been generous to me and—and—honeſt.

sp.speaker: C. Bloomſ.
sp.p: I knew him my girl in the army, he is as fine a ſoul as lives—what ſhall I give you Manly? (to Manly) Will you take Juliet.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: (bowing reſpectfully) Will you let me have her?

sp.speaker: C. Bloomſ.
sp.p: Yes if ſhe be willing—what ſay you my girl— ſhe bluſhes with eyes partly caſt down, looks ſideways in her father's face, and remains ſilent.

sp.speaker: C. Bloomſ.
sp.p: Her tongue ſays nothing, but her eyes ſay yes—take her— (Quits her hand, and Manly takes it warmly.)

sp.speaker: Manly.
sp.p: Now I'm the happieſt man on this earth and the richeſt—but I will be happier in a few days by your aſſiſtance. (To Mr. Treadwell.)

sp.speaker: Tread.
sp.p: (bowing.) Any time when you pleaſe, ſhall I delight to contribute to your felicity.

sp.speaker: C. Bloomſ.
sp.p: O my friends how ſweet is domeſtic pleaſure. Riches, victory, and glory are nothing in compariſon. It is a pleaſure which I have not taſted till now for fourteen years. (Wipes his eyes which flow in tears of joy.)

sp.speaker: Tread.
sp.p: Come captain you ſhall tarry with me this night. Manly after ſupper will conduct Juliet home—and let it be known that you are come—all her enemies will be ſilent now. Miſs Mayflower tarry till after ſupper, and my girls, ſhall go home with you—come be ſeated—I will call my wife and daughters, and while ſupper is preparing we will have a ſong. (or dance) There is no crime in decent joy. It is practical Thankſgiving to the Author of all our mercies.

div.stage: They ſit. A ſong or dance is performed, as the exhibitor pleaſes.

div.head: The Coquette. A DRAMA, IN THREE ACTS.
THE FOLLY OF A CAPRICIOUS TEMPER, AND THE DISADVANTAGE OF COQUETRY TO THE GENERAL INTERESTS OF WOMEN.
div.p: IT is a very good inſtance of policy in a woman, if ſhe has engaged the affections of any man, with a view to marriage, to avoid the ſmalleſt danger of loſing them. A woman deſerted by a man once engaged to her, is ſubject to many cenſures, and dangerous ſuſpicions. Were it not univerſally known, that there are women, who uſe men extremely ill, in conſequence of gaining their affections; the deſertion of a woman, after indications of love, would ruin a man's character. Coquettes injure not themſelves only—but their ſex in general.

list.head: MEN.
list.item: MR. BOOTHBY—an honeſt houſeholder; Guardian to the two young ladies, Marcella and Daphne.

list.head: WOMEN.
list.item: MISS SEAFAIR—common friend to Marcella and Daphne.

sp.speaker: Booth.
sp.p: MY wards, the time approaches when I muſt act the part of a father to you no more. This evening I muſt give up my charge. Tomorrow morning you will be at your own diſpoſal—It was ſo ordered that I ſhould give up the guardianſhip when the youngeſt was of lawful age.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.p: I regret indeed that I muſt be left to myſelf, your kind care left me nothing to wiſh for, but the continuance of it. If we muſt be left to ourſelves, can we not have ſome kind of advice from you; ſome of your maxims which contain much wiſdom in a few words?

sp.speaker: Booth.
sp.p: I chooſe to ſay but little▪ Long diſcourſes are not apt to be remembered—Let the foundation of your character be plain honeſty and good nature. Depend principally on your virtue for your happineſs—As you both are ſufficiently genteel, affect no uncommon character, but be what nature and common ſenſe have made you. If you have a good offer, I adviſe you to marry; but not ſuddenly—let a polite acquaintance with the perſon whom you are to marry, remain for ſome time, that you may acquire the habit of pleaſing, & being pleaſed with the perſon who is to be yours for life. Never trifle with a man who ſeriouſly addreſſes you; but by all means marry a man of ſenſe, and think of no earthly things ſo much as pleaſing him, ſo long as you live.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You need not have told my ſiſter of that—She never had any company of the gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Booth.
sp.p: My niece, I hope you do not perverſely exclude them—If you do▪ I ſhall almoſt think you loſt to ſociety.

sp.speaker: Daph
sp.p: Sir I never affected gallantry. Marcella outſhines me ſo much in that, that they paſs by me, and pay all their attention to her, but perhaps I ſhall have my turn, and in the beſt time too.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You have a great faculty at hoping, and I adviſe you, for your comfort, to keep it up.

sp.speaker: Booth.
sp.p: I muſt retire to my own affairs—Good bye, my amiable wards. Remember what I have told you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: WHAT do you think of the advice the old gentleman has been giving us?

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.p: I cannot perfectly underſtand it, for want of experience in ſuch matters—but as our uncle has experienced all theſe things himſelf; and is certainly a man of ſenſe, and honeſty; I am apt to think he has told us right.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I mean to do as I pleaſe. I am glad that tomorrow morning I ſhall be at my own diſpoſal—And as to the gentlemen who pay their addreſſes to me—I mean to trifle with them as much as I pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe it, for every perſon who ſpeaks of it, thinks you treat Mr. Malcolm in a very abſurd manner; for they ſay he is a gentleman of real merit, virtuous, honeſt, polite, and of decent fortune, a man of good ſenſe in every thing but his attachment to you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: His attachment to me. I think that this is all that diſcovers his good ſenſe! Mark this, that what nature has denied us in courage, and natural ſtrength ſhe has made up in the power, which ſhe has given us, of affecting the hearts of men.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.p: And if we have that power, ought we not to uſe it to a good purpoſe?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
That I ſhall, I promiſe you. There is nothing which affords me ſo much amuſement, as to ſee how I can play with their ſenſations. When they come trembling to me to aſk for ſome trifling attention, which I am already more than willing to grant—when they heſitate, and ſtammer, with exceſſive anxie • y. To ſee how elate they will be, when they are ſucceſsful; how diſmal and forlorn▪
when they are rejected, it makes me as proud as a queen.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.p: Poſſibly one might carry that vanity too far.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You know nothing of the matter. The men never pay much attention to you. I conſider a ſuitor as worth nothing, unleſs you can treat him in as many different ways, as you can dreſs a fiſh; and ſtill find him humble and paſſive—A fiſh you know may be baked, broiled, roaſted, boiled, ſmoked and dryed—may be dreſſed with ſauce, or without, and every way makes a good diſh. So a lover ſuitable to my taſte, muſt broil with reſentment, muſt be roaſted with anger, muſt be baked by the heat of conſtant affection, muſt boil with jealouſy, muſt be ſmoked with contempt—and his very marrow muſt be dried up with anxious expectation. If I afford him any attention he muſt be elated to the higheſt degree of joy. If I deny him, he muſt ſink into the grave of diſappointment—Such a man, always paſſive as the lamb, is the man to my taſte.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.p: There are other women of the ſame taſte, but they are not always ſo happy as to realize their ideas.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I ſhall take care of myſelf for that▪

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: I WISH you would interpoſe your authority in this affair. [Exit Marcella.]

sp.speaker: Booth.
sp.p: When I was young I always did my own work, in reſpect of the ladies—I do not love to meddle with that of others.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: But as you are guardian to the young lady I can apply to no one elſe.

sp.speaker: Booth.
sp.p: My charge expires this evening, and I have given her my laſt advice. But what do you complain of?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: She has perfectly bewitched my ſon. I compare it to nothing but a ſerpent's charming a bird—I have ſeen a ſnake raiſe his neck to a lofty ſpire, his ſeal •• gliſten, and his eyes ſparkle. Then he fixes his eyes on ſome harmleſs bird, who appears to be in extreme diſtreſs; and to make efforts to get away; but the more he endeavors to eſcape, the nearer he gets to the ſerpent till he is deſtroyed.

sp.speaker: Booth.
sp.p: Is that the condition of your ſon?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p:
You may judge, as well as I, of the ſtate of
his mind, when I ſhall mention a few facts—He aſſociated himſelf with her—and has been conſtantly unhappy—He is agitated to that degree that I fear the loſs of his reaſon —Not long ſince ſhe ſent him home, on a rainy evening without a grea • coat; tho he met her on appointment. He caught a ſevere cold, and was confined a fortnight—Another time ſhe pretended that ſhe took a new beaver hat from him, and burnt it—but ſhe kept it and changed it for an umbrella. She frequently makes him do the meaneſt errands for her—ſend him all over town, to buy a penny-worth of needles, half a knot of thread, and half a yard of tape. Every way ſhe tries to injure him, and make him ridiculous—by his attachment to her. A woman who treats a man ſo deſerves to be puniſhed.

sp.speaker: Booth.
sp.p: She commonly is. The huſband having ſuch no one in his power commonly pays the old debt, with intereſt upon intereſt; but if a young man will be a fool, he muſt anſwer for it himſelf.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: My ſon Harry is as ſenſible man as any of his age, and as virtuous.

sp.speaker: Booth.
sp.p: I doubt it not. But he would reſent it, ſhould I attempt his liberty. None can free him; but himſelf.

sp.speaker: Mrs Mal.
sp.p: I hoped that you would uſe your authority in the caſe. And that you would endeavor to make her behave better▪ You ought to conſider my extreme anxie • y for my ſ • n.

sp.speaker: Booth.
sp.p: I pity you, and him ſincerely. But a woman who has that preverſe temper is of all beings the hardeſt to cure: I have given her my laſt advice; you muſt excuſe me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Alas my only remedy is patience; but I do think that a woman who makes uſe of the art of charming▪ to ſuch a purpoſe, is the moſt miſchievous ſerpent in the univerſe.

sp.speaker: Booth.
sp.p: Your own ſex too, I am glad I did not ſay that.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: IT gives me great pleaſure to ſee you ſo well, you look delightful.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I am very much out of health however, how ca •• you to think of ſeeing me to-day?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: It was by your appointment; but if you ſay the word I withdraw; I come to invite you to Mr. Sprightly's ball—but if you do not chuſe to go—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Who told you that I did not mean to go? I ſhall dreſs, but ſtay, I have not a pin to dreſs myſelf with.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I will ſtep over the ſtreet and get you ſome at the next ſhop.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: They have none fit to dreſs a d • ll with, you muſt go to Mrs. Mer • ers.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: That is two miles & an half at leaſt▪ we ſhall loſe the time▪ perhaps the others may do for the preſent.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: That's like a gentleman to be ſure, to make a difficulty of obliging his lady—if you will get me pins to dreſs me, I will go—otherwiſe I ſhall not.

sp.speaker: Mar▪
sp.p: SO you ſee, I teach him his duty. A woman who means to have a good huſband, muſt bring him up to her hand.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.p: You are not certain of his being your huſband.—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Will he brake his word—I did not treat him ſo till I got him faſt.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.p: Perhaps not ſo faſt as you imagine—If he be a man of honor, your treatment of him is very improper.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: How do you underſtand theſe matters. When did a man ever ſpeak to you—how would you treat a gentleman?

sp.speaker: Daph
sp.p: Common ſenſe tells me I ſhould treat a real gentleman kindly—if that be right—before he is engaged to me—much more ſo after, elſe I ſhould be guil • y of falſhood. The caprice of Coquettes is well known, which is the very reaſon why men do not become infamous by deſerting a woman.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You would be all honey and no vinegar. I love to torment them for variety's ſake—Let us hear your curious theory of converſation.

sp.speaker: Dalph
sp.p:
Female honor demands its proper reſerve. Yet my promiſed lover ſhould certainly have my confidence above any man in the world, he ſhould be my inviolable
friend, and confident—I would ſtudy to pleaſe him—we would adviſe and correct each other—our virtues ſhould be mutual, our joys and ſorrows united; I would mourn his diſappointments and encourage his virtues, I would imitate his virtues, and improve by his learning, I would find an endleſs variety of kind offices, and never be forced to torment him for variety's ſa • e.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And for what purpoſe?

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.p: He ſhould reward me, by being my conſtant patron, defender and friend, and by doing every kind office in his power. Previous acquaintance is the ſchool in which nature trains us up for marriage. It is obſerved by ſome reputable authors, that they who quit this ſchool too ſoon, are often unhappy; that they who torment each other will continue to do ſo after marriage—they who act rationally will not alter—they who deceive in their previous acquaintance, will after marriage be openly vicious. I have treaſured many of theſe maxims in my mind —to me if it ever fall to my lot, I intend it ſhall be the ſchool of wiſdom—and prepare my mind for the various duties of domeſtic life.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: This is queer ſtuff—think to manage love by reaſon—do ſometime tell this in the circle of our acquaintance, that we may have an infinite fund of ridicule and laughter.

div.head: SCENE III.—MALCOLM and DAPHNE.
div.stage: [As Malcolm enters, Marcella goes out as if by deſign.]

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: TELL me, Daphne, what humor is your ſiſter in now?

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.p: She adheres to her own ſyſtem—I do not ſee that ſhe relents at all.

sp.speaker: Mal
sp.p: I procured the pins for her at the next ſhop—who had the beſt, you will not tell her.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.p: No, for I do not like her ways.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I wiſh ſhe had your ideas of thoſe matters. They are excellent, or that it had been ſo ordered that I had been attached to you. But do one thing for me, and truſt me upon my word, for once. Dreſs yourſelf for the ball, and truſt me for the event.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.p: I will. (He withdraws.)

div.head: SCENE IV.—MARCELLA reenters with SEAFAIR and DAPHNE.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: WHAT fools the men are—I love dearly to plague them—I have ſent my ſpark two miles and an half only to get ſome pins to dreſs with, and I have more than a year's ſtock-by me now,

sp.speaker: Sea.
sp.p: My friend Marcella, notwithſtanding the keenneſs of your wit—I ſuſpect you are very erroneous on this ſubject.

sp.speaker: Mar▪
sp.p: I ſee you are going into our Daphne's notions, I ſuppoſed that no other perſon in the world thought as ſhe does.

sp.speaker: Daph
sp.p: My ſentiment is, that to treat others rationally, is the likelieſt way to be treated well ourſelves.

sp.speaker: Sea
sp.p: That idea is certainly a juſt one Why need human beings be ignorant of their own happineſs? I know by happy experiment that the ſeaſon in which young perſons are acquainted, previouſly to their marriage, may not only be rendered very agreeable, but extremely uſeful.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: There you have it again morals, morals, morals, forever, and upon every ſubject. Do give me volatiles for I ſhall certainly faint.

sp.speaker: Sea
sp.p: And why not moral forever? Does not our whole happineſs depend on them? To conduct well and ſucceſsfully—i • certainly the knowledge we moſt need—you have loſt time enough in quarrelling with your humble ſwain, to have made you a very prudent woman, if you had conducted yourſelf property.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Well, what do Malcolm and I fail in? Tell me, perhaps I may reform.

sp.speaker: Sea.
sp.p: Inſtead of quarrelling and uniting, contention and reconciliation again, which have •• pt you both uneaſy and unhappy for three years paſt; you might both have been improving your minds, tempers, and manners, more than in the beſt ſchool in America.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: How does that appear?

sp.speaker: Sea.
sp.p: A conſtant tendency to any object, will have its effect in all caſes, but that of impoſſibility. The deſire of pleaſing, directed to a conſtantly alluring object—wil • make a perſon ſocial, and polite. Hence perſons, attached to virtuous, and ſenſible partners, almoſt immediately diſcover in their general converſation, a better temper, and a more ſociable diſpoſition, than before.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What can they find to talk of in ſo many long interviews?

sp.speaker: Sea.
sp.p: You quarrel then, to paſs away the time, do you? Are there not other topics, even if you omit faſhions, and the ſcandal of the day? Human paſſions, and human characters, politeneſs of manners, and principles of humanity. The polite, and elegant arts; the qualities of books, and friends; and the intereſting views, which piety and morality exhibit—might claim ſome attention. And friends may make any ſubject intereſting by conſidering it in the relation which it bears to themſelves.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.p: I have long believed, that two friends may always make each other happy if they have only the neceſſaries of life. If happineſs comes ſo cheap, human beings owe their miſeries chiefly to their own follies.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: For heaven's ſake away with this dull ſtuff—I hope ſome perſon will come in, and give a change to this ridiculous converſation.

sp.speaker: Sea.
sp.p: My converſation if it be diſagreeable ceaſes in a moment—madam I wiſh you a good night.

div.head: SCENE V.— MALCOLM, MARCELLA, and DAPHNE.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Madam I am ready to conduct you to the ball.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I will be ready in a moment, (ſhe goes out, and comes in again with a coarſe checked apron on.)

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Now ſir, I will go with you.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Will you? but you will not go with that apron.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why not—It is proper to dreſs according to our company.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: My company, you mean—well, I do not object; will the company at the ball think that they are well treated? However that is none of my concern. I will go with you as you are.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No, I will not neither, the company will be affronted▪

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: You may change your dreſs.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: That is too much trouble.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Then keep it and go with me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I ſhall be laughed at.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Then ſtay if you pleaſe—But I mean to go. • I'll
wait on another lady; and I would pay no more attention to you, but that I do not love to break my word.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: That's brave! Let not that be any hindrance.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Then if you will diſcharge me, I quit you forever.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: The difficulty is to get rid of you. I have heard you ſay ſo ſeveral times before; but you did not keep your reſolution. I ſhall have you tormenting me again in a few days.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I was not provided with another lady then; but I am now. Come my ſweet Daphne, you are now the miſtreſs of my heart; will you go with me?

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.p: If my ſiſter refuſes; but ſhe ſhall ſpeak firſt.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I will not.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.p: Then I will.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What a droll figure you will make. You ſcarcely ever ſaw a ball in your life. I will dreſs myſelf this moment, and go with my uncle, that I may be there to laugh at you. [Exit Marcella.]

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Well now ſhe is gone, why may we not tarry? I have no great deſire to go to the ball; I had much rather remain here with you.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.p: I certainly have no great deſire to dance. It is what I am very little acquainted with—But let us go, and ſee that ſhe is gone. [They wihdraw from the ſtage.]

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: MISS Laurella, is Marcella gone to the ball?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: She is going with her uncle—ſhe thought you and Daphne were gone.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: No, and I believe we ſhall not go. I had rather remain with Daphne.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Then Marcella will be extremely diſappointed.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: She muſt thank herſelf for it; ſhe might have ordered it otherwiſe.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: I know it; but ſhe thought ſhe had you ſo ſecure, that ſhe might treat • ou any way; and you would not dare to reſent it.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: She is not the firſt woman who has found herſelf miſtaken in ſuch a matter; and perhaps will not be the laſt.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: I believe it, and am ſenſible that the conduct of Marcella was extremely ungrateful to you.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: She thinks now that I ſhall return to her, but ſhe will ſoon perceive her error.

sp.speaker: Lau
sp.p: Yet ſhe was really attached to you, and will ſeverely feel the loſs of you▪

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Why then did ſhe treat me in that manner?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Nature made her a coquette, and ſhe could make herſelf otherwiſe.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Is Daphne of the ſame diſpoſition?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Certainly ſhe is not. There is ſo great a difference between them, that I could hardly ſuppoſe them ſiſters.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Let who will take Marcella, I have long wiſhed for an opportunity to break my chain. She has given me a fair one, and hence forward the mild, the ſweet Daphne ſhall be the object of my attention.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.p: WHAT has Marcella done with herſelf?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: She is gone to the ball with her uncle in full expectation of ſeeing you there, and laughing at you.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: She is welcome to her all felicity, I have borne her tyranny long enough.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: No body will blame you, I am confident. Every perſon ſaid you bore with her too long.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: The point of honor was the thing, I had given my word, ſhe ſays that need not hinder me from leaving her, ſo I have a purlough at all points.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Certainly you have.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Many another poor ſlave has, I dare ſay, been glad of his diſmiſſion, but I am no ſooner free than I am a captive again. I have long noticed your virtues; and now wiſh to give my permanent homage to you.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.p: You muſt allow me time to conſider of that— but if I finally conclude to detain you, I ſhall not keep you in perpetual torments; as Marcella did.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
My acquaintance with your ſiſter gave me an opportunity to obſerve your virtues; and it was the kind
relief of my mind, by your gentle and rational converſation, which made me think of breaking the fetters of the imperious Coquettè.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.p: Time, and acquaintance, only, can ſhow whether we be ſuited to each others manners. But I ſhall endeavor to conduct myſelf properly.

sp.speaker: Nem
sp.p: SOME buſineſs with Mr. Boothby occaſioned my calling this evening.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: He is in the oppoſite room.

sp.speaker: Nem.
sp.p: Juſt returned from the ball; you did not tarry ſo long as you commonly did with Malcolm.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I only went to ſee them a little while.

sp.speaker: Nem.
sp.p: It is droll enough. You and Malcolm have had a breaking off this evening; and he went with your ſiſter Daphne; you may give him up for loſt—the ſweet, and delightful manners of your ſiſter will detain him forever.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What a blockhead he was to break his word with me? I am purſuaded he never will proſper.

sp.speaker: Nem.
sp.p: After you had releaſed him from it?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I did it in a pet. I am extremely mortified, and ſee that you enjoy it—Enjoy it you may; for I am quite in the humor to puniſh myſelf. But that he ſhould attach himſelf to that honeſt, good natured, awkward thing, my ſiſter Daphne.

sp.speaker: Nem.
sp.p: She is no ſiſter of your's—you was indeed bro't up with her—but your parents are unknown to us—Nor have you any portion out of the eſtate, which you have ſuppoſed to belong in common, to you▪ and Daphne—you have only £. 120 to purchaſe furniture for a houſe. The whole eſtate is Daphne's— She being the only child.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Then I have loſt a happy opportunity of eſtabliſhing myſelf in life. Was ever girl ſo unfortunate? I will aſk Mr. Boothby. I do not believe it.

sp.speaker: Nem.
sp.p: I thank you for diſputing my word, and wiſh you a good night.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I AM moſt unfortunate, my dear uncle, pray comfort me a little. Is not Malcolm a villain?

sp.speaker: Booth.
sp.p: I cannot blame him—You treated him very ill; and challenged him to leave you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nemeſia always hates me. She has told me I am not your niece, and that the whole eſtate is Daphne's.

sp.speaker: Booth.
sp.p: All that is true; but it is a myſtery that ſhe ſhould know it— You ruined yourſelf by loſing Malcolm. But you would take no advice.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: When I have once caught a man in the toils of love, I muſt plague him—It is my nature, and I ſhould do it again if I died for it.

sp.speaker: Booth.
sp.p: I believe it, I never knew a woman of that perverſe temper to reform—But they may not begin it, if duly warned—It is certainly the ruin of the woman who is ſo inclined, and a great damage to the intereſt of the ſ • x. For what is the very reaſon, why a man does not loſe his character in deſerting a woman, to whom he ſtands engaged—but this; that the caprice of coquettes, is ſo generally known.

div.head: The Inſol • able Queſtion. A DRAMA, OF ONE ACT.
PRUDERY AND FORWARDNESS ARE EQUALLY PERNICIOUS TO WOMEN.
div.p: IT is altogether abſurd for women to think of captivating the men—by throwing themſelves forever in their way. This mode of conduct will only create diſguſt—and there is as little of charm or attraction in the behavior of a Prude.
div.l: "The honor of a Prude is rage and ſtorm—
"'Tis uglineſs in its moſt frightful form."

list.head: MEN.
list.item: MR. DILEMMA—a S • ph of the college, and a Pedan • .

list.head: WOMEN.
list.item: MISS WINDFALL—a jealous girl, young and gay.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: MY dear Lucinda, what a happy girl you are, your company is deſired by all people old and young— and every perſon ſpeaks of you with pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I am ſorry for that, the view of too many will be directed to me—It would coſt me much trouble—I ever tho't it an unhappineſs to be too much the object of admiration.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: Why, how can any perſon be loved and admired too much? I ſhould like to be admired by every body.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Your ambition then muſt deſcend very low ſometimes.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: I did not mean exactly ſo neither. But there is a certain claſs whom I ſhould wiſh to be in raptures with me, whenever they ſaw me—I ſhould not care much about old people.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: There you differ from me — The ſentiments of people who are not of our own age may be of great uſe to us. They can give us credit and a good name—But I doubt whether it is right to ſeek the particular admiration of many perſons of our own age at once.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: You, it ſeems, are very ſcrupulous.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Were the perſons, from whom attention to young ladies might be expected, diſtributed among us all, there would ſcarcely be one apiece—Were it then poſſible, I ſhould ſuppoſe it unjuſt, to engroſs a number. I had rather enjoy the beneficial ſociety of one true friend, than be the dupe of twenty flatterers — To flatter a lady that is really deſerving, is very much like painting a diamond to make it ſhine.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p:
I am not very fond of flattery; but it may do
when one can get nothing elſe. It is more pleaſing to hear good ſenſe, or what we call good ſenſe; but I had rather men would flatter me than ſay nothing.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: The whole buſineſs is commonly artificial. A man uſes flattery as muſicians do the fa, ſol, la, me, of their gamut, to put their voices into tune. When one knows the artifice, it ſoon becomes tireſome. But tell me, my friend, if you be ſo fond of admiration, by what means you have attempted to ſecure it.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: I have in various ways tried to accompliſh my purpoſe. They may all be reduced to one principle—that of doing things extraordinary But my friends ſeem to be growing more & more indifferent to me every day—I ſhould be glad, if by converſing with you I could ſet my ideas right.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why ſo much anxiety on the ſubject?

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: Becauſe you know one wiſhes to be acceptable, let matters, other wiſe, be as they may.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I am ſorry that you have been ſo much mortified. It muſt be bitterneſs to a woman of ſpirit. But before I give my ſentiments, let me know the method you have hitherto practiſed. The phyſician always examines his patient, before he preſcribes a cure.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: Well, to make the matter clear, I will introduce to you my illuſtrious couſin, Miſs Bridget Crowbar.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p:
(aſſ • on as ſhe enters)
I AM really aſhamed of the ladies of theſe times—They marry as if they were made •• ly for the happineſs of the men—I'm out of all patience.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: No madam, you muſt not be affronted; thay will ſome of them take notice of you yet—The men, I mean.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: That's none of my meaning—I'll have you to know—modeſty wins the love of all our acquaintance. I love to drive a principle quite to a violent extreme.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: That I have thought of, and I have been modeſt: I have been violently modeſt, have I not?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I thought modeſty always avoided violence and extremes, and brought every action to the teſt of reaſon and diſcretion.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: I profeſs to be the white roſe of modeſty.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
And beſet, I believe, with a double portion of
thorns—You will keep the men at a diſtance, I dare ſay.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: That I will—I will not be courted but adored— My lovers ſhall worſhip me at an immenſe diſtance.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How do you think a young lady ought to behave in preſence of gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: She ought to be as croſs as vengeance, and not ſay a word to them.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Not if they aſk her queſtions?

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Then ſhe muſt anſwer, no—in a faint mincing voice—and liſp a little—A woman ſhould never ſay yes to a man—That's very immodeſt.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Suppoſe a man ſhould aſk her, whether ſhe made a point of being virtuous—what? muſt ſhe ſay no then?

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: There may be extraordinary • aſes; in theſe one may ſay yes.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I take it the moſt extraordinary queſtion a woman is ever aſked is, whether ſhe will conſent to be married— ſhe muſt always ſay yes—in ſuch a • aſe then.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: You are a wicked creature. I do not know what will become of you —I ſuſpect if you were courted you would be married in leſs than eight years—It ſeems as if modeſty was baniſhed from the earth—I have tried to keep it up. But all my ſex is ſunk into degeneracy—woful degeneracy.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Propoſe yourſelf then as a pattern to all the world.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: I am lo • h to propoſe myſelf as an example—But I can find no other—Now I have meant to let the young gentleman ſee how much I avoided them.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How did you do this?

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Mr. Tiptoe is coming, I will ſhow how it is done.

div.head: SCENE III.—Mr. TIPTOE (entering) and Miſs BRIDGET.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.p: MADAM your moſt obedient humble ſervant.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: (Receding to the fartheſt part of the ſtage.) Sir?— (ſeats herſelf prim and bridles up)

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.p: Madam if my converſation could be tho't agreeable (offers to ſeat himſelf by her; ſhe removes, places an empty chair between him and her, with the back towards him, and draws another chair before her, and ſays)

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.p:
I could wiſh madam—
(ſurveys her around—at laſt removes the chair at her ſide and ſeats himſelf by her—and lean •
towards her—ſhe takes a large pin and ſtabs it into his fleſh near his knee.)

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: There ſir. (He ſtarts up and exclaims.)

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.p: O you beaſt—I meant to ſay that you was too ſevere, I aſk pardon—But I ſhall trouble you with my company no more. (Rubs the wounded part as he goes off.)

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: (with an air of triumph) There! I have ſerved many a one ſo in my life time—I have ſhed more blood in my life-time, than has been ſhed in twenty duels, ſuch are told of in our newſpapers—A fellow went to ſeat himſelf by me, the other day; he was intoxicated by my beauty.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: That was extraordinary, what did you do in that caſe?

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: It was a dreadful trial for me. (Whining.) But I overcame. (Triumphantly.) He ſpake, I knit my brow into frowns, he turned to me his face, I immediately turned mine from him; he came ſo near to me that I 〈◊〉 his breath.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What did you do then?

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: I boxed his cars well: and I have done greater exploits than that.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What? I am ſure I never heard of any more extraordinary.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: One particular piece of conduct I can't help bragging of a little.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What is that?

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: A few evenings ago, Mr. Complaiſant, finding me a mile and half from home, in a very dark and ſlippery night, very handſomely (to do the creature juſtice) conducted me home.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I ſhould ſuppoſe you would have thanked him for it.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Fye and I am aſhamed of you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What did you do?

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: What did I do, why when I got home he ſaid I ſhould allow ſome little decent complaiſance, for waiting on me ſo carefully.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You tho't it reaſonable I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Not I—As he came a little too near me, I put my ten claws right into his face, I warrant I pealed it well.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Then you do not wiſh the men to reſpect you.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: Don't I, that I do—They admire me—They'll break thro every obſtacle and marry me by and by, whether I will or not.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: They will do otherwiſe than I expect; certainly, if they do as you ſay.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: I am afraid I ſhall not convince you, ladies; ſo I go where my advice is more deſired—But I can tell you, ladies, that Diana of the Epheſians, who was worſhipped as a goddeſs, was the perfect tigreſs of her ſex.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: The men, I imagine, are not ſo fond of worſhipping tigreſſes in theſe times.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: If I take up a principle, I never give it up. What is right will come to right at laſt. [Exit Bridget.]

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Now to know how Miſs Crowbar's principles relate to ſucceſs in life; we muſt ſee whether they made her happy.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: They have not, the men hate her beyond all bounds—Tho ſhe expects that ſome one among them will very ſoon be ſo enamoured of her ſuperlative excellence, as to break thro all bounds; and inſiſt on marrying her—But there is no appearance of it at preſent.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What counſel do you propoſe to take next?

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: I am reſolved upon nothing—I juſt mention Miſs Jemima Toogood—She adviſes to the oppoſite extremes— to change the tables with the ſwains, and purſue them in turn—If you make direct advances to the men, write letters, billetdoux &c, unaſked—or let them take a good deal of liberty—there is no harm in it; if the intereſt of virtue be ſecure—theſe are her maxims.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
If the intereſts of virtue be ſecure—That is a great i •
indeed—now if this ſame IF can preſerve us from folly, after we have parted with diſcretion—it ſhall forever after be printed in capitals, I ſhall never admit her propoſition while I have my ſenſes.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p:
Theſe ladies are a curious-contraſt: their reading is as ſingular as their conduct. A book which was owned by Miſs Crowbar, repreſented in the burleſque, a man who was in purſuit of a prude—kiſſing the ſhadow of her glove on the wall; while ſhe held her hand near a candle —Miſs Crowbar gravely obſerved, that ſhe wondered why
that ſhould be tho't burleſque, for it was being quite to • familiar with the lady; conſidering he had paid her only two years attendance; and ſhe baniſhed the book from her library.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: If ſuch was the reading of Miſs Bridget, it would be curious to know that of Miſs Toogood.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: It was chiefly of Anecdotes, and SECRET HISTORIES, with a ſmall addition of very amorous plays—Her books were all of the caſt which melt rather than warm the heart; and confound rather than enliven the imagination. She is not at all to my taſte; and you need not fear my following her example or advice—But now it is your turn, you ſhould introduce ſomebody—or diſmiſs our conference.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: There is a man of my acquaintance in the college, a very good man in the main—Indeed he is a little too apt not to hear readily, when one ſpeaks to him; to talk to ladies with his back turned to them; to pair his nails in company, or ſo—but he is reputed a ſcholar nevertheleſs, and is I believe, a very good man.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: How ſhall we obtain his opinion?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: He was to have called here to day—The time is paſſed that he ſhould have come—heigh—he is knocking now.

sp.speaker: Dilem.
sp.p: LADIES your ſervant! your ſervant!

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: Will you pleaſe to take a ſeat?

sp.speaker: Dilem.
sp.p: It is as hot as mount Veſuvius to day. You have heard of the volcanoes, ladies, I ſuppoſe—Virgil deſcribes one in a very grand manner.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: We have heard of volcanoes—But we were talking of ſomething very different; of the moſt pleaſing mode of converſation for—Ladies.

sp.speaker: Dilem.
sp.p: How to mix the jucundum cum dulci.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: No 'tis not about jumping or mull'd cider. Something more curious than that.

sp.speaker: Dilem.
sp.p: Of what the Greeks, to pronounce the finale a broad, kalo cagathâ.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: Oh no ſir, it is not about kale, nor cabbage ſlaw; but—

sp.speaker: Dilem.
sp.p: I believe I underſtand you madam—There is ſomething about it in Ariſtotle.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: I did not know that ſir.

sp.speaker: Dilem.
sp.p: Xenophon abounds with it, more than any other author.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: Sir, (ſmiling) let me tell you my deſire if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Dilem.
sp.p: O yes, madam, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: It is a queſtion of the greateſt importance—And it is this: which is the greateſt diſadvantage to a lady— to be too forward or too prudiſh.

sp.speaker: Dilem.
sp.p: Aye, that is a great matter—it is a ſubject not unknown to the ancients—much was ſaid of it between the Pithagoreans and Peripatetics—The Lyceum and Academus were divided about it.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: Well ſir, we ſhould be glad to hear you diſcuſs the ſubject.

sp.speaker: Dilem.
sp.p: I muſt take it up, pro and con, according to mode and form—We muſt handle it in our own way.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: As methodically as you pleaſe, if we can only only underſtand it.

sp.speaker: Dilem.
sp.p: For the firſt general propoſition. It is thus— whether that which is generally called forwardneſs in a woman, can ever be for her advantage. Now upon this queſtion there are thirteen good reaſons againſt it—and Firſtly, that if a woman be too forward, the men will always hold her in contempt—Secondly—

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: O dear ſir, you have ſaid enough on that point— you may paſs to another. Pray tell us the reaſons why a woman ſhould not be a prude.

sp.speaker: Dilem.
sp.p: They are reckoned fourteen—but the thirteen againſt forwardneſs, tho leſs in number, are thought to be ſtrongeſt.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: Will you pleaſe to recite them?

sp.speaker: Dilem.
sp.p: Firſtly—if a woman keep a man at a mile's diſtance, he never can be ſociable with her—

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: O ſir! your propoſitions are quite deciſive—I fancy you are a great ſcholar.

sp.speaker: Dilem.
sp.p: Why ladies, it has been tho't at college, that, tho prudery & forwardneſs are oppoſite cauſes in the order of nature; yet the effect of them comes to the ſame thing in Greek.

div.head: SCENE VI.— Miſs WIND • ALL and LEMIRA.

sp.speaker: Wind.
sp.p: LADIES you mean me, I know you do?

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: Mean you, I did not know that you was within a mile of us.

sp.speaker: Wind.
sp.p: It is not true that I held Tom Longſhanks a whole evening in my lap.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: I did not ſay you did.

sp.speaker: Wind.
sp.p: And it is as great a lie which was told about me, that I ſent a letter to Joe Moonſhine—with our hearts united, for the firſt ſalutation.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: I never ſaid any ſuch word that you or any body elſe did.

sp.speaker: Wind.
sp.p: I'm glad, ladies, if you are clear: but as you was talking about forwardneſs among the ladies, I thought you meant me.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: Not I, by any means, if you have any thing of that kind to ſettle with your own conſcience, you may ſettle it alone if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Wind.
sp.p: I am obliged to you ladies, but if I did as bad as they tell of me, it was not ſo bad as Miſs Crowbar; who, when a young gentleman came near, wounded him ſo with the points of her ſciſſors, that the blood ſpouted to a yard's diſtance, and they were obliged to ſend for a ſurgeon to take care of him. (Enters Madam Senſible.)

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: No, no Miſs Windfall, we meant nothing of this kind—but we were only enquiring what was the ſureſt method of behaving acceptably; we found that the forward woman and the prude were equally unſucceſsful we wiſhed to know the right way.

sp.speaker: Wind.
sp.p: I believe that madam Senſible can tell you.

div.head: SCENE VII.—Mad. SENSIBLE, LUCINDA and LEMIRA.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: MADAM we have enquired of many ſenſible perſons, how a woman may be acceptable to the other ſex—She that is too fond of them, in the firſt inſtance, ſails, and ſhe that is too ſhy—We ſhould wiſh for your opinion on juſt conduct.

sp.speaker: M. Sen.
sp.p: I do not imagine myſelf qualified to decide ſuch important queſtions.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: O madam, you, if any perſon can.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: You are the only perſon in the world; teach me how I may be agreeable.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p:
I am not a profeſſor of gallantry—But all the arts which I believe to be neceſſary, are comprehended within a very ſmall compaſs. Young ladies ſhould have honeſt
hearts, virtuous principles, and ſhould be educated to decent manners, before they ſee much company of young gentlemen. Theſe being granted they need not affect, any extraordinary character. They will pleaſe moſt by avoiding all affectation, and appearing juſt what they are—They are beſt to appear what nature, illuſtrated by a good education, has made them—They who are never rude in their behavior, will ſeldom be treated with rudeneſs—women may even be grateful to men, for their generous attentions, if they converſe with them ſenſibly, and with proper, and decent manners—And if men will not converſe in this manner, there is no need of quarrelling with them, or offering them any perſonal abuſe. The ſevereſt and moſt effectual puniſtment, is to leave them to their own ſociety—Theſe are not artifices, but comprehend the ſimple, juſt conduct, of a virtuous woman—I would not have any woman affect the extremes of behavior—the medium in my opinion is the ſafeſt, becauſe it is the righteſt.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: Madam we thank you.

sp.speaker: Think.
sp.p: WELL, there never was ſuch a wretched author, I believe, as he who wrote this Dialogue.

sp.speaker: Dom.
sp.p: Why the ſentiment is bro't to a point and yet there is no change of fortune or ſign of a cataſtrophe in the piece—It ends with a tame moral ſentiment—good enough 'tis true but no remarkable event to ſet it off I am worried prodigiouſly. I am afraid I ſhall never make it take. Pray were is the author of it.

sp.speaker: Pale.
sp.p: WHAT is your will gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Dom.
sp.p: Only ſee, what a piece of work you have made— here my ſcholars you ſee are all at a ſtand—cannot move on with the Drama. You have bro't them into the moſt ſhocking hobble—I expect we ſhall be obliged to break off ſhort; and go off the ſtage with lopt ears—for there is not a ſign of a cataſtrophe to the piece—what put it into your head to leave the Drama without a cataſtrope?

sp.speaker: Pale.
sp.p: Why, ſuppoſe you had played it off without a cataſtrophe, what ill conſequence would have come of it?

sp.speaker: Think.
sp.p: Why the critic • would maul it unmercifully.

sp.speaker: Dom.
sp.p: The people would clamour againſt it.

sp.speaker: Think
sp.p: The democrats will ſay, it was done on purpoſe to introduce monarchy.

sp.speaker: Dom.
sp.p: The ariſtocrats, will ſay 'twas meant againſt the Federal government.

sp.speaker: Think.
sp.p: It will get to the univerſity, and the ſcholars will declaim againſt it.

sp.speaker: Dom.
sp.p: The Government will ruſticate it.

sp.speaker: Think.
sp.p: The metaphyſicians will ſay you are non compo • .

sp.speaker: Dom.
sp.p: The aſtronomers will ſay you are excentric.

sp.speaker: Think.
sp.p: The lawyers will ſay you ought to be nonſuited.

sp.speaker: Dom.
sp.p: The phyſicians will deteſt it as a peſtilence.

sp.speaker: Pale.
sp.p: That's a miſtake, peſtilence is all in their favor.

sp.speaker: Think.
sp.p: The Clergy —

sp.speaker: Pale.
sp.p: Hold ſir you ſhan't ſay a word about the clergy; they have reproaches enough from other quarters. But here you blame me unmercifully. What? do you think all ſubjects can be treated exactly alike—There is Dr. Burgo, who is as great a critic as any—I'll leave it to him, if you dare; to ſay, whether I have done right or not.

sp.speaker: Pale.
sp.p: SIR I am moſt unmercifully accuſed by theſe people for not giving this Drama a regular cataſtrophe—The ſubject ſir, is whether Prudery or Forwardneſs be moſt prejudicial to women—I wiſh you to inform me, whether this ſubject be capable of a regular concluſion.

sp.speaker: Burgo.
sp.p: Ladies and Gentlemen. It is my opinion that this author is excuſ • able—Solomon himſelf could not deſire acceptability in love matters—All that we can ſay, is, that all affectation, and extremes of character, ought to be avoided. But which is the moſt pernicious to women, that which is called Forwardneſs or Prudery— will forever remain an Inſolvable Queſtion. Between theſe two large extremes—there is a wide field for the exerciſe of diſcretion— So pardon neighbor Paleface, let him give his hand to which lady he pleaſes, and lead off the ſtage.

div.head: The Match Diſſolved. A DRAMATIC DIALOGUE, IN THREE ACTS.
THE MEANNESS OF FORTUNE HUNTING.
div.p: THERE can be no greater inſtance of inſincerity; than to pretend love for the ſake of getting money. Conſequently there is no character among men, more properly the object of contempt, than a fortune hunter. Diſproportionate matches, in point of eſtate, bring inſult on the part of the monied party; contempt and diſguſt on the other—And why ſhould not the woman be contemptible too, who ſets her cap at a man of fortune, when once ſhe has learned to write her name, and is able to buy her a ſilk gown?

list.head: WOMEN.
list.item: AUNT GRISSEL—an old maid, ſiſter to Mrs. Honeycomb.
LEVINA—a friend and confident of Maria.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: MY deareſt wife, the condition of our marriage has been extremely pleaſing to me; tho it is not wholly without its cares—I believe there is no perfectly unmixed happineſs in this world.

sp.speaker: Tart.
sp.p: I have often told you ſo, and there are troubles now I find—cheeſe and butter are likely to be very dear, and we have not laid in our win • er's ſtock of pickles.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: That is a matter of very ſmall conſequence—but the young man whom we hired to teach our Maria muſic, is paying his addreſſes to her moſt ſincerely.

sp.speaker: Tart.
sp.p: A blockhead, a little impudent coxcomb. He court our Maria! 'Tis impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: You will find it but too true, I am afraid her affections are ſo engaged to him, that I never ſhall be able to diſengage her▪

sp.speaker: Tart.
sp.p: Do puniſh him well, huſband; I'd be revenged on him, I would break his back.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: What, break his back for being fond of an agreeable girl—My own back on that principle would have been broken before this day.

sp.speaker: Tart.
sp.p: But I can't bear it, that ſuch a fop as he ſhould have our Maria.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: I will prevent it, if poſſible, without breaking his back, or his head; but I am very much afraid that the affair is paſt remedy.

sp.speaker: Tart.
sp.p: This comes of her learning muſic.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Let us not have any words, my dear, on that matter—you was as fond of her learning muſic as I, but we were both much to blame.

sp.speaker: Tart.
sp.p: Why I have always told her ſhe muſt not pretend to like any of the young fellows without my leave; and I have never given her any leave about it.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Girls do not always wait for their mothers leave in thoſe matters. But we were more to blame than ſhe, to hire him into the houſe and let him have acceſs to her at all hours.

sp.speaker: Tart.
sp.p: But girls need not throw themſelves away neither, if their parents do give them liberties.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: It is poſſible they may be affected with kind, and tender attentions as well as men. I have no diſpoſition to quarrel with her.

sp.speaker: Tart.
sp.p: I'd quarrel with him then, and I ſay again, if I could not make him leave her otherwiſe, I'd break his back.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: It is my ſerious opinion that the parents who take a gay young man into the family as an inſtructor to their daughters, are more to blame than their daughters, if conſequences ſhould not be agreeable—But I ſhall uſe my beſt endeavor, to remove the evil, and in the eaſieſt manner poſſible.

sp.speaker: Tart.
sp.p: GRISSEL, do you know any thing of any peculiar friendſhip between our Maria, and Mr. Semibreve?

sp.speaker: Griſ.
sp.p: There is, ſo far as I can gueſs, every ſign, that ſhe is fond of him. I ſaid nothing about it becauſe you often blame me, for intermeddling in the affairs of the family.

sp.speaker: Tart.
sp.p: But when you ſaw any thing likely to take place, which muſt hurt the family extremely, you ought to mention it.

sp.speaker: Griſ.
sp.p: How ſhould I know how it would turn? perhaps you would have ſaid, in one minute, that I meddled, becauſe I was envious; and the whole family would have pointed at me becauſe I was the old maid.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Hem! we may have carried that matter too far.

sp.speaker: Griſ.
sp.p:
I find married people in general have a d • ſguſt againſt old maids. But why ſhould they be treated as the worſt of criminals. You never would have married a man,
who was diſagreeable to you — would you? (To Tartana.)

sp.speaker: Tart.
sp.p: Moſt certainly I would not, I ſhould rather have died.

sp.speaker: Griſ.
sp.p: So I think, and tho you urged me ſo much to marry Mr. Landworth; he was ſo diſagreeable to me; that I am perſuaded, if I had married him, I ſhould have died within three months.

sp.speaker: Tart.
sp.p: Then I don't know why you ſhould be blamed— but have you never adviſed Maria better?

sp.speaker: Griſ.
sp.p: Yes, but ſhe never would take any notice of me.

sp.speaker: Tart.
sp.p: Then I wiſh you would talk with her again—and ſchool her well.

sp.speaker: Griſ.
sp.p: Why would you not do it yourſelf?

sp.speaker: Tart.
sp.p: Becauſe I am apt to get into a paſſion, and if I ſhould, and abuſe her, I ſhould be ſorry for it afterwards.

sp.speaker: Griſ.
sp.p: Well now, ſince I know you will approve of it—I will talk with her upon the ſubject—and I ſhall give it to her well—I wiſh to puniſh her—I ſhall do it with a goodwill—becauſe ſhe is often vexing me about being an old maid.

sp.speaker: Griſ.
sp.p: WELL, Miſs, where's your Butterfly? Shall we not expect him fl • ttering about here to day?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: If you wan't him for your amuſement—perhaps he may be.

sp.speaker: Griſ.
