sp.p: Want him for my amuſement! I care not for him the value of his own fiddleſtick; and I wonder you can be fond of ſuch a coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: A coxcomb do you call him? Truly he is fond of ornament, which ſhows him to be a neat, and cleanly man; and attentive to our ſex—and you know that kind of attention, is agreeable to all women.

sp.speaker: Griſ.
sp.p: I wiſh to know whether you expect to live upon love, and muſic; without any ſolid eſtate? Fa, ſol, la, twedle dum and twedle-dee, muſt be poor conſolations in an empty houſe and ſtarving family.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: So you muſt deal in your diſmals. That's always the way with a woman, when ſhe's fit for nothing elſe.— But I dare ſay, he'll provide for every thing that is neceſſary.

sp.speaker: Griſ.
sp.p: Let him pretend what he will, he never ſhould trouble me with his addreſſes.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: He would not, I am confident for they would be to you the greateſt conſolation imaginable▪

sp.speaker: Griſ.
sp.p: I'd ſettle the matter quick. He ſhould not court me long.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe not, for you would comply ſo eaſily, and promptly; that there would be no occaſion for a long courtſhip.

sp.speaker: Griſ.
sp.p: No he ſhould not ſo much as darken my doors.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No for his preſence in your fancy would be much brighter than the day.

sp.speaker: Griſ
sp.p: You know, you ſaucy, impudent creature, what I mean, well enough. I mean, that I would not let him come after me at all.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No, for you would meet him more than half way— and follow him to the ends of the earth.

sp.speaker: Griſ.
sp.p: You are ſo ſaucy, there is no bearing with you: and were it not that it is a ſhame for ladies to quarrel; I would give you a good thumping, that I would.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: MY friend, I cannot think it ſafe to truſt to a future maintenance, unleſs he is engaged in ſome buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: It has often given me the moſt ſerious concern— for I perceive that I cannot reſign him without pain—yet I have had many ſerious hours of reflection, if he does not apply himſelf to any ſteady buſineſs how we ſhall be able to live in any credit, or reputation—and indeed, how we ſhall be able to live at all—for my fortune is not ſo great as to laſt forever, without any further income.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: How ſtrange we young folks manage between ourſelves. The idleneſs of a young man, who is agreeable, always gives us great pain—yet we treat them as if it were well that they were always idle—by affecting to be above the laborious employments of life ourſelves.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
And the young gentlemen have the ſame abſurdity in their treatment, of us. They expect every thing of us, of delicacy and propriety of conduct. And yet often
behave towards us, as if they would have us be the reverſe.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: That is very true. But in both caſes reaſon ſhould bear rule, in ſpite of cuſtom. And, were I in your caſe— I certainly, before I bro't myſelf into any engagement—I would know whether he meant to follow any ſerious buſineſs—for the mere profeſſion of muſic, will never ſupport any perſon with reputation; unleſs it brings more profit, than it does among us.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I am of your opinion, and ſhall have the diſcretion to ſee to that point myſelf.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: And, (I muſt leave you for a moment) I would not paſs over that matter ſlightily. (Exit Levina.)

sp.speaker: Sem.
sp.p: MARIA, my dear delight, happy, and cheerful, I hope as you always are.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You would make me happy were it in the power of complaiſance to do it.

sp.speaker: Sem.
sp.p: Complaiſance, my dear Maria! Is the affection of my heart no more than complaiſance? Is the moſt refined, moſt intenſe and exalted paſſion, no more than complaiſance? My ſweet angel, you undervalue the heart, which is devoted to you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I ſhould be happy to find all your aſſertions true. But you know, that by liſtening to your addreſſes, I have affronted my relations. And it is neceſſary for us, to have ſomething to live upon, in caſe they ſhould not be kind to us.

sp.speaker: Sem.
sp.p: Depend on it, my divine Maria, depend on it, that I ſhall ſee to that, I ſhall live nobly with you, Maria, depend on it, we ſhall be happy as poſſible.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Women, you may ſay, are apt to be more anxious than men; but I muſt own that I fear the profeſſion of muſic will not maintain us. I could wiſh that you would engage in ſome other buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Sem.
sp.p: All in due time, my ſweet girl, depend on it, if I marry you, I will maintain you well, and leave no ſcheme or buſineſs untried, that I may gain a happy living.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Well, ſir, I wiſh you will bear it in mind, for it has really given me uneaſineſs. For I am ſenſible of your merit, tho I cannot ſee how you will eſtabliſh a living.

sp.speaker: Sem.
sp.p: All in good time, never fear me my ſweet girl▪ you ſhall find me a man of the ſtricteſt honor.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: WHAT does he ſay? will he do as you wiſh to have him?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: He promiſes fair and upon the ſtricteſt honor what other aſſurances can I have from him?

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: Nothing; unleſs he actually engage in buſineſs— but if he promiſes upon honor, he muſt be a perfect villain if he breaks his word.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: I can have no firmer ground of truth.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: True; but I would not be married to him, till he was ſettled in ſome good buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I do not intend it, but it will come to much the ſame thing—I muſt promiſe in order to ſecure him—and if I promiſe I ſhall marry him at all events.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: Heaven direct my good girl, I know not what to adviſe you to.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: WHY my dear girl ſhould you appear to avoid me? I wiſh to converſe with you, on a ſubject intereſting to both of us.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: If I were ſure, I had nothing of ſeverity to fear; you would ſee no diſpoſition in me to avoid you.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Severity, my girl, you have no ſeverity to expect. What made you think of it? I wiſh, however, to enquire in a manner, the leaſt diſagreeable to you, if Mr. Semibreve has any proſpect of ſettling in any permanent buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I cannot ſay poſitively; but I believe he intends it.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: This buſineſs, in teaching muſic, will hardly be ſufficient for the maintenance of a family.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe it cannot be, but I believe him to be a man of the ſtricteſt honor. He ſays he means to go into buſineſs ſoon.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p:
Have you no apprehenſion, Maria, that he is one of thoſe idle fellows that cheat girls, who only pretend, to have a regard for you, that he may be maintained in
idleneſs and diſſipation? —he perhaps imagine • u have a fortu • e.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: He is always very decent in his conduct to me, and certainly pretends to be very ſincere; whatever his real views may be.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: And you have no ſuſpicions of him?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Not in the leaſt. I believe him to be a man of the ſtricteſt honor.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: If you believe him to be ſuch a man; then you will have no objection to my bringing him to the teſt; and it will only ſet his virtues in the ſtrongeſt • ight.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I would not wiſh any thing rude, or uncivil to be offered to him.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: No, that is 〈…〉 my nature; I will only converſe with him concerning you and let him talk as he pleaſes — You know that fr •• our parlor to my ſtudy, every word which one ſpeaks in the common pitch of converſation, may be heard diſtinctly.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And what, ſir, would you propoſe?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: That you take your place in my ſtudy, while I converſe with him, and hear our converſation.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: That I will do moſt willingly; for I am not in the leaſt apprehenſive, that I ſhall hear any thing; but that which is moſt agreeable, and which will tend to make you and me reſpect him more than we do.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: You will be ready when he comes.

div.head: SCENE V.—TAR • ANA HONEYCOME and GRISSEL.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.p: HUSBAND, I am out of my wits about Maria— I have been thinking of it, and the more I think, the more I am uneaſy. I ſhall go crazy, if there be not ſomething done about it.

sp.speaker: Griſ.
sp.p: I talked with the little jade about it today; and ſhe was ſo ſaucy, I could hardly keep my hands from her. I never had ſo good an appetite to my dinner, as I had to give her a beating.

sp.speaker: Tar
sp.p: If ſhe would not give him up, I'd turn her out of doors.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: That is, to ſave her, we muſt deſtroy her at once— Shall we ruin her, becauſe her affection mortifies us? That's acting on a ſelfiſh motive.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.p: That's juſt like you, you never can reſent any thing.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Never mind it, my wife. If I do not gro • miſtake, they'll ſettle the matter between themſelves yet.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: MR. SEMIBREVE, it has been repreſented to me; that you have ſought an alliance with our family.

sp.speaker: Sem.
sp.p: That is, as things may prove to be. I believe Maria has a regard for me.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: I ſuſpect that ſhe has, and truly, I believe you have taken ſome pains to gain her affections.

sp.speaker: Sem.
sp.p: It always was my fortune, by ſome means, or other, to attract the notice of the ladies. I hope they don't blame me for the manner in which they are affected, when they ſee me.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Perhaps not, but if you be in purſuit of Maria, or 〈◊〉 you ſeem rather to inſinuate, ſhe is in purſuit of you; the effect comes to the ſame thing. You muſt have a maintainance, in order to live comfortably together.

sp.speaker: Sem.
sp.p: There is no doubt of that.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Well, it becomes an intereſting matter to me; do you intend to purſue any ſteady buſineſs for the purpoſe of ſupporting yourſelf?

sp.speaker: Sem.
sp.p: Sir, I mean to live like a gentleman—I teach muſic occaſionally—As for our maintenance, in caſe I marry your daughter, I ſuppoſe you will give her enough to maintain us.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: If ſhe marries agreeably to my mind I ſhall do my beſt for her.

sp.speaker: Sem.
sp.p: You can give her a hanſome eſtate, and permit me to ſay, ſir, you ought to do it.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Sir, I hope you do not mean to diſpoſe of my eſtate, till you have it in your hands.

sp.speaker: Sem.
sp.p: No—but as I know the hold I have on Maria's affections—I mean to have ſomething handſome with her, if I take her.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Well ſir, I ſuppoſe I could give her as much as eight hundred pounds— you know I have many children.

sp.speaker: Sem.
sp.p:
Eight hundred pounds, ſir, I ſhall not accept.—I
know, you can afford to give more—I have no mind to marry without the means of living genteelly.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: You do not however promiſe to make the beſt kind of a ſon in law; but as I mean to treat my daughter kindly— and I believe ſhe reſpects you—I will make an effort to give her twelve hundred pounds.

sp.speaker: Sem.
sp.p: I know the hold I have on Maria's affections—you will not wiſh to deſtroy your daughter's happineſs—I ſhall not accept of twelve hundred.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: I will give you fifteen hundred, rather than hurt my daughter, in the feelings of her heart—I have a great averſion to croſſing children in their love— I am confident that Maria will prove a very kind and induſtrious wife— and with her I will give you fifteen hundred pounds; which is as much as I can give.

sp.speaker: Sem.
sp.p: No ſir, I thank you. I ſhall not accept of any thing leſs than two thouſand pounds—which is as little as I can think of taking, and be ſaddled with a wife—tho I believe with a little tutoring, ſhe might be a tolerable family piece—tho not a fine woman, by any means.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: What if I tell her what you ſay of her?

sp.speaker: Sem.
sp.p: She never would believe it. She would credit one word of mine more than a thouſand of yours.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: I ſhall never give you two thouſand pounds.

sp.speaker: Sem.
sp.p: You are not ſure of that; you will be glad to come to my terms yet. If you do not, you may depend on loſing your daughter.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: MY dear Maria▪ your humble ſervant ſeems to be a hard man to deal with.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Dear ſir, give yourſelf no more trouble about him, I deteſt the coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Will you admit the addreſſes of Mr. Plaintruth, who has long cheriſhed a kind regard for you? I recommend him to you, my girl, as a perſon of approved worth.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Dear ſir, I have been fooliſh long enough in following my own inclination—I will be governed by your advice. [Enter Tartana]

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Well wife, Maria has given him up.

sp.speaker: Tart.
sp.p: You are the ſtrangeſt man that over was; you will make all women folks do juſt as you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Sem.
sp.p: MY divine Maria—I ſhall make the old gentleman deal out freely to us yet.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Yes, perhaps I may marry you yet, if any body will give me two thouſand pounds. But I would not for fifteen hundred pounds, tho you might make her with a little tutoring a tolerable family piece.

sp.speaker: Sem.
sp.p: Ha! it ſeems you have overheard me. I have often heard that people always get paid for liſtening.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Yes, I am well paid for it. I ſhall get rid of an inſufferable coxcomb—I ſhall never forgive myſelf the weakneſs of having been attached to him. Sir, inſtead of giving me any more of your fulſome flattery; get out of the houſe, and if you ever come into it again you ſhall meet with proper correction.

sp.speaker: Sem.
sp.p: Oh! blaſt my ill luck, ſhe is certainly angry, and my game is up. What a fool I was that I did not accept the fifteen hundred pounds.

div.head: The Spring for Flowers. A DRAMATIC DIALOGUE, IN THREE ACTS.
YOUTH IS THE SEASON FOR LOVE AND MARRIAGE.
div.p: Few of human follies have leſs excuſe to plead, than the neglect of marriage in youth—and the conſequent anxiety for it, in later life. A quick ſenſibility, ſtrength, activity, ambition and power of ſuſtaining family cares—ability to govern and educate children—with freedom from uncouth habits; and full propenſion to love; all invite to early marriages. Cold prudence is all the virtue peculiar to later life; and it is generally left without the aſſiſtance of the other virtues.

list.head: MEN.
list.item: MR. ALLWORTHY—a gentlemen of exce • lent moral • .

list.head: WOMEN.
list.item: MISS HAWTHORNE—a ſingle lady of thirty ſix.
MISS FORESIGHT—a cunning maiden of twenty eight.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: MADAM, every thing in life may be tranſacted acc • rding to rule and reaſon; I have a deſire to invite you to the ſtate of mariage, and ſee here, I have ſtated my propoſals on this paper; that you may conſider them at your le • ſure.

sp.speaker: Haw.
sp.p: Sir I ſhall conſider them; it would be rude not to do it, conſidering your reputable character. But I cannot ſpeedily come to a concluſion.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Take what time you think proper, if you will only give them due conſideration. I ſhall perhaps ſee you again in an hour or two. But will not inſiſt on a haſty determination,—take what time you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Haw.
sp.p: NOW from my ſoul I wiſh he had leſs reaſon, then I could ſuppoſe he had more love—He is as cool in his courtſhip as if he were caſting up a column of figures— He is a worthy man, but after all not at all to my taſte.

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.p: Why, Madam you really appear melancholy.

sp.speaker: Haw.
sp.p: I am ſo—I find I have left my morning's work to do in the afternoon, I am vexed with myſelf.

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.p: I do not comprehend your meaning.

sp.speaker: Haw.
sp.p:
The truth is, when I was young, from twenty to thirty, I had a number of very good offers for marriage, but full of the love of liberty & diſſipation, I declined them,
and now, to conceal nothing from you—I am heartily ſorry for it.

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.p: Many a woman I ſuppoſe has committed the ſame error—But for Heaven's ſake don't get into the dumps, your proſpects are good yet.

sp.speaker: Haw.
sp.p: Why, I am ready to look upon myſelf as a poor, forſaken creature.

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.p: Poh! There's Mr. Goodfort, is as fond of you, as he can be of any woman.

sp.speaker: Haw.
sp.p: An odd piece of furniture truely.

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.p: Why, what's the matter with him?

sp.speaker: Haw.
sp.p: Matter, I am afraid he is all matter and no ſpirit— His courtſhip it as methodical as a book of accounts— He comes juſt ſo often, ſtays juſt ſo long, talks juſt ſo, and juſt ſo much.

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.p: He is an exact gentleman, to be ſure.

sp.speaker: Haw.
sp.p: Exact! All ſyſtem, method and order; I do not love to be meaſured by the ſquare and compaſs.

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.p: He is a very virtuous man.

sp.speaker: Haw.
sp.p: Yes, I eſteem him, and yet after all I don't like him—He makes love by calculation,—beſides he is eight years older than I.

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.p: He muſt be old then, with an emphaſis.

sp.speaker: Haw.
sp.p: You ſaucy—I was going to call names, but to own the truth I am on the wrong ſide of thirty five—But he is eight years older than I.

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.p: Has he not made his propoſals?

sp.speaker: Haw.
sp.p: Yes, he has made them, on paper as you live; and as formal as any bond or deed.

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.p: You had better comply with them.

sp.speaker: Haw.
sp.p: I mean to, unleſs I have thoſe which are more pleaſing.

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.p: From whom have you any proſpect of thoſe which are more agreeable?

sp.speaker: Haw.
sp.p: I have had ſome viſits from that elegant pink of all courteſy, Mr. Allworthy.

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.p: Your hopes are deluſive.

sp.speaker: Haw
sp.p: He is very complaiſant to me.

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.p: He ſays openly, he only reſpects your good ſenſe, and hopes to profit by your experience.

sp.speaker: Haw.
sp.p: Experience! a ſaucy fellow. Experience is the reſult of age—Yet tho he is ſaucy, he is complaiſant and young.

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.p: Too young I ſhould ſuppoſe, he is eight years younger than you.

sp.speaker: Haw.
sp.p: I do not think that any reaſonable objection.

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe not—But he is very much engaged with Miſs Emily Howard.

sp.speaker: Haw.
sp.p: There is an eaſy remedy for that; I could fright her out of that fancy in five minutes.

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.p: I am not ſo certain of that—Thoſe modeſt girls, when they once get engaged, are commonly engaged to purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Haw.
sp.p: I can eaſily fright her out of the project. She is afraid of her own ſhadow.

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.p: She may be afraid of a ſhadow, and have no objection to the ſubſtance.

sp.speaker: Haw.
sp.p: O I can manage the matter with her. There is Mrs. Eaſy,—She had a moſt wretched huſband, and if ſhe were to talk with Emily about the men, ſhe would half fright her to death in ten minutes.

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.p: Much I doubt that. But I have no objection to your trying the experiment. [Exit Foreſight]

sp.speaker: Haw.
sp.p: DO tell me Emily, what is that which worries your mind ſo, and makes you ſo penſive?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Pray be not ſo teazing; I would not tell my own mother of ſuch a ſubject.

sp.speaker: Haw.
sp.p: Then there is a ſubject —you ſhall tell it me, Emily.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: You would only ſay that I was a fooliſh girl; and that would mortify me extremely.

sp.speaker: Haw.
sp.p: P • haw! Emily—you don't leſſen my curioſity at all; you know I am a good friend to you, Emily; you own auht too; you ſhall tell me.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: I am 〈◊〉 loth to give you pain.

sp.speaker: Haw.
sp.p: You give me the more pain by this management —My curioſity puts me on the rack—Tell me, or I ſhall not enjoy a moment's peace.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: I have a right to k • ep ſome things to myſelf, and I will not tell you—your ſervant madam. [Exit Emily.]

sp.speaker: Haw.
sp.p:
(alone) She is cunning▪ and l • es right for herſelf; but there is one way which never 〈◊〉 ſurpriſe d •• icate minds: it is almoſt too wicked. It is to put them on the
rack, in fears for their honor. Emily deſerves this puniſhment for thinking to outwit my old head. I will accuſe her and ſet her to juſtifying herſelf. [Emily enters.] Emily, my dear, excuſe me if I detain you one moment. You, I underſtand, have had a quarrel in your family.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: That's a total miſtake; I have the full confidence of my parents, and the happieſt harmony with my brothers and ſiſters.

sp.speaker: Haw.
sp.p: Then Miſs Fidget was wrong; but Miſs Coaxer might be in the right, in ſaying that you became melancholy in conſequence of being neglected by the young gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: I have diſmiſſed three within a month, and I have one now.

sp.speaker: Haw.
sp.p: There it is; they are right; you carry on a clandeſtine correſpondence with him.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Nobody who knows me would ſuſpect me of ſuch a thing. Mr. Allwor • hy never viſited me once, but with the approbation of my parents.

sp.speaker: Haw.
sp.p: They like him then.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: They treat him reſpectfully.

sp.speaker: Haw.
sp.p: Then the reaſon muſt be, that he is not ſo attentive as—

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: More attentive than I deſire.

sp.speaker: Haw.
sp.p: Then he's a perfect libertine, is he?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: You aſtoniſh me—What did I ſay, which ſhould lead you to that? He is a man of moſt excellent morals.

sp.speaker: Haw.
sp.p: Now, you fancy girl, I have got the ſecret out of you—Mr. Allworthy is very attentive to you, and that grieves you.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: You have been ſucceſsful—I ſee you have not loſt your faculty to do miſch • ef.

sp.speaker: Haw.
sp.p: Mr. Allwor • hy then addreſſes you—and you are all in fear leſt you ſhould loſe him.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Not in the leaſt, my fears are all the other way, leſt I ſhould be perſuaded to detain him.

sp.speaker: Haw.
sp.p: Aye, there you are right—this marrying is a dangerous affair—By ſaying yes, a woman may ruin herſelf forever. Never think of marrying, Emily—Never make yourſelf miſerable for any man. Mrs. Eaſy will ſoon be here, and ſhe will tell you all about it.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: MRS. Eaſy, I wait on you at the requeſt of Miſs Hawthorne, deſiring that you would attend her.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: What does ſhe wiſh of me?

sp.speaker: Good
sp.p: She ſays that ſhe deſires you would tell Emily all that is bad about marriage, and terrify her ſo, that ſhe may not venture herſelf into that ſtate—She ſays that ſhe is afraid Emily is about to engage in a very improper match.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: I can tell her all the bad which I know of it—But if ſhe will not be terrified, I cannot help that—Do you know what Miſs Hawthorne means by this?

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: I do not; but ſimply to expreſs her deſires to you.

div.head: SCENE II.—Miſs HAZARD and Mrs. EASY.

sp.speaker: Eaſy.
sp.p: THAT poor old pigeon Miſs Hawthorne has commiſſioned me, to fright Emily Howard.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: And I am to make a ſuit of clothes for her; to enable her to catch Mr. Allworthy.

sp.speaker: Eaſy.
sp.p: She may as well try to catch all the larks that wing the air—I can tell her madam ſhip, that 'tis not for ſuch old croakers as ſhe, to match with the fine young gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Somehow, I always feel a diſpoſition to plague old maids, tho I expect to be one myſelf.

sp.speaker: Eaſy.
sp.p: Tho I never was one myſelf; nor ever wiſhed to be—I think them excuſable when they could not be married reputably.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: But Miſs Hawthorne's celibacy is her own fault ſhe owns, and by her own confeſſion, ſhe is proper prize for ridicule.

div.head: SCENE III.—HAWTHORNE, HAZARD and Mrs. EASY

sp.speaker: Haw.
sp.p: HAVE you finiſhed my clothes?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: No, I forgot to aſk you the faſhion of them.

sp.speaker: Haw.
sp.p: The neweſt faſhion—ſuch as Miſs Sprightly's.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: That is almoſt in the faſhion of a young Miſs▪ clothes.

sp.speaker: Haw.
sp.p: I would not have you think I am ſo terribly old neither.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Why you look very freſh and fair for a woman of your years.

sp.speaker: Haw.
sp.p: Of my years you creature you; what do you mean by that?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Have you forgot how you wiſhed me to tell your fortune.

sp.speaker: Haw.
sp.p: No Madam, no—I have kept my tea cup, prepared in due order for you to ſee.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: It ought to have been a cup, taken in the morning faſting—the lady who is to have her fortune told, ſhould only drink one cup in the morning and eat nothing with it —nor taſte any food till four in the afternoon.

sp.speaker: Haw.
sp.p: I have prepared it accordingly.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Let me ſee it then.

sp.speaker: Haw.
sp.p: Pray look out and ſee if any body be coming in— I ſhould be very much aſhamed to be caught in telling fortunes.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Well this is odd. (Looking attentively in the cup.) Here's a man who intends to have you. He is about forty four—a very methodical man. He is ſerious—and will have you. But here's a letter.

sp.speaker: Haw.
sp.p: It is a letter, as plain as it can be.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: This is from a man about twenty ſix or twenty eight—His name begins with an A.

sp.speaker: Haw.
sp.p: (Looking ſly.) Well what do you think of him?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: He does not ſeem to be quite ſo fond of you as the other—See he has a lady of his heart—See here—her name begins with E.— I ſuſpect 'tis Emily Howard.

sp.speaker: Haw.
sp.p: (Strikes the cup from her hand.) A fiddleſtick. It is the ſillieſt thing in the world to tell fortunes.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: What I told you madam is true—I am ſorry it has put you out of humor, and I wiſh you good night.

div.head: SCENE IV.—EMILY, Mrs. EASY and Miſs HAWTHORNE.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: MRS. Eaſy, I am very happy to pay my reſpects to you.

sp.speaker: Eaſy.
sp.p: Hey! my young lady—ſo compliaſant to an old creature ſuch as I—I thank you Emily.

sp.speaker: Haw.
sp.p: This young lady is troubled in her mind — ſome people ſay ſhe is on the point of being married. Has ſhe not reaſon to be afraid? Is not that a very dangerous, and a very important affair?

sp.speaker: Eaſy.
sp.p: Yes, yes, ſomewhat dangerous and quite important. But a woman can manage her huſband well enough, if ſhe knows how.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Will you excuſe me. Mrs. Eaſy!—I never wiſh to take one ſtep in life but upon ſure grounds. Was you happy in your marriage?

sp.speaker: Eaſy.
sp.p: Yes, my dear girl—I frankly anſwer yes. Other perſons complained of my huſband—but to me he was truly a kind man—Yes Emily I can ſay truly, that I was happy.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe you are always happy in whatever ſituation you are.

sp.speaker: Eaſy.
sp.p: Few men are ſo bad, as not to be good in ſome reſpects—Yes, I was happy my dear.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Did your huſband ever put on high airs of authority?

sp.speaker: Eaſy.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Did he ever talk with paſſion, and be ſaucy to you?

sp.speaker: Eaſy.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Was he ever croſs and ill humored?

sp.speaker: Eaſy.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Was he ever in a paſſion with you?

sp.speaker: Eaſy.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Did he ever leave you, to go into company abroad?

sp.speaker: Eaſy.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Was he ever ſuſpicious of you?

sp.speaker: Eaſy.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Was you ever afraid that he might leave you to diſtreſs and want?

sp.speaker: Eaſy.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Had he a great many faults then?

sp.speaker: Eaſy.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: And could you be happy with ſuch a man?

sp.speaker: Eaſy.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: O admiration. Had I ſuch a huſband I muſt die out-right—Do you not think I ſhould?

sp.speaker: Eaſy.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: This is quite beyond my comprehenſion.

sp.speaker: Eaſy.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe it—but all men have their faults. If you cannot be happy with a man who has faults you can be happy with none.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Then it will be beſt for me to remain as I am.

sp.speaker: Eaſy.
sp.p: You are a little ſimplicity, Emily. Tho my huſband had ſo many faults, and other people ſaid he had more than ever I ſaw—Yet when he died I was very ſorry.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Well, Mrs. Eaſy, will you tell me how one may manage with a huſband who has faults? How ſhall a woman make her huſband treat her with reſpect?

sp.speaker: Eaſy
sp.p: By never giving him any reaſon to deſpiſe her.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: How ſhall ſhe prevent his leaving her to want and diſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Eaſy.
sp.p: By not wantonly ſpending his eſtate.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: How prevent his being croſs and ill humored.

sp.speaker: Eaſy.
sp.p: Set him an example of good humor and pleaſantneſs.

sp.speaker: Em
sp.p: If he goes much into company abroad —

sp.speaker: Eaſy.
sp.p: She muſt cure him by making him happieſt at home.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: What if he be liable to ſudden paſſions.

sp.speaker: Eaſy.
sp.p: Let him alone till his paſſion is over.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: How ſhall ſhe prevent his being ſuſpicious of her.?

sp.speaker: Eaſy.
sp.p: By telling him every thing he wants to know.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: How ſhall ſhe prevent his withdrawing his confidence from her?

sp.speaker: Eaſy.
sp.p: By always telling him exact truth.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: If he has many faults and ſhe cannot but know it?

sp.speaker: Eaſy.
sp.p: She ſhould count her own, and ſee if ſhe has not more than he.

sp.speaker: Haw.
sp.p: You are a ſtrange woman, Mrs. Eaſy. The women muſt all come to you to learn the matrimonial catechiſm—but all this will do me no good.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p:
Alone COULD Mrs. Eaſy be happy with ſuch a
huſband as ſhe had. And I not be able to find a bleſſing with ſuch a man as Mr. Allworthy—I'll let him know my ſentiments are altered and be will fly to me like a bird.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Miſs Emily, I muſt know my definitive ſentence— ſuſpence is ſo uncomfortable to me that I ſhall not long be able to endure it.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: I muſt then accept your offers, on this ſuppoſition— that we both have many faults, and each muſt learn to bear with them.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: The beſt footing in the world in point of prudence —but my affection will not let me anticipate them on your part.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Well • am willing to contrive to be happy with as few faults as poſſible on either ſide.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Neither is that condition diſagreeable—I believe we had better ſay nothing more againſt concord, and harmony, but let them take place between us if they will.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: I ſhall not try to baniſh them.

sp.speaker: Haw.
sp.p: WELL I may now reſign myſelf to deſpair, unleſs you will give up your pretentions.

sp.speaker: Em
sp.p: A good friend is a treaſure worth keeping. I have no tho'ts of parting with ſuch a bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: SHALL we ſet on a ſupper?

sp.speaker: Haw.
sp.p: I am perfectly indifferent about it.

sp.speaker: Lucy
sp.p: The ladies will want it; and they all will collect here in a few moments.

sp.speaker: Haw.
sp.p: You may do what you pleaſe—I feel very diſagreeably.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Madam, you are diſappointed and cannot conceal it—but I would take the methodical gentleman.

sp.speaker: Haw.
sp.p: I ſhall, but to marry when one is not perfectly ſatisfied with it, is not the thing—But one muſt do it, when they can do nothing better—I wiſh I had not been ſuch a fool when I was young.

div.head: SCENE IV.—HAWTHORNE, and EMILY, and all the ladies preſent.

sp.speaker: Haw.
sp.p: LADIES you are welcome; but pray do not expect me to be very cheerful.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: My aunt, I hope will not blame me, for not reſigning the beſt part of my fortune to her.

sp.speaker: Haw.
sp.p: No ladies— I blame none of you: I have no one to blame but myſelf. But let me, like all other criminals, caution you not to do as I have done, youth is the ſeaſon of beauty, and of attention from the men — and I believe if a woman cannot ſuit herſelf with a partner then—there is very little proſpect that ſhe ever will.

div.stage: [Exit Hawthorne, and after her all the ladies.]

div.head: The Diſcontented Wife. A DRAMATIC DIALOGUE, IN THREE ACTS.
THE QUARRELS OF MARRIED PERSONS ARE GENERALLY FRIVOLOUS.
div.p: IT is generally very idle for people in the vicinity, to interpoſe in the quarrels of married perſons. Marriage obliges, and almoſt neceſſitates, a man and his wife, to be of a mind, in things of great conſequence—Their quarrels ariſe from ſome trifles: a mere momentary humor, or accidental word, and counter paſſions, have more influence in reconciling them, than their reaſon. Hence this important moral ariſes; that married perſons never make complaints of each other abroad, and that their neighbors interpoſe in none of their differences—leſt work be made for repentance.

list.head: MEN.
list.item: COL. FORTINBRASS—officer of the United States army, married in N. York.
MR. WILLIAMSON—a wealthy citizen and good huſband.
MR. LEWISTON—a neighbor, friend to Mrs. Fortinbraſs.

list.head: WOMEN.
list.item: MRS. LYMAN—wife of a reputable citizen, friend of Mrs. Fortinbraſs.
MRS. DELANO—formerly rival of Mrs. Fortinbraſs.

div.head: SCENE I.—Mrs. WILLIAMSON and Mrs. FORTINBRASS.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Will.
sp.p: O MY dear Mrs Fortinbraſs, I am glad to meet you here—I am going to Philadelphia, and wiſhed to ſee Mrs. Lyman before I went. But I am ſo happy as to ſee you here! I hope you and the Col enjoy good health.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: Not very good, indeed I get very little reſt anights—The Col. at preſent is from home—But how ſweetly you look, what bright eyes, what roſy cheeks.

sp.speaker: Mrs Will.
sp.p: Thanks to that Great Being who gives health and cheerfulneſs, I enjoy both in a great degree—The peace and ſatisfaction of my mind have done me more good than medicine.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: And how ſweetly dreſſed too: where did you get this delightful gown?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Will.
sp.p: My huſband gave it me, it was his own choice.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: Your huſband gave it to you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Will.
sp.p: Yes. I hope you do not think that I would have accepted it from any other man.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: Then your huſband is good to you—Is he indeed?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Will.
sp.p: I am almoſt angry with you—What a queſtion! But I pardon you; for many have propheſied that I ſhould be unhappy in my marriage—But what thanks do I owe to Heaven for my huſband, whoſe kindneſs and virtues exceed my moſt romantic expectations.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: Well, I believe you are one of the happy few—I am ſick of marriage—only ſee how I look—this ordinary gown—But this is nothing could I enjoy peace at home—I had better been laid in my grave, than to have married Col. Fortinbraſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Will.
sp.p: Mrs. Fortinbraſs, I am ſurpriſed. You unhappy—and with Col. Fortinbraſs too—ſo fine a perſon, ſo elegant in his dreſs and manners—Fifty girls in this city were ready to die with envy when you married him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: Could I▪ part with him now, they might have him very cheap.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Will.
sp.p: But you ſurpriſe me, my dear friend—What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: Matter enough, I think; he holds his ſoldier frolics abroad, deſpiſes my company at home, gets me no new cloaths. When I reprove him, he will either look as ſurly as a bear, or get his old flax ſtringed fiddle and play a tune to my reproof.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Will.
sp.p: That vexes you I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: It does mortally, I have tho't a number of times that I ſhould have died with vexation—But I could only retire, and weep in floods of tears—But huſh, he is coming.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Will.
sp.p: I withdraw a moment to talk with Mrs. Lyman. But will ſee you again in half an hour.

div.head: SCENE II.—Mrs. FORTINBRASS and Col. FORTINBRASS.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: Well ſir, you got home very early laſt night. It was but one of the clock in the morning.

sp.speaker: C. Fort.
sp.p: I hoped, madam, to have met with a kind reception from you. I do not think it was very late.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: But I know it was late—and it was a pretty fancy indeed, if one muſt marry and expect to find a friend in a huſband, and have him leave one in utter contempt, and tarry out late.

div.stage: [The Colonel takes up an old fiddle and plays.]

sp.speaker: C. Fort.
sp.p: Tum tum diddle de dum dum dum.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: You pretend to have your ſoldier frolics— who knows what you are about when you are abroad?

sp.speaker: C. Fort.
sp.p: Tum dum, &c. (plays)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: No woman of ſpirit can bear ſuch treatment, I proteſt.

sp.speaker: C. Fort.
sp.p: Tum dum diddle, &c. (plays)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: You have not bought me a new gown this twelve month.

sp.speaker: C. Fort.
sp.p: Tum dum, &c. (continues playing)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: I won't bear this treatment—It is intolerable.

sp.speaker: C. Fort.
sp.p: Tum dum diddle, &c. (ſtill continues)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: If ever there was a woman ſo abuſed by her huſband.

sp.speaker: C. Fort.
sp.p: Tum dum diddle.

div.stage: [He purſues her with his muſic till ſhe is off the ſtage.]

div.head: SCENE III.—Mrs. FORTINBRASS and Mrs. LYMAN.

sp.speaker: Mrs Fort.
sp.p: O MY dear Mrs. Lyman, I am undone— Never was any perſon ſo abuſed by her huſband. I ſhall die— I ſhall die.

sp.speaker: Lym.
sp.p: Fye, fye Mrs. Fortinbraſs—do not diſgrace yourſelf and diſgrace your huſband, by theſe quarrels—but find means to make yourſelf and your huſband eaſy. Theſe proceedings are very dangerous.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: I cannot bear it; I muſt give him my mind, if I die for it.

sp.speaker: Lym.
sp.p: You may do it and ſee what you will get by it—but I will not ſtay to hear you. [Exit Mrs. Lyman.]

div.head: SCENE IV.—COL. FORTINBRASS and Mrs. FORTINBRASS

sp.speaker: C. Fort.
sp.p: WELL madam it is really a fine morning today.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: So it ſeems by your muſic—you are quite inſpired it ſeems by the ſeaſon.

sp.speaker: C. Fort.
sp.p: I love to ſing when I feel cheerful—I have very fine ſucceſs in fowling.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: I ſaw you have a large bunch of birds ſtrung up by their bills—I wonder how you came to kill ſo many ſtarlings. They are a lean kind of birds, and of little, or no uſe.

sp.speaker: C. Fort.
sp.p: No not ſtarlings, child. They are thruſhes my dear • delicious as marrow.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: Do you think me ſuch a fool that I do not know a thruſh from a ſtarling.

sp.speaker: C. Fort.
sp.p: And do you think me ſuch a ſot that I don't know a ſtarling, from a thruſh?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: You ſtaid out very late, laſt night. Your eyes, and ſenſes too, might be a little hurt.

sp.speaker: C. Fort.
sp.p: What an impudent woman you are, to talk thus to your huſband.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: What an inſolent coxcomb you are to treat a woman of ſpirit, and good family, in this manner.

sp.speaker: C. Fort.
sp.p: (Extremely agitated.) O torment! why did I marry? Can I bear ſuch impudence.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: Yes, you inſolent Dutchman—to behave with no more complaiſance to a woman of ſpirit and good family. You are not fit for human ſociety—Go abroad among the brutes. If you cannot behave yourſelf with more propriety, get out of this houſe, this inſtant, and as faſt as you can. [The Colonel approaches ſlowly to the door, turne and ſpeaks to his wife—looking dejected the whole time.]

sp.speaker: C. Fort.
sp.p: Sylvia farewell—I have long borne with ſome ill qualities in you, on account of ſome others, which I admired and loved; but this laſt ſtroke is intolerable—Farewell Sylvia, I ſhall ſee you no more. Yet remember this houſe was mine—you have it but by marrying me—And now you order me from it. It is very well—I will go. And you ſhall have it to yourſelf.

div.head: SCENE I.—Mrs. FOTINBRASS and Mrs. LYMAN (entering here.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: O MY friend, I am the moſt miſerable of women.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lym.
sp.p: What did your huſband do, when you ordered him out of the houſe?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: He went ſoftly away—and I ſaid nothing. It has been three weeks that we have been much out of humour with each other. Now he has bid me a ſolemn farewell. O I am the moſt miſerable of women! Why was I ſuch a fool as to marry!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lym.
sp.p: Well, and I cannot but think that you are partly to blame too—I have no deſire to exculpate the colonel—why ſhould you bluntly contradict him? That is unpolite to any body. Why inſult him with his being a Dutchman▪ National reflections always wound deep. You knew that before you married him—and to order him out of a houſe which you acquired by marrying with him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: If I have been to blame, I have been to blame. But I will aſk your advice.

sp.speaker: Lym.
sp.p: Well madam, I adviſe you to ſend a polite meſſage to the Colonel, and invite him to come home.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: So give up my will, and let him gain his point, a grand leſſon for a lady of faſhion.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lym.
sp.p: Then get ſome friend to mention it to him, ſo as to ſave your pride in the caſe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort
sp.p: After all, it will be a kind of ſubmiſſion, and that is a word which of all words I hate.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lym.
sp.p: It is ſimply a compliance, and I truſt you know what compliance is—when you truſted your life, your property, your honor, your happineſs with your huſband, nay your very ſoul—did you think after that, that you muſt be ceremonious?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: But in that caſe there was no impropriety.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lym.
sp.p: Neither is there here. Maids are bound to ceremony. But a married woman may do whatever ſhe pleaſes, for the happineſs of herſelf and her huſband.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: You will not eaſily purſuade me to give up my will, and reſentments, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lym.
sp.p: What then do you mean to do?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: To ſue for a divorce, or ſeperate maintenance at leaſt.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lym.
sp.p: You may intend to have your own way; but I do not mean to give you up ſo—there is my good friend Mr. Williamſon, he ſays his heart has bled for you, when he knew the diſſenſions between you, and your huſband.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: If that be true it is more then I have done for myſelf, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lym.
sp.p: Dear Mrs. Fortinbraſs, ſay not that again, if you be inſenſible to the better affections of the heart, I ſhall deſpair of you entirely.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: You, or any one, may ſay then juſt what you pleaſe.

div.head: SCENE III.—Mr. WILLIAMSON and Mrs. FORTINBRASS.

sp.speaker: Mr. Wil.
sp.p: LADIES, I reſpect you all moſt ſincerely; but I mean to pay my attention particularly to Mrs. Fortinbraſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: Juſt as you pleaſe, Mr. Williamſon.

sp.speaker: Mr. Wil.
sp.p: I mean in regard of your affair with Col. Fortinbraſs—I will not mortify you afreſh by telling the ſad ſtory, but if I can be of any ſervice to you by healing the unhappy wound, and reſtoring happineſs, I ſhall greatly rejoice—will you be ſo kind as to tell me what your intentions are?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: To ſue for a divorce or a ſeparate maintenance at leaſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Wil.
sp.p: Let me then aſk you if you have not unnatural relations who hate you, and rivals who owe you a mortal grudge, and indeed enemies of various kinds?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: Yes, perhaps a hundred, who would rejoice to hear of my death.

sp.speaker: Mr. Wil.
sp.p: Conſider then what you are about to do—will it not be the greateſt gratification to your enemies, to ſee you abject, and miſerable, worſe than a widow, forſaken of all reputable company, and an object of general contempt—how will your rivals exult over you? Would you do what would gratify their malice?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort
sp.p: No, I would ſooner confound them forever.

sp.speaker: Mr. Wil.
sp.p: Here is one of them coming now.—She'll torment you, you had better go out of the way.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: No, let her come. I cannot be more miſerable than I am.

div.head: SCENE III.—Mrs. DELAND, Mrs. FORTINBRASS and Mr. WILLIAMSON.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Del,
sp.p: LADIES moſt welcome all of you; and in particular Mrs. Fortinbraſs. Well madam how do ye do?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: Indifferently madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Del.
sp.p: Rather indifferently I ſuppoſe. The Col. they ſay has forſaken you. Well, this is odd that after you took ſo much pains to have him, you ſhould loſe him ſo ſoon.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: I expect no mercy from you Mrs. Delano.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Del.
sp.p: I love to ſhow mercy as well as other perſons, to thoſe who are proper ſubjects of it. But that can hardly be ſaid of you—were I to take into the account, all the ſcandalous reports, you ſpread concerning me —the letters you forged—had the Col. remained with me he might have been a worthy-man.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: You love him now, I know you do? tho you have another huſband—well you may have him, and welcome.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Del.
sp.p: No, madam, I am better provided for, and I am afraid he has caught ill habits by acquaintance—you wounded me once, very ſeverely, but I am now cured, and have lived to ſee juſtice.

sp.speaker: Mr. Wil.
sp.p: Forbear, my good lady, forbear, tho your wrongs may have been great.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Del.
sp.p: What I ſaid was not out of malice, but to bring this lady to a ſenſe of her duty—I will not add affliction to the afflicted; but juſt mention the matter and leave this lady to her own reflections.

div.head: SCENE IV.—Mr. WILLIAMSON and Mrs. FORTINBRASS.

sp.speaker: Mr. Wil.
sp.p: Now Mrs. Fortinbraſs—ſhould you love to gratify this woman too, who is animated with ſuch keen reſentment againſt you—pleaſe your enemies, mortify your friends; and make your huſband unhappy?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: He ſhould have taken care of that himſelf.

sp.speaker: Mr. Wil.
sp.p: And what ſhall be done with your ſweet little—ſon—that little cherub who bears ſuch a lively reſemblance of the Colonel. When you ſhall hear him ſob, and cry; as he undoubtedly will; becauſe papa does not come home—how will you bear it; Can you endure to ſee him an orphan, or will you give him up for ever; to a parent againſt whom you cheriſh the moſt implacable reſentment.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: O my heart, my heart.

sp.speaker: Mr. Wil.
sp.p: While you have been on ill terms, he has not abſented himſelf for nothing. He has been aſſembling a regiment, and he is going to the weſtern army.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: He may find himſelf happier there than here.

sp.speaker: Mr. Wil.
sp.p:
It may be, but the probability is that the Indians will take him; and torture 〈◊〉 —fill his fleſh full of pine ſplinters, and ſet them on fire—o •
• ery way to torment him with relentleſs cruelty—can you bear this in reſpect
of him—who once was the deareſt object of your love?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: It was his buſineſs to have guarded againſt that; as well as mine.

sp.speaker: Mr. Wil.
sp.p: Well if you cannot hear any thing you muſt be left to the conſequences. But he told me he was going to the army in three weeks—His old ſoldiers have all enrolled themſelves and the new ones admire him—The preſident of the ſtates has made him a general.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort
sp.p: (Looking up.) That's odd that he ſhould be made a general. (Her countenance alters from the expreſſion of diſcontent to curioſity.)

div.head: SCENE V.—Mr. LEWISTON, Mrs. FORTINBRASS and Mrs. LYMAN.

sp.speaker: Mr. Lew.
sp.p: O MRS. Fortinbraſs, this is of all things moſt extraordinary—Col. Fortinbraſs is come with his regiment, and in his new uniform of a general. He reſembles with his noble airs, and fine perſon— the heroes deſcribed in poets who were tho't to be like the Gods.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: I think it is odd enough that he ſhould be made a general—if he would come home now, and ſubmit and aſk pardon—

sp.speaker: Mr. Lew.
sp.p: You would not wiſh for ſuch humiliation in your huſband, would you degrade the man whom you are to love? more than this, if he can find that you will ſee him; he will come to ſee you this very day—and if he can reconcile matters at home, he means to reſign his commiſſion; if not he means to march in three days.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lym.
sp.p: Go you wretch, don't go to be obſtinate now, you have better clothes than theſe; put them on—and look as handſome as you can—receive him genteelly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: I never ſhall be able to bear him again—But I want to ſee how he looks, ſince he has been made a general.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lym.
sp.p: Go forward, and one of the ladies ſhall help you to dreſs yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: I go ladies, to obey you; but it will all be in vain I can never endure him unleſs he will make a proper ſubmiſſion. [Snaps her handkerchief as ſhe goes out.]

div.head: SCENE I.—Mr. LEWISTON and Mrs. WILLIAMSON

sp.speaker: Mr. L.
sp.p: WHAT do you think the creature will do?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Wil.
sp.p: I cannot conjecture.

sp.speaker: Mr. L.
sp.p: Nor I; but this I know that perſons who have been ſo long tender to each other, cannot part very eaſily.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Wil.
sp.p: I believe that; and do you think that if married perſons ſhould ſometimes hurt each others feelings, that, therefore, they muſt neceſſarily be miſerable?

sp.speaker: Mr. L.
sp.p: No, not by any means, perſons of quick ſenſibility, and who have not been uſed to curbing their paſſions in their youth—may live years together before they will be perfect in matrimonial wiſdom.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Wil
sp.p: There is ſomething in thoſe things ſimilar to what we find in other parts of nature—It is as natural for human beings occaſionally to be agitated with paſſion—as that there ſhould be unſettled weather in the months of April and May—Thoſe ſudden guſts which for awhile deform the beautiful face of nature, are commonly ſucceeded by the moſt ſerene and delightful weather.

sp.speaker: Mr. L.
sp.p: You talk very ſenſibly but I long to have them meet; and then ſee how the creatures behave. Let us ſtep aſide when the Colonel comes in.

O alas! never was a perſon in ſuch confuſion bafore — what a figure he makes at the head of his regiment—He looks divinely—But if I receive him—I give all up & ſhall be aſhamed to reſent his conduct in time to come— (Goes and looks out.) —But O! how divinely he looks—what ſhall I do? I am aſhamed to think how much I may be diſpoſed to receive him. (Looks out.) But I muſt bear the teſt. (Returns and walks agitated acroſs the ſtage—Col. Fortinbraſs enters—ſhe almoſt falls on her knees before him—He catches her and raiſes her.)

sp.speaker: C. Fort.
sp.p: No, my dear girl no—no humiliations to me— Stand with me upon equal and juſt footing—The firſt thing you are to do is to go, and ſee my regiment—and then we will find, if we have not reaſon ſtill to reſpect each other. Tarry till I return. (To the company on the ſtage.)

div.head: SCENE III.—Mrs. LYMAN and Mrs. WILLIAMSON.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lym.
sp.p: This exceeds all my acquaintance—I'll never believe a woman again, who pretends to be affronted with her huſband.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Wil.
sp.p: How did ſhe behave herſelf?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lym.
sp.p: She fretted all the time we were dreſſing her —and proteſted ſhe would ſue for a divorce, and what not. But ſhe looked out at the window, and ſaw her huſband at the head of his regiment—I verily tho't ſhe would have fainted away—and when ſhe ſaw him come into her preſence—ſhe was going to throw herſelf at his feet—But he ſaid—No humiliation, my dear girl—and led her out to ſee his ſoldiers. But before they got to the door, the tears guſhed from their eyes—The old veteran who had ſtood ſo many battles melted to the ſoftneſs of a woman.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Wil.
sp.p: You had no trouble then to reconcile them.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lym.
sp.p: No, they reconciled one another very ſucceſsfully—we ſhall ſee her with a different face ſoon.

div.head: SCENE IV.—Mrs. WILLIAMSON, Mrs. FORTINBRASS, &c.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Wil.
sp.p: You may ſpare your obſervation; for ſhe is coming now. [Enter Mrs Fortinbraſs.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lym.
sp.p: Mrs. Fortinbraſs, I hope affairs go very well on your part.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: I thank you ladies—I am well at preſent.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Del.
sp.p: How is the Colonel? General I meant to ſay.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: In fine health and ſpirits, and gives the ladies his hearty reſpects.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Del.
sp.p: You ſeem much altered, madam, all at once.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: Altered did you ſay? I know nothing of it, but that I am very happy.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Del.
sp.p: But to be ſick of marriage.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p:
But to be ſick of marriage. Who ſick of marriage? Not I—I ever conſidered it as the capital bleſſing of my life—when does your ſiſter intend to be married?
—I ſhould ſuppoſe ſhe might know her mind in ſix o • ſeven years.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Del.
sp.p: She is in no haſte, ſhe has been terrified by your example.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: By my example, that's ſtrange—you know I always reſpect matrimony. If that be an obſtacle, tell her from me that I would have her think better of it, better— I ſay.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Del.
sp.p: But who ſaid to-day, that ſhe was ſick of marriage?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: Not I ſurely—I ſhould be aſhamed to have ſaid ſo.

sp.speaker: Alltogether.
sp.p: Yes, yes, yes, you did this day.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: Ladies you muſt excuſe me; I have had ill turns of late, my head is dizzy ſometimes, and I do not appear to myſelf to be perfectly in my right mind.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Del.
sp.p: So it ſeems that the return of an abſent huſband, will put a lady into a right mind.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: Yes; and right ſpirits too—ladies, I ſee you are determined to vex me, but I mean to turn, and defy you.

sp.speaker: Mrs Del.
sp.p: Well, how does Mr. Fortinbraſs look ſince he has been made a general?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: Excellently madam; I wiſh your huſband could be ma • e a general for your ſake—I dare ſay you would think him better for it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Del.
sp.p: It ſeems too that you are more polite than when you was here before.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fort.
sp.p: We ought always to be improving. And if I make ſuch progreſs in half an hour, I ſhall ſoon be perfect.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Wil.
sp.p: Shall we wiſh her joy, ſhe has a huſband now as well as we?

sp.speaker: Gen. Fort.
sp.p:
Ladies I wiſh you all joy—my houſe is again a grateful home—you ſhall all ſup with me this evening, and I will ſend for your huſbands—let us devote the hours to rejoicing—I mean to annihilate the conteſt between me and my wife's relations about certain matters of property —& then I doubt not we ſhall live in peace—I ſhall bid abieu to the purſuit of wealth and the wars—and ſhall devote
myſelf to that moſt rational and perfect of all enjoyments, the felicity of domeſtic life.

div.stage: [IF in this Dialogue the Scenes in which Fortinbraſs appears, be left out—except the laſt; that being put into the mouth of Mrs. Fortinbraſs, as a meſſage to the ladies—and if Mr. Williamſon's part be put to Mrs. Williamſon, and Mr. Lewiſton's part to Mrs. Lewiſton, it will be fitted to young ladies]

div.head: The Father of a Family. A COMEDY, IN FIVE ACTS.
SOCIAL CONFIDENCE IS NECESSARY TO THE HAPPINESS OF FAMILIES.
div.p: IT is very pernicious to families, when parents form deſigns which produce miſtruſt among their children —or children purſue ſchemes of their own, without the intelligence of their parents. It is commonmonly the caſe, that perſons devoted to celibacy, know not the ſocial principles of a family—and from that cauſe become troubleſome inmates. Of maidens we ſay nothing accuſatively —but if old bachelors ſay our charge is grievous, let them marry, and that will confute it—and let the maids all ſay—amen.

div.head: PERSONS.

list.head: MEN.
list.item: MR. ROBERTSON—the Father of a family.
AIMWELL—a brother's ſon, brought up with Mr. Robertſon.

list.head: WOMEN.
list.item: WIDOW HERBERT—a woman, who boards Sophia.

div.p: SCENE.—A merchant's houſe in the city of New-Haven.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: I CAN beat you, Albin, two rubbers out of three all day long.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: Why did you not beat me then juſt now?

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Becauſe that fellow (pointing to Aimwell) always looks over my ſhoulder, and talks about the game.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: He did the ſame to me, but it did not diſturb me.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Well, let us take the other rubber now.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: I am almoſt tired of cards.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: That is, becauſe you have beat, and want to have the credit of it.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: (to his father) Sir, ſhall we play here?

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: I think you had better defer it—I do not love to ſee people play when they are angry.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: OH dear! this execrable gout is coming on again. I am good for nothing. I am an old man in the midſt of my days.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: When you was about twenty three years old, you uſed to ſay, that you would never marry, becauſe married men would ſoon grow old—Now you are half the time laid up with the gout, while I have no ſign of bodily decay—tho three years older than you—have not a gray hair on my head, nor a wrinkle in my face—no gout or rheumatiſm, as you have.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: You need not have any bodily torments—your children will give you torment ſufficient.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: (looking about) Wh • re is my ſon?

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: He ſtole out, juſt now, and watched your eyes, that you might not ſee him.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: He has no reaſon to be afraid of me.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: He is engaged in ſome ſcheme which he knows you will not approve. He has of late been out much anights.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: (ſighing) That is but too true.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Why need you trouble yourſelf about it?

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: (wakling about) O thou too tender heart of a father, canſt thou not calm thyſelf one moment? How anxious I feel! could I only know that he was in good company, I might then enjoy ſome comfort—Brother, you had better go to bed. [Exit Major.]

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: HERE I will try to compoſe myſelf till my ſon comes home. [Albin enters in a ſtopped hat and ſpeaks, looking at his own toes.]

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: So I loſt my viſit to night becauſe the widow ſaid ſhe had a fainting fit & was ſick—An't I a fool to love a little puny girl who will faint away, and be ſick, and all that— She is an exccellent girl however, and that's the reaſon why I love her ſo.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: (ſuddenly) Albin!

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: (ſtarting) Sir I did not know you was here.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Who is that who is ſo ſick?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: I wiſh ſir you would excuſe me.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: I ſhall not, tell me for what purpoſe you have been abroad ſo much of late.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: Sir, I went—I went ſir, to viſit, Sophia.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: And who is Sophia?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: Sophia Clifford ſir.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Where does ſhe live?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: At the widow Herbert's.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: A fine place for you to go a courting—The beſt furniture in the houſe, is an old maple table and a few old chairs bottomed with ſtraw.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: The widow is poor but ſhe is honeſt, and Sophia is a genteel girl.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p:
What do you mean to do with her? I will not ſuffer you to delude her into vicious ways, or if you mean to
amuſe her a while and then forſake her—That would be mean, and cruel.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: O ſir, ſhe is a ſweet little angel as ever was—no body can do an unbecoming thing in her preſence. Now, ſir; ſince you know it, I wiſh you would go, and ſee her; and if you talk with her one half hour, and do not approve of my choice, I ſhall wonder.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: I will ſee her that I may underſtand this affair— But do not expect that I will encourage you in any of your fooliſh ways. (Exit Albin)

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: WILL you ſit, madam Herbert?

sp.speaker: W. Her.
sp.p: Yes ſir.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: I want to know ſomething about Sophia▪ the girl that lives with you. I have heard of her; but ſince I have heard of her, I am more at a loſs what to think of her than before.

sp.speaker: W. Her.
sp.p: What makes you think of her?

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: I am afraid of unwarrantable connections between my ſon, and her.

sp.speaker: W. Her.
sp.p: O, thank you ſir, my houſe is as honeſt a houſe as any in this city.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Be not affronted widow, I am a widower you ſee —We will not be upon ill terms; does my ſon viſit this girl?

sp.speaker: W. Her.
sp.p: Yes, ſir, often.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: How does • e paſt his time with her?

sp.speaker: W. Her.
sp.p: Sometimes he talks about common matters, ſometimes he reads very pretty things to her out of books, and one time, but I chid him for that, he made a pair of verſes about Sophia.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: You know how it is, widow, you and I have been courting before now—Does he ever talk to her, in a manner which you ſhould think l • ly to affect the heart.

sp.speaker: W. Her.
sp.p: I have tho't that if I were as young as I once was, and he had ta • ked 〈…〉 I ſhould have been affected—and I once ſaw 〈◊〉 , when he ſeemed to be very earneſt with her, ſhe puts her hands over her eyes, and I ſaw the tears ſlip thro between her fingers, and trickle down her arms.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Do you know any thing of her family?

sp.speaker: W. Her.
sp.p: She ſays ſhe lately loſt her father, and I don't ſay much to her about her family, for if I do, it makes her cry.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: And do you ſuppoſe Sophia to be a good girl?

sp.speaker: W. Her.
sp.p: Yes, ſir, that I do; ſhe has been with me but ſix weeks waiting, as ſhe ſays, for ſome money coming to her mother—And I would keep her if ſhe never paid a farthing for her board, for ſhe is always ſo pleaſant, and when my work drives me, ſhe will work upon the hard, coarſe cloth, till her fingers bleed—I love her, ſir, as if ſhe was my own child—good night ſir, I have no children of my own, but I hope my little Sophia will ſtay with me and be a comfort to me.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Stay widow, a moment; I will walk with you, and talk more about Sophia.

sp.speaker: W. Her.
sp.p: O Sir you are very kind to take notice of a poor old widow—If I had been young and worth twenty thouſand pound, I ſhould not have wondered to have heard you ſpoke up. [They withdraw.]

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: IT is all out about my attentions to Sophia.

sp.speaker: Aim.
sp.p: I tho't it could not be kept a ſecret long.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: The Major has told all the ſtory to my father.

sp.speaker: Aim.
sp.p: There is no keeping a ſecret in a houſe where there is an old Bachelor putting his noſe in every man's diſh. But I cannot talk of it now. [Exit Aimwell.]

div.head: SCENE II.—FATHER and ALBIN.
div.stage: (As the Father is ſitting in a chair Albin comes up to his elbow—ſpeaks anxiouſly—The father anſwers coldly.)

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: HAVE you ſeen her Sir?

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Yes, I have ſeen her—what then?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: How do you like her ſir?

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Aye that's to the point to be ſure.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: Is ſhe not beautiful?

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Yes ſhe is very beautiful.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: Do you believe her ſenſible?

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Yes I believe ſhe is quite ſenſible.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: Do you not think ſhe is good tempered?

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Yes, by her looks, ſhe is a good tempered girl.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: Do you not believe ſhe is virtuous?

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Yes I am apt to think ſhe is virtuous.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: Is ſhe not genteel?

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Yes her manners are very genteel.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: How did ſhe converſe?

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Finely, indeed very finely.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: Then what objection can you have to my acquaintance with her?

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: She is not fit for you.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: Who then is fit for me? beautiful, good tempered, ſenſible, genteel, and converſes finely; and yet not fit for me. Do ſir tell me who is fit for me!

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: A lady of fortune, of great relations, who will help you to get places in the government.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: Then, I ſuppoſe, ſome time or other, you will marry me to ſome fat, clumſy, awkward ſquab of an heireſs— I ſhall hate her, and kill her with grief.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: However that may be, my family muſt not be degraded—on the pain of my diſpleaſure, you muſt quit this girl, and renounce her forever. [Exit Father.]

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: I ſhall be able to renounce my life as ſoon.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Your Father would have had me gone to bed, but I did not chooſe it, ſo ſince I ſat up; I tho't I would talk with you.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: I do not wiſh to hear you, you will only torment me.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Your father will have you talk with me.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: Talk what you pleaſe; but I have only one word to ſay. Sophia ſhall be mine.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: A hopeful youth. You are nineteen years old— What will you do with this girl?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: Courtſhip, it is ſaid, is the happieſt part of life— If ſo, let it begin early, and laſt long—What will I do with this girl? I will marry her, when it is convenient.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Your Father will diſinherit you. You, your wife, and children muſt ſtarve.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: I know my Father's temper very well. Were my family in want, and my little children were to go, and ſpread out their little hands to him; it would melt him to pity, and he would relieve them at once.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Your father is a fool—He lets his children know that he loves them. There never was ſuch a match in any family.

sp.speaker: Alb
sp.p: Then this will be the firſt—it will be a great curioſity

sp.speaker: Maj
sp.p: And heireſs of nothing.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: Who has taught me to deſpiſe all things but virtue?

sp.speaker: Maj
sp.p: Poor people always abound in children. If you do marry Sophia▪ I hope you will have a dozen.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: Four dozen at leaſt, uncle, if they reſemble Sophia.

sp.speaker: Maj
sp.p: If you have • ver ſo many, you ſhall never name one af • e • me.

sp.speaker: Alb
sp.p: Not I Your name is Benedict—I would as ſoon call one Shara • h, Meſhech and Abednego.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: By heavens! this is inſufferable. I had rather you had died—I had rather when we ſtormed Stoney-Point, that one of the enemy had ſkewered you with his bayonet, and dropped you in the ditch among the dead. Leave my preſence, you ſaucebox, in a moment.

div.head: SCENE IV.—FATHER and CECILIA.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: TELL Clairet to bring my ſupper.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: I will go and get it myſelf; it will be a pleaſure to me. (Major goes out)

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: What a lovely daughter that is—I intend ſhe ſhall be married and live with me; for I ſhall never be able to part with her, becauſe ſhe is the very image of my loſt wife.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: Your ſupper, ſir, will be ready in a few moments.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Stay Cecilia now—Have you ever thought of that manner of life, which would be agreeable to you?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: No farther than that it is very agreeable to live with you.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: But you ſhould have a friend to protect you when I am gone.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: I am not in the leaſt anxious about that.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: There is no need of affected modeſty—if you prefer any gentleman, I ſhall be happy to complete your felicity.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: (After a long pauſe.) My brother's ſituation affrights me.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Your brother is a fool.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: Perhaps if I ſpeak my mind you will think me no leſs unreaſonable than he!

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: If your modeſty will not permit you, let me dedeclare for you. The Major has given me hints about Aimwell.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: (Riſing ſuddenly.) O dear ſir, believe not a word he ſays. He is always trying to make miſchief—Excuſe me ſir, I muſt be abſent a moment.

div.stage: [Goes out weeping, and wiping her eyes.]

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: How unhappy this is! I have loſt her confidence, certainly; I am afraid I ſhall never ſee the happineſs of one of my children. [Exit Father.]

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: AIMWELL, will reward you well, if you do one article of buſineſs for me.

sp.speaker: Aim.
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: I have got a warrant from Squire Smart to carry Sophia out of town. • s a vagrant—If you will ſee it executed, I will make my will in your favor.

sp.speaker: Aim.
sp.p: I would do it, if I tho't it juſt.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: You will think it juſt I dare ſay—fifteen thouſand pounds—and that • ine girl, Cecilia, into the bargain—you muſt find it to 〈◊〉 juſt. But you will not ſpeak of my project to Al ••• .

sp.speaker: Aim.
sp.p: I will not. [Exit Major.]

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p:
I AM on the verge of diſtraction and deſpair—I will
carry Sophia away to the farms which will ſoon be mine, in New-Jerſey.

sp.speaker: Aim.
sp.p: What, even if ſhe be not willing?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: I warrant I will make her willing. At any rate ſhe ſhall go—I will aſſure to myſelf all that I hold valuable in life.

sp.speaker: Aim.
sp.p: You are ruſhing on your own deſtruction.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: You are ſcrupulous beyond meaſure, and a little piece of a coward—But I wiſh my letters from Danbury would a • tive—Thoſe might ſave me the trouble.

sp.speaker: Aim.
sp.p: alone. SEE two men reſolved on this poor girl's deſtruction—The Major would carry her out of town as a vagrant, and ruin her character—Albin would ſeize her and run away with her, and ruin her that way—There is no way to ſave her that I can think of; but to put her under Cecilia's protection—and then if ſhe proves a bad girl Cecilia will be ſub • ected—I muſt try to perſuade Cecilia, tho it would be dangerous for her. What ſtrange creatures we men are; we perſuade women to imprudent things, and then blame them for it. [Cecilia enters.]

sp.speaker: Aim
sp.p: My excellent Cecilia, I believe you muſt give refuge to the unfortunate Sophia.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: O that muſt never be done—She may be a bad girl.

sp.speaker: Aim.
sp.p: I believe ſhe is very honeſt.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: Ah but what proof have you?—You muſt not introduce her. (Aimwell goes out into the ſtreet, returns in a moment, introducing Sophia.)

sp.speaker: Aim.
sp.p: Here ſhe is—If you can believe her a bad girl, turn her out in the ſtreet.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: O Aimwell what have you done—I hope you will own that I have been kind enough to you now; that by your means I lie at the mercy of all my enemies.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: MY good lady who ever you are have pity upon me. (Taking her by the hand.)

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: Amiable and unfortunate girl, who are you?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: One of whom you would not have been aſhamed in my better days—But my father is dead, I came here to receive a ſum of money for my mother—and what miſeries have I not endured. O that I had never ſeen your brother.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: My brother loves you with the tendereſt affection.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: That I believe, and it is the ſource of my miſery— He contemplates to run away with me, and that cruel Major, what have I do done to him, that he ſhould perſecute me?

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: My heart bleeds for your diſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: You won't let Albin carry me off, or any of the ugly officers take me.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: No my ſweet girl I will not, you have melted my heart within me.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: You are my guardian angel, my generous Cecilia. Your goodneſs ſhall be rewarded, if the prayers of the afflicted have any avail.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: Compoſe yourſelf, my dear lady, nothing ſhall hurt you here.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: I feel a heavy ſenſation; I am afraid I ſhall faint.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: No you are only ſleepy—You ſhall take a little repoſe in your chair. (Cecilia lays a pillow in the back of a chair and covers Sophia with a ſhaw!—Sophia ſleeps covered.)

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Don't let any man come into the room.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: I will not. (Exit Cecilia)

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p:
I Have eluded Cecilia ſweetly — ſhe made faſt one door; but forgot there was another—Now is the time to carry her off, but I will ſee her firſt, and not carry off a wrong girl for they may mean to cheat me. (Advances on tiptoe lifts up the ſhawl ſtands and looks with aſtoniſhment on Sophia ſleeping.) Yes it is ſhe and how delightful ſhe looks when ſleeping—I am filled with rapture and aſtoniſhment—can I violate that ſweet temple of beauty? (pauſes) Can I reſiſt her reaſons, or her intreaties when ſhe ſhall refuſe to go— Albin, you have undertaken what you dare not not execute— (Sophia moves as if diſtreſſed in ſleep and ſays) "Albin carry me away, no that is not like Albin." (Albin ſtarts and runs to the edge of the curtain) Yes it is like Albin and
Albin is a wicked fellow—O how her preſence ſtrikes me with veneration! I cannot touch her, to do her harm— Now if ſhe ſhould wake and catch me here▪ how angry ſhe would be. But I never ſhall forget how ſweetly ſhe look • when aſleep. (Exit ſoftly.)

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: I AM now glad I received this girl, and I begin to think that happineſs conſiſts in doing good.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: (waking) My good protectreſs, how long have I been aſleep?

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: Not more than fifteen or twenty minutes.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Has there not been a man in the room?

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: Certainly not.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: I tho't I heard one ſtep acroſs the floor; but was ſo overcome with ſleep that I could not move.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: You muſt have dreamed it; for I locked the door and put the key in my own pocket.

div.head: SCENE VII.—ALBIN, SOPHIA and CECILIA. Albin runs in and offers to catch Sophia's hand.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: SOPHIA my life my— (ſhe refuſes him her hand.)

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Albin, how dare you to come into my preſence, after the odious ſcheme you had formed?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: How! I do not comprehend this—perhaps Albin may be capable of his reſentments too.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: You may reſent my conduct in what manner you pleaſe—you intended to have carried me off, whether I would or not.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: But I do not intend it now.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: No matter for that, he who has once formed an ill deſign againſt a woman, ſhould be truſted no more.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: Well, I ſuppoſe I have done wrong, but I aſk pardon.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: I pardon the paſt. But I mean to truſt you no more—I forbid you my preſence.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: I muſt intreat you to revoke the harſhneſs of that ſentence. My heart after admitting you to its affections, can never admit an inferior; and I muſt be miſerable for life—I will for the future treat you on the ſtricteſt rules of honor, you may depend on it.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: I have no evidence but your own teſtimony, and you have always been unfaithful, ſo you muſt depart.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: I have imagined an injury againſt you, and would you deſtroy me entirely? You are more ſevere, than virtuous.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: Sophia you muſt pardon my brother. He was driven to the borders of dſepair—I riſked my honor to ſave you from odious perſecution—I have ſaved you, you muſt not deſtroy my brother—you will make me miſerable.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: For your ſake I forgive him; you ſhall be his ſurety that he will not attempt the like again.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: I will not even imagine it—may I preſume to take this hand?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Yes it is your's again, and when I forgive, I do it heartily.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: Sweet Sophia—every moment I ſee new cauſe to admire you.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: Did my Father know your true character—he could not oppoſe your introduction into the family.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: ALAS! what ſhall I do? My ſon flies my preſence—Cecilia diſtruſts me—Aimwell is ſhy of me—I almoſt repent my treating my ſon ſo ſeverely reſpecting Sophia.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Repent! That is a pretty fancy, and ſo encourage them in their impudence.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: What would you do were you in my caſe?

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: I would diſcard that villain of a ſon, forever—That little ſaucy minx of a daugher—I'd take away all her fine cloaths, confine her to her chamber, and feed her on water-gruel. I'd give that young knave a dreſſing, whom you have brought up. They ſhould obey me, or I would make them all ſkip—that I would.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p:
Your advice does me ſome good—It is ſo abſurd
it diverts me—I want to know what my happineſs would be if I had diſinherited my ſon—ſtarved my daughter—and baniſhed the ſon of my deareſt friend, or what would my neighbors think of me?

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Oh you dread to loſe your children, and be tho't a cruel father.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: I own it. If my children can live without me, I cannot live without them.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: There it is now. I thought you had been more of a man—are you not aſhamed? you have no notion of that lively reſentment which becomes a Father, whoſe authority is inſulted.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Firſt attain the honor of being a father, and then judge of his duties—are you not aſhamed? You would deſolate my houſe, as effectually as the plague.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe I ſhall ſee you kiſſing, and forgiving them all in a few days.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: I hope they will prove themſelves innocent; I wiſh it might be this hour—I could not imagine a greater happineſs.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: I did not intend to have told you, but I'll • art your dull blood—the knave you bro't up is courting your daughter.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Not Cecilia, is he?

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Yes! I have catched them ſeveral times in ſuch a fondling way as made me ſick, perfectly ſick. (He ſpits.)

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Lover's careſſes are apt to be a little • ickiſh to an indifferent obſerver but more to an envious one—how is it, brother?

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: She has ſitten up a great many nights, pretending to work—but there is very little work done. What do you think of that, brother?

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: It is juſt as I would have it be. It is the beſt news I ever heard from you in my life.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: You will do nothing for the honor of the family— but I have—I have got a warrant, and Aimwell is to execute it—to take up this girl as a vagrant, and cart her out of town.

sp.speaker: Fath.
