sp.p: You have done a baſe action—but Aimwell is coming; I will ſtop the proceſs this moment. [Exit Maj.]

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: AIMWELL, what have you done? To execute a warrant againſt an innocent perſon—I ſhould have been glad of your fondneſs for Cecilia, but for this baſe action— I cannot conſent.

sp.speaker: Aim.
sp.p: Then this warrant will ruin me. The deteſtable ſcroll— [throws it under his feet] I will kick it to perdition. [kicks it off the ſtage.]

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Hold—you have not executed it—I am glad of that—give it to me; I will ſee what ſhall be done with it.

sp.speaker: Aim.
sp.p: There it is—I am glad to be rid of it, and will tell the Major you have got it. [Exit Aimwell.]

div.head: SCENE III.—FATHER, SOPHIA and CECILIA.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: CECILIA, tell Sophia to come to me.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: Sophia ſir?

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Yes, you impudent girl, I know you have her here; tell her to come to me. (to Sophia) Sophia I have it in my power to treat you with ſeverity, but I had rather uſe other methods—If you will give up my ſon I will make you a rich girl.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: I cannot, ſir, be guilty of falſhood.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: You ought not to interfere in the rights of my family—you are determined to marry my ſon.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Not till you conſent to it.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: But you will not give him up.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Becauſe I have promiſed that I would not.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Here Sophia, give up my ſon, and take this. Here is enough to buy you a firſt rate huſband at Danbury (puts a purſe into her hands, and ſhe lets it fall.)

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Not for the univerſe, would I ever give up the man of my choice.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Then the warrant muſt have its courſe.

div.stage: [Takes the warrant out and appears to be going]

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p:
(catching his arm) O dear ſir, I implore your pity; tho I cannot give up your ſon — you know the tenderneſs of youthful boſoms—would you have given up your wife, in all the bloom of youth? Leave me not to diſgrace—and
the odious purſuit of laws—moſt humbly do I implore your compaſſion, but cannot give up my friend.

lg.l: "If ever a fond inclination,
"Aroſe in your boſom to rob you of reſt—
"Reflect with a little compaſſion,
"On thoſe ſoft pains you felt in your breaſt,
"Where, where, where, where, could I ſhun him,
"Or would I, how could I, deny his requeſt—
"Kneeling before you,
"Let me implore you,
"O is there no language can move!
"Where, where, where, where, could I ſhun him,
"For hard is the conteſt 'twixt duty and love."

div.head: SCENE I.—FATHER, ALBIN and MAYOR.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: NOTHING can compenſate a man for the loſs of an excellent wife—ſince the death of my dear Cecilia— happineſs has forſaken my houſe—I took in my brother to divert my melancholy—but be only ſows diſſention between me and my children. He has no idea of the family ſtate—my prudent wife foreſaw my miſeries, and adviſed me, that was all I could hear of her laſt broken accents, to marry the "general's ſiſter"—what general I know not. But could I find out whom my wife meant, I would marry again, and ſee if I could not reſtore peace to my family. [Albin enters.]

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Dear ſir, I have a letter, which came by the poſt this day, and it concerns you as well as me. Shall I read it?

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: By all means. (Albin reads.)

body.p:
I SEND you the intelligence which you deſired
me to procure—by the records of Danbury church, it appears that John Clifford, was married to Anne Waterbury, ſiſter of Capt. Waterbury, afterwards general—the 27th of January 1768. Sophia their third child, for they loſt their two firſt—was baptized June 4th 1775—they are a family not of ample fortune, but decent eſtate, of eminent good ſenſe, of the moſt diſtinguiſhed virtues— Sophia ſuſtains an excellent character, in this place—If you can obtain her you will be happy.

closer.signed: I am with all imaginable reſpect, yours, JOSEPH TRUEMAN.

postscript.p: P. S. John Clifford, Sophia's Father, died univerſally regretted, Sept. 29th 1791—the widow who is general Waterbury's ſiſter, is yet alive.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p:
( • lapping him on the ſhoulders)
Albin my boy? This is excellent—you carefully enquired out the character and connections of your virtuous miſtreſs. Few men have ſo much prudence at three times your age—this Anne Waterbury was my firſt love, we ſeparated on account of a violent quarrel between our families; but on a promiſe that if ever we were at liberty we would meet again—ſo Anne Waterbury that was is now my promiſed wife.

(Turning to Albin.) So Albin, if you will accept of the widow Clifford for a mother, Sophia is yours forever; Aimwell is the perſon I wiſh Cecilia to marry—all comes exactly to rights—let friendſhip and love once more reign thro the whole family. (Enter Sophia and Cecilia.)

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: So things are come to a fine paſs, making love and marrying are become the general buſineſs of the houſe. This is no place for me, I • ll get away as faſt as I can, I ſhall be glad to get out of a family where things are carried contrary to every principle of nature, and common ſenſe. (Exit Major.)

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p:
Come my children let me indulge my joy; you have behaved well, I acknowledge it with ſincere delight: it is one of the greateſt of earthly bleſſings to have virtuous children; Aimwell and Cecilia, you need no more fear my diſpleaſure—Sophia, you are my daughter now, and dear to my heart—let us forget our errors, and partake the delights of virtue—now are we—my children, deareſt of my earthly treaſures, now are we happily united.
And we will be ſeparated no more, nor ſhall any ſow diſtruſt and jealouſly between us.

lg.l: What anxious cares a Father's mind employ;
Yet when thoſe cares ſucceed how great his joy.

div.stage: (Father leads—Albin leads off Sophia—Aimwell conducts Cecilia—they leave the ſtage in the higheſt tranſports of joy.)

div.head: The Bottle Conjuror. A DRAMATIC DIALOGUE, IN THREE ACTS.
DISPLAYING THE WEAKNESS OF THOSE WHO BELIEVE IN FORTUNE-TELLERS.
div.p: THE rage of curioſity, enquiring into future events, has been a vice of mankind in every age. There is more wickedneſs in this vice, than every one is aware of. It implies impatience, under the preſent diſpenſations of Divine Providence, and diſtruſt for the future—It often excites deluſive hopes— at other times, fills the mind with needleſs anguiſh and terror—And it greatly injures ſociety, by ſupporting a number of idle, unprincipled wretches, who make a fortune, in earneſt, from the purſes of the credulous.

div.head: PERSONS.

list.head: MEN.
list.item: SHERIFF—ordered by the Juſtice to take Sidrophel.
SUITOR—to Miſs Firebrand, enquiring his fortune.

list.head: WOMEN.
list.item: MISS FIREBRAND—courted by the ſuitor, who was conſulting the conjuror.

div.p: [☞ IF in this dialogue, the ſcene of Miſs Firebrand and Sidrophel be left out; and what the Mother ſays be continued under the name of the Father; it may be performed by men only.]

sp.speaker: Sid.
sp.p: I BEGIN to be aſhamed of myſelf that there is ſo much roguery in the world, and, as yet, I have had no hand in it.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Sir, you ſeem to be very anxious and penſive— Have you met with any thing diſagreeable?

sp.speaker: Sid.
sp.p: I am in deep ſpeculation on a very important matter—I wiſh, like thouſands of my fellows in this world, to get money without earning it. But hitherto, I can hit on no expedient for the purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Sir, I wonder at that very much—I have tho't you had better ſet up for a conjuror.

sp.speaker: Sid.
sp.p: A conjuror! Who would be fool enough to believe any thing of that.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Can you be ſo ignorant of human kind? Do you not know, that if one man has courage to cheat, there will be thouſands who ſtand ready to believe?

sp.speaker: Sid.
sp.p: I can make no calculations on the ſtars.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: That is a matter of no kind of conſequence. Other conjurors know as little of that as you. Only tell ſomething extraordinary—and you will have people enough to believe it

sp.speaker: Sid.
sp.p: By what means ſhall I begin the buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p:
Only look here—Take this bottle and fill it with any kind of liquor—and call it Elixir Planetarium—and give out that he, who taſtes this liquor, immediately becomes ſenſible of the influence of the planets; and that you
can tell the fortunes of all who apply to you. You will find multitudes ready to believe you.

sp.speaker: Sid.
sp.p: There is ſenſe in what you ſay—I will get all matters ready, and do you ſpread a number of ſurpriſing ſtories among the people and prepare them for the ſport.,

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Then you ſhall let me ſhare half of the money.

sp.speaker: Sid.
sp.p: Yes; but do you be filling their minds with ſtrange ſtories without delay. [Exit Sidrophel.]

sp.speaker: Farm.
sp.p: HAVE you ſeen any thing of a roan mare who ſtrayed away, or was ſtolen from my paſture yeſterday?

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: What were her marks?

sp.speaker: Farm.
sp.p: She had three white feet, trotted very ſquare; and had a blaze in her forehead.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: I have not ſeen ſuch a mare—but I believe my maſter can tell you of her—He underſtands ſuch things well.

sp.speaker: Farm.
sp.p: They ſay he underſtands the art of conjuring; and can find loſ • things.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: He has got the true Elixir Planetarium a liquor which diſtills from the moon—and is ſqueezed out of the moſs which grows on the tops of old "ruined caſtles and moſs grown ſteeples." It reſembles ſome of the finer wines —but the taſte of it is very fine—And if any one taſtes it, it makes him ſenſible of the influence of the ſtars, he can tell peoples fortune's—declare the place of loſt goods—and indeed every thing one wants to know.

sp.speaker: Farm.
sp.p: And how came your maſter by this liquor?

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: He has a bottle of it which was owned by Peter the Hermit, who preached up the Cruſades for the recovery of Jeruſalem. It deſcended from him to Dr. Fauſtus— and from him to the famous Radcliffe of London—and it comes by inheritance to my maſter, who is the ſeventh ſon of a ſeventh ſon.

sp.speaker: Farm.
sp.p: That's very ſtrange I'll ſay for't. And can't he tell what has become of my mare?

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: I am confident he can, for he can tell almoſt every thing.

sp.speaker: Farm.
sp.p: Do you know of particular caſes in which he has told the truth?

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p:
Yes, there was a girl in our neighborhood had a ſwee • heart, who was tho't to love her, very much. But
ſhe ſaid—Now my market is made—and • he grew ſluttiſh, and careleſs and fancy. My maſter told her fortune, that ſhe would grow careleſs and he would be ſick of her and leave her—and that ſhe would be miſerable.

sp.speaker: Farm.
sp.p: How did the matter end?

sp.speaker: Ralph
sp.p: Juſt as my maſter told in every particular. You would be ſurprized to find how exact he is.

sp.speaker: Farm.
sp.p: Why that is good gueſſing I count—But one inſtance not enough.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: There was a young man, who courted a very induſtrious girl—He diſliked her and left her, becauſe ſhe had a hard hand, and the ends of her fingers were rough by being pricked with a needle; and the mark of a thimble ſpoiled the beauty of one of her fingers—after he had left her he came to have his fortune told.

sp.speaker: Farm.
sp.p: Immediately after leaving this girl?

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: No, but he was then courting another, whoſe hands were as ſoft as paſte—and there was not the leaſt mark of a needle, thimble, or any blemiſh to be ſeen on her hands.

sp.speaker: Farm.
sp.p: Could your maſter tell his fortune?

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Yes, he told him that he would marry an idle wife who would diſſipate his fortune. And it turned out juſt ſo, in every particular.

sp.speaker: Farm.
sp.p: There is reaſon in that—I gueſs your maſter is no common conjuror.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: He is an extraordinary man—One more inſtance I will tell, which muſt ſurprize you—For, I aſſure you, that bottle of my maſter's is brimful of wiſdom—A young lady of our village truſted a gentleman his mere word for the ſecurity of her reputation—She came to my maſter to tell her fortune—He told her that the wretch would never marry her, and it turned out juſt ſo.

sp.speaker: Farm.
sp.p: How under the heavens could he know that?

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: He would know it above the heavens. Aſſoon as he taſtes the Elixir Planetarium he becomes acquainted with the whole circuit of the ſtars—with all ther aſpects and influence on the earth—and I have often heard him ſay that if a woman truſt her reputation, to the mere word of a man —eight times out of twelve ſhe will repent her confidence.

sp.speaker: Farm.
sp.p: I long to enquire of him about my roan mare.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Then I'll call him immediately.

div.head: SCENE III.—SIDROPHEL and FARMER.
div.stage: (The conjuror enters in a great wig, long gown, ſtaff and bottle.)

sp.speaker: Farm.
sp.p: THEY ſay you tell of things loſt and ſtolen. Can you tell me of my roan mare?

sp.speaker: Sid.
sp.p: As far as the influence of the planets goes; but we have nothing to do with the black art.

sp.speaker: Farm.
sp.p: I've loſt as good a mare as man could wiſh to own.

sp.speaker: Sid.
sp.p: From whence was your mare taken?

sp.speaker: Farm.
sp.p: From my paſture, I ſaw freſh tracks in the dew, about day light.

sp.speaker: Sid.
sp.p: (takes his bottle and looks wiſe.) I perceive that your horſe was taken out of the paſture juſt at morning—And did you ſearch all the public roads?

sp.speaker: Farm.
sp.p: Yes, we did, and ſhe could neither be heard, nor ſeen any where—There is no account of her.

sp.speaker: Sid.
sp.p: I perceive that your mare has got into ſome buy place. (looks very wiſe and important.)

sp.speaker: Farm.
sp.p: That may be.

sp.speaker: Sid.
sp.p: Are there not girls in your neighborhood who are courted?

sp.speaker: Farm.
sp.p: Yes ſir, three, or four.

sp.speaker: Sid.
sp.p: And do their ſuitors live remote from the public road?

sp.speaker: Farm.
sp.p: Yes, two or three of them live very remote from public ways.

sp.speaker: Sid.
sp.p: Well ſir I ſee how this matter is—The planet Venus rules in the evening; that ſen • the young lads in queſt of the girls—In the latter part of the night the influence of Mercury became predominant—that planet impels to thieving—going h • me the young fellows ſtole your mare. They have left her 〈◊〉 that • ye place and there you will find her.

sp.speaker: Farm.
sp.p: What is to pay ſir?

sp.speaker: Sid
sp.p: About fifteen ſhillings, if I aſk any thing, or you may give me what you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Farm.
sp.p: There ſir, I think is juſt the money.

sp.speaker: Sid
sp.p:
Well ſir, ſtep into the other room, and take a drink with 〈◊〉 .
( 〈◊〉 Sidrophel and Farmer.)

sp.speaker: Fire.
sp.p: I HOPE you won't tell Mr. Small thought about me—If the ſtars ſhould let you know, don't tell him any thing about my being ſo paſſionate—I hope to manage the matter to my advantage, for he has been pretty attentive to me and I don't wiſh him to find it out.

sp.speaker: Sid.
sp.p: And have not you other vices too?

sp.speaker: Fire.
sp.p: I don't love to get up early in the morning.

sp.speaker: Sid.
sp.p: You don't love houſework neither.

sp.speaker: Fire.
sp.p: There is ſome truth in that.

sp.speaker: Sid.
sp.p: Well if he marries you there is danger, that he will have an idle paſſionate wife and a bad economiſt.

sp.speaker: Fire.
sp.p: That he may find out—Now it is my deſire that he may not know of it—Could you caſt a ſpell too, to prevent his finding out my being given to tattling, and injuring people's characters?

sp.speaker: Sid
sp.p: Why, I am afraid, there is no art can tame a wanton tongue—I fear the power of all the planets would not reach to that.

sp.speaker: Fire.
sp.p: O ſir, I had no thought that you ſhould confine my tongue, I would not have you do that for the world —But prevent the gentleman's hearing any thing bad of me.

sp.speaker: Sid.
sp.p: Well this matter belongs to Mercury, he has influence over all ſtratagems. When Mercury rules I'll try what can be done. And the price is juſt the ſame, for preventing a things being known as to diſcover what is unknown—I have fifteen ſhilling's for every trip to the ſtars.

sp.speaker: Fire.
sp.p: Well if you can conceal all my faults, I would not grudge ten times the money.

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p:
IT is a grief to me to ſee how eaſily human beings are deceived—Multitudes give money to conjurors,
and fortunetellers freely, who would never give a farthing for any honeſt purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Sher.
sp.p: Why ſir, we muſt take mankind as we find them, and do them all the good we can. I know nothing more humane than to bear men's vices if we muſt, and cure them if we can.

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: But ſince I am come into office I will turn over a new leaf in this neighborhood—The people ſhall not go after conjurors and witch-men. I'll proſecute ſuch fellows as vagrants to the utmoſt rigor of law—They ſhall have ſomething elſe to do than to ſhow magic lanthorns, and ſet up conjuring bottles. Such fools defy the whole commonwealth?

sp.speaker: Sher.
sp.p: How much influence they have I cannot ſay, nor how you will prevent them.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: I'll apprehend this ſame Sidrophel, by warrant— when we have him under authority we'll get the whole matter out of him.

sp.speaker: Sher.
sp.p: Sir excuſe me, I am apt to be nervous. If I ſhould ſee a ghoſt, or a devil, it would fright me to death.

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: Are you a fool? How many ghoſts and devils can he cork up in his old junk? Do you ſuppoſe it would hold as many as Mary Magdalen's? You ſhall ſerve the warrant or be broke.

sp.speaker: Sher.
sp.p: You may procure me to be broke, but your worſhip ſhould conſider that he can turn himſelf into all ſorts of ſhapes—and if he ſhould turn himſelf into a dead horſe without a head, ſtretch his noſe out half a yard long, or ſwell out his eyes as big as two warming pans, I ſhould be ſo frighted that I ſhould not get over it in a mouth; and folks ſay he can do this, or any thing elſe.

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: For ſhame to believe ſuch nonſenſe. Take this warrant, and execute it, or it will be the worſe for you.

div.head: SCENE II.—HOLDFAST, followed by FARMER, MILLER, FATHER and SUITOR, with a mob, armed with clubs.

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: WHY do you follow me thus? What's your will?

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.p: Our Bottleman is as good a man as you, Mr Juſtice. He told me how to find old Roan. If you offer to meddle with him. I'll burn your houſe over your head.

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p:
Shame neighbor, how fooliſhly you talk—to expoſe
your life for a wretched juggler. Have you any reaſon?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Mr. Juſtice, you have got to be a great man ſince you got your commiſſion. Will you take up our Bottleman? If you do, (ſhaking his club) I'll open my mill-dam and drown all your flax.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: I want to know my children's fortunes—if you take up our bottle prophet and put him into jail, I'll raiſe a mob, and give you a new ſuit of tar and feathers.

sp.speaker: Suit.
sp.p: I want to know if Miſs Firebrand will have me— and if you offer to take up our Bottleman, I'll way lay you and knock your brains out. You may put the Doctor, the muſic maſter, all into jail, with all the ſchool maſters in town—you may burn the meetinghouſe, and all the ſchool houſes in town; but if you touch our Bottleman you touch my heart's blood.

sp.speaker: Hold.

div.head: SCENE III.—SIDROPHEL, MILLER, FATHER, MOTHER and SUITOR.

sp.speaker: Sid.
sp.p: YOU do well, fellow citizens▪ to conſult the ſtars. They know every thing that is done in this world.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: I knew a miller ſir, that fixed a bag below the box which contains the meal that is grinding, in ſuch a manner, as to catch meal from the box—and he called this practice making preſents to his Peggy.

sp.speaker: Sid.
sp.p: Well ſir, and what is your will?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: I wiſh to know whether this miller will ever be detected.

sp.speaker: Sid.
sp.p:
(taſting his bottle and looking wiſe) This is a matter
of ſtealing—it belongs to Mercury—yes—this Mercury tells, that the rogue is yourſelf. Going home you will find a man who has Peggy and all the preſents you have given her in the mouth of his bag. [The miller is going away, but he calls after him.] Stop ſir, and pay your fifteen ſhillings, o • I will bring you out in ſome of your other tricks.

sp.speaker: Fath
sp.p: I have a ſon; I wiſh very much to know his fortune—Something makes me anxious about him. He is a likely well made fe • low; and I want to know whether I had beſt ſend him to college, and make a learned man of him.

sp.speaker: Sid.
sp.p: How does he like inſtruſtion at home?

sp.speaker: Fath
sp.p: He would like it pretty well, I believe, if we could ever get a ſchool maſter that was worth the money—But he is diſſatisfied with all we have had yet—and indeed according to his account, they were wretched fellows.

sp.speaker: Sid.
sp.p: Does he drink hard?

sp.speaker: Fath
sp.p: Not very; I never knew him drunk more than four or five times in my life.

sp.speaker: Sid
sp.p: How is he with reſpect to the women?

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Pretty well—he is often playing with the girls whom I hire to do my work; but he is rather baſhful with your genteel women, your fine ladies.

sp.speaker: Sid.
sp.p: (taſting his bottle) Well, this is a matter of learning—It depends on the Sun—by the the antients called Apollo, the God of Wiſdom. He finds much fault with his ſchool maſters.—He hates learning then. At College he'll kick up a rumpus a • d diſturb the government. He has been drunk ſeveral time —He will be a capital hand for high goes. He plays with hired maids, and is abaſhed and confounded among modeſt women—This is the opinon which I have drawn from the Sun; that he will be a rake, a dirty low rake.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: (pays cheerfu • ly) I do not grudge the money —my wife I hope will be eaſy on that ſcore. [Exit Father.]

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Sir, I have two daughters, and of very different manners▪ I ſhould be glad to know their fortunes The eldeſt is given to ſcandal, and is nice about her company, to a very great ex • reme—There are none but • ip tops that can ſpeak to her. But I'm a plain woman; ſhe has not birth, and certainly not fortune nor accompliſhments to boaſt of.

sp.speaker: Sid.
sp.p: (taſting his bottle) Venus has the charge of theſe matters; and madam Venus ſays; the queen of beauty declares; that this daughter of yours muſt be an old maid —for it has lately been ordained, in the court of celeſtial beauty, that every girl (now a juſter law was never made) that every girl that is given to ſcandal and ill nature, and diſſimulation, ſhall be an old maid.—That the good tempered, tender, agreeable girls, who at the ſame time are ſociable and diſcreet, ſhall marry young, genteel, handſome lads, who will be fond huſbands even to old age.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Then there will be a reformation among the women ſoon.

sp.speaker: Sid.
sp.p: Certainly, it begins to operate already.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: My other girl is handſome, lively, good tempered, fond of good books, and good men; neat in her dreſs, ſociable, and tender; yet ſhe is a good prudent girl—She has the name of a very prudent girl.

sp.speaker: Sid.
sp.p: I predict her fortune will be very good. She will be courted early in life, marry a likely man who will ſupport her genteelly and live very well.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Well (taking money and paying cheerfully) I do not grudge the money, now I ſhall know what to do with them.

sp.speaker: Suit.
sp.p: Sir, I am courting a maiden lady of fortune, who is paſt fifty, and—

sp.speaker: Ralph,
sp.p: SIR the ſheriff is coming, to ſerve a warrant on you immediately.

sp.speaker: Sid.
sp.p: (putting on his viſor aſide) Now let him come if he dares. (The conjuror comes forward—The ſheriff comes on with his warrant, is about to clap Sidrophel on the ſhoulder when he diſplays his viſor, breathing from his mouth.)

sp.speaker: Sid.
sp.p: Thou enemy of the arts and antichriſt of the ſciences, avaunt, begone.

sp.speaker: Sher.
sp.p: (in a terrible fright.) O mercy, mercy, mercy on us, O terrible oh, dreadful oh! (Flies off the ſtage and Sidrophel and Ralph purſues him.)

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: How do you do ſir?

sp.speaker: Sid.
sp.p: Well, and • earty what do you want of me ſir?

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Nothing very ſpecial; but as I was walking with ſome people acroſs the plain, with ſeveral young ladies— I tho • it my duty to call on you, upon ſome ſerious buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Sid.
sp.p: What do you wiſh to know ſir? whether you ſhall meet with ſucceſs with the ladies. Is that it ſir?

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: No, ſir, by no means, but as I came along I ſaw your barn and ſtable all in a blaze and I knew your beſt horſe to be in the ſtable.

sp.speaker: Sid.
sp.p: You villain why did you not tell me before.; they are all in a blaze before this time—Now they are all in aſhes before this time—Run Ralph run. (they run out in haſte.) (Holdfaſt enters.)

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: WHAT have you done with him?

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: We ſhall now have him faſt enough—for in fact his ſtable is on fire.

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: Here he has left all his tools behind him.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: He has; there's his viſor, his bottle, ſtaff and all.

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: And this is that which put the Sheriff in ſuch a terrible fright.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Yes, but is perfectly harmleſs now—And here's the bottle—Let us taſte—It did not poiſon him neither will it poiſon us.

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: Let us drink it off—or take a genteel ſip at leaſt. Do you ſuppoſe, we ſhall underſtand the ſtars—It may make us ſee ſtars if it be too ſtrong.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: We will not drink the whole. (Sets the bottle down.) Now let us fill it with about 150 drops of laudanum and that will give him a decent nap. (Drops Laudanum from a vial into the bottle.)

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: That will be very dextrous—Now I truſt Mr. Conjuror will find his match. And we ſhall accompliſh by art, what we could not accompliſh by open means, thro the madneſs of the mob—But do you ſtay here, and amuſe him when he returns.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: (to Sidrophel.) HAVE you loſt any valuable property.

sp.speaker: Sid.
sp.p: I have not loſt any thing of great conſequence, tho my ſtable was indeed on fire, but in ſuch a manner as eaſily to be extinguſhed—But you did not help us to put it out.

sp.speaker: Sly
sp.p: I have long ſince much uſed myſelf to Philoſophy— and am not moved with the accidents of this life. But can you tell my fortune?

sp.speaker: Sid.
sp.p: Your fortune I ſuſpect is to be hanged, for you are a rogue in grain You told me my ſtables were on fire, but never • ent the leaſt aſſiſtance to put it out. I ſuſpect you ſet the fire yourſelf

sp.speaker: Sly
sp.p: One who knows the plane's as well as you. ſhould not ſuſpect; he might know—Now calculate upon the influence of the planets, and if you can furniſh any proof by means of them, I ſhall be hanged no doubt: but if you will not calculate for me, you may go to ſleep.

div.head: SCENE IV.—SUITOR and SIDROPHEL.

sp.speaker: Suit.
sp.p: Sir, we we were broken off before, by the cry of the fire—Tell me now, ſir, what will be the conſequence if I marry Miſs Firebrand.

sp.speaker: Sid.
sp.p: (taſting his bottle) Why ſir, this is the oddeſt love affair that ever I had any concern with. Venus has nothing to do with it. The queen of love is quite out of the queſtion Mercury has a hand in it, as it is a matter of gain. You will make yourſelf rich by it—But then Mars, the fiery planet, has a hand in it—There will be wars (he nods) and fightings between you—yes, yes, yes—you will —you'll quarrel—yes—O dear, how ſleepy I am—I think you'll quarrel—ſir—

div.stage: [He ſinks down and is ſoon faſt aſleep]

div.head: SCENE V —HOLDFAST, SHERIFF, and aſſiſtants; and SLYBOOTS.

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: Here he is, Mr. Sheriff; and here is his bottle, and his formidable viſor which affrighted you. How vain all your fears were you may now ſee.

sp.speaker: Sly
sp.p: If he knew the ſtars could he not have known what we were about to do with him?

sp.speaker: Hold
sp.p: No doubt, and from this you may ſee how credulous thoſe people are who believe in people who have a preſent intereſt to deceive them.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Alas, my formidable aſtronomer, man familiar with the ſtars, O Lucifer how art thou fallen—Up and take a ſip of the Elixir Planetarium, and tell us all t •• t is doing among the ſtars—Thou art overcome by •• yboots— how weak is human wiſdom.

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: Here Mr. Sheriff take this mitt • mus, and for the preſent commit him to jail.

div.head: The Apparition. A DRAMA, IN THREE ACTS.
VICE, IN GENERAL, IS THE CAUSE OF SUPERSTITION.
div.p: WE ſay, in general, becauſe ſometimes ſuperſtition ariſes from weakneſs of mind, or accidental cauſes.—But, in general, the mind which is conſcious of guilt, is, by that very ſenſation, prepared to ſee ghoſts, devils, and furies, and all the armies of terror. It is probable that Brutus had never ſeen Caeſar's ghoſt at Em •• hia, had he not been conſcious to himſelf that he was the aſſaſſin and murderer of Caeſar. It is eaſy to ſee, from theſe obſervations, how neceſſary it is, that we keep our minds free from guilt; that we may enjoy contentment and happineſs.

list.head: Two young gentlemen of the country.
WOMEN.
list.item: ROSINA—a girl extremely fond of amuſement • .

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: WELL, you will allow that I contrived the entertainment, we have had this evening.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Was it not agrreeable?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Yes, while it laſted.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: And it is quite agreeable to think of it, when it is over.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: It is common for me to feel dull after a frolic.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: I think girls we have a chearful proſpect. I never ſaw our young beaux behave half ſo well, as they did this evening.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: I have often ſuppoſed the girls here had a melancholy view of time to come—our young ſparks were ſo dull and numpiſh—but they ſhone out this evening quite plauſibly. Yet after all I feel dull and heavy, and heavy I muſt feel.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: You are a heavy, dumpiſh, creature, I know; I hope ſome of the reſt of the girls will come in and relieve me. [Enter Rhoda]

div.head: SCENE II.—RHODA and ROSINA.
div.stage: (Almeria is penſive thro this whole ſcene.)

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: WHAT ails Almeria? She is as dull as a block.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: I am afraid you will not find me any better.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: What ails you? Has the dance tired you out. It never tires me. I could dance forever.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: It is not the dance that tires me. The reflections of my mind are diſagreeable.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Now Almeria thinks that we never had ſo fine a proſpect of having a ſet of agreeable young gentlemen about us, as at preſent.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: That proſpect gives me very little comfort now.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Why now?

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: Becauſe I fear, if they be worthy of our regards, that we have behaved in ſuch a manner as to be unworthy of theirs.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Why unworthy of theirs?

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: Becauſe Almeria, Levania, and myſelf, as well as you, came out this evening with an expreſs promiſe to our parents that we would be back again by ten—They know not where we are, and even now it is almoſt two in the morning.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: And why did you not think of that in the time of it?

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: The muſic, the dance, the refreſhment, ſo exhilirated my ſpirits, that I found it next to impoſſible to get away —and when the time was now elapſed, the ſhower detained us; as the time was paſt I thought we might as well be killed for a great fault as a ſmall one — ſo I concluded to ſtay.

div.head: SCENE III.—LEVANIA, ALMERIA, ROSINA and RHODA.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: DO you not feel very diſagreeably, now the dance is over?

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: She expected Mr. Lightfoot would have remained —Her comfort is departed.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: It would not have been in his power to have afforded me much conſolation.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: What do you ſuppoſe our parents think of us?

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: I know not; but muſt ſuppoſe they are very uneaſy — I dare ſay mine have not ſlept a wink this night.— They are always uneaſy, when I ſtay out late, and they know not what has become of me.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: And what account can we give of ourſelves, on our return?

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: What account ladies? I wonder you ſhould be puzzled about that. I can manage that matter very well.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: I wonder how?

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: I am ſurprized that you can be ſo dull—I can fix the whole buſineſs, as nicely as can be. Only tell them that there has fallen a ſhower this night, that it began to rain in the place where we were, at half paſt nine—and never left raining till paſt two in the morning.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: That I ſuppoſe we muſt tell, or meet with a very diſagreeable reception. Tho I muſt confeſs the ſtory is bad enough, take it lie and all.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: That is the moſt plauſible ſtory we can tell, I ſuppoſe whether it be true or not.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: I ſhall tell my parents the whole truth, be the conſequence what it may—I ſhall have nothing to do with your fictitious ſtories; for we may depend on it that the black man will have us, if we tell ſuch abominable lies.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Why Rhoda! what do you mean? You talk enough to fright one.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: I talk juſt as I think, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: There is another thing to think of which is as perplexing as any thing can be. There has no one invited us to ſtay here. How ſhall we get any reſt?

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: I'll manage that matter too. I will go to the 'Squire's daughter, and ſee how we can be accommodated: pick up all your things, and have them ready; and if we cannot reſt here, we will all ſet out together a little before day, ſo as to get home, before the people are up in the morning.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: A pretty figure we ſhall make, but for that matter, no body will ſee us. (Exeunt omnes)

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.p: NOW let us conſider what is to be done with theſe girls. Will you ſee them home?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Not I, I have tired myſelf already, with dancing and waiting on the miſſes.

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.p: But it would be unpolite to let them go home alone.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Why, they came out alone; and they may return alone—No one invited them here.

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.p: Then I ſhall not trouble myſelf with them.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Nor I, for they ſtole away from their parents; and if we go home with them, their parents will believe that we enticed them away, and we ſhall get a bad name.

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.p: I am aſtoniſhed that the girls ſhould not think of that, how they expoſe themſelves by ſuch things—I ſhould be afraid to marry ſuch a girl, for fear ſhe ſhould run away from me.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: I leave them to you. You may be 'ſquire to them all if you pleaſe. (Exit Philander)

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: ARE all the young ladies gone yet?

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.p: No; Roſina, and they who came with her, are in the ball room now.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why have you not the complaiſance to wait on them home?

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.p: They ſtole away from their parents; and now if we wait on them home, it will be tho't that we ſeduced them away.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What a reflection for a young man—had you been ſixty years old, I ſhould not have wondered to hear you make it.

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.p: I am ten times more intereſted in the virtue of young girls than any man of ſixty—When I marry I ſhall wiſh to have a wife that won't run away.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: IS not the company all gone yet? I am tired and wiſh to go to reſt. Have you aſked any of them to tarry here to night?

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: Not one, I did not know how you would like it, as I underſtand my Papa leaves all theſe things to you in his abſence.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: Are they in the back parlour yet?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
No, I believe they are gone into the ball room— But they cannot go away, for it is tremendous dark; and
the moon does not riſe till a quarter paſt three—There has been a ſhower too! and the roads are all full of water.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: And why did not ſome of the young gentlmen wait on theſe girls home?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Becauſe they knew they run away from their parents; and they were afraid to go home with them leſt it ſhould be tho't that they ſeduced them away.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: That is quite curious—but a young man of twenty five is always more rigid in his ideas of women's morals, than a man of ſixty five.

sp.speaker: Smil.
sp.p: (ſtarting up and ſpeaking quick) And don't you know the reaſon of that ma'am?

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: Why what is it?

sp.speaker: Smil.
sp.p: The young men ſuffer by the faults of the girls. The old ones are not afraid of it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: That's a deep obſervation for you miſs; where did you learn all this wiſdom?

sp.speaker: Smil.
sp.p: I knew our Pat would ſtart to hear me ſay ſo— But I heard Pâ ſay ſo himſelf once; but Pat don't like to hear of it, I know.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: How came there to be ſuch a collection of young people here to night?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: It was all Roſina's contrivance, ſhe loves frolicks, and is a perfect witch at intrigue to get young people together in the abſence of the elder ones; that they may take the more liberty together.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: I fear the 'Squire's diſpleaſure—were this houſe mi • e I ſhould not like ſo much company in my abſence.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: He will not like it. He ſays the amuſements of young people ſhould not exclude the obſervation of the elder—Becauſe the obſervations of the elder perſons inſpire the young ones with a ſenſe of decency—and the aged by ſympathy enjoy over again the delights of youth.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: That I ſuppoſe contributed to the happineſs of both—I've heard him ſay that in Switzerland they dance after prayers in the evening, and the elder people wait on the young ones—I don't like this creeping into houſes, in the abſence of their owners—A ſhyneſs between the elder people, and the younger ones, denotes vulgariſm in manners and a low ſtate of ſociety.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What will you do with them—will you turn theſe four girls out of doors?

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: No, give them ſome buttered rolls and beer, and then put them to bed in the chamber where the 'Squire commonly ſleeps—So I will go to reſt; and you may go to the ball-room and ſee how the girls are to be diſpoſed of.

div.head: SCENE IV.—MARTHA, ROSINA, ALMERIA, RHODA, and LEVANIA.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: SINCE the ladies are willing to ſtay we will lodge them in the haunted chamber.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: The haunted chamber did you ſay? I ſhould not ſleep a wink.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: It is only a notion about its being haunted—It is as handſome a room as any in the whole houſe—The 'Squire ſleeps there when at home—and his man George in the little room adjoining—There are two beds perfectly neat, and well aired—juſt ſufficient for you four ladies.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: But for heaven's ſake don't put us to bed in a haunted chamber.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why, I tell you it is nothing but a notion.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: How do you know it is nothing but a notion?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: My mother always uſed to ſleep there; ſhe was a Church of England woman, and always ſaid her prayers by book—ſhe had a reading deſk over the Sofa againſt the inner wall, where ſhe uſed to kneel and ſay her prayers.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: What connection has that with the chamber's being haunted?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Only ſince my mother's death a vapory old woman who has lived with us, ſays that between day-light and dark, ſhe has ſeen my mother in that chamber, reading her prayers, juſt as if alive.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: And did none of the reſt of the family ſee her?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Never. My Sir. always ſleeps there, when at home. My mamma has been dead about eighteen months— and my papa ſays there is no place ſo pleaſant to him, as where ſhe uſed to be—If ſhe comes he ſays he ſhould be glad to ſee her—for as ſhe never did any thing, but good, in her life time—he cannot think ſhe would hurt any perſon now ſhe's dead.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: And is not any one of the family afraid to lodge there?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
No, no more than any where elſe—It is only by way of joke that we call it the haunted chamber—You may
ſtay here Ladies till I get a light—It will be perfectly ſafe for you.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: WELL what will you do ladies? Will you ſleep in the haunted chamber?

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: I am not afraid, for I am determined to tell no lies —What do you ſay Almeria? That was a pretty lie you contri • ed to tell your parents when you went home.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: I don't like ſleeping in a haunted chamber very well —we may poſſibly get a fright.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: I ſuſpect there may be ſome truth in the ſtory about the old lady's appearance. I have heard of a number of ſuch things in my life.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: And ſo have I; but I never believed them. What is the reaſon, that people of the beſt ſenſe, and beſt underſtanding, never ſee ſuch things? But they are commonly ſeen by nervous, hypocondriac, or half crazy perſons. I do not ſay ſuch things never were; but I believe moſt ſtories of that kind are without foundation.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: I do not know what to think of ſuch things; but I know it is natural for me to be afraid; and I own I do now.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: I wiſh I never had thought of going from home this evening.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: O, you are a faint hearted creature as ever exiſted—You are not capable of doing any thing that is ingenious—I am not yet twenty years old—and I have contrived up more than a hundred evening parties already—I love amuſements. Life is inſipid without them.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: And ſo it is a pretty amuſement to lodge in a haunted chamber—I gueſs you will meet with ſomething to try your high ſpirits yet.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: I proteſt I am not in the leaſt afraid. Let old grand mother come if ſhe will, and ſay her prayers—If ſhe be a good woman—we ſhall ſleep the ſafer for that. Come, come, let's go.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: I feel afraid—I do not wiſh to go—I do not love to ſleep in a haunted chamber.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: Nor I, and am willing to own it.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: O for ſhame girls, what cowards you are, afraid of nothing—come—come along, or I will leave you here in the dark. [Exit all the Ladies.]

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: WELL Smiley, where's your Doll?

sp.speaker: Smil.
sp.p: I have put it where you cannot find it.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I ſhall get it yet—and cut its head off.

sp.speaker: Smil.
sp.p: O you cruel, barbarous wretch, to go to murder my poor baby, little innocent, that never did any harm in its life.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I ſet my black cat to day on your white one, and ſhe has ſtript her ears all into fiddleſtrings; and one of theſe days I intend to kill her. (Exit Simon.)

sp.speaker: Smil.
sp.p: I TELL you what Patty, our Simon is a rogue— he's always ſetting his black cat on my white one; and he ſays he means to kill my cat.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: He ſhall not kill your cat. If he does he ſhall be turned out of doors.

sp.speaker: Smil.
sp.p: Then he is always plagning my babies. He ſays he'll get my prettieſt Doll; and cut off its head.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Simon had better mind his manners, or he'll be turned out of his place, when papa comes home.

sp.speaker: Smil.
sp.p: I do think pâ will do right to turn him off if he does ſuffer by it, he is ſo forever playing the rogue.

div.head: SCENE III.—ROSINA, and her aſſociates enter, ſcreaming out with a fright.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: O MERCY help us, I never was ſo frighted in my life—the chamber is certainly haunted.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: There are more than a thouſand evil ſpirits in it now.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: And what a ſhocking noiſe they made? I never heard any thing before ſo terrible. Dear me, what ſhall I do?

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: Did you ſee that great ſomething all in white—It was as big as a man.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: And there was ſomething all in black. It ſeemed to be as big as a horſe; and it had eyes like balls of fire.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: That was old Satan himſelf, I do believe; I never ſaw any thing ſo dreadful.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: And there were a thouſand little white creatures that flew all about the chamber like lightening—it was the dreadfulleſt ſight I ever ſaw—I never believed ſuch things before.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: Theſe are ſerious matters ladies—and we muſt think of our bad actions, and be ſorry, elſe we know not what will become of us.—I am ſorry now, ladies, that I ever did any thing but what was ſtrictly honeſt, we had better own the whole truth, and not tell any lies about our going out, elſe the black creature we ſaw will have us all.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: Yes, you know I told you ſo—I believe that it was he whom we ſaw, that it was old Satan himſelf—and we had better take care of ourſelves—did you hear what noiſe he made when he trotted away? He made a noiſe as loud as a horſe treating on a barn floor.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: O dear! I ſhall always be afraid to go out a nights after this. (Pompoſa enters.)

sp.speaker: Pomp.
sp.p: Ladies how came you to diſturb me with your noiſe? I have to riſe early, and work hard; and I think it unkind, that when you have your lodging given you, you ſhould diſturb the whole family with your noiſe.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: We could not help it—you put us to bed in a haunted chamber.

sp.speaker: Pomp.
sp.p: But you have not been to bed, you are in your proper dreſs now—you ſit up I believe on purpoſe to make a noiſe.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p:
No, Miſs Martha gave us a candle, and we attempted to go into the chamber, and the candle burnt blue and almoſt went out—and I was going to take a pin, and pick open the wick; on a ſudden I heard the dreadfulleſt noiſe that ever I heard in my life, and I ſaw ſomething all in white, nearly as large as a man, fly off one way; and another all black, which the ladies ſay looked as big as a horſe, trotted off another way, and made a noiſe as loud as a horſe ſtepping on a barn floor. The candle burnt dim and blue, and there was a ſtrong ſmell of brimſtone, all the while, and no one could know how many white creatures were ſeen flying about the chamber like lightning.
How came you to put the ladies to bed in the chamber if you knew it to be haunted?

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: I knew nothing of the matter, nor ever believed it to be haunted—Ladies, are you not deceived?

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: The candle burnt very dim and blue, but we could ſee.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: O yes, we could diſtinguiſh objects, and colors: I could ſee the great black creature, and the white one, and the ſmaller ones, all flying about: It was a dreadful ſight.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: I ſaw them plainly.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: So did I!

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: All this is perfectly aſtoniſhing to me. I never heard of any ſuch thing before, much leſs believed it.

div.head: SCENE IV.—The ſame Ladies—SMILINDA enters, crying out.

sp.speaker: Smil
sp.p: They ſhan't kill my cat! They ſhan't kill my cat! You won't let them kill my cat, will you?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why who is going to kill your cat?

sp.speaker: Smil.
sp.p: Simon ſays he'll kill my cat.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No my dear, he ſhall not kill her; but why does he ſay ſo?

sp.speaker: Smil.
sp.p: Why, I took my white cat with all her ſweet little white kittens and I put all nine of them into Pa's bed, you can't think how pretty they looked all nine of them together—Then Simon went and got his great awful black cat, and ſhod her feet all round with walnut ſhells, ſticking them on with wax. And then he ſent him right into the chamber amongſt my cat and kittens, and at it they went, fighting, and frighted the ladies almoſt out of their wits, and now Simon ſays he'll kill my cat, becauſe ſhe ſcared the ladies, and his cat ſcared them full as much as mine— For he made an awful noiſe trotting away on his four ſhoes.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: There ladies the matter is all out now—I adviſe you to go home and never ſteal away from your parents any more, nor frame any lies to excuſe the matter; for a guilty CONSIENCE can turn nutſhells into horſe ſhoes, and cats into devils, and even do ſtranger things than all that.

div.head: The Wooden Boy. A DRAMATIC DIALOGUE, IN THREE ACTS.
THE FOLLY OF LOCAL PREJUDICES.
div.p: PERHAPS there is not a prejudice in human beings more unfriendly to ſociety than that which improperly called local prejudice. A remarkable inſtance of this we have between cits and clowns—In the exerciſe of this prejudice it is difficult to ſay which diſcovers the moſt impenetrable ſtupidity. The cits commonly, however, are moſt inſolent: the clowns have, perhaps, the moſt ſettled malice. Differing diſtricts of the ſame nation often carry it almoſt to open hoſtility—How can men ſo far forget, that they are all of the ſame ſpecies, and have the ſame feelings?

list.head: MEN.
list.item: MR. FREEMAN, OR JOHN HICKORY, a polite young gentleman, affecting to be a ruſtic.
JACK BATTLEDOOR—a boxer, affecting to be a high fellow.
CHRISTOPHER—a waiter in a boarding ſchool.

list.head: WOMEN.
list.item: MYRA—a miſs, favorite of Harry Plume.
SISTERS—of Mr. Freeman who appear but do not ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Plume.
sp.p: I WONDER what the marvellous cauſe can be that our young fellows do not ſtudy the art of dreſs!

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: I think the art of boxing of much greater conſequence.

sp.speaker: Plume.
sp.p: Dreſs recommends us to the ladies, dear creatures; my heart is charmed with them; tho people laugh at me, for taking notice of them becauſe I am ſo young.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: But you can learn puſh, parry, quart and tierce, I mean to learn the art of fencing before I make pretenſions to the ladies, and then if a man rivals me, I'll call him out.

sp.speaker: Plume.
sp.p: I gueſs I'm not far from being a man, for when the miſs Linnets ſung laſt evening—they are ſweet little angels you know—I felt my heart go pi • a pat as plain as day light. If I be not pretty near a man, I wonder what in the name of beauty, that could mean.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: I care not, I love to throw every boy in the ſchool of my age; and beat every one of my ſize in boxing—then, if I like any of the girls, I can defend myſelf in poſſeſſion.

sp.speaker: Plume.
sp.p: But to make the girls like you, that is a ſerious matter, to captive their little tender ſouls, then you may keep them forever.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: I would rather undertake to knock down a boy of twice my ſize, than to flatter a girl, or even to coax her to walk with me half a mile.

sp.speaker: Plume.
sp.p: You and I ſhall not agree in our notions—But do you know that we are to have a new ſtudent, in our ſchool, to day?

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: I heard of it—They ſay his name is John Hickory, and that he comes from the town of Bruſhwood, a rare wooden fellow—I dare ſay we ſhall pick fun out of him. (Enter Hotſpur.)

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Well boys, they ſay we ſhall have a queer fellow come into ſchool to day—We ſhall have muſic with him.

sp.speaker: Plume.
sp.p: I wonder you ſhould not have the prudence to acquaint yourſelf with the ſweet little angels, and l •• rn genteel manners, as I do.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: If he comes I gueſs I ſhall box him, or at leaſt I ſhall challenge him to wreſtle with me at the firſt daſh, that's my way.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: I'll try, and ſee how he'll bear a joke. Th • y ſay he dreſſes very queerly, all out of faſhion. We ſhall joke him all to rags.

sp.speaker: Plume.
sp.p: I wonder he ſhould not dreſs himſelf when he comes to ſchool, becauſe that's a matter of importance.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: I mean to buy me a jeſt book, and learn to joke by rule—It will coſt only one dollar, and wit, you know, is worth every thing.

sp.speaker: Plume.
sp.p: Better lay it out in pomatum to keep your hair ſlick; and give it an agreeable ſmell; that will make the young ladies like you.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: When I get all the wit in the world, the ladies will like me for my wit; and then I ſhall be as ſmart as any man.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: I am determined to learn boxing and the back ſword; for if you and I travel together, as we may; when you affront a man with your wit, then I ſhall have to fight him.

sp.speaker: Plume.
sp.p: Rare work you'll make of it, and I ſhall have to follow you in order to make peace. So we have buſineſs planned out for the reſt of our lives.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: We will contrive ſome way to make fun of neighbor Hickory—I love to take a fellow, who can't ſay his ſoul is his own, and give him a hearty ſweat.

sp.speaker: Plume.
sp.p: Now I had rather pleaſe one girl, than plague ten boys, and there is more amuſement in it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: NOTHING gives a greater luſtre to learning than prudence and good morals. I cannot join you in afflicting our new companion, it can only render us odious.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: You never had any ſpirit for fun more than my grandmother—Always preaching your grum morals, what do you ſay Jack, ſhall we give up to him?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Not till he has had a ſpice of my jokes; I mean to try titles with him for the greateſt wit.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: If he can give me a fall, or beat me in boxing, then I'll allow him to be a good fellow.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: I'm aſhamed of you both—forever in riots and miſchief—a terror to the neighborhood. You'll ſooner be in priſon than in Congreſs, at this rate of proceeding.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: What a preacher! Let's collect money to buy him a new black coat—and he ſhall hold forth to the ſchool.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: You will need no preacher. Soon the conſequences of your folly will give you tormenting conviction, very ſoon.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: Think I'll give back for you—I'll only go deeper —I'll get a blanket, and toſs Mr. Wooden head in a blanket. [Exit Martin, and after him the reſt.]

sp.speaker: Hick.
sp.p: SIR can you introduce me into the ſchool?

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.p: No! (in a ſurly tone.)

sp.speaker: Hick.
sp.p: Why not? (complaiſantly.)

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.p: I have no time to wait on ſuch wooden headed fellows—You came from the town of Bruſhwood—I muſt attend to my buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Hick.
sp.p: Sir it will take you but a moment to introduce me.

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.p: I cannot ſpend my time to wait on you—You have no more manners than a bear—What ſort of people live, where you came from?

sp.speaker: Hick.
sp.p: A very rough unſociable people I muſt ſay to their diſhonor—They will refuſe to direct a ſtranger on his way —aſk the town he came from, and tell him he has no more manners than a bear.

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.p: That is pretty much as they do here.

sp.speaker: Hick.
sp.p: Will you pleaſe to direct me into the common room?

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.p: You muſt firſt croſs the yard—then turn over to the left—then you muſt come to the right again—then you muſt go back again to the left—then come to the right, and take a winding courſe up the back ſtairs into the common room.

sp.speaker: Hick.
sp.p: It is impoſſible to find the way by theſe directions. Here, I'll give you this if you will ſhow me the way.

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.p: I will wait on you ſir. (Looks wiſhfully at the money) But I muſt aſk leave of abſence of the maſter of the kitchen. [Exit Chriſtopher.]

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: WELL, Sir what's your name?

sp.speaker: Hick.
sp.p: John Hickory ſir.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: What town did you come from?

sp.speaker: Hick.
sp.p: Bruſhwood; a very remote part of the ſtate.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: You are the fellow I have been hearing of a number of days paſt—they told me there was a ſtrange, woodenheaded fellow coming from Bruſhwood, a dark obſcure hole, and that he had no more manners than a bear.

sp.speaker: Hick.
sp.p: Well what do you think of him?

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: Think of you—Why as to your own proper ſelf, you look paſſably well—But then how you dreſs, all as far from the faſhion as from Nova Scotia to Georgia—What do you mean by wearing that old bayonet-hat—Your coat is half a yard too ſhort—oh! fun indeed! this is pretty! what a coat!—and then your hair tied up with a leather— whang — You like old Jeremy—fact!—Why ſir, what ſort of people are they at Bruſhwood?

sp.speaker: Hick.
sp.p: They are a very droll people it would make you laugh to ſee their manners.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: Why, how are they?

sp.speaker: Hick
sp.p: O they are ſo ridiculous, they ſay you love fun— it would make you die with laughing.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: I long to hear then—Let us have it.

sp.speaker: Hick.
sp.p:
The firſt thing theſe coarſe, rough people do, when they ſee a ſtranger—is to aſk him what is his name—where
he came from—they tell him he is a fellow they have heard of before—that he is a ſtrange wondenheaded fellow, with no more manners than a bear—then they examine his perſon, and tell him he looks paſſably, but his dreſs is out of faſhion—his hat is not right, and his coat is half a yard too long or too ſhort—they find fault with the tying of his hair, and aſk what ſort of people they were in the town from whence he came.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: You lie. Thoſe are not the manners of the people at Bruſhwood.

sp.speaker: Hick.
sp.p: They are ſir, and you may enquire of any perſon you pleaſe—They are the manners of all people who have no ſenſe of propriety.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: Very pretty indeed! and ſo I have no ſenſe of propriety!

sp.speaker: Hick.
sp.p: I have never ſaid that ſir.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: But you told the manners of the people of Bruſhwood, to be juſt like mine.

sp.speaker: Hick.
sp.p: If they be alike, you would not have me tell a lie.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: You are a ſaucy fellow; and I dare you out to box with me.

sp.speaker: Hick.
sp.p: There are two things more which the people at Bruſhwood, are very apt to do —If they do not like what a man ſays to them, they tell him he lies, and challenge him to box.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: I won't bear this—you mean to impoſe upon me, I know you do—I'll knock you down.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: Stop your fire ſkull; what are you about to do? Fight a ſcholar before he enters the ſchool—And for what? Has he ever injured you? It is not poſſible.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: He has inſulted me, and I won't bear it.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: How inſulted you?

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: He deſcribed the manners of the people of Bruſhwood to be juſt like mine.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: What then? one unmannerly fellow is juſt like another.

sp.speaker: Hick.
sp.p: O let him alone if he has a mind to fight, let him fight.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: But he ſhall uſe fair play.

sp.speaker: Hick.
sp.p: Fighting is fighting after all. I am not much concerned about the manner of it.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: Yes I ſuppoſe in your Town they uſe the Indian hug, and ſtrike a fellow after he is down.

sp.speaker: Hick.
sp.p: If the buſineſs is to be civil, it is beſt not to fight at all.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: That is becauſe you are a coward. Yes, becauſe you are a coward, I ſay, you refuſe to fight. (with vehemence.)

sp.speaker: Hick.
sp.p: No ſ • r, I do not refuſe—but as you are the challenger, you muſt let me have the choice of weapons.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: That's certainly fair—you can have no objection to that.

sp.speaker: Hick.
sp.p: Then when I fight, I always fight with a large lemon in my fiſt—look you here, this is the way I fight, if I fight at all.

sp.speaker: Battle.
sp.p: What is that for?

sp.speaker: Hick.
sp.p: The buſineſs of fighting, you ſee, is to hurt one another—if you bruiſe any one, the juice gets into the wound, and the ſmart it intolerable—and if you ſtrike them in the face, the juice gets into the eyes, and the anguiſh is inconceivable. Here ſir, (offers him a couple of lemons) take a couple and prepare yourſelf. We muſt hurt one another very much, before we have done—I mean to fight as long as I can move a finger. I hope if I hurt you ever ſo much, (civily) you will not take it ill

sp.speaker: Battle.
sp.p: (looking at the lemons) 'Twould be a pity—really 'twould be a pity.

sp.speaker: Hick.
sp.p: What is a pity?

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: To bruiſe theſe lemons all up in fighting, it will ſpoil them entirely.

sp.speaker: Hick.
sp.p: Would it not ſpoil a man's face as much. But that is no matter—it is my way of fighting; and I have a right to chuſe.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: I think I don't want to fight much now.

sp.speaker: Hick.
sp.p: That's becauſe you are a coward.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: Why I think—I think, I'm dry, and I want a drink of punch—had we not better make theſe lemons into punch, I'm very fond of punch.

sp.speaker: Hick.
sp.p: With all my heart; I love punch for that matter, as well as I love fighting.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: I like it, ſo lay the lemons aſide for a moment and we will have a drink of punch.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p:
[clapping Hickory on the ſhoulder] On my word I aſk pardon for being ſo rough with you at firſt. I begin to think
you are a clever fellow. There's Hotſpur a coming—don't ſay a word to him, that we have made all up.

div.head: SCENE III.—HOTSPUR, entering—the others as in the laſt ſcene.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Where's our new genius—Well my friend, did you come here to buy wit?

sp.speaker: Hick.
sp.p: I have come, I believe, to a bad market, for I do not find you have any to ſell.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: He's ſharp, you ſee, very ſharp. He lives upon razors, don't you think he does?

sp.speaker: Hick.
sp.p: You had better not meddle with me then, for I have juſt this moment finiſhed my dinner.

sp.speaker: Hot
sp.p: You came from Bruſhwood, I think, where foxes are plenty.

sp.speaker: Hick.
sp.p: Yes ſir, and when I dine on razors, I have fox-brains for ſauce—that makes me very keen, you ſee.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: And ſo you mean to deal out your fox-wit by wholeſale among us.

sp.speaker: Hick.
sp.p: There is no need of that; a very ſmall portion will ſerve for you.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: I fancy you have been uſed to fox hunting; do yo mean to purſue it here?

sp.speaker: Hick.
sp.p: No, I'm hunting for fools, and have had great luck—the game is plenty.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: You will find one if you look in the glaſs.

sp.speaker: Hick.
sp.p: Then I won't look, for I am ſatisfied with what I ſee already.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: How his wit bites; he ſtings cloſe; he has been a pepper merchant, you may depend on it.

sp.speaker: Hick.
sp.p: Yes, and have enough of it yet to ſeaſon a dozen ſuch fellows as you.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: You are a proper blackguard—I am aſhamed to talk with you.

sp.speaker: Hick.
sp.p: A cur is always aſhamed when he is beat.

sp.speaker: Hot
sp.p: I'll be revenged on you for this.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: O ſhame on you—You began the attack, and are only angry becauſe yau are out witted.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: I'll go and call a number of boys, and I'll be revenged on you.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p:
How common it is for boys, who begin with joking, ſoon to get angry—I thing we may fairly draw the conſequence
from this; that judgment is much better than wit.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: AH how do ye do, my pretty Miſs.

sp.speaker: Myr.
sp.p: You are not to be very converſant with me ſir, till you behave yourſelf better.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: Why, have I done you any harm?

sp.speaker: Myr.
sp.p: No, but I am told that you this day contrived to inſult a new ſcholar, juſt as he was entering the ſchool.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: That does not concern you that I know of.

sp.speaker: Myr.
sp.p: It concerns me to keep ſuch rude, unmannerly wretches at a due diſtance, I hope, you will not have admittance, where we dance this evening.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: You are always very particular about your company.

sp.speaker: Myr.
sp.p: I wiſh every girl were as particular, then we ſhould cure you of your high-goes—that is to ſay of your low frolics.

sp.speaker: Bat
sp.p: Madam, if you are out of temper, it is not worth my while to ſtay here? (Exit Battle.)

sp.speaker: Plume.
sp.p: YOUR ſervant Miſs—I am happy in hoping for the pleaſure of dancing with you, this evening.

sp.speaker: Myra.
sp.p: Sir if it be agreeable to you, and the company chooſe partners I have no objection.

sp.speaker: Plume.
sp.p: For one thing Miſs you muſt ſuffer me to blame you a little gently—I ſaw you walking with Jack Battledoor; he has not the beſt character in the ſchool.

sp.speaker: Myr.
sp.p: O never fear my growing fond of his company—he ſeized my arm, 'tis true, but I obliged him ſoon to quit it —I do not like him, his manner is quite too rough.

sp.speaker: Plume.
sp.p: Shall I conduct you home.

sp.speaker: Myr.
sp.p:
You may if it be agreeable—tho it is but a little way —it will not be unpleaſant to have company—yet now I
wiſh you to ſtay here and prevent the boys from inſulting Mr. Freeman. [Plume takes his leave of Myra very genteelly—comes to the middle of the ſtage and ſings.]

lg.l: ſings. 'Tis the lovelieſt ſeaſon of life,
When the ſpirits ſo merrily flow.
Our heart quickly riſes with joy,
And is ſuddenly melted at woe.
Our minds are as ſimple as doves,
Our hearts yet not hardened with crimes,
Admit the firſt dartings of love,
And have their ſweet meltings betimes.
Why, Myra came tripping to me,
So livelily over the green,
Thro all our fair village, than I,
Not a happier lad could be ſeen.
But when I walked o'er the green furrow,
Deeply muſing on every charm,
I ſaw my ſweet maiden with ſorrow,
With another lad, locked in her arm.
Yet ſurely I welcome the joy,
Altho it be mixed with much pain.
The ſenſible heart, touched with love,
Never wiſhed to be ſenſeleſs again.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Well, Harry, wont you join us, we mean to have a high go?

sp.speaker: Plume.
sp.p: I am always afraid of you, you carry matters to ſuch a violent extreme.

sp.speaker: Hot
sp.p: You are a ſoft hearted thing, juſt fit to pleaſe the girls; and for nothing elſe.

sp.speaker: Plume.
sp.p: What marvellous plan have you on foot, that you urge me ſo much, to take a part in it?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: We have a ſcheme to take John Hickory, and toſs him in a blanket.

sp.speaker: Plume.
sp.p: Have your rough play to yourſelf, I will have nothing to do with it.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Go, then, and tie yourſelf to the girls apron-ſtrings; and let them coax, and wheedle, and befool you forever.

sp.speaker: Plume.
sp.p: I have no taſte for ſuch rough play—It always ends in ſomething diſagreeable. As for my miſſes, they will ſoften, and poliſh my manners; and teach me to be a gentleman. [Exit Plume.]

div.head: SCENE IV.—HOTSPUR, BATTLEDOOR, (entering here) with other boys and MARTIN.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: COME lads; ſee John Hickory cut capors in the air—We mean to toſs him in a blanket.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You are forever inventing miſchief. What has John Hickory done to you, that you ſhall bear malice againſt him?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: He is a new ſcholar you ſee.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: The very reaſon why he ſhould he treated kindly —If he be not polite at preſent it is his unhappineſs not his fault.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: We know more than he does.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Give credit to your knowledge then, and behave yourſelves well.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Wonderfully wiſe to be ſure.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ignorant people have ſome excuſe for bad morals —but to thoſe who profeſs to be the knowing ones—nothing can be more infamous, than to deſpiſe the manners of civil life.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: It always is the cuſtom among ſcholars to play the rogue.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: For that very reaſon ſeminaries of learning become odious. If men profeſſing learning behave worſe than they, who inhabit the woods—who can wonder that men hate the idea of a ſcholar—by ſuch methods too, they are bred up to be the peſts of human ſociety—and the more learned the more pernicious they are.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: But ſeminaries of learning are the reſorts of politeneſs— the ſeats of the muſes.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: They ought to be; but ſuch fellows as you give them the character of the ſeats of illiberality, and vice. If we find in colleges and acadamies, the rough ſtoic, the contemptuous cynic, the coarſeſt pedants, and the ſons of riot, and debauchery, who can wonder if the public conceives an averſion to ſuch ſocieties?

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: A fig for your morals—There are your high fellows in all the ſeminaries of learning.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Yes, a worthy object to be ſure. To ſtudy one, two▪ three, or four years, in ſome ſeminary of learning—to qualify ourſelves, to get drunk as brutally as porters, and grooms—to introduce ourſelves to vicious women, who after all prefer the aſſaſſin and ſtreet robber—and to acquire an averſion to modeſt ladies, to be embarraſſed, and know not how to ſpeak to them. One need not reſide in a college to learn theſe things—They may be learned in taverns, and gaming houſes to perfection.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: Come on, boys—down with this preacher—Does he think we came here to hear ſermons of terror? Let us all fall on, have him in the blanket, and give him a ſhaking.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Stand off you villains; if you attack me, I ſhall defend myſelf. [Hickory enters.]

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Well he is a great heavy lubber, we will let him alone; and take Hickory; he is the very man we want.

sp.speaker: Hick.
sp.p: What do you mean, by this rude aſſault on me?

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: Silence ye young villains—Let this young gentleman alone—unhand him. There now, be eaſy; or I will bring every ſoul o • you before the government.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: I SEE we are likely to have no fun to day—I will go and ſee ſome of the miſſes—I do that when I can find nothing better.

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: What would you have better, than to recommend yourſelf to the beſt part of the human ſpecies?

sp.speaker: Hot▪
sp.p: Why do not our inſtructors then let the maſters and miſſes perform their excerc • ſes toge • her—or why in ſchools where they ſtudy together, do they make them ſit in different parts of the houſe.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: It is to ſave them the pain of being corrected in the preſence of each other—to preſerve their delicacy, and • ncreaſe their mu • ual • eſpect—There is n • thing which makes the intercourſ • of men and women ſo happy as preſerving mutual reſpect a • d eſteem.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: On my word, I believe you are right, for I have found when we had been from the miſſes all day—and had a nice genteel dance after ſchool—it was the fineſt pleaſure, I ever experienced in my life.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: That's always the caſe—The more decent and proper we are in converſation with women, the more we enjoy • heir ſociety, which is in fact, and truth, the greateſt bleſſing of human life

sp.speaker: Bat
sp.p: That's what I have not tho't of ſo much before— But there ſeems to be good ſenſe and reaſon in what you ſay.

div.head: SCENE VI.—TALBOT, (entering) HOTSPUR, BATTLEDOOR, and MARTIN.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: YOUNG men you are very fortunate indeed, that you did not meddle with Hickory, for he is indeed a very genteel young man—He lived in Bruſhwood but one fortnight—as he knew you to be ſaucy, he contrived this way to mortify you; ſo he makes you the fools of the play. His real name is Freeman.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Yes, boys you will be mortified with a witneſs.— The wooden boy you laughed at is rea • ly as genteel a lad as any in the ſchool, and has permiſſion to invite the young gentlemen and ladies to a dance after ſchool.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: O I ſhall die to appear before him.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: I muſt excuſe myſelf—How he muſt deſpiſe me— I may as well be annihilated as to appear before him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I have often told you, young gentlemen, that you would bring yourſelves i • o diſgrace by ſuch proceedings— But ſee, he is coming with his two ſiſters—ſweet girls as ever lived. He looks like a Wooden Boy to be ſure.

div.head: SCENE VII.—Mr. FREEMAN entering with his two Siſters, richly dreſſed.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: GENTMEMEN, I have the honor to invite you to dance with my ſiſters, and a number of the other miſſes after ſchool; at the houſe of Mrs. Careful, the Governeſs.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: Mr. Freeman I aſk a thouſand pardons—if I had but known you I ſhould not—

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: No matter, it afforded me ſome amuſement—no matter.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: If you will only pardon my jokes. I was wrong, perfectly wrong, I confeſs.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: I think ſir, your jokes were quite harmleſs. Gentlemen I ſhall wait on you at four. [Exit Freeman.]

div.stage: (Battledoor and Hotſpur walk acroſs the ſtage, with their heads down.)

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: My jokes quite harmleſs—That is worſe than all the reſt—He muſt think meanly of me, and cannot think otherwiſe. In fact, I feel very ſmall.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: And I too, as ſmall as a mouſe—I wiſh I had been in France before ever I heard of the Wooden Boy.

lg.head: MARTIN Epiloguizes.
lg.l: We ſee, in conteſts of the prize of wit;
The biter oft by his own malice bit.
In circles, boaſting of politeneſs, find
Low manners the diſgrace of human kind.
Ignorance in colleges may find a place;
And profligacy in a man of grace.
Cits think that Clowns are brutes, and Clowns again,
Eſteem poor Cits the dulleſt ſons of men.
The town Belle ſneers at every rural laſs—
The laſs deſpiſing madam, lets her paſs.
Thus mutual prejudice, and malice reign;
And all the joys of ſocial life profane.
Yet baniſh prejudice, and love revives,
And ſocial bliſs, in fields, or cities, lives.

div.head: Bernard of Berlin. A DRAMATIC DIALOGUE, IN THREE ACTS.
THE ABSURDITY OF PROFUSENESS.
div.p: THERE is in many perſons of ſome plauſible qualities, a great vanity of ſpending money profuſely. It is laviſhed away on paraſites and flatterers, who give their patron nothing but empty praiſe.— And it is commonly the caſe, that they who help a man to ſpend his eſtate profuſely, are the firſt to deſert him in diſtreſs, if not upbraid him with his folly.

list.head: MEN.
list.item: BERNARD OF BERLIN—a man of exceſſive hoſpitality.

sp.speaker: Bryſ.
sp.p: WHO lives in this houſe?

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.p: Nobody lives here.

sp.speaker: Bryſ.
sp.p: Is not the houſe inhabited?

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.p: Here my maſter ſtarves, with his wife, and family, and myſelf.—We are ſtarved to death all of us.

sp.speaker: Bryſ.
sp.p: You have no regard to decency, to be ſtarved to death, and yet walking about and tranſacting buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.p: We are in no danger of being called to an account—We have no buſineſs to follow, and are grown by ſtarving ſo thin and ſo pale, that were we examined on the qualifications of ghoſts, there would not be a wretch of us all, but would paſs muſter.

sp.speaker: Bryſ.
sp.p: You have loſt your manners as well as your fleſh— Who ſtays in this houſe? I aſk again.

sp.speaker: Chriſ
sp.p: Bernard, ſir my maſter Bernard.

sp.speaker: Bryſ.
sp.p: Has he no other name but my maſter Bernard?

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.p: Why ſir there are a number of Bernard's in this town, there is one who was a man of figure—Is that the man you want?

sp.speaker: Bryſ.
sp.p: Deſcribe his particular quality or buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.p: There are two Bernards noted men in this city. One is a poet and a man of wit—He is as ſocial a fellow as eve • you ſaw, he'd entertain you with his fine verſes.

sp.speaker: Bryſ.
sp.p: The Bernard, I want, is the Bernard who gives ſuch good dinners. I have heard an ex • ellent character of him —I am tired, faint, and hungry, coming off from a journey, and have a better reliſh for a good ſirl • in of beef, than for the fineſt verſes in the world. Will you tell me at laſt what your maſters' name is.

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.p:
Why ſir, he has been ſo popular in his day, that
they called him Bernard of Berlin—No man has ever given better dinners—But he can give them no more.

sp.speaker: Bryſ.
sp.p: Why, if that be the caſe, I will dine at the tavern. But, I reſpect his memory, and will call and ſee him after dinner. (Exit Bryſſen—Bernard enters.)

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: THERE is a man knocking, introduce him. (Chriſtiern introduces him.)

sp.speaker: Scru.
sp.p: Sir, here is a note which is become due.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Due to whom? (Exit Chriſtiern.)

sp.speaker: Scru.
sp.p: To a neighbor here in Berlin.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Go to my ſteward.

sp.speaker: Scru.
sp.p: He has already put me off, from day to day— The holder of the note wants the money, and muſt be paid.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Perſuade him to wait till tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Scru.
sp.p: I cannot ſir. It muſt be put in ſuit.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Eye, you may ruin a reſponſible man by ſending him at once to priſon. Here take this (gives him money) and aſk him to wa • t a month longer, not ruin me and my whole family.

sp.speaker: Scru.
sp.p: You talk enough to break one's heart. (Chinking the money) I will try to perſuade him. But with a little exertion you can pay this other.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: I cannot anſwer that neither. Can you nor put it off till next week?

sp.speaker: Scru.
sp.p: Perhaps I may by ſome perſuading, for which I ought to be payed. But here is another.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: O conſcience, what? another!

sp.speaker: Scru.
sp.p: Yes, another; and he ſays he muſt have ſpeedy payment. The ſum is leſs than either of the others—I hope you will pay this.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: I cannot pay that nether — But how came I over head and ears in debt? Is it poſſible that my ſteward has done his duty, Bruſch—Tell Widdel to ſtep here in a moment.

sp.speaker: Scru.
sp.p: Pay this laſt note by to morrow or it will be put in ſuit, (Goes out ſurlily.)

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: HOW came my • ſtate ſo deranged! Why did you not tell me of it?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I did a great many times, but you put me off.— You told me I was honeſt, and that you would look into it another time.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: You muſt ſell off ſome of my land.

sp.speaker: Wid
sp.p: It is all ſold, except one little dark ſpot in the corner of Sileſia, hardly fit for a coblers ſtall. This will hardly ſatisfy your preſent creditors; what is to be done for the future I know not.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: But there was not a village from Berlin to Dantzick, that I had not a farm in, or near it.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: True—but when it coſt you 1000 acres for a feaſt, or you gave away 10 • 000 in a breath—had you poſſeſſed all Europe, in one farm, it ſoon would have been gone.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: What you ſay is reaſonable.

sp.speaker: Wid.
