sp.p: If you ſuſpect my honeſty, or truth, I'll ſettle my accompts in preſence of a magiſtrate—But I muſt tell you▪ that your feaſts, revels, illuminations▪ balls, and what not, at ſuch an exceſſive charge, have often made me retire to a corner and weep.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Prithee ſay no more.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Then, what fellows thoſe were who praiſed you.— Count Bernard! the noble Bernard; and Bernard of Berlin; who had every man's hand, head and heart at his ſervice—now your fortune is gone they are as ſtill as flies after a ſummer's ſtorm.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Finiſh your diſcourſe—I will apply to my friends— I have mines in their hearts, and treaſures in their inmoſt ſouls—I can get favors from my friends as eaſily as I can ſpeak the word.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I wiſh you may find it ſo.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Never mind it▪ Widdel, my wants are my bleſſings —You ſhall ſee that I am rich in friends, tho I be low in caſh.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I have the warmeſt wiſhes for your ſucceſs.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Here▪ Bruſch, come in an inſtant. Go to Count Anſpach; aſk him to lend me 200 pounds; to Goltz, and aſk him for 150; to S • r • ſmund, the miſer; aſk him for 100; to Keenſpruck▪ the architect: aſk him to lend me 50. for he has had many a good job by my means—I advanced to the city magiſtrates £ 3000 in a time of difficulty; I ſhall aſk £. 1000 of them▪

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I wiſh you may be ſucceſ • ful, but I greatly fear you will not. [Exit Widdel.—Gertrude enters.]

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: DEAR ſir, what are we to dine upon to day?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Upon victuals, what do you think?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: But the cook ſays there is not a mouthful of any kind of proviſions in the houſe.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: We ſhall have plenty in a few minutes. I have ſen • my ſervant to borrow money of my friends.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: If that be the caſe we may faſt and reckon upon faſting—we will lay i • up againſt a faſt day comes.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: What, my dear, we will not be uncharitable towards our friends—They cannot be ſo ungenerous as not to relieve our wants.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Heaven bleſs your hopes, my huſband, and render them ſucceſsful: but much I fear, that we muſt keep lent, for many days to come, in ſpite of all our friends.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: O woman—woman! how ſuſpicious you are—I wonder you had faith enough to be married.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I ſhould not, if I had dreamt of ſtarving in conſequence.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Well, well—I'll expedite the ſervants, and get a ſupply, the moment my money arrives. [Exit Gertrude.]

div.head: SCENE I.—Anſpach enters, then Bruſch.—ANSPACH and BRUSCH.

sp.speaker: Bruſch.
sp.p: MY maſter Bernard wiſhes your health and proſperity.

sp.speaker: C. Anſ.
sp.p: Here, take a glaſs of my bell wine, you are welcome above all men—Here take another glaſs—How does that complete gentleman your maſter do, whom I love as my life?

sp.speaker: Bruſch.
sp.p: Very well, as to health, very well indeed.

sp.speaker: C. Anſ.
sp.p: And what haſt thou got under thy cloak? Some genteel preſent from your maſter. I dreamt laſt night he gave me a ſilver tankard.

sp.speaker: Bruſch.
sp.p: I have no ſilver tankard ſir, for you.

sp.speaker: C. Anſ.
sp.p:
Something more elegant. Your maſter ſhows
his genteel taſte always in his preſents—a pair of diamond buckles, perhaps. O, I love him as my life.

sp.speaker: Bruſch.
sp.p: No ſir he is in want: he ſends this empty box for you to fi • l. He aſks 200 pounds, not doubting but you'll ſupply him.

sp.speaker: C. Anſ.
sp.p: Ah! not doubting—Why I told him when I dined with him laſt, I was afraid he ſpent too faſt on his capital.

sp.speaker: Bruſch.
sp.p: And then came to ſupper to tell him to ſpend leſs.

sp.speaker: C. Anſ.
sp.p: Liberty was always his fault. But you are an arch fellow—you know theſe times.

sp.speaker: Bruſch.
sp.p: What of the times ſir?

sp.speaker: C. Anſ.
sp.p: That no-body pretends in theſe times to lend money upon friendſhip, without ſecurity.

sp.speaker: Bruſch.
sp.p: My maſter has lent you three times the ſum without ſecurity.

sp.speaker: C. Anſ.
sp.p: Yes, and I took it becauſe I wanted it. But I tho't him imprudent, then.

sp.speaker: Bruſch.
sp.p: Shall I ſay that to my maſter?

sp.speaker: C. Anſ.
sp.p: No, take this piece; and ſay I was not at home.

sp.speaker: Bruſch.
sp.p: Thank you ſir, I will not tell a ſcandalous lie for three ſhillings. [Exit C. Anſpach.—Goltz enters]

sp.speaker: Bruſch.
sp.p: ILLUSTRIOUS magiſtrate, that gentleman, Bernard of Berlin, ſends to know of your health.

sp.speaker: Goltz.
sp.p: Ha, has he ſent to me, and what has he ſent? He is the genteeleſt man on earth in ſending a preſent.

sp.speaker: Bruſch.
sp.p: O ſir, he will make no more preſents He ſends this empty box for you to fill—He deſires you to lead him 150 pounds.

sp.speaker: Goltz.
sp.p: He is only merry, he has ten times that ſum to ſpare!

sp.speaker: Bruſch.
sp.p: No ſir, he is in preſent want; or he would never have troubled his friends.

sp.speaker: Goltz.
sp.p: Hah! in preſent want do you ſay? How then will he be able to pay?

sp.speaker: Bruſch.
sp.p: He was kind to you, in difficulties; and expected a return.

sp.speaker: Goltz.
sp.p: What a perfect fool, and ſcoundrel I was; that no more than three days ago, I made a purchaſe that ſwept off every ſtiver of my money.

sp.speaker: Bruſch.
sp.p: Then you will not • upply him.

sp.speaker: Goltz.
sp.p: Why juſt before you came in I was going to ſend to my lord Bernard, to borrow, which I ſcarce would have done for the worth of all Germany. Give him my moſt ſincere reſpects; tell him my utter inability; and beg him to conceive in the faireſt manner of my intentions.

sp.speaker: Bruſch.
sp.p: Shall I tell him you will not?

sp.speaker: Goltz.
Bruſch.
sp.p: (alone) And is this the return you make for all my maſter's kind • eſs to you—Well there remains old Straſſmund the miſer. I will ſee what I can do with him.

sp.speaker: Bruſch.
sp.p: MASTER Bernard ſends his reſpects to you ſir, and aſks the loan of a hundred pounds.

sp.speaker: Straſſ.
sp.p: How came he to think of me?

sp.speaker: Bruſch.
sp.p: Why he ſent to lord Anſpach, and Goltz; but they proved of baſe temper; they gave him no relief.

sp.speaker: Straſſ.
sp.p: And ſo he ſends to me the laſt of all—I was the firſt man that received a preſent of him; the firſt who was invited to dinner by him; and now that he ſhould ſend to me the laſt— I will not lend him a farthing—I am downright affronted with him. Exit Straſſmund,

sp.speaker: Bruſch.
sp.p: There is no one who now remains but old Keenſpruck the architect—whom my maſter took out of priſon; and gave him many a fine job—I will try him, and then I have executed my maſter's orders. [Keenſpruck enters.]

div.head: SCENE IV.—BRUSCH and KEENSPRUCK.

sp.speaker: Bruſch.
sp.p: MASTER Bernard ſends to you ſir, his moſt ſincere reſpects.

sp.speaker: Keen.
sp.p: What job does he want me to do now? I'll not do another ſo cheap as I did the laſt; but I don't perfectly underſtand you—I am hard of hearing, you know. Come cloſe to me now.

sp.speaker: Bruſch.
sp.p: Maſter Bernard is in want of caſh, which is the worſt ſituation in the world for building.

sp.speaker: Keen.
sp.p:
Hah! the ſituation—Don't he like the ſituation of the building. Then let him build ſomewhere elſe. There
is room enough in the world to build upon.

sp.speaker: Bruſch.
sp.p: He does not want to build •• r. He has built too much already —He wants to borrow fifty pounds of you —and if it pleaſe you, I call upon you for it by his order.

sp.speaker: Keen.
sp.p: The order pleaſe me? Let him pleaſe himſelf about the order—If he does not like the Ionic or Tuſcan orders which are very plain • ; let him take the Corinthian, which is very grand.

sp.speaker: Bruſch.
sp.p: My maſter does not want to build. He has built too much already. He wants to borrow money; he has a number of little debts which he wiſhes to ſquare off.

sp.speaker: Keen.
sp.p: Square roof. It ſeems he don't like a ſquare roof— He may have a bevil if he pleaſes, or a common pitched roof.

sp.speaker: Bruſch.
sp.p: It is no ſuch thing—Sir, my maſter is a little out of caſh at preſent—he wants fifty pounds, if you will do it for him.

sp.speaker: Keen.
sp.p: Do it for him, yes if he will pay me well—But I muſt have the dimenſions of the building, before I can tell what to charge for it.

sp.speaker: Bruſch.
sp.p: You know what I mean well enough, you old knave. (In a low voice.)

sp.speaker: Keen.
sp.p: Aye, who is a knave? Not I, I hope.

sp.speaker: Bruſch.
sp.p: Will you come, and dine with my maſter immediately?

sp.speaker: Keen.
sp.p: O yes by all means; the gentleman is very kind— (Bruſch goes out, Keenſpruck looks after him, then walks acroſs the ſtage and ſpeaks.) Thanks to my old deaf ear, I have eſcaped—He was ſo anxious and ſo uneaſy: I knew the dog wanted to borrow money by his phiz.

div.stage: [Exit, and aſſoon as he is out Bernard enters, and ſoon after his daughter.]

sp.speaker: Cath.
sp.p: MY mother ſends to you to know if you are likely to have any thing for dinner to day?

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Then tell her not to be anxious; we ſhall have it ſoon.

sp.speaker: Cath.
sp.p: She ſeems almoſt out of patience; and if any company comes in, we have nothing in the world to ſet before them.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: I am not anxious about that. If they furniſh money, then we can furniſh them a dinner. Or otherwiſe we make them welcome to the beſt we have—If we have nothing I mean to invite them all to dine.

sp.speaker: Cath.
sp.p: O dear ſir do not expoſe us in that manner.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Yes, by all means, and let them ſee how • olks live who live upon nothing.

sp.speaker: Cath.
sp.p: O ſir, I ſhould be ſo mortified I ſhould leave the houſe.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: You muſt not be affrighted at that; we may all ſoon he obliged to leave the houſe.

div.head: SCENE I.— Bernard enters, then Widdel. BERNARD, WIDDEL and BRUSCH.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: WHAT not one of them lend me a farthing?

sp.speaker: Bruſch.
sp.p: Not one upon my life.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Go immediately and invite every one of them to dinner.

sp.speaker: Bruſch.
sp.p: I could not have tho't there had been ſo much ingratitude in mankind—I tho't they might have ſome ſenſe of obligation; but he who is ſmitten of the diſeaſe of poverty is ſhunned of the human ſpecies.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I have long known it to be ſo. The warmeſt trencher friends, when a man is in diſtreſs, would deny him even the crumbs of charity. [Scruter enters.]

sp.speaker: Scru.
sp.p: (ſurlily) THE laſt note I had againſt you ſir is put in ſuit.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: It is juſt as agreeable to me as any way—Let my creditors take all I poſſeſs, if they will be content with that.

sp.speaker: Scru.
sp.p: If you remain here in Berlin they will not be content till they have you in priſon. [Exit Scruter.]

sp.speaker: Ger
sp.p: MY dear, you muſt take care of yourſelf—I have found out that tomorrow they mean to put •• u in jail.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
There is a great favor my dea •
▪ I re • pected they would have done it to day.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I tremble for the conſequences. We muſt flee immediately.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Will you go with me?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: It is my deſign to live and die with you.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Let me have my wife; and they may take my fortune▪ I ſhall be richer than they all.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Sir, you are ſtill a gentlema • ; and the more is the pity that you will not have a fortune. [Exit Gertrude.]

div.head: SCENE IV.— ••• PACH, GOLTZ, STRA •• M •• D, SCRUTER, and K ••• SPRUCK, all come in together.

sp.speaker: C. Anſ.
sp.p: I HAVE done myſelf the honor to wait on you according to your obliging commands.

sp.speaker: Goltz.
sp.p: I thank you for your invitation. You are a compleat gentleman, not to flatter a word.

sp.speaker: Straſſ
sp.p: I am ſorry you did not ſend firſt to me to borrow money—I cannot get it over.

sp.speaker: Keen.
sp.p: I love to be invited to dinner▪ it ſaves all the expenſe, and trouble, you ſee.

sp.speaker: Scru.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe your good ear was offered to this invitation—I w • nder, far the advantage of it, that I never tho't of being deaf of one ear.

sp.speaker: Keen
sp.p: You can be deaf of both ears; when you find it to advantage.

sp.speaker: Straſſ
sp.p:
Neighbor Bernard you have invited us to dinner, but you ſhow us nothing of dinner yet—To be a little free, what are we to have for dinner to day.—
(Bernard goes to a table which is cove • ed with a clean cloth uncovers it, and diſcovers the table laid with a ragged table-cloth, broken diſhes, knives, forks, &c and not a mouthful of victuals.)

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Juſt what you gentleman helped me to—Had I obtained any thing, you ſhould have been welcome; but ſince I obtained nothing you are as welcome.

sp.speaker: C. Anſ.
sp.p: I think you treat us very ſcandalouſly, maſter Bernard.

sp.speaker: Goltz
sp.p: You might be aſhamed to treat gentlemen in this manner.

sp.speaker: Straſſ▪
sp.p:
I ſhall not conſider you after dinner▪ as I •
ed to do.

sp.speaker: Keen.
sp.p: I ſhall turn a deaf ear as I do on all ſuch occaſions.— They all go out angrily and haſtily—he hurls the diſhes &c. and kicks the table after them.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Adieu my dear friends adieu, • love you as my eyes love ſmoke, or as my mouth warm water▪—You •• ingy, deceitful, worthleſs vermin▪ begone! (After he has cleared the ſtage he returns to the middle of the ſtage—and ſpeaks.) Now I could curſe theſe deteſted Paraſites; is there lan • uage ſtrong enough to do it in—The ſum of all my curſes is that they may be as they are—that's bad enough.

div.stage: [Bryſſen enters with Bernard's wife and friends.]

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: HAVE I one friend left?

sp.speaker: Bryſ.
sp.p: Yes, you have one, who knew you not, except in fame, till this day —I heard of your affairs, and pity you moſt ſincerely. I live in Sileſia near the little farm which you have left. It is worth near five hundred pounds— You may make a ſafe retreat to this little ſpot—where if you cannot live in ſplendor—you may be honeſt and independent of every man.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Bernard ſhall ſeek Sileſia's gr •• es and find,
The fierceſt brute more friendly than mankind.
sp.p: I will go with my wife and daughter. You, Widdel, and Bruſch may if you pleaſe go with me—I have been extremely mortified, and mankind ſeem exceſſively cruel— But how can I juſtly blame them for not taking care of me; when it is evident, that I did not take care of myſelf?

div.head: The Rogue proved honeſt▪ A DRAMATIC DIALOGUE, IN THREE ACTS.
THE EXCELLENCE OF THE GENERAL PRINCIPLE OF A FREE COMMONWEALTH.
div.p: A SENSE of liberty infuſes life and activity thro a whole commonwealth—And not only are particular laws a ſecurity to the citizen, but a greater ſecurity ariſes from the general principle of liberty— That in every inſtance will cauſe the preſumption to be made in favor of the accuſed citizen; that he is innocent, and that the ſufferings of the innocent will by that means be prevented—Happy above all people are they of the United States, if they know their own good.

list.head: MEN.
list.item: ESQ. RIGHTWAYS—a juſtice of the peace.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: SISTER I wiſh you to lend your attention to me a moment.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: As long as you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: Have you heard any thing bad of me in this neighborhood?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Certainly your character is given out as extremely bad; and you are threatened with a proſecution for ſeveral very high crimes.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: I hope that gives you no uneaſineſs.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: It certainly does, and I can ſcarcely ſleep becauſe of it.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: I am ſorry if it affects you ſo diſagreeably, it certainly gives me very little diſturbance.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: I am aſtoniſhed at your calmneſs; for I am told, there is one proſecu • ion againſt you for falſe coinage, another for highway robbery, and another for forgery—They ſay the proofs are all flagrant againſt you, and you cannot eſcape.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: I defy them all to hurt me; and yet I do not ſuppoſe that one of them owes me any malice. Juſt ſo prone are human kind to believe every thing that is bad concerning a man who falls into diſtreſs in his affairs.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: But by what means do you expect to ſupport yourſelf, when ſo many falſe accuſations ga her round? by what means will you be extricated?

sp.speaker: Jam
sp.p: I ſuppoſe twenty witneſſes might be brought who •• ou • I ſwear againſt me and yet all be honeſt and believe they ſwore to the truth.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p:
My brother, you don't ſay ſo, I almoſt think you
guilty myſelf how could it be, unleſs you have been very w • cked▪ you never can clear yourſelf of them; and how do you expect it?

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: I have no money to defend myſelf with▪ I cannot a • preſent procure a ſingle witneſs in my favor—All my dependence is upon the author of all truth; and the teſtimony of my own conſcience, and they being on my ſide, are all the witneſſes I need.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: I wiſh you may find it ſo, in the concluſion of your affairs—but I am on the rack with anxiety day and right on your account.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: Be quiet my ſiſter—Never believe that he who brings the righteous into affliction; has not power to bring them out again. (Exit Jamiſon.)

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: SERVANT, Miſs Clara, your ſervant—where is your brother?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: He has this moment gone out.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: Why miſs Clara, there is an old racket in this neighborhood about your brother, what has he done?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: He has always been an honeſt man from a child▪ the kindeſt brother that lives to his ſiſters, the moſt dutiful ſon to his parents, whom he his with the tendereſt care ſupported in their feeble, and decriped ſtate. And now he has the tears of the poor, ſince he has fallen into diſtreſs, witneſſing in his favor.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: Why I was at the alehouſe laſt evening and they called him all the raſcals in the world, I tho't if half they ſaid was true, I would not give one of my old boots for his head.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: They talk frightfully about him I know.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: Well and can't he have them up for it, I'd bring 'em corum nobus—If they talked ſo about me.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: He is more anxious, leſt he ſhould be proſecuted himſelf, than how he ſhall proſecute others.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: Well this is a proper harum ſcarum world, all things go hoity toity, head over heels. I have hitherto taught my children to be honeſt and truſt providence.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Well, I hope you do not mean to teach them otherwiſe in time to come.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p:
I have been thinking whether men get any thing by being honeſt, or whether ſome men did not cry up
honeſty that they might the better cheat their neighbors— I have loſt many a hundred pounds by being honeſt, and among great folks it is a •
〈…〉 of faſhion.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Yes, and perhaps gained thouſands by it at other times—Do you ſuppoſe that you ſhould have been worth what you are if you had not had a reputation for being honeſt?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: Aye there you have it now, you are a cunning little puſs. (claps her on the ſhoulder) I love to hear you talk dearly.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: My clothes don't want bruſhing ſir; or if they do we will not trouble you to do it, I mean to be honeſt, tho my brother be ever ſo unfortunate.

sp.speaker: Por
sp.p:
But ſuppoſing now, juſt for the notion on' •
that what we call vice had been called virtue, and what we call virtue had been called vice?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Suppoſing what we call white had been called black and what we call black had been called white— would it have altered the nature of thoſe colors?

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: But then would we not have been as much pleaſed with black, as we are with white? there, I gueſs I've got you now.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: No ſir, ſuppoſing ratſbane had been called butter, then we might eat it on bread without harm—or ſuppoſing butter were called ratſbane, then it would poiſon us, would it not?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: That's ſly now—and I will own you have got ſome wit—but ſuppoſing that no man had any thing of his own but every thing was earned by every body, and every body had aright to it—all things in common.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Why then ſome would do nothing but live on the earnings of other people, while only a few would have to maintain all the reſt.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: Why girl you reaſon away ſtoutly now—can you tell me girl why a woman is called the weaker veſſel—it is not becauſe ſhe is naturally more ſhallow—that is a little too bad too—I mean whether ſhe has not naturally leſs underſtanding than a man.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe ſir, that a great iron pot, will bear a ſtouter blow than a china bowl, but I do not know that of conſequence it is more valuable—or in fact worth more.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: People will have their different fancies about that— you know.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Well ſir, from certain circumſtances I judge that men are weaker than women, and have leſs underſtanding—are not all the whims and extravagances of learning invented by men—the ideal ſyſtem—denial of providence, atheiſm, or putting nature inſtead of God▪ Miſchance agency, ſcepticiſm concerning morals &c. which have deranged ſociety and corrupted mankind. Are they not all inventions of men? Women in general deſpiſe ſuch notions—and they refer all their ideas to uſe and benefit— they value no learning but which is profitable—and refer all ſtudy to its moral uſe. I appeal to facts for this. Is it any ſign of weakneſs in their underſtanding?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: Why ah—hem—ah—as for that—hem—I hardly know what to ſay.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: However I will be candid—I will allow men have as much ſenſe as women—but I deteſt all principles that weaken the obligations of morality—our happineſs depends on right conduct, and however calum • iated my brother is, I would have him be ſtrictly honeſt—nor make uſe of any art or evaſion, to avoid ſuffering—He had better follow truth even if he ſuffers for it.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: BUT then as to that maſter you are right; you don't approve that girls ſhould have much learning, it nonſuits their underſtanding. [Exit Po • terſon]

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Your underſtanding (curtſying) was never nonſuited that way.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: But then it is my opinion, that women ſhould learn to ſpin, and knit, to mend clothes; and darn ſtockings.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: So it is mine. They ought to learn all thoſe matters—I will put it ſtronger, they ought to be very attentive and diligent in theſe things—But if they have as much learning beſides, as they have opportunity to acquire; I do not ſuppoſe it does them any harm.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: I think that women have no buſineſs with much learning—they had better keep to their kniting, patching, and mending, &c. and waſhing diſhes &c.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p:
Sir, I ſuppoſe you do not know it. Such obſervations hurt the tender feelings of my ſex—we have as lively a taſte for knowledge as you—It becomes us as well—What
〈◊〉 or has befallen the authoreſs of the Coquette? Or did Montague diſgrace her ſelf by her Letters? Would not many men be proud to write •• ke P • ilenia?

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: They had better mind their own buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: How would you like it ſir, if the women ſhould ſay of you that it would have been better for you, if you had been confined all your days to the ſpade and plough, inſtead of pettifogging and ſetting neighbors to quarrel— or what would ſome Doctors of Theology ſay, if we had ſaid concerning them, that it were well if they had mended ſhoes inſtead of making ſermons. I reſpect the profeſſion of the law too much; and certainly I reſpect the religious profeſſion too much, to make any ſuch obſervations. Yet I do not know but ſuch obſervations are altogether as good natured, and as juſt, as thoſe which are thrown out by ſome men againſt the education of women.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: Well, I know this▪ your brother is a villain, & I intend to proſecute him to the utmoſt rigor of the law. I gueſs his ſiſters won't get him out of my hands▪

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I do not know that they will, but I gueſs they will try.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: WELL Mr. Ready-caſh—what's your complaint againſt young Jamiſon.

sp.speaker: Ready.
sp.p: Why he paſſed a number of counterfeited bank notes, here to day.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: And do you believe he counterfeited them himſelf?

sp.speaker: Ready.
sp.p: Yes; for they were all altered with a pen, and every body knows that he is in very low circumſtances as to eſtates—and there is a great probability that he did it for his own benefit.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: Well, and have you no further evidence againſt him?

sp.speaker: Ready.
sp.p: Yes, he urged me very much to take them, and I thought he appeared very uneaſy becauſe I did not take them readily.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: But you took them.

sp.speaker: Ready.
sp.p: Yes, I took them, and paſſed them to his credit▪ but they are certainly counterfeits—I paid him ſome in hard caſh for them.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: Well, mind this, if you mean to get recom • ence, you muſt ſwear plump • y—perhaps the Juſtice won't li • t you much about your oath—and as you really believe that he did counterfeit the bills, you may ſwear plumply

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: WELL, Miſs Muſlin, I underſtand you have ſomething againſt young Jamiſon he is an anointed rogue I know.

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.p: Yes, ſir, he called upon me the other day with an order in his brother's name, ſaying, that his brother had given him power of attorney to draw in his abſence —he got the goods; now ſince he is uneaſy in his circumſtances I felt concerned about it; and called upon him to ſhow the evidence of his right, and his power to draw in his brother's name; he could not ſhow any, and pretended he had loſt the paper.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: Aye he is rogue enough, but I ſhall catch him yet, lawyers are the only men for ſuch matters. Theſe facts you can atteſt to becauſe you muſt be ſworn to your depoſition.

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.p: Aye, I know that, and I have aſſerted nothing but what I can prove—I obſerved him well he lookod concerned and uneaſy, and he has for theſe many days: and I gueſs by that, he has ſome ſchemes on foot which are not right.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: Do you know any thing about Jamiſon's wife.

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.p: Yes, they ſay ſhe is confederate with him in all his villanies. (Exit Muſlin.)

sp.speaker: Non
sp.p: SO madam, how does Jamiſon do to day.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Jam▪
sp.p: He is very well ſir — but none the better for you.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: None the better for me? but I intend he ſhall be— I intend to cure him of his vices, and then he will be a better man.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Jam.
sp.p: That he will be perſecuted by you with all poſſible malice, I doubt not; but I believe he will triumph over you all finally.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: Why do you think ſo?

sp.speaker: Mrs Jam.
sp.p: Becauſe I believe he is a very honeſt man, nay I know he is ſo.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: But the proofs againſt him are very pointed—Certainly you cannot get over them.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Jam.
sp.p: It is poſſible to make truth appear what it is —but you will not be able to make it appear otherwiſe by all your craft.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: If that be the, caſe what is all the artifice of our profeſſion good for?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Jam.
sp.p: Good for nothing, I ſuppoſe—but when you deal honeſtly, you, like all other men, appear reſpectable— I hope you will lay that to heart. [Exit Mrs. Jamiſon.]

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: AYE, Mc. Mullock, you are a principal witneſs againſt Jamiſon.

sp.speaker: Mc.
sp.p: Yez zur, pleaſe your honor—I ſwore againſt him, may't pleaſe your honor with all ray might—I could not have ſwore ſtronger if I had been to die for't.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: Now your oath may be depended on a • ſubſtantial evidence, becauſe you was an eye-witneſs.

sp.speaker: Mc.
sp.p: O yes, may it pleaſe your honor, I was an eye-witneſs—for our Nab ſaw it with her own eyes; and ſhe told me firſt of all.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: But that will weaken your teſtimony if you own that Nab ſaw it; and not yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Mc.
sp.p: Aye but, Nab ſir is my own fleſh, and Nab's eyes are my eyes, may pleaſe your honor.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: Aye but that won't do—you cannot ſwear to that which was ſeen by another perſon.

sp.speaker: Mc.
sp.p: I know I can ſir —I can ſwear to any thing I pleaſe —I'll lay a mug on't.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: I mean you cannot with truth.

sp.speaker: Mc.
sp.p: Aye that another matter — you did not ſay about my ſwearing to the truth—you only aſked me if I could ſwear.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: Well I've got your depoſition—are you ready to ſwear to it, be it what it may?

sp.speaker: Mc.
sp.p: O yes I could ſwear all day, if you will pay me •• r't—But a man's a fool to ſwear without pay.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: Be ready then when you're called.

sp.speaker: Mrs. R.
sp.p: DO you mean to take Mc. Mullock's oath againſt my brother?

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: Yes, why not?

sp.speaker: Mrs. R.
sp.p: You know he cannot be depended on. He may be an honeſt man or may not be; but he is a ſtranger among us, and we know nothing of his character.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: We don't know it is a bad one.

sp.speaker: Mrs. R.
sp.p: And we don't know it is a good one.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: That's nothing; if no exception can be made againſt a witneſs, his teſtimony is good in law.

sp.speaker: Mrs. R.
sp.p: I know better—It is not in all caſes; becauſe when a man's character is unknown there can be no dependance on his veracity.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: Do you think you know law better than I?

sp.speaker: Mrs. R.
sp.p: I know that is no law which is not agreeable to reaſon—and certainly it is not agreeable to reaſon to take the oath of a foreigner, an unknown perſon, againſt a citizen of known eſtabliſhed good character.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: Theſe are fine times indeed; when women muſt meddle with laws.

div.head: SCENE I.—JUSTICE RIGHTWAYS, NONSUIT, JAMISON, READY-CASH, M •• LIN and Mc. MULLOCK.

sp.speaker: Right.
sp.p: MR. Attorney—Where are the depoſitions which have been ſworn to?

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: They are here, the very ſame, which your worſhip has peruſed ſo carefully, before you appeared to be ſatisfied with them.

sp.speaker: Right.
sp.p: Why yes—it appears to me that there is ſufficient cauſe for committing him—What have you to ſay for yourſelf Jamiſon? Have you any objection to the ſta • e of •• e evidence?

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: Nothing ſir, yet I know my own innocence—I have two good witneſſes on my ſide—My own conſcie • ce, and he who gave it me.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: What ſignifies it for him to ſpeak of his witneſſes, his conſcience, and all that, when the facts are ſo plain againſt him? I move for his commitment.

sp.speaker: Ready.
sp.p: I think I have a right to expect he will be committed without delay for trial.

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.p: I cannot but expect 〈◊〉 will be? for I am ſure, if I loſe my debt, he ought to be puniſhed for it.

sp.speaker: Mc.
sp.p: Aye indeed may it pleaſe your worſhip—if he be not trounced for't, the next time I go abroad, I ſhall not dare to ſtir a foot from home—I ſhould expect he would rob me of my money if I had not a farthing in my pocket.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: I beg your worſhip will let me have one hour's reſpite; perhaps ſome witneſs may arrive who may make my innocence appear.

sp.speaker: Right.
sp.p: Can you ſpecify any one?

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: Indeed I cannot ſir.

sp.speaker: Right.
sp.p: Then I do not ſe • any cauſe for delaying proce • dings—It may be a more fetch to gain time to effect a reſcue—or ſomething of that ſort—Make out his mittimus Mr▪ Attorney and let the conſtable take him to priſon.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: I ſee nothing now but I muſt ſuffer. It will be the work of providence. • f I eſcape —for if I be committed —then there is no money nor power among my friends to procure one witneſs in my favor—yet I know myſelf innocent.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: I wiſh you would make that fellow hold his tongue —I deſire to know what all this is to the purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Right.
sp.p: Silence, Jamiſon, ſilence.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Jam.
sp.p: PERMIT me Mr. Juſtice to intercede 〈◊〉 my huſban • —You muſt know that it muſt be a terrible event to my family; if he ſhould be taken from it. What is more diſtreſſing than the ſtate of a woman, left with a family of ſmall children, without a protector? And what would add to my diſtreſs is that I have my huſband's father, and mother, aged people to look after, who cannot help themſelves. Tho I cannot at preſent give any particular reaſon, yet I beſeech your worſhip to give my h • ſband the reſpite of one half hour.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: They give no reaſon, they mean to raiſe a mob and reſcue him, or ſome way effect his eſcape.

sp.speaker: Ready.
sp.p: I cannot think he ought to be reſpited.

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.p: I ſhall not conſent to it, Mr. Juſtice—and if you reſpite him, I'll complain.

sp.speaker: Right.
sp.p: Order, I ſay, order—I hope you won't interfere in my department—I muſt ſay, notwithſtanding there is no reaſon given for it ſpecially, that the reſpite of half an hour ought to be granted—No one knows what may come of it—Perhaps ſome perſon in that time may appear in his favor—You ought to eſteem yourſelves happy to be born in a commonwealth, where the rights of citizens are held ſacred; and where it is ſo difficult to reſtrain any one of his liberty. I grant the privilege to this man now. It is the privilege of you all▪ that your liberties are held thus ſacred. You ought to love your country and laws, elſe you are the moſt ungrateful people in the world. On this principle, upon which our whole government reſts — that the liberty of the citizen is ſacred—I grant this priſoner another half hour for his defence.

div.head: SCENE III.—MISS CLARA, RIGHTWAYS, BETTY, and MUSLIN.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: I COME, oh I am out of breath, oh my brother is nor committed.

sp.speaker: Right
sp.p: What's your will miſs?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Here ſir, this I got ſworn to before Juſtice Quickſight, and here's the girl who will atteſt it before you to the ſame purpoſe—She ſaw the inſtance in which it is ſaid that Jamiſon was guilty of robbery—Was eye witneſs to the whole affair, it was mere accident that I found her— She mentioned ſomething about a young man's being accuſed of robbery—I told her it was my brother—She then related the circumſtances.

sp.speaker: Right.
sp.p: What do you ſay, Betty Laundreſs, I think your name is.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p:
Why, I ſaw a man go up to Mr. Jamiſon, hold a piſtol to his breaſt and demand his money—Mr. Jamiſon delivered, but the robber had only turned a corner not ten yards diſtance, before the robber's feet ſlipped, and I ſaw Mr. Jamiſon catch a piſtol, which the robber dropped in his
fall, and ſprang on the robber, and redemanded the money and got it.

sp.speaker: Right.
sp.p: This you can ſwear to.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Yes, ſir, I ſaw the whole.

sp.speaker: Right.
sp.p: What did you do with the money? juſt now you complained you had none.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: I bought ſome medicines for my poor aged father who is very ſick.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: There for miſs Muſlin.

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.p: Betty, hold your tongue about me, or I never will employ you in my buſineſs again.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I ſhall not ſay any harm of you madam.

sp.speaker: Right.
sp.p: Say away Betty, you have as good a right to ſpeak as any body.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I heard maſter Jamiſon had got into difficulty— thought it might do ſome good to give his ſiſters theſe papers, which I • nd in the pockets of one of his waiſtcoats, which he ſent me to waſh.

sp.speaker: Right.
sp.p: What are they?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Here ſir is the power which my brother, who is gone to the Weſt Indies, gave to him to tranſact any matter of trade for him and in his name, ſee.

sp.speaker: Righ.
sp.p: Very good, this is very good, but as to the coinage, how will you clear yourſelf of that?

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: I know not yet, I know I am innocent.

div.head: SCENE IV.—Mrs. ROBERTS, RIGHTWAYS, CLARA, NONSUIT and JAMISON.

sp.speaker: Mrs. R.
sp.p: SIR let me ſpeak a word with the juſtice.

sp.speaker: Right.
sp.p: Speak madam if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. R.
sp.p: There Squire Firm-truſt, and my brother had been playing at whiſt and they changed accidentally two papers which had bank notes in them, and my brother took up a paper in which the notes were all counterfeit. The Squire has rode 150 miles in • days and half, in order to rectify the miſtake—Here the true notes are for the banker.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: What ſay you now, Mr. Nonſuit.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: This comes of giving girls learning, they take the buſineſs of the law all out of our hands.

sp.speaker: Mrs. R.
sp.p: A great evil no doubt to defend the innocent; we have done nothing theſe three days but pick up evidence in favor of our brother.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: Heaven bleſs you my good girls. (bowing.)

sp.speaker: Right.
sp.p: Now learn my friends to revere the ways of providence, which bring unexpected relief to oppreſſed innocence, by which honeſty is ſafe, and render your fervent thanks for your conſtitution of government, which conſiders the liberty of a citizen as his moſt ſacred treaſure.

div.head: The Little Box. A DRAMATIC DIALOGUE, IN THREE ACTS.
MODERATION IS NECESSARY IN POLITICS— FOR JUSTICE WILL HAVE ITS PROPER TIME.
div.p: THERE is the aſſemblage of all the virtues in a true politician. He is impartial with regard to parties, and his connections with foreign powers— He reſpects religion and thoſe who adminiſter its ordinances—He is not moved by violent attachment or averſion to individuals—He treats none with contempt; for they who make no great ſhow in the eyes of the public, may have ſtrong connections with the eſſential intereſts of the State—He is not bigotted to his own opinions.—In one word, no man can be a thorough politician, but an able, and good man.

list.head: MEN.
list.item: TIMOCLES—Grand Secretary of the State of Syracuſe.
HAMILCAR—his rival in party and politics.
HIERO—an old politician, uncle to Timocles.
A PARASITE—one who affects the character.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: PARTY rage is indeed a dreadful paſſion.— My whole life has been devoted to the ſtate. I have equally oppoſed the influence of Carthage, and Rome, and have met with no reward but perſecution.

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.p: Timocles is againſt you, he repreſents you as a perſon endeavoring to overturn the ſtate, and place yourſelf at the head of affairs.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: What prete • t have they againſt me?

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.p: That you are a ſtranger.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: So much is true, that when my infant mind firſt knew reflection; twas in the arms of a Carthaginian, who named me after his general; yet Syracuſe, my native ſtate, was always the object of my love.

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.p: I wiſh they who oppoſe you had half of your zeal for the public good.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Love for the ſtate is certainly my ruling paſſion. I love money; but I have neglected my private fortune for the ſtate. I have often wiſhed to marry the delicious girl, who has honored me with her affections, but the buſineſs of the ſtate has wholly engroſſed my attention.

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.p: I obſerved you one day talking to yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: And liſtened like a rogue I ſuppoſe to hear what I ſaid.

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.p: Yes, and I expected to have heard the name of the fair Phileſia—but I heard you ſay, O Syracuſe! charming Syracuſe, my dear native city. Shall the Carthaginians inſult over thee? Shall the Romans ru •• thee with a rod of iron? No I will redeem thy proſperity with all that is dear to me, with the laſt drop of my blood.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Such are my conſtant thoughts, if I do not always
thick publicly—uſe your influence my worthy friend to mitigate the public rage againſt me, and ſet mine actions in a proper light. (Exit Hamilcar.)

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: GUARD againſt traitors—every man in the intereſt of Carthage is a traitor. We had better fall into the hands of Rome.

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.p: I cannot underſtand your politics; if the ſtate muſt be ſubject to foreign power, it is of little conſequence into whoſe hands ſhe falls.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: So the government muſt never act with vigor. I ſhould have had Hamilcar's head before this day, were it not that ſome are always pretending the benefits of moderation.

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.p: And what good from his death will accrue to the public.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: It will be the means of ſaving the ſtate. He is in the intereſt of the farmers, and favors the party of Carthage —he oppoſes the land tax and is for laying heavier duties on impor • ed goods.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: He is a villain. He oppoſes the ſenate, and keeps up the low people.

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.p: He may be honeſt tho he differ from you.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I can never believe it. He oppoſes every meaſure to • avor the Romans, and would make us a colony of Carthage.

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.p: Would not your meaſures, for the ſame reaſon, make us a colony of Rome—I cannot ſee.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I can; you never fully conſidered the buſineſs; he ſhall be impeached, and his credit forever deſtroyed in this ſtate.

sp.speaker: Sen
sp.p: The laboring people muſt never get head. It makes them ſo ſaucy—They are ſo uppiſh, that it is time they were taken down a little.

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.p: They would take you down, if they know what a ſpeech you made againſt them.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: Let them find it out if they can—If they do, a little electioneering honey will ſweeten all again.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: That is as I ſay.—Puſh the matter for the mercantile intereſt—Then ſee if our bunkers can raiſe themſelves to the higheſt places in government.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: Don't let that get abroad— (to Hiero.) Come home with me and I will ſhow you more of the villany of Hamilcar.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Illuſtrious Secretary; We hope that your health is as good, as your merits are great.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: My merits are not of the ſize which your praiſes repreſent them to be—But I hope my actions have been of ſome uſe to the public.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Immenſe! prodigious! infinite! There is no calculating the benefits of your adminiſtration.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Why ſir, I have been guilty of ſeveral errors in government.

sp.speaker: Par
sp.p: Not one upon my honor—Thoſe things which the public has charged on you as miſtakes are the moſt glorious acts of your official ability.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: There are many who complain of me.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Not a man of any conſequence; you poſſeſs the hearts of all our people.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: You flatter me, ſir.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: I flatter—Your actions are above flattery, your deeds are as great as your genius is ſublime, and that we know is ſuperior to any thing elſe, done by man. For ſince the days of Saturn, ſince the golden age▪ there has not been ſuch an adminiſtration as yours.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I am happy if my conduct meets the public approbation—then if I puſh the affair againſt Hamilcar, I ſhall certainly ſucceed. (Exit Timocles.)

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Blaſt him, a villain, if I do not think that ſo much praiſe deſerved an invitation to dine. But one may go hungry forever, for any thing that is to be expected from his adminiſtration. I have a great mind to change ſides, and ſee whether there be any thing to eat among thoſe in the oppoſition. (Exit Paraſite.)

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.p: MOST noble ſecretary, I wiſh your health forever and ever.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Let us hear the omens of our future proſperity; what are they?

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.p: I have attended to the office of augur to day with great care—I was never more deſirous or more careful to know the will of the Gods.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: What is it then, my reverend prieſt?

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.p: Every thing tells the coalition of parties and the ſafety of the ſtate—not human craft but divine providence diſcovers itſelf—the merchants and ploughmen will ſoon agree, and there will be rejoicing thro all Sicily.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: What are the ſigns of this.

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.p: I ſaw three hawks paſs by a flock of doves in peace —trees were ſtruck with lightning, then ſoft muſic was heard, and ſhepherds danced in the ſhade—the tygers and the lambs played together—gamecocks refuſed to fight and picked the grain together in peace—every thing portends peace and harmony.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Thou art a falſe prophet—you have been bribed by the Carthaginians—This is no time for coalition—it is time for every man to riſe and cruſh oppoſition, and baniſh every moderate man from the ſtate.

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.p: I a falſe prophet Timocles! was I falſe when I foretold that you would be a great man, and throw the ſtate into parties? Nor am I a falſe prophet now—when I predict that your meaſures will turn to peace—you will be violent, cruel and revengeful—but the more violent the ſooner your influence ends, and the ſtate is in peace.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: No man can conduct the meaſures of government properly, when prieſts meddle with every thing—I wiſh there were a particular law to puniſh every meddler of the ſacred order.

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.p: When you ſet new meaſures on foot, you aſk our prayers for ſucceſs—that makes us of your party; and if we pray and preach as you would have us; all is right— but if we differ from you then we are knaves, and ought to be hanged—But as prieſts are ſo dependent, if they be diſhoneſt it is becauſe the people love to have it ſo, for the maxim is true, like people, like prieſt.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Let us hear no more of your falſe prophecies, but go home, parſon, and kiſs your wife, and mind your domeſtic pleaſures. If I find you meddling with politics again I will commit you to jail.

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.p:
Do what you will, the counſel of the Gods will
take place—The events predicted will come, and the more violent you are, the ſooner you will bring them about.

div.head: SCENE II.—The PARASITE and TIMOCLES.
div.stage: (Timocles ſtands at the edge of the curtain at one entrance— the Paraſite enters at the other, & does not ſee Timocles.)

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: NOW let my heart be joyful, my ſtomach exult, my palate be delighted; and my appetite rejoice. Never I believe did there exiſt a man who took more pleaſure in eating and drinking, than myſelf. And here in this Little Box (looks at it in his hand) is the reſource of eating forever—Never more ſhall this body, mine own dear, dear fleſh, know the torture of emptineſs, and famine. Never ſhall theſe dainty ribs know the judgment of leanneſs. This Box ſupplies me with good eating forever. The preſent adminiſtration is a dry, lean, adminiſtration—I gave the prime miniſter to day a buſhel of praiſe, but he never gave me a mouthful of dinner. His party muſt ſoon fall. A ſtarving government never proſpers—But this Box—O! this Box, this lovely, ſweet Box, (kiſſes the Box) this is my farm, my plantation, my trade, my ſhop, my magazine of riches. Never was man more lucky than I, to find this Box. It will afford me the means of eating forever and ever—This day deſtruction falls on all ſorts of proviſions. Wo to ſpare-ribs and hams of bacon. Wo to roaſt pullets, ſirloins of beef, and mince-pies. Wo to gravy ſauces, pickles and mangoes. Wo to vegitables, and eatables of all kinds.—Hoh! (He ſees Timocles and ſtops ſhort.)

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: What, wretch, is this thy tone? This morning the government was perfectly ſublime, now it ſtarves its citizens. Would it could ſtarve you and all your race to death. Know, if I hear again of your railing againſt the government, I will put you in priſon, and you ſhall be hanged. [Timocles goes out.]

div.head: SCENE III.—HIERO and PARASITE.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: THAT Blunderbuſs is gone. He took fire at what I ſaid and in the ſpirit of true party rage threatened all the oppoſition. But this Box he ſearc • es not—nor dreams that it contains his •• te.

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.p: Let me ſee it. (Takes the Box and examines it attentively.) Aſtoniſhing! Let no man know this myſtery till you hear from me—Good heaven! the fate of Sicily is certainly contained in this Little Box.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: But muſt I ſtarve, who bear on my ſhoulders the fate of the whole nation? I have thro the whole city, done errands for ſome, flattered others, threatend more, for a man is apt to be croſs when he is hungry; and have not broke bread theſe fifteen hours. I ſhall be tired of carrying the weight of the whole • ation, if I be kept ſo ſhort.

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.p: Well ſir, come with me—as far as food will go, I will ſupport the main pillar of the Commonwealth.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Say what they will, the weight of the public lies on my ſhoulders.

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.p: There let it reſt for the preſent, but we ſhall ſoon find means to take it off—Now let me lead you to my pantry, and leave you there; and let all kinds of proviſion ſurrender to you at diſcretion.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Illuſtrious hero! Glorious patriot, I revere thy virtues—I will always be of this party in the time to come; for the other is a dry faction, and muſt finally ſtarve its ſupporters.

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.p: Live here at large—But excuſe me after leading you in—while I receive other compny.

div.stage: [Conducts him out, and returns with Hirax]

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.p: MY worthy friend, what think you of the preſent adminiſtration?

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.p: I dare not ſpeak ſir, and ſcarcely dare to think.

sp.speaker: Hir
sp.p: That is giving a character of them very pointed— Now I think Timocles honeſt, but at the ſame time a very infatuated man.

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.p: I perceive it, and know that he may be very much mortified—But have you conſulted the Omens?

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.p: I have with great care.

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.p: What do they portend?

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.p: Peace and harmony to the whole nation. I to • d Timocles of it to day but he was angry and threatens to impriſon me, and hang me.

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.p: Under what pretence?

sp.speaker: Hir
sp.p:
That one of the religious profeſſion muſt not med
• le with politics.

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.p: A religious officer is a citizen—and is never blamed if he favor the right party—But they whom prieſts oppoſe always diſlike it; becauſe the religious profeſſion carries weight with it.

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.p: In a time of peace, and in a government eſtabliſhed by the cleareſt law—can it do good to carry matters with ſuch violence?

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.p: It cannot—it is like overcharging the Baliſta—It hurts the army that uſes it, more than the enemy.

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.p: And what do you ſuppoſe is the point of prudence for one of the religious profeſſion in ſtate • matters?

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.p: Why if he thinks it will do good, let him declare his opinion honeſtly—if he thinks it will not, let him keep the matter to himſelf.

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.p: If any enquire of him the will of the Gods, what muſt he do?

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.p: Tell it exactly according to the beſt of his diſcernment, whether they like it or not; for a prieſt loſes all his importance when he becomes a noſe of wax for every man to ſtretch or ſhorten at his pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.p: Happily you agree with me I muſt go to the augury again, and, depend on it, I ſhall declare my real ſentiments. [Exit Hirax]

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: NOW I ſhall be deciſi • e▪ You will not interfere.

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.p: I ſhall make no promiſes.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Hamilcar is coming to trial—he is impeached—his trial is voted—the Archon approves it.

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.p: You do as you pleaſe, but I diſlike your meaſures.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Bold enough in fact.

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.p: Bold and juſt. Nothing is more improper for a miniſter of ſtate than ſuch fiery proceedings. Politics ſhould have no paſſions, but be conducted with a ſimple view to the public good.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: A citizen ſhould love the ſtate warmly.

sp.speaker: Hiero
sp.p: Warmly as you pleaſe, but with diſcretion: he loves not the ſtate who deſtroys one half of its people— Hamilcar oppoſes you, and defends the farmers—are we not all one nation? What benefit is there to ſhow malice, or favor, either to Carthage, or Rome? A nation ſhould ſtand on the broad baſis of its own independence, and virtue.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Hamilcar if he be let alone will deſtroy the ſtate.

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.p: That is, he oppoſes you—who will ſpeak the things beſt in the world, if for ſpeaking, he muſt loſe his head? Men ſhould ſay and do what they pleaſe within the law; without this there is no liberty.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: He is attached to Carthage.

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.p: I doubt it. But if he be, you are as much attached to Rome.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I am determined to humble the landed intereſt, and get the law paſſed to tax corn two ſeſterces on a buſhel enacted—you had better be quiet, I ſhall ſpare none who oppoſe me.

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.p: Then your reign is ſhort I promiſe you.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Well I begin to be confirmed in my principles of government. I have been for the mercantile intereſt while they gave me good dinners; but now they give me none.

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.p: You ſeem to have found quite a deliberate reaſon for deſerting them.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Yes, I think for the future I ſhall be firmly attached to the intereſt of the farmers; they raiſe the grain; there is proviſion made for bread, pudding and pye-cruſt; they raiſe the graſs and from graſs comes milk, of which we make ſyllabubs, whipt creams, and cuſtards—beef alſo is the produce of the farm—I determine from this time to attach myſelf to the intereſt of the farmers. And why cannot I do ſome thing for the public?—the public ſay I'm lazy. But I can carry news from place to place, and tell all the ſtories of the day; and when the candidates kiſs the freeholders wives with pieces of gold in their mouths I can make as good a ſtory of it as any man. But my little box, my precious treaſure. What future feaſts am I to derive from this little box. (Paraſite goes out.)

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: MY ſon, I muſt, from the tenderneſs of a mother's heart, ſay ſomething concerning your conduct.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Women are naturally ſo timid that they are poor counſellors in political affairs.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: If I know politics leſs I have more experience of human life, and manners, than you. I have ſeen the fall of ſeven miniſters of ſtate, and I have ever obſerved it to be in conſequence of heat, and violence in their meaſures.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: They were unſkilful as well as violent.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: A ſhip is never ſafe with a mad pilot—I ſpeak in the bitterneſs of a mother's heart, I pretend not to dictate meaſures; but entreat you to conſider whether you be right—Your ruin, my ſon, is at hand; for heaven's ſake deſiſt—I am overwhelmed with grief.

sp.speaker: Tim
sp.p: In other matters I could reſpect you; but here—

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: I meddle not with ſtate affairs—But I have ſeen ſo many men ruin themſelves by viole • t meaſures that I tremble every moment.

sp.speaker: Tim▪
sp.p: Leave all thoſe matters to me; I ſhall manage them ſucceſsfully. (Sebaſte withdraws.)

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I HEAR you have told, thro the city, that you have power to bring me down when ever you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: If I have ſaid ſo it is no more than the truth.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: And that I am a niggard, and tho you treated me very politely, that I had not the complaiſance to invite you to dinner.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: If I ſaid that too, I ſaid no more than the truth.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: If you ſaid that you are yet not worthy my notice. Where is the wonderful Box which contains the fa • e of Sicily

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: I have a Box which contains the fate of Sicily— Look here, and judge for you • ſe • f (Lawyer enters.)

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: A fig! It is nothing but your box of tooth powder, what a miracle! well I ſuppoſe I underſtand you now— you ſay the fate of Sicily depends on this box. If your teeth be kept clean you will devour all the proviſions of the whole iſland—if they fail the iſland may yet be ſupplied. (Paraſite pouts his lips at him) Were it not that I deſpiſe you; and think it a diſgrace to have any competition with you; I would make you ſmart for this, you dotard. (Paraſite is moving away) Take that and begone.

div.head: SCENE III.—HAMILCAR, TIMOCLES, SENATOR, LAWYER, and HIERO.
div.stage: (Hamilcar enters guarded by two ſoldiers; Hiero enters after him.)

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: YOU ſee me now condemned to death, on the impeachment of Timocles—the witneſſes, lawyers, judges, were all his creatures. Never was a more dangerous precedent. Yet I chuſe to die, that all the citizens may ſee, what a deſpotic ſecretary can do with the moſt innocent man.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: There are certain caſes not deſigned in the ordinary courts; and muſt conſequently be managed by the prime miniſter of the time. But I could wiſh the mode of theſe trials were altered, that they might at leaſt have the appearance of equity—For next to the ſubſtance of juſtice, the appearance is of importance.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: I have fought ten times with the Romans in pitched battles; and twenty times with the Carthaginians. My main principle of politics has been to equalize the taxes among the citizens. Party zeal now diſpoſes of my life, and the ſame fate avails you all, ſhould the current of party turn againſt you—all depends on Timocles.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: I could not prevent it—a defence would have been followed by an impeachment. But it is no uncommon thing for a criminal, to complain of his accuſers.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: Delay not, Timocles, as it belongs to you to read his ſentence and order his execution. Delays may give room to excite the compaſſion of the people.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: See a grave Senator thirſting for my blood, becauſe Timocles will have it ſhed. I only wiſh that I had died before I ſaw any thing ſo ſhameful, and could have departed with ſome pride on account of my nation.

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.p: My friend Hamilcar is condemned on a trial, ſhort, violent, partial, and unjuſt. Let me but know the articles of impeachment.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: (reads) 1. Being a foreigner he aſſumed an office. 2. He was under the influence of Carthage. 3. Was the author of a law to promote confuſion.

sp.speaker: Hiero
sp.p: I can prove all thoſe articles falſe.

div.head: SCENE III.—PHILESIA is introduced ſuddenly, and breaks off the dialogue—She curtifies to the floor to Timocles.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: ILLUSTRIOUS Secretary, let the prayers of innocence and truth prevail—Spare a man who poſſeſſes a mind rich with all that is honorable, and juſt.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Juſtice muſt prevail, juſtice rules all.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: At leaſt indulge to hearts, which have ever cheriſhed virtue, more than life, the ſad conſolation, of mingling the tears of their laſt adieus—Let Hamilcar with one keeper only withdraw a moment with me,

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: There muſt not be any delay to the courſe of juſtice.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Excellent woman—beſeech him not, he has a heart inſenſible to pity—I d • e with honor, I mean in heart and principle—we ſhall meet in the Elyſian fields, and be aſſured nothing but Elyſium itſelf could compenſate the want of your ſociety—adieu Phileſia, took for a better huſband than I could be—aad may the gods make you happy. (She withdraws with her eyes covered, and leaning on Hiero, who inſtantly returns.)

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.p: I ſay I can prove every one of theſe articles to be falſe, and would have done it before the court if you had given opportunity—did he make a law to promote confuſion? It was only to equalize the taxes between the merchants and the plowmen. May not any man originate a law in an orderly way? You ſay he is under the influence of Carthage—it was but three days ago that he gave the money he had prepared for his own wedding, in bounties to ſoldiers to fight againſt Carthage—truly it is capital for a foreigner to aſſume an offi • e; but Hamilcar is not a foreigner.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I ſay he is a foreigner▪ and ſhall be executed immediately. (Pulls out a paper and begins to read) The court finding Hamilcar gu •• y— (G • ycerie enters ſuddenly and ſeizes his hand which holds the paper.)

sp.speaker: Glye.
sp.p: Monſter of cruelty deſiſt; it is not enough that every thing is ſubject to thy power, muſt thy malice be ſatiated with the blood of innocence? He is no more a foreigner than thyſelf.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Guards ſeize this woman, and keep her at a diſtance.

sp.speaker: Glyc.
sp.p: My brother is innocent, you won't let me tell how.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Silence woman, or I ſhall order you to priſon immediately.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Ceaſe my dear ſiſter, it will be of no avail—let him execute his bloody work—be virtuous, my dear ſiſter, & we ſhall meet in Elyſium. [The ſoldier holds her arm while ſhe hides her eyes with the other, and leans her elbow on Hiero's ſhoulder—Timocles reads.]

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: The court finding Hamilcar guilty of the crimes recorded againſt him in this proceedings of this court, do order the execution of the ſaid Hamilcar, to be firſt ſcourged with rods without the walls of the city—and then be ſuſpended on the croſs—Go, officers, ſee this executed immediately. [Officers march.]

sp.speaker: Hiero
sp.p: S • ay raſh man!

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Proceed guards, and do your duty.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: [ruſhing in.] Raſh man! he is your brother.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: You lie.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: I'll prove it on my life.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Guards, halt, reconduct the priſoner.

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.p: Liſten noble ſecretary to reaſon—have a little patience. Paraſite where is your box?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: This little box, O my ſweet box, many good dinners I ſhall have by means of this box.

sp.speaker: Hiero
sp.p: Huſh your nonſenſe and open the box.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Take it, and open it yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.p:
Here, according to the cuſtom of this city, on the birth of a pair of twins a plate of braſs was engraven with their names, and put into a little box, and given to the nurſe in record of their birth▪ [ſhows the plate in the bottom of the box] ſee here, the figure of two i • f • and •• e • r little hands cle • ched together, 〈◊〉 their names below "Timocles▪ and Eraſtus" The nurſ • Athea had this, when the city was t • k • n by the Carthaginians, 35 year •
〈◊〉 , and it was kept by her.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
I was then a priſoner, and the on • y Syra • uſian
ſhe knew in her captivity—I ſaw her, when ſhe was dying, and ſhe gave the box to me, and it has bro't me ſeveral good dinners, and ſo—

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: How do you know Eraſtus and Hamilcar to be the ſame?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: When the nurſe Althea expected to die; ſhe procured another little plate to be engraved ſhowing the time when the Carthagenian who took him, charged his name to Hamilcar calling him after the name of his general —bu • how he came here, I know not.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: I made my eſcape when the fleet lay at Agrigentum. I ſwam in the night to the rock Lebeta, and was received by a ſhepherd▪ who afterwards conducted me to this place—I was ſo well treated by the ſhepherd, and farmers, that I have loved them ever ſince.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Do you Paraſite remember the birth of the twins; my mother always told me I was a twin; and that my mate was carried off by the Carthaginians? I am full of aſtoniſhment—I am petrifyed with ſurprize. I ſ • y do you remember the birth of the twins, and the giving of the box?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: I remember it well —my brother was as grand as Hercules, to think that he had a pair of ſuch fine boys. He made a great ſacrifice to the houſehold gods, and a great feaſt—I remember it—the mince pies were admirable; the ſauſages were delicious, and as for the gravy ſauce that did beat all.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Infamous Paraſite—it is all a cheat, and a lie— you only mean to impoſe on my influence.

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.p: No, this Paraſite, is Paraſite no more—he is your uncle; I, your father, and he, were brothers of the ſ • me father and mother—he is your uncle, and a ſenſible man; he lived at Athens and coming home was afraid of being too well known, as his principles were ſo oppoſi • e to yours, therefore aſſumed the ridiculous character of a Paraſite—we all know what he has ſaid to be true. And here I preſent you with a ſiſter, your own ſiſter Glycerie.

div.stage: [Timocles takes her hand and kiſſes it with affection]

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p:
I yield—I have been wrong, what wonders there are in divine providence—I foreſee what the good prieſt told me of. Coalition of parties, and the tranquility of the ſtate. What will be the joy of my mother to diſcover her children, to ſee my ſiſter and both her twin boys.
How will ſhe weep for joy, over her long loſt children; and to ſee my brothe • married to his dear Phileſi • . My firſt work ſhall be to redreſs the wrongs of all. But let me now, my dear brother, unburden my heart, and preſent you to my mother. [Goes out and embraces his brother with one arm, while his ſiſter hangs on the other.]

sp.speaker: Hiero
sp.l: This ſcene in future times ſhall grace the ſtage,
And hold forth uſeful truths to every age;
That party ſpirit is the bane of peace;
The root of evil and its vaſt increaſe;
That howſoe'er our private tho'ts may jarr;
The public intereſt is a patriot's care.
Would he not have the public building fall,
One view, one law, one LOVE, muſt bind us all.

div.head: The Inquiſitor. A TRAGI-COMIC DIALOGUE, IN FIVE ACTS.
HONESTY WITHOUT LEARNING, IS BETTER THAN LEARNING WITHOUT HONESTY.
div.p: THO every rational man muſt diſcern the value of learning—when rightly uſed; yet if a man abuſes his learning to the injury of his fellow men—he degrades himſelf below the moſt illiterate perſon in the world—The greateſt ſimplicity of ideas, united with common ſenſe, and fidelity in buſineſs, may make uſeful men—The Popes, and Inquiſitors, tho ornamented with the higheſt poliſh of learning, excite our odium▪ while a ſimple▪ honeſt, farmer, mechanic, or ſailor—may even be an agreeable companion, and uſeful friend.

div.head: PERSONS.

list.head: MEN.
list.item: PHERON—prince of Abyſſinia—priſoner in the Inquiſition.
LT. BOWLING—a ſailor, priſoner in the Inquiſition, remarkable for his honeſty.
A GRENADIER—a patrole ſoldier of the Inquiſition.

list.head: WOMEN.
list.item: ILISSA—daughter of the prince of Abyſſinia.
MRS. MONROE—wife of the Engliſh reſident.
MISS MONROE—daughter of the Engliſh reſident.

div.p: SCENE—An apartment in the priſon of the Inquiſition.

sp.speaker: In.
sp.p: I AM much obliged to you for this honor.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: I ſhould not have troubled your eminence this evening, after the fatiguing day you have had, were it not on buſineſs of importance.

sp.speaker: In.
sp.p: The commands of the Engliſh ſhall always meet with ready attention—They are powerful by ſea; and our nation needs their aſſiſtance.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: The court of London enquires after the prince of Abyſſinia—It is ſaid that he is ſent to the Inquiſition.

sp.speaker: In.
sp.p: The Prince of Abyſſinia!

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: The Prince of Abyſſinia—a territory twenty times as large as Portugal, is now confined here.

sp.speaker: In.
sp.p: Let that remain a ſecret, or the demand for his ranſom will be enormous—I tho't him a perſon of rank, but had no idea of his being a prince.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Let him be treated honorably for England's ſake, and the court will reward you. (Exit Monroe)

div.head: SCENE II.—INQUISITOR, alone.
div.p:
WHAT evil genius directed me to the office of Inquiſitor to reign in this court of infernal torments? Me, whom nature formed of the ſofteſt mould, and poured the milk of humanity, and the honey of kindneſs, into all my veins. How happy was I when in my little retired village—I exhorted the old men to contentment▪ and the young men to matrimony, and felt the conſciouſneſs of doing good—The church to reward my ſervices, has made me wretched— Deteſtable preferments, by which I ratify acts which my ſoul abhors, and reign like ſatan ſupreme in the • egions
of miſery. (Walks backward and forward diſturbed.) But why do I not fly from this deteſted place? Alas the charming Iliſſa; can any thing be more charming? Hardly can the pureſt ſaints in heaven exceed her in beauty; or in dignity of manners—I muſt remain in horrid office till ſhe can eſcape with me—O love! immortal ſongs have already celebrated thy power, tho ever haſt bleſſed heaven, and haſt conquered hell—But this is thy laſt effort to penetrate the gloom of the inquiſition—I live only to admire and hope for Iliſſa. (Enter Father Joſeph.)

sp.speaker: F. Jo.
sp.p: I ASK pardon of your eminence—I hope I did not interrupt your devotions.

sp.speaker: In.
sp.p: I had done ſir before you came in.

sp.speaker: F. Jo.
sp.p: How go the affairs of the faith—were the priſoners condemned as uſual?

sp.speaker: In.
sp.p: Yes. The Conſiſtory ordered puniſhment as follows— Four renegado Moors were ſent to the gallies, two Jews to the mines, the Engliſh ſailor remanded to priſon—who has been chaſtized for ſpeaking diſreſpectfully of St. Dominic.

sp.speaker: F. Jo.
sp.p: And what became of that genteel looking man, and his daughter? The daughter ſir is innocence itſelf.

sp.speaker: In.
sp.p: She certainly is, and the father has ſo much condeſcenſion and docility about him; that we cannot find the ſhadow of a charge againſt him.

sp.speaker: F. Jo.
sp.p: Then he was diſmiſſed, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: In.
sp.p: No, it was ordered that he ſhould be retained in priſon; and his daughter kept at the Inquiſitor's houſe— and that they ſhould not be treated with any great degree of ſeverity.

sp.speaker: F. Jo.
sp.p: That daughter of his is a delicate little piece.

sp.speaker: In.
sp.p: Fye, I wonder Father Joſeph, you will let your fancy run upon ſuch ſubjects—you ſhould not let vain tho'ts lodge in your mind—I expect ſoon that you will quarrel with your vow of celibacy.

sp.speaker: F. J.o
sp.p: I ſhould now if I dared— But I am all ſubmiſſion to the church—Yet I do not ſee why people ſhould take vows contrary to the order of univerſal nature.

sp.speaker: In.
sp.p: Silence, Father Joſeph, or you will be called to an account—Let us go and ſee what other buſineſs muſt be attended to this night. (Ex Inquiſitor and F. Joſeph.)

div.head: SCENE I.— (The curtain draws and diſcovers Pheron on a little bed—Iliſſa ſitting by the bed and raiſing his head on a pillow with her arm.) ILISSA and PHERON.

sp.speaker: Iliſſa.
sp.p: MERCY ye kind heavens! grant mercy to poor beings miſerable beyond expreſſion—Let not my good •• re loſe his reaſon—ſir, my dear ſir, ſpeak, my dear papa, ſpeak to me, do you know me?

sp.speaker: Pher.
sp.p: Know you; yes. You are one of the ſpirits of the juſt made perfect—you are in a ſtate of complete happineſs.

sp.speaker: Iliſſa.
sp.p: Alas! I fear his reaſon is gone forever—and what will become of me—My dear, moſt dear father, my life my happineſs, pray, dear ſir, wake up. Do you know yourſelf, who are you?

sp.speaker: Pher.
sp.p: A poor creature; but honeſt—The devil and the Inquiſitor. O, I had a dreadful ſtruggle, tried above an hour to tie me on a wheel of fire that keeps rolling, and rolling to all eternity—But a ſweet little angel came and took me away and laid me in her lap.

sp.speaker: Iliſſa.
sp.p: Merciful heavens reſtore him, or let me die with him. (The Doctor enters.) O dear ſir, I am extremely glad to ſee you,

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: And how, my ſweet lady, does your father now?

sp.speaker: Iliſſa.
sp.p: O ſir, I cannot tell; he ſeems to be diſordered in his mind.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: (examining his patient) Why, truly, madam, his fever is not very high—his diſorder ariſes from fatigue and anxiety of mind. I have given him about 30 drops of Laudanum; and that makes him ſleepy. He will wake ſoon; and may be a little wild at firſt; but he will ſoon recover.

sp.speaker: Iliſſa.
sp.p: He will wake ſoon! The idea makes my heart ſpring with joy—Yet to what can he awake but to new ſcenes of miſeries. (Curtain cloſes and hides the ſtage.)

div.head: SCENE I.—PHERON and BOWLING.
div.stage: (The curtain opens and diſcovers a ſailor, hand cuffed and fettered, lying on a mattraſs. Pheron by a little table reading the Epiſtles of John.)

sp.speaker: Pher.
sp.p: HOW wide from their principles are many who are called Chriſtians! their religion breathes pure benevolence; and yet they perſecute each other—why am I in priſon? and in danger of ſevere ſufferings—ſee, here— [reads] "whoſoever hateth his brother is a murderer—we ought to lay down our lives for the brethren. Whoſo ſhutteth the bowels of compaſſion from his brother in need, how dwelleth the love of God in him—my dear children, let us not love, only in word and tongue; but in deed and in truth."

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: (ſtarting up.) That's good doctrine, as true as my chriſtian name—what book is that?

sp.speaker: Pher.
sp.p: The Epiſtles of John—it contains many beautiful ſentiments.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: What you read, is right up, and right down good — had ſome folks minded that, I ſhould not have been confined here; nor would they have given me ſuch an infernal toaſting.

sp.speaker: Pher.
sp.p: Then you have ſtudied the maxims of religion.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Not much maſter, I have been rather too buſy for that.

sp.speaker: Pher.
sp.p: You took ſo much notice of what I read; that made me aſk.

sp.speaker: Bow▪
sp.p: Yes, my father, who was as good a ſailor as ever ſ • epped between ſtem and ſtern, taught me and my brothers religon.

sp.speaker: Pher.
sp.p: I ſhould be glad to hear a ſailor's theory of religion.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: This my father uſed to tell us always, and he told us it on his dying day—My boys, perform your duties well in this life, and in the next life you'll be promoted, and put into a good meſs.

sp.speaker: Pher.
sp.p: Did that have any great effect upon you?

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: I never have forgot it; and I dare ſay I never ſhall.

sp.speaker: Pher.
sp.p: Why did it make ſo ſtrong an impreſſion?

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: 'Twas my own father ſir, and would he deceive his ſons, as he was juſt going out of the world?

sp.speaker: Pher.
sp.p: And did it have as great effect on your brothers?

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: There were four of us, you ſee, the four Bowlings, the youngeſt is now thirty one years old—and not one of them has been bro't before the maſt yet.

sp.speaker: Pher.
sp.p: It is a ſhort and ſimple religion—and does it keep you from evil in general?

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Why ſir, I do my duty—ſwear but little—and the bad girls, I never ſee them at all.

sp.speaker: Pher.
sp.p: And do you forſake the women altogether?

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: O no maſter—there's black Moll of Wapping that I love as I do my eyes—Her ſkin is not ſo white nor ſo ſmooth as ſome, but ſhe is a fine veſſel for all that—ſhe's good ſpunk—I pledge you that maſter.

sp.speaker: Pher.
sp.p: If ſhe be fond of you, I hope ſhe does not know, that you are here.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: I hope ſhe does not, poor Moll, 'twould break her heart if ſhe did—I was to have gone home at Chriſtmas, and the parſon was to have given us the grand reef that would have made us man and wife, you ſee.

sp.speaker: Pher.
sp.p: O maſter Bowling that goes near your heart— come take a glaſs of my wine—and here's a • health to black Moll, hoping you will get the grand reef yet.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: O maſter, (wiping his eyes with his arm) your honor I know is good—When I think of poor Moll, I have a great ſtomach to cry—but I keep it down—It ſhall never be ſaid that Tom Bowling cried for a girl—tho I have a ſtomach for it, and hardly can keep it down.

sp.speaker: Pher.
sp.p: With ſuch an honeſt and humane heart, who put you here, Mr. Bowling?

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: The people of this place—becauſe when they praiſed St. Dominic—I was mad, and tho I do not ſwear often, I ſwore them and damned his Saint off the reel—for I hate cruelty—then they ſent me here, and gave me an infernal toaſting, ſuch, as when pay-day comes, they will have to take themſelves.

sp.speaker: Pher.
sp.p:
We often bring ourſelves into difficulty by too free
uſe of our tongues—but we will ſay no more of that, we are companions in affliction. Let us be friends Mr. Bowling; and we may be of uſe to each other to get out of this place.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: I hope to ſee that day—If I can get aboard my frigate again—I will bring her up the Quay, ſo as to bear on this place, then I'll pour in my broadſide upon them, and daſh them all to duſt—Then, I'll tell them that's Tom Bowling, and get away as faſt as I can.

div.head: SCENE II.—PHERON and MONROE.

sp.speaker: Pher.
sp.p: SIR, whoever you are, you come to viſit me in a horrid place.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: I bear with me the commands and reſpect of the Engliſh nation.

sp.speaker: Pher.
sp.p: Of what extent they may be to me is unknown.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: I can do all the Engliſh nation can do—without interfering in the government of Portugal—and I have a perſonal curioſity to know why you are here.

sp.speaker: Pher.
sp.p: Religion is aſſigned as the cauſe, but how I have offended them, I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: It is preſumed that you are the prince and apparent heir of the whole empire of Abyſſinia.

sp.speaker: Pher.
sp.p: That is the preciſe tru • h. The Abyſſinians are a moſt inoffenſive people—They are Chriſtians, on the inſtruction, and principles, of the apoſtle John.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Your religion is then, very ſimple and benevolent.

sp.speaker: Pher.
sp.p: Certainly, and our clergy the moſt prudent in the world—They hate ſects and parties; and that they may better agree—they reduce all religion to two principles— Belief in the mercy of God, thro Chriſt, for the remiſſion of ſins—and the ſincere pactice of duty—Theſe two principles make all their ſyſtem.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: I admire their prudence—The way to agree in a ſyſtem, is, to ſimplify it as much as may be. But how did a perſo • of your rank become a traveller?

sp.speaker: Pher.
sp.p: I loſt my beautiful princeſs, and melancholy poſſeſſed my mind—I tho't to relieve it by travelling—My daughter, my only child▪ refuſed to be left alone; ſo ſhe became the companion of my journies.

sp.speaker: Mon
sp.p:
It was like travelling w •• h a guardian angel—No
foreign princeſs was ever admired, in England, ſo much as Iliſſa.
